headline: For Better Health, Try Fitness From the Inside Out
abstract: A career in health journalism has taught me that when it comes to living well, it’s the inner workout that counts the most.
lead_paragraph: When I first started writing about health more than 20 years ago, my columns mostly focused on the physical body: A healthy diet, exercise and screening for disease were regular topics.

headline: Patrick Demarchelier, Fashion Photographer, Dies at 78
abstract: He was famous for his portraits of supermodels and his close relationship with Princess Diana. His images are part of the fashion canon.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Demarchelier, a photographer whose work helped define fashion and celebrity in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, died on Thursday. He was 78.

headline: ‘The Bubble’ Review: Swabs, Camera, Action
abstract: Judd Apatow’s new film is a comedy about actors trying to make a dinosaur movie during the pandemic that plays more like a documentary of actors trying to make a Covid comedy.
lead_paragraph: “The safest place in the world right now is a film set,” an agent (Rob Delaney) tells his actress client Carol (Karen Gillan) to encourage her to join the quarantined production of “Cliff Beasts 6.” “The Bubble,” a new comedy from Judd Apatow, tells the story of how the stars of this apparently long-running dinosaur franchise spent their pandemic while doubling as a sort of documentary about how Apatow, who wrote the screenplay with Pam Brady, spent his.

headline: This Might Help Clear Things Up
abstract: Evan Mahnken opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Constructors have this habit of trying to one-up each other when it comes to crossword derring-do and, frankly, I’m a fan. There was a time not too long ago when the constructor who could stack the most long entries on top of one another was a hero. This puzzle by Evan Mahnken, however, is on a whole different level. I’ve never seen anything like this one.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: Brendan Emmett Quigley drums up a challenging variety puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MARCHING BANDS — This is always a fun puzzle to work on. The empty grid is a bit disconcerting to me — the alternating bands of gray and white have an optical-illusion effect and the lack of breaks between any of the words is intimidating. It’s hard to adjust to words running in four directions — across from right to left and up, as well as across from left to right and down. But as long as I get lucky with the across entries, or the beginnings of the bands, I find this variety grid more pleasant than frustrating.

headline: E.P.A. Decides Against Limiting Perchlorate in Drinking Water
abstract: Drinking water for as many as 16 million Americans may be contaminated with perchlorate, a chemical that can harm the development of fetuses and children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday said it would uphold a Trump-era decision and not impose limits in drinking water of perchlorate, a contaminant that has been linked to brain damage in infants.

headline: Two Swimmers Take a Deep Breath Together
abstract: Ian Slater and Michael McVicker became best friends after arriving at Brown University, where they were on the swim team. By their junior year, they were ready to dive into dating.
lead_paragraph: Michael Theron McVicker and Ian Poris Slater met on the campus of Brown University in 2008, when both were visiting as high school seniors on a swim team recruiting trip.

headline: Picking Him Out From a Crowd
abstract: Eliza Giles knew that George Luo was “the one” after spotting him in a crowded high-school assembly 12 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Giles first spotted George Luo on Jan. 19, 2010, during a crowded assembly at their high school, Cate School, in Carpinteria, Calif.

headline: Before Love Came a Lot of Likes
abstract: To show interest in Jayla Moody, a fellow undergraduate at his college, Jordan Marshall liked bunch of her Instagram photos. She then did the same.
lead_paragraph: Jayla Moody and Jordan Marshall’s love story might have started sooner if only they had spoken during the time that both attended Mercer University in Macon, Ga., where he was the captain of the football team, and she was the 2018 Homecoming Queen.

headline: From the Start, Their Relationship Was ‘Uglies’
abstract: Jaclyn Tokarz met Dieter Seelig in 2015 at his bar, Plug Uglies, where she was a regular. But more than two years would pass before their romance took off.
lead_paragraph: When Dieter Demetrios Seelig and Jaclyn Michelle Tokarz first laid eyes on each other in 2015 at Plug Uglies, a bar he owns in Manhattan’s Gramercy Park neighborhood, both felt an immediate attraction.

headline: The Dentist Who Treated My Divorce
abstract: When in pain, it helps to know someone who has experience treating it.
lead_paragraph: I have spent countless hours reclined in dentists’ chairs, but this was the first time I had cried in one.

headline: In Paris, and Each Other, They Found Home
abstract: More than a decade after Miranda Robertson studied abroad in the city of her dreams, she returned to discover the man of her dreams in Nicolas Bayle.
lead_paragraph: When Miranda Patricia Robertson matched with Nicolas Robert Michel Bayle on the dating app Bumble in 2018, Ms. Robertson had also recently reconnected with what she called “the love of my life” — the city of Paris.

headline: Paige Bueckers Has Performed in Minneapolis Before
abstract: In December, UConn’s star player had an ugly knee injury. On Friday night, she will try to lead her team to a national title game.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Brian Cosgriff first saw Paige Bueckers play when she was in second grade, during a scrimmage at the University of Minnesota.

headline: Judge Tosses Out New York’s New Political Districts
abstract: The ruling puts the state’s June primary elections in doubt, but Democrats said they would appeal.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the latest twist in redistricting in New York. We’ll also catch up on the state budget in Albany, about to be officially late.

headline: Corrections: April 1, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 1, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about pro-Russian Serbians misstated the given name of a Belgrade-based psychotherapist. She is Aurelija Djan, not Arijan.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Judge Rules Parts of Florida Vote Law Unconstitutional
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 1, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “For the past 20 years, the majority in the Florida Legislature has attacked the voting rights of its Black constituents.”

headline: Word of the Day: oblivionaire
abstract: The teenage winner of our Invent a Word challenge suggests a noun for some leaders of the globalized economy.
lead_paragraph: Note: This April Fools’ Day, we’ve turned our vocabulary column over to the winner of our Invent a Word challenge, which invited students to fill a gap they saw in the English language.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Fighting rages on in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Facing deeper isolation by the day over the war in Ukraine, Russia seemed to slightly recalibrate its stance, allowing greater humanitarian access to the devastated port city of Mariupol and apparently retreating from a payment confrontation with European gas customers. Fighting around Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, continued unabated. Follow the latest updates.

headline: Boy, 12, Is Fatally Shot in a Parked Car in Brooklyn, Police Say
abstract: The boy was the latest child to be caught in the crossfire of a surge in shootings that has plagued New York City since the pandemic began.
lead_paragraph: A day after a 12-year-old boy was fatally shot in a parked car in Brooklyn, community leaders said the killing was just the latest episode to unsettle neighborhood residents who are both scared of street violence and wary of a return to aggressive police tactics.

headline: Late Night Gets Why Putin’s Advisers Keep Him in the Dark
abstract: “Of course they’re afraid to be honest,” Stephen Colbert said. “No matter what you say to a psychotic boss, you lose.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Midnight Oil Brings Australia Home
abstract: Australia has had its fair share of music that made it big overseas. But why do some bands succeed internationally while others do not? And does that even matter?
lead_paragraph: In the days immediately following my return to Australia in September 2017, after almost 30 years of living in the United States, an old high school friend invited me to go with her to see Midnight Oil at the Sidney Myer Music Bowl. I was an Oils fan as a teenager almost by osmosis: My best friend was obsessed with them, and my stepfather was part of the same late-70’s Australian punk scene from which they sprang.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘I’m in Hot Demand, Baby’: Nebraska Thrives (and Copes) With Low Unemployment
abstract: The jobless rate in February, 2.1 percent, was close to the lowest ever. Employers are adjusting to the power of workers.
lead_paragraph: Harry’s Wonder Bar is a trusted old dive in Nebraska’s capital, frequented by office clerks, construction workers and graduate students alike: the sort of wood-paneled place with a pool table in the back where phones generally stay in pockets, second fiddle to casual conversation, and beer mugs come frosted regardless of the season.

headline: Stop and Smell the Roses
abstract: Or take a cloud out on a walk, or climb the antlers of a deer.
lead_paragraph: EMILE AND THE FIELDWritten by Kevin YoungIllustrated by Chioma Ebinama

headline: After the Protesters Left, an Illicit Weed Began Growing in Parliament’s Garden
abstract: New Zealand officials say anti-vaccination protesters seeded cannabis during a three-week occupation.
lead_paragraph: When anti-vaccination protesters finally cleared out of New Zealand’s Parliament grounds after a three-week occupation, they left behind a scene of destruction and disorder — the charred remains of a children’s playground, camping equipment and human waste, among other items.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from our current articles on weekend events, including a preview of the Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Selections from our current articles on weekend events, including a preview of the Grammy Awards.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Caul Baby’ and ‘While Justice Sleeps’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: WHILE JUSTICE SLEEPS, by Stacey Abrams. (Anchor, 480 pp., $17.) In this legal thriller, a young law clerk catches a whiff of a dangerous conspiracy in Washington after the Supreme Court justice she works for slips into a coma. “Those desirous of perils and surprises will encounter them in abundance,” commented our reviewer, Richard North Patterson.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 1, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Murder in the Mohalla
abstract: In Aamina Ahmad’s stunning debut novel,“The Return of Faraz Ali,” a police officer is asked to cover up a young girl’s death in the red-light district of Lahore, Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, not long after President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was assassinated, my father was walking home from work one night when two soldiers stopped him. They were young, bored. They decided to give him a hard time.

headline: This Teen Romance Is Like Any Other. That’s What Makes It So Different.
abstract: Julian Winters’s new novel, “Right Where I Left You,” is a love letter to queer Black and brown nerds.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to YA/NYT, a monthly column in which we recommend one new young adult book that you won’t want to miss.

headline: This Is Why It Took More Than 100 Years to Get an Anti-Lynching Bill
abstract: Our political system was the primary obstacle to protecting the lives and livelihoods of its own citizens.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, President Biden signed a bill to make lynching a federal crime. Devised by a group of Black lawmakers in the House and Senate — Tim Scott of South Carolina, Cory Booker of New Jersey, Bobby Rush of Illinois and Kamala Harris of California (when she was still in the Senate) — the law comes into being after more than 200 failed attempts, over more than 100 years, to pass anti-lynching legislation through Congress.

headline: Separated but Under the Same Roof
abstract: Some couples who’ve ended their marriages are finding common ground right at home.
lead_paragraph: Kate Warren and her husband, Yanni Kotsonis, separated in early 2016. But they didn’t exactly go their separate ways.

headline: Reverse Mortgages Are No Longer Just for Homeowners Short on Cash
abstract: Turning your home equity into cash can help pay bills and preserve other savings and investments. But they’re complicated, and not for everyone.
lead_paragraph: After her husband died suddenly from a fall in 2016, Marjorie Fox decided to hold off on any big decisions. She waited two years to retire as a financial planner and three to sell their house and buy a lakeside townhome in Reston, Va. For added protection, she took out a reverse mortgage on her new home.

headline: At the Fountain
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: How to Endure the Big Decline in Bonds
abstract: Our columnist answers questions about the troubles in the bond market, and what they mean for investors.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a horrible start of the year for the bond market, the worst in decades.

headline: This article was published in error.
Do You Enjoy Taking Long Walks?
abstract: Do you see walking as an enjoyable activity, or is it just a way to get from one place to another?
lead_paragraph: Do you enjoy walking around your neighborhood? Have you ever discovered something interesting or surprising near where you live when walking around? During the pandemic, Mary Hosbrough and Jennifer Jacobsen-Wood tried something new: They met up daily to walk every street of their hometown, Peoria, Ill.

headline: The Right’s Disney Freakout
abstract: How the company got mired in a moral panic.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know Latoya Raveneau, but I feel terrible for her. An executive producer at Disney, she was a speaker at a recent virtual all-hands company meeting about Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” bill. Inside Disney, there had been considerable anger that the company, one of the state’s largest employers, had donated to politicians behind the bill and hadn’t done more to fight it. Raveneau stepped up to defend the company’s queer friendliness, only to become a national object of right-wing fury and disgust.

headline: Living With Gusto Despite a Rare, Fatal Disease, and Hunting for Answers
abstract: At 26, Sammy Basso is believed to be the oldest person with the disease Progeria. And now he’s researching it, hoping to find a treatment and the secrets of aging.
lead_paragraph: TEZZE SUL BRENTA, Italy — Like many an Italian man living at home in his mid-20s, Sammy Basso is a little embarrassed by the childhood mementos that clutter his small bedroom.

headline: How Low Will Senate Republicans Go on Ketanji Brown Jackson?
abstract: In seeking to discredit her, they have concocted a scary version of a Black woman  to serve up to their base.
lead_paragraph: When Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Supreme Court nomination reaches the Senate floor soon, every Republican who votes against her confirmation will be complicit in the abuse that the Republican members of the Judiciary Committee heaped on her.

headline: Strong Job Gains in March Keep a Flame Under the Recovery
abstract: The U.S. economy added 431,000 jobs and the unemployment rate fell to 3.6 percent. Wages showed sharp gains, but that has been blunted by inflation.
lead_paragraph: A continued torrent of consumer demand, paired with a decline in coronavirus caseloads and health restrictions, led to a burst of job creation last month, showing the staying power of the economic recovery.

headline: As Biden Pleads for More Covid Aid, States Are Awash in Federal Dollars
abstract: States pushed back on a plan to take back some of their stimulus money to fund President Biden’s emergency spending request. Now Congress is trying to find other ways to offset the cost.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFORT, Ky. — Gov. Andy Beshear has been toting oversize checks around his state in recent weeks, handing them out to city and county officials for desperately needed water improvements.

headline: Why Putin Went Straight for the Nuclear Threat
abstract: Vladimir Putin made a threat of nuclear weapons. The U.S. and NATO should be less deferential.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has done an admirable job checking Russian disinformation efforts by disclosing U.S. intelligence assessments of Moscow’s intentions and marshaling unified political support for Ukrainian sovereignty and indirect military support for its defense.

headline: Sanctions Against Russia Are a Form of War. It’s Time We Recognize That.
abstract: The historian Nicholas Mulder on how the West’s sanctions can help end Putin’s war — or escalate it.
lead_paragraph: The Russian political scientist Ilya Matveev recently described the impact of the West’s sanctions on his country as “30 years of economic development thrown into the bin.” He’s not exaggerating. Economists expect the Russian economy to contract by at least 15 percent of G.D.P. this year. Inflation is spiking. An exodus of Russian professionals is underway. Stories of shortages and long lines for basic consumer goods abound.

headline: As Earmarks Return to Congress, Lawmakers Rush to Steer Money Home
abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike stuffed nearly 5,000 earmarks totaling $9 billion into the $1.5 trillion government spending bill signed by President Biden.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One hundred million dollars for an airport in Mobile, Ala. Tens of thousands for upgrades to a police station in the tiny town of Milton, W.Va. Hundreds of thousands of dollars sent to Arkansas to deal with feral swine.

headline: Like Its Players, Villanova Keeps Coming Back
abstract: Under Coach Jay Wright, the Wildcats have made four Final Fours and won two national titles, all without any one-and-done players.
lead_paragraph: Update: Kansas beat UNC to win the NCAA Championship.

headline: April Vocabulary Challenge: Create a Word Field Note
abstract: Create a one-page field note that explores the meaning and usage of one of our Words of the Day. Submissions are due on April 29.
lead_paragraph: Naturalists often record their discoveries about nature in field notes. A field note about fire ants might catalog where they are found, what they look like, how common they are and how they interact with other animals.

headline: An Olympian’s Plea Against War Resonated, but His Work Goes On
abstract: Vladyslav Heraskevych, a skeleton competitor from Ukraine, gathers supplies and uses the team van to deliver them to Kyiv as he waits to be called for military duty.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a month has passed since the end of the Beijing Olympics, but already the Games, like the ones before, have distilled into a handful of images and moments.

headline: Is This the Last Generation to Live on New York City’s Wild Fringes?
abstract: A major restoration project aims to protect the Jamaica Bay area — and all of New York — by returning salt marshes and sand dunes to their natural states. But will it be too late for the people of Broad Channel?
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: In Miami Where It All Began, Naomi Osaka Is Rolling Again
abstract: After struggling for more than a year, the former world No. 1 has advanced to her first women’s singles final since she won the Australian Open in 2021.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.— Thirteen months.

headline: Jurors Begin Deliberating Case of Alleged Plot to Kidnap Michigan’s Governor
abstract: Lawyers made closing arguments on Friday in the federal trial involving four men with militia ties who are accused of conspiring to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The government’s accusations were jarring: Several men with militia ties had schemed to abduct Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan at her vacation home. The group, prosecutors and witnesses said, had held a series of “field training exercises” and discussed killing or stranding her in a boat in the middle of Lake Michigan.

headline: He Was Demoted for Harassing Women. Now He’s the Front-Runner for President.
abstract: In Costa Rica’s runoff on Sunday, voters will decide between a candidate found to have sexually harassed junior employees at the World Bank and a former president once accused of corruption.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — He was demoted from a senior position at the World Bank because of sexual harassment. Now, the economist Rodrigo Chaves — who has campaigned as a populist outsider in an election marked by anger at traditional politicians — leads the polls to become Costa Rica’s next president on Sunday.

headline: Democrats Worry That What Happens in Nevada Won’t Stay in Nevada
abstract: Democrats have long held up Nevada as a symbol of their future. But as the state’s economy struggles, it has become the epitome of the party’s midterm difficulties.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Scars from the coronavirus pandemic are still visible here. Housing prices skyrocketed, with rents rising faster than almost anywhere else in the country. Roughly 10,000 casino workers remain out of work. Gas prices, now more than $5 a gallon, are higher than in every other state except California.

headline: The Fed eyes a hot labor market as unemployment nears prepandemic levels.
abstract: Federal Reserve officials are tasked with fostering “full employment.” At least for now, some see the labor market as uncomfortably tight.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are tasked with fostering “full employment,” and while it has been difficult to guess what that means as the economy recovers from huge job losses at the start of the pandemic, March hiring data seemed likely to reaffirm to policymakers that the labor market is running hot.

headline: How to Make Kids Feel at Home in Both Homes After a Divorce
abstract: When parents go their separate ways in a divorce, children are torn between two places — both should feel like home.
lead_paragraph: The day my ex and I had to tell our children that we were getting divorced, we sat on the couch in the living room as they played on the rug below us. It was a pivotal moment, and our almost 5-year-old, Isaac, sensing that something big and disruptive was happening, had one very important question: What would happen to his Legos?

headline: Verifying Images of the War in Ukraine
abstract: The Times’s Visual Investigations team shares the rigorous process of confirming (or disputing) the authenticity of videos about the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A brief, shaky video uploaded to Telegram on March 17 showed bodies on the ground in Mariupol, one of Ukraine’s largest cities, which has been battered by Russian military attacks in the continuing war. The person behind the camera shouted that it was March 13. But could the date — and the content itself — be corroborated?

headline: As Gas Prices Soar, Biden’s Climate Ambitions Sputter
abstract: Rising costs at the pump, war in Ukraine, an emboldened fossil fuel industry and stalled legislation have imperiled President Biden’s climate agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year after he entered the White House with a vow that fighting global warming would be a driving priority for his administration, President Biden finds his climate agenda is mired in delay and faces legal, legislative and political headwinds that could diminish or dismantle it entirely.

headline: Strikes, Inflation, Now War: Uncertainty Escalates for Europe’s Travel Season
abstract: As pandemic restrictions lifted, the travel industry was looking forward to a strong summer season. But they may be disappointed.
lead_paragraph: Diego Sanz, a tour guide on Spain’s southeastern Mediterranean coast, received his first international group booking in more than a year in mid February. It was, he thought, an augury of better things to come.

headline: Remembrance of Bookstores Past
abstract: New Yorkers still tell stories of browsing at Harlem’s Liberation Bookstore or spending the afternoon at Scribner’s.
lead_paragraph: New York City is home to wonderful bookstores, but there used to be so many more of them to choose from — from Coliseum Books, just south of Columbus Circle; to Ivy’s Curiosities and Murder Ink on the Upper West Side; to the dearly departed St. Mark’s Bookshop in the East Village. By one count, there were 386 booksellers in Manhattan in 1950, including almost 40 on a six-block stretch of Fourth Avenue. (By comparison, there are fewer than 100 in the city now.) Here’s a look back at a few old favorites.

headline: Hillsong and Subversive Kids’ Books: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: A nuclear agency is investigating reports of radiation poisoning among Russian troops at Chernobyl.
abstract: Russian soldiers left the decommissioned nuclear plant and a nearby city after five weeks of occupation.
lead_paragraph: As Russian troops pulled out of Ukraine’s shuttered Chernobyl nuclear plant five weeks after seizing it, an international nuclear watchdog agency is looking into reports that some of the soldiers are experiencing radiation poisoning.

headline: Inside Mariupol
abstract: What the fight for the Ukrainian port city means for the future of the war.
lead_paragraph: This episode details graphic scenes.

headline: U.S. Navy to Name Ship After Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
abstract: The ship, a replenishment oiler, is designed to carry fuel to the Navy’s operating carrier strike groups.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Supreme Court Justice who fought for women’s rights for more than a half century before her death in 2020, will have a U.S. Navy ship named after her, military officials said on Thursday.

headline: Battleground Nevada
abstract: The state will help determine Senate control in this year’s midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Nevada, perhaps more than any other state, has showcased the potential for a more diverse America to move the country’s politics to the left. Rising numbers of Asian American and Latino residents have helped Democrats win the state in the past four presidential elections. The party also holds both of Nevada’s Senate seats.

headline: Energy prices in Europe soar 45 percent as inflation hits another record.
abstract: A continued run-up in prices shows how rapidly the impact of the war in Ukraine is coursing through Europe’s economy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Soaring energy and food prices driven by Russia’s continued aggression against Ukraine pushed inflation in Europe last month to levels not seen in four decades, with prices in the 19 countries that use the euro soaring 7.5 percent, according to data released Friday by Europe’s statistics agency.

headline: Native Hawaiian Hula Teacher Among Five Women Who Will Appear on Quarters
abstract: Edith Kanaka‘ole, who died in 1979, will appear on the coin next year along with four other notable women.
lead_paragraph: George Washington will be sharing some space with a native Hawaiian hula teacher next year.

headline: Is U.S. Employment at Its Peak?
abstract: Despite strong job growth, all the positions lost during pandemic may not be regained.
lead_paragraph: This morning, the Labor Department will report how many jobs employers added to their payrolls in March. Economists expect a healthy gain. But how much longer can the labor market keep it up?

headline: ‘I Feel Shame’: Pope Apologizes to Indigenous People of Canada
abstract: Pope Francis also promised to visit Canada as part of a process of healing and reconciliation over the church’s involvement in an abusive system of residential schools.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis apologized on Friday for the Roman Catholic Church’s involvement in a system of Canadian boarding schools that abused Indigenous children for 100 years, and said he would travel to Canada as part of a process of healing and reconciliation.

headline: Will Smith Resigns From Academy After Slapping Chris Rock at Oscars
abstract: The producer of the telecast, Will Packer, said that Smith had been asked to leave after slapping Rock, and that he had urged officials not to “physically remove” the actor.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Will Smith, who slapped the comedian Chris Rock at the Oscars, said Friday that he was resigning from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, saying that he had “betrayed” its trust with conduct that was “shocking, painful, and inexcusable.”

headline: Where Ukrainian Refugees May End Up Settling in California
abstract: The state is the home of some of the nation’s biggest Ukrainian population centers.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced last week that the United States would accept up to 100,000 refugees fleeing the conflict in Ukraine. Many of them, it turns out, may end up in California.

headline: Outbreak at Shanghai Hospital Exposes Covid’s Risks to China’s Seniors
abstract: Coronavirus infections have spread at an elder care facility in Shanghai. Workers said deaths are increasing and resources dwindling.
lead_paragraph: A coronavirus outbreak is ravaging a hospital in Shanghai for older adults, underscoring the difficulties officials have had in containing infections even as the city imposed a 10-day staggered lockdown.

headline: House committee opens investigation into Amazon’s labor practices.
abstract: A tornado that hit a delivery station in Illinois last year will be a focus of the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The House Committee on Oversight and Reform has opened an investigation into Amazon’s labor practices during severe weather events, according to a letter members sent to Andy Jassy, Amazon’s chief executive.

headline: Jobless Benefits’ Unintended Fallout: Reduced College Financial Aid
abstract: A pandemic program allowed people to exclude the benefits from their income, but in some cases they are still being counted. Here’s what to do.
lead_paragraph: Unemployment benefits helped millions of people who lost their jobs in the pandemic, but now the payments may throw a wrench into the college financial aid process.

headline: ‘Tokyo Vice’ Revisits a Faded Underworld
abstract: This cross-cultural crime thriller, which recalls a time when the yakuza ruled Tokyo’s red-light districts and back alleyways, traced a twisty path to TV.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — These days there are few visible signs of the yakuza in Kabukicho, the storied entertainment and red-light district in the heart of this churning metropolis of more than 37 million people — the biggest city in the world. Aggressive laws have weakened Japan’s organized crime syndicates and chased their aging, declining memberships into the shadows.

headline: Bright Colors, Dark Subjects: Hew Locke’s Unsettling Pageant
abstract: In a major new commission for the Tate museum group in London, the British-Guyanese artist returns to the themes of empire and postcolonial reckoning that have fascinated him throughout his career.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a recent morning, a cavernous studio in south London was a vista of ordered chaos. Elaborate headdresses covered several tables, a jumble of cardboard cutout body parts lay heaped on a palette and boxes overflowed with leopard-print fabrics, fake fur and gaudy fake jewelry. Sewing machines whirred and hammers banged.

headline: Rising Wages Are Good News for Workers but Keep Pressure on the Fed
abstract: Federal Reserve officials have said the pace of pay gains, if they continue, would not be consistent with stable inflation.
lead_paragraph: Wages climbed at a rapid pace in the year through March and the unemployment rate dropped notably last month, signs of a hot labor market that could keep pressure on the Federal Reserve as it contemplates how much and how quickly to cool down the economy.

headline: Get to Know the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
abstract: Every year, hundreds of crossword constructors and fans gather to compete in Stamford, Conn. This year will feature the first live Wordle competition.
lead_paragraph: Every year, crossword lovers and solvers come together to participate in the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

headline: Yes, You Do Deserve a Little Treat
abstract: Two years into the pandemic, people are coping with big existential problems by making time for simple joys.
lead_paragraph: These days, whenever Jules Zucker has to run an errand, she throws a Reese’s Fast Break candy bar into her bag.

headline: War in Ukraine Compounds Hunger in East Africa
abstract: The conflict has driven up the cost of food in a region that depends heavily on crops from Russia and Ukraine and is facing what could be its worst drought in four decades.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — First came the drought, drying up rivers, and claiming the lives of two of Ruqiya Hussein Ahmed’s children as her family fled the barren countryside in southwest Somalia.

headline: Changing Workplace and Workday Norms
abstract: Readers discuss the pros and cons of remote work and more flexible schedules. Also: A mortal Putin; Buffalo Bills’ new stadium; Senator Joe Manchin.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The 1950 census reveals its secrets. Also in this edition: how a star of “The O.C.” became a crypto critic, and women call out “medical gaslighting.”
lead_paragraph: The 1950 census reveals its secrets. Also in this edition: how a star of “The O.C.” became a crypto critic, and women call out “medical gaslighting.”

headline: Industries hit hard by the pandemic continued their rebound.
abstract: Leisure and hospitality jobs are still far below their pre-Covid levels, but represent a big share of employment gains.
lead_paragraph: The jobs report released Friday — which showed U.S. employers added 431,000 jobs in March on a seasonally adjusted basis — received a round of applause from many economists and labor market analysts, cooling off fears of a major slowdown in growth. And it spurred hope in the service sector that good times may be back again, and stick around more sustainably.

headline: Cannabis for Better Sex? Here’s What the Science Says.
abstract: The research is thin, but anecdotal experience suggests that the right dose and delivery method can make a positive difference for some people.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The C.E.O. of a Running Company Who Can No Longer Run
abstract: Jim Weber, the chief executive of Brooks Running, was a devoted distance runner. Then came cancer.
lead_paragraph: Jim Weber, the longtime chief executive of Brooks Running, was for many years a devoted runner. The hours spent racking up the miles were more than exercise for him. They were a chance to meditate on life, to devise strategy about business, and to ruminate on the thorny problems that come with operating a company with more than $1 billion in annual sales.

headline: Harry Styles Tries On Synth-Pop, and 13 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Angel Olsen, Koffee, Barrie and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks are proof that it doesn’t take big bucks to scare people’s pants off with undead messiahs, unseen demons and uncanny commotions.
lead_paragraph: Kevin (Oghenero Gbaje) and his older sister, Brittney (DeShawn White), arrive with Brittney’s fiancé, Tony (Lenny Thomas), at their parents’ waterside cabin, only to discover that their mother, father and the neighbors have been killed. That’s when they — all three are Black — are accosted by an angry white guy (Nick Damici) with a gun.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Try our newest recipes for qatayef, caldo de costilla and Italian broccoli salad.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today I am pleased to announce that New York Times Cooking will no longer publish recipes for chicken, duck, turkey, goose, Cornish game hen, pigeon or grouse. This is in keeping with recent reporting that shows that birds aren’t real. They are actually drones used by the government to spy on Americans. They charge on power lines.

headline: U.S. Allows Hunters to Import Some Elephant Trophies From African Countries
abstract: After settling a lawsuit filed during the Trump administration, the Fish and Wildlife Service granted six permits to bring elephant parts into the country. It may approve more in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service informed some hunters last month that it would allow the import of six elephant trophies into the United States from Zimbabwe. The African elephant carcasses will be the first allowed into the country in five years.

headline: Nancy Lane, Spirit Behind Studio Museum in Harlem, Dies at 88
abstract: An art collector and the institution’s longest-serving board member, she was also a pioneering Black woman in the corporate world.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Lane, a trailblazing corporate executive who promoted the works of Black artists as a champion of the Studio Museum in Harlem for a half-century, died on March 28 at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: Researchers Find Another Clue in the Dyatlov Pass Mystery
abstract: The mystery of nine hikers who died in Russia has baffled people for more than 60 years. The authors of a recent paper think they’ve found another clue.
lead_paragraph: A small avalanche on a desolate Russian mountain, harming no one and quickly erased by the relentless wind, does not usually make news.

headline: G.M.’s and Toyota’s U.S. first-quarter sales fell sharply as a chip shortage persisted.
abstract: The companies struggled to produce vehicles in the first three months of the year, a sign that shortages could last longer than executives had hoped.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and Toyota Motor suffered significant drops in car and truck sales in the United States in the first three months of the year as the global shortage of computer chips continued to disrupt production and leave dealers with bare lots.

headline: Ted Mooney, Author of Inventive Novels, Is Dead at 70
abstract: His attention-getting first book, “Easy Travel to Other Planets,” began with dolphin-human sex. The three that followed were comparably offbeat.
lead_paragraph: Ted Mooney, who opened his first book, in 1981, with a scene of dolphin-human sex, and who proceeded to write three other offbeat, inventive novels at roughly 10-year intervals, died on March 25 at his home in Manhattan. He was 70.

headline: Is the Group of Death a myth? Not if your team is in it.
abstract: Everyone talks about it, no one wants to be in it, and it may not even really exist.
lead_paragraph: Everyone talks about it, no one wants to be in it, and it may not even really exist.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: The week started out with a bang — well, a slap — at the Oscars. The late-night hosts had plenty to say about that and about news revolving around former President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The week started out with a bang — well, a slap — at the Oscars. The late-night hosts had plenty to say about that and about news revolving around former President Donald Trump.

headline: World Cup 2022 Draw: The Group Assignments
abstract: Here are the latest results from FIFA’s draw for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar.
lead_paragraph: Regional and historic rivalries were renewed on Friday as the draw for the 2022 World Cup set out the paths for 32 teams hoping to claim soccer’s biggest championship. The tournament won’t start until November, but for a few teams it might have already been lost: There is only so much luck of the draw to go around, after all.

headline: Jen Psaki is said to be in talks to join MSNBC.
abstract: Ms. Psaki faced tough questions from the White House press corps about performing her job while negotiating with a news outlet.
lead_paragraph: Jen Psaki, the White House press secretary, is in advanced talks with MSNBC to join the network after she leaves the Biden administration, according to two people familiar with the negotiations.

headline: How war has upended life for climate activists in Russia
abstract: “It’s kind of difficult to be afraid all the time that someone might knock down your door,” one said.
lead_paragraph: Raising climate awareness under an authoritarian government is lonely and dangerous. But Arshak Makichyan, a young activist from Russia, deeply believed in it.

headline: More nations will join U.S. in releasing emergency oil reserves.
abstract: The International Energy Agency said member countries had agreed to a release to ease global oil markets rocked by Russia’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The International Energy Agency said Friday that its 31 member nations had agreed to a new release of emergency oil reserves in what is turning into a historic, wide-reaching effort to calm global markets roiled by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Shaken at First, Many Russians Now Rally Behind Putin’s Invasion
abstract: Polls and interviews show many Russians now accept the Kremlin’s assertion that their country is under siege from the West. Opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
lead_paragraph: The stream of antiwar letters to a St. Petersburg lawmaker has dried up. Some Russians who had criticized the Kremlin have turned into cheerleaders for the war. Those who publicly oppose it have found the word “traitor” scrawled on their apartment door.

headline: Endless Summer Fridays
abstract: Some lucky workers are only working half-Fridays year-round, if they work Fridays at all. The verdict? “It’s magic.”
lead_paragraph: On a warm Friday afternoon in March, around 2 p.m., the West Village in Manhattan was bustling with activity.

headline: Treasure Hunting at the Winter Show
abstract: This browser’s delight, with one-of-a-kind art, antiques and modern design, has moved from the Armory to a new Spring Palace — the former Barneys on Madison Avenue.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 70 years the Winter Show — formerly the Winter Antiques Show — has been raising money for the East Side House Settlement in the Bronx. This year, a late Covid surge pushed it from January to April and knocked it out of its usual home in the Park Avenue Armory (where it will return next year) to a one-time-only residence at the former Barneys building on Madison Avenue.

headline: Books You Wish You Hadn’t Read and Other Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Amazon Workers on Staten Island Vote to Unionize in Landmark Win for Labor
abstract: Despite heavy lobbying by the company, workers at the facility voted by a wide margin for a union. It was seen as a rebuke of the company’s treatment of its employees.
lead_paragraph: It was a union organizing campaign that few expected to have a chance. A handful of employees at Amazon’s massive warehouse on Staten Island, operating without support from national labor organizations, took on one of the most powerful companies in the world.

headline: House Votes to Decriminalize Cannabis
abstract: Democrats, with some Republican support, voted 220-204 to remove marijuana from the federal list of controlled substances, moving to catch up to the states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House passed legislation on Friday to decriminalize marijuana at the federal level, as Democrats and three Republicans banded together to capitalize on the political resonance of legalized cannabis as an issue of economic growth, racial justice and states’ rights.

headline: Wonking Out: The Curious Case of the Recovering Ruble
abstract: Why has Russia gone all out to defend its currency?
lead_paragraph: It has now been 37 days since Vladimir Putin’s forces reportedly thought they could capture Kyiv within 48 to 72 hours. Many news reports describe the Russian invasion as “stalled,” but as I read the detailed analyses, that isn’t quite right: Ukrainian forces are counterattacking, and in many places Russia appears to be losing ground.

headline: 15 Recipes for Observing Ramadan
abstract: As a month of fasting begins, these flavorful dishes will enliven suhoor meals and iftar celebrations.
lead_paragraph: With the holiest month in the Islamic calendar right around the corner, plans for suhoor and iftar meals, which bookend long days of fasting, are well underway across the globe. Below is just a sampling of recipes often found on tables across cultures and countries throughout the holiday, which begins Saturday in the United States and comes to a close with Eid al-Fitr on May 2. Some are savory, others are sweet, but all are sure to satisfy.

headline: Joni Mitchell Will Make a Rare Televised Appearance at the Grammys
abstract: The singer-songwriter, who has spoken in public infrequently since a 2015 aneurysm, will present an award live at the ceremony Sunday night in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: When viewers tune in to the 64th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, they will see some familiar celebrities at the microphone as presenters, including Megan Thee Stallion, Questlove, Dua Lipa, Lenny Kravitz and Jared Leto.

headline: Meet the Best New Artist Grammy Nominees
abstract: The Grammys expanded its top four categories this year to 10 nominees, from eight, freshening up best new artist most of all. Listen to them here.
lead_paragraph: The Grammys expanded its top four categories this year to 10 nominees, from eight, freshening up best new artist most of all. Listen to them here.

headline: C.D.C. Confirms It Will Lift Public Health Order Restricting Immigration
abstract: The agency cited “current public health conditions and an increased availability of tools to fight Covid-19” as grounds for returning in late May to prepandemic policies for admitting migrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced on Friday that it would lift an emergency public health order that had restricted immigration at U.S. land borders since the beginning of the pandemic, citing “current public health conditions and an increased availability of tools to fight Covid-19.”

headline: Doctor-Approved Recipes
abstract: Schnitzel with grapes, pasta amatriciana and more ideas from an afternoon of playing recipe concierge.
lead_paragraph: One of the great joys of my job is that there are people in my life who commandeer me when I see them and tell me what they’ve made from New York Times Cooking. My favorite interactions are with my doctor, a consummate New Yorker whom I love, and who has taken care of me for many years. Yesterday, in the exam room during an appointment, she took out her phone, opened the Cooking app, and began scrolling as she gave me the rundown on recipes:

headline: Jerrod Carmichael Comes Out in a Riveting Special That’s About So Much More
abstract: In “Rothaniel” on HBO, the stand-up grapples with secrets that defined his upbringing, the toll silence has taken and the price he’s paying to break it.
lead_paragraph: In his 2014 debut special, “Love at the Store,” the stand-up comic Jerrod Carmichael offered advice to gay people about the right time to come out of the closet. “Save it until you need it,” he said, quipping: “I would come out of the closet when a friend asked me to move.”

headline: How Stephen Sondheim’s Work Did (and Didn’t) Translate to the Screen
abstract: A new series of adaptations, documentaries and more examines the different ways the composer-lyricist left his mark on movies.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Sondheim, the unparalleled composer-lyricist who died in November, may have changed musical theater forever, but as a new program at the Museum of the Moving Image argues, he left his mark on film as well. Whether it’s Elaine Stritch’s screen-shattering performance of “The Ladies Who Lunch” in D.A. Pennebaker’s documentary “Original Cast Album: ‘Company’” or Madonna’s slinking around and cooing “Sooner or Later” in “Dick Tracy,” Sondheim’s work has given film audiences memorable moments.

headline: The student loan pause is supposed to end in a month. That looks unlikely.
abstract: Loan servicers were told to hold off on sending bills, signaling that an extension is probably in the works.
lead_paragraph: On May 1, the federal government is supposed to resume collections — for the first time in more than two years — from 43 million borrowers on $1.6 trillion in federal student loan debt.

headline: Review: Two Artists Arrive at the Philharmonic, Loudly
abstract: The conductor Anna Rakitina made her New York Philharmonic debut, while the pianist Haochen Zhang had his first subscription series appearance.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic performed Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No. 2 on Thursday, barely a month had passed since that piece was heard nearby at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Transcript: Rogé Karma Interviews Nicholas Mulder for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
abstract: A conversation with the historian.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Rogé Karma and featuring Nicholas Mulder. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Artists and Rock Stars Mingle at the Whitney Biennial
abstract: The 80th edition of the museum’s survey of American art opens.
lead_paragraph: “It’s nice to have people back, in person, celebrating art and the next-generation artists,” said Adam Weinberg, the director of the Whitney Museum, as he welcomed more than 1,000 guests to celebrate the museum’s 80th biennial on Tuesday.

headline: How to Find Newly Released Census Records From 1950
abstract: It is now easy to access information on individuals from that census, but beware of misspelled names.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives and Records Administration posted millions of records from the 1950 census online at 12:01 a.m. Friday, revealing for the first time a trove of data on people’s lives — from income to ancestry to education and more — that had been kept secret under federal law for 72 years.

headline: Red Cross postpones its effort to rescue civilians from besieged Mariupol.
abstract: At least one group of private vehicles left the battered city, but a larger effort failed when unsafe conditions prevented a Red Cross team from reaching the city to escort an evacuation convoy.
lead_paragraph: A planned mass evacuation of civilians from the besieged southern city of Mariupol, facilitated by the International Committee of the Red Cross, failed on Friday, even as Ukrainian officials said that about 3,000 civilians had managed to escape the city without a Red Cross escort.

headline: Netrebko Loses Work in Russia After Seeking Distance From Putin
abstract: The star soprano Anna Netrebko lost work in the West over her ties to the Russian president. Now, following an about-face, she has been called a traitor at home.
lead_paragraph: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko, one of opera’s biggest stars, faced backlash on Friday in her home country after she tried to distance herself from President Vladimir V. Putin amid his invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Love Letter: My Dentist, My Divorce
abstract: How to treat the pain of divorce? Go to your dentist, of course!
lead_paragraph: Hillery Stone came to her latest dentist with intolerable pain. After years of unsuccessful dental surgery and a recent divorce, she couldn’t pinpoint where the pain was coming from. She thought it might be a tooth in the back of her mouth — but that tooth had been removed years ago.

headline: Turkey Moves Closer to Ending Khashoggi Murder Trial Without Conclusion
abstract: Turkey’s justice minister said he would agree to transfer the trial to Saudi Arabia, effectively ending a case that rights groups hoped could offer a measure of justice.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkey moved another step closer on Friday to transferring the trial for the murder of the Saudi dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi to Saudi Arabia, a decision that would effectively kill the last case that rights groups hoped would serve a measure of justice for a grisly crime that shocked the world.

headline: Ask Wirecutter: Using Scratched Nonstick Pans
abstract: They probably won't hurt you, but you should replace them anyway.
lead_paragraph: They probably won't hurt you, but you should replace them anyway.

headline: A European playoff will determine the third U.S. opponent.
abstract: Ukraine, Wales and Scotland will battle in June for Europe’s final place in Qatar.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s World Cup draw assigned groups to the 29 teams that have qualified for the tournament in Qatar in November. But the moment the draw ended, fans — especially those of teams with a big “to be determined” in their groups — started asking: What about those three playoff spots?

headline: Fires, Then Floods: Risk of Deadly Climate Combination Rises
abstract: A new study found that the dangerous pairing of disasters may become more common in the American West as rains trigger runaway surges of mud and debris in areas damaged by wildfire.
lead_paragraph: Global warming is greatly increasing the risk that extreme wildfires in the American West are followed by heavy rainfall, a new study has found, highlighting the need for better preparations for hazards, like mudslides and flash floods, that can cause devastation long after the flames from severe blazes are out.

headline: Boy Fatally Shoots Classmate, 12, in South Carolina, Sheriff Says
abstract: It was not clear what led to the shooting or where the student had obtained a handgun. The two students were familiar with each other, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The authorities are investigating the fatal shooting of a 12-year-old student on Thursday by a classmate at their South Carolina middle school.

headline: Europe Asks China Not to Aid Russia’s War in Ukraine
abstract: A first E.U.-China summit in two years was overshadowed by Ukraine and China’s alliance with Moscow and produced few results.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union on Friday called on China not to aid Russia’s war against Ukraine or to subvert Western sanctions on Moscow, in the first summit meeting between the two sides in two years.

headline: What Will Smith and Joe Biden Have in Common
abstract: The slap and the slip were the same kind of gaffe.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s gaffe about Vladimir Putin and Will Smith slapping Chris Rock at Sunday’s Academy Awards ceremony were demonstrations of a single phenomenon.

headline: This Man’s April Fools’ Day Prank Is a Wordle Song
abstract: The singer and composer Tom Rosenthal has released a song that contains only five-letter words, like the game.
lead_paragraph: The English singer and composer Tom Rosenthal has released an April Fools’ Day song every year since 2018, and this year’s contribution is a dreamy, Zen-like composition called “Drift Along Small World.” The song contains only five-letter words, and the lyrics float by the animated train window as Wordle entries as a passenger plays the game on his phone.

headline: U.S. World Cup Schedule Is Set: T.B.D., Then England, Then Iran
abstract: The Americans’ first game will come on the World Cup’s opening day, but the opponent won’t be known until June.
lead_paragraph: After all that waiting, after months of qualifying, the United States men’s soccer team finally learned its World Cup opponents at the tournament’s official draw on Friday: England, Iran and a question mark in the form of a European team that has yet to be determined.

headline: Overlooked No More: Elizabeth Hayes, Coal Town Doctor Who Fought for Miners
abstract: “Dr. Betty” led 350 miners on a strike in Pennsylvania in 1945 demanding that the mining company that owned their town improve horridly unsanitary conditions.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Russia’s Aggression Prompts Calls to Rethink U.S. Uranium Imports
abstract: The war in Ukraine has highlighted the risks of U.S. dependence on Russia for the fuel needed for nuclear energy, creating new challenges for the industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Western leaders have raced to respond to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with steps to reduce imports of Russian fossil fuels, U.S. lawmakers and officials are confronting a thorny dilemma over another source of energy: the Russian uranium that powers many American nuclear plants.

headline: Book Twitter Comes to Life
abstract: Literary luminaries including Marlon James, Leslie Jamison and Jennifer Egan attend gala for Poets & Writers.
lead_paragraph: “Asking a writer how they did during the pandemic is a little bit like asking a cat,” Seth Meyers told a group of 600 literary luminaries Tuesday night. “‘It was weird! I just sat around, never went out.’”

headline: Yale Museum Surrenders Items as Part of Art Looting Investigation
abstract: The 13 artifacts, valued at more than $1 million and all from South Asia, were given to investigators who say some of them are linked to an accused antiquities smuggler.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials have seized 13 artifacts from the Yale University Art Gallery that they say were looted. Many of those, the authorities said, are part of an ongoing investigation into Subhash Kapoor, a former Madison Avenue art dealer accused of being one of the world’s most prolific antiquities smugglers.

headline: ‘Meatspace’? Technology Does Funny Things to Language
abstract: Our words reveal a lot about changes in society.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate April Fools’ Day I’ve tried to have some fun in this newsletter, including in the choice of reader mail and the quote of the day. Everything’s true, though — no fooling.

headline: New York City Keeps Mask Mandate for Kids Under 5 as Cases Rise
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams made the announcement as a judge moved to strike down the requirement. Coronavirus cases are increasing again in New York, fueled by the Omicron subvariant BA.2.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Friday that New York City would keep its school mask mandate in place for children under 5 in response to rising rates of coronavirus cases in the city.

headline: Bruce Arians Gave the N.F.L. a Diversity Blueprint It Shouldn’t Ignore
abstract: His tactical retirement plan as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers coach created an opportunity for Todd Bowles and left a pipeline of experienced Black assistant coaches and coordinators.
lead_paragraph: Rooney Rule? Maybe the N.F.L. should forget the Rooney Rule, which the league leans on in a halfhearted effort to increase diversity among its head coaches. What the N.F.L. needs are more leaders like Bruce Arians.

headline: Former Yale Official Admits to $40 Million Fraud Scheme
abstract: For a decade, a Yale School of Medicine administrator used university funds to buy computer equipment, which she resold to pay for luxury cars, real estate and vacations, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A former Yale School of Medicine administrator pleaded guilty this week to defrauding the university of $40 million in computer equipment that she had purchased and resold to pay for luxury vehicles, real estate and vacations, the authorities said.

headline: Russia and Ukraine Have Long Been This Filmmaker’s Subject
abstract: In documentaries and fictional features, including two timely new movies, Sergei Loznitsa takes a hard look at both countries, examining daily life amid war and other historic forces.
lead_paragraph: The scenes of German and Soviet soldiers overtaking Ukraine in Sergei Loznitsa’s “Babi Yar: Context” inevitably bring to mind the current Russian invasion of the country. For more than two decades, Loznitsa, a Ukrainian filmmaker who was raised in the Soviet Union, has chronicled the past and the present in Ukraine and Russia by revisiting historic events and depicting daily life in the grips of war and empire.

headline: Republicans Target Progressive Advocacy Group Amid Opposition to Jackson
abstract: Some Republicans have linked their criticism of President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee to the support she has received from Demand Justice, a group that wants to expand the court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of progressive activists crowded into the Hamilton music venue a few blocks from the White House on Monday night to celebrate the nomination of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, listen to queen of funk Chaka Khan perform and hear someone, as the song goes, tell them something good.

headline: A Producer Seeks a Broadway Comeback, Mired in Offstage Drama
abstract: With the musical “Paradise Square” preparing to open Sunday, Garth Drabinsky is hoping to re-establish himself after serving time in a Canadian prison for fraud.
lead_paragraph: Ten days before opening night of his Broadway show, “Paradise Square,” Garth Drabinsky was sitting at a breakfast table at the Peninsula Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, fending off a stream of cellphone calls from members of his production team.

headline: A Matzo-Based Brittle for the Modern Age
abstract: An adaptation of a popular chocolate matzo toffee, this recipe pairs salted peanut and caramel for a sweet-salty crunch.
lead_paragraph: Like so many others, I, for years, drizzled chocolate over matzo for my children at Passover, so I was no stranger to matzo treats. But somehow, I missed the creation of caramel matzo crunch, also called “matzo buttercrunch” or “matzo brittle,” its many incarnations found in cookbooks, on blogs and websites. Sometimes the provenance is recognized, but mostly not.

headline: Margaret M. McGowan, Who Expanded the Field of Dance History, Dies at 90
abstract: She took a unique interdisciplinary approach and created a new field of study by exploring the collision of politics, ballet, design and music.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Margaret M. McGowan, a British cultural historian who created a new international area of academic study, now known as early dance, and received national honors in both Britain and France, died on March 16 in Brighton, England. She was 90.

headline: World Cup Draw Brings Certainty. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: Often, draws do not mean what they seem to mean at first reading. Just ask Spain and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Louis van Gaal said it all with just the hint of a playful smile. The Netherlands’ draw for the World Cup was not easy, he said, with his characteristic bluntness, and nor was it lucky. It was, instead, “colorful.” That was a better word. Ecuador’s sunshine yellow, Qatar’s rich maroon, Senegal’s deep green and that blazing Dutch orange: colorful.

headline: Can You Be Too Old for a Jean Jacket?
abstract: A reader wonders whether she has outgrown denim outerwear.
lead_paragraph: Though the pandemic did indeed briefly cast a shadow over jeans (and with them, jean jackets), that cloud has largely dispersed. In January, Levi’s reported a 29 percent growth in net revenues in 2021, and said the upward trend was expected to continue.

headline: Final Four Lore Shaped With Indelible New Orleans Moments
abstract: This will be the sixth Final Four held in the Superdome, and each of the previous five has provided a signature moment.
lead_paragraph: Update: Kansas beat UNC to win the NCAA Championship.

headline: Preparing for the next wave
abstract: What to do in advance of the BA.2 wave.
lead_paragraph: Just when the Omicron wave seems to have died down in the U.S., experts are already warning about the next surge of cases — this time driven by the highly infectious subvariant BA.2.

headline: How Conflicts of Interest Are Hurting the Climate
abstract: Bill McKibben, the environmental activist, explains.
lead_paragraph: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: Caleb Landry Jones Can Do This
abstract: The actor — whose latest film, the Australian drama “Nitram,” earned him a top prize at Cannes — discusses his distinctive career in challenging roles.
lead_paragraph: Until recent events at the Oscars, the film season’s most memorable best actor speech belonged to Caleb Landry Jones. In July, the Cannes Film Festival awarded Jones its top male thespian prize for his portrayal of a mass shooter in the Australian drama “Nitram” (now in theaters and on digital). The 32-year-old actor had been to Cannes twice before and had experienced its queasy jitters, spurred by drinking too much, sleeping too little and feeling eyeballs scan his face to gauge his importance. (“L.A., but times 50,” he said.) But this time, all eyeballs were fixed on him as he clutched the awards podium like a fainting chaise. “I think I’m going to throw up,” he sputtered. The audience tittered, uncertain if his panic was a bit. Then Jones fled the stage, leaving in his wake a few exhalations that lingered like dust clouds from a cartoon roadrunner: “I am so sorry — I cannot do this. Thank you so much.”

headline: New York Mob Hit Man Escapes Custody With His Sentence Nearly Served
abstract: With less than a year before he would likely be released, Dominic Taddeo did not return to a halfway house in Florida earlier this week, officials said.
lead_paragraph: After decades in prison, and less than a year before his likely release, Dominic Taddeo apparently decided he couldn’t wait to get out.

headline: Russians Line Up Behind Putin
abstract: Most of the war’s opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Tobacco Road Prepares for Basketball Nirvana — or Apocalypse
abstract: The rivalry between Duke and North Carolina, always fearsome, is reaching new levels as the two schools meet Saturday for a chance to play in the men’s national championship game.
lead_paragraph: Update: Kansas beat UNC to win the NCAA Championship.

headline: An Exuberant Take on Onions and Rice, for Passover and Beyond
abstract: Glistening with honey and pomegranate juice and studded with pine nuts, this baked onion and rice casserole is anything but unassuming.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, the Rabbinical Assembly, an international organization of Conservative Jewish rabbis, revoked the longstanding prohibition of eating kitniyot (such as legumes, beans, rice and corn) during Passover. For many Ashkenazi Jews, this meant a rabbinical green light for serving the likes of rice, lentils, chickpeas, corn, beans and spices like mustard and cardamom at the Seder table — the first significant menu change in approximately 800 years.

headline: Budi Tek, 65, Dies; His Fortune Built a Vast Trove of Asian Art
abstract: He was one of the world’s top collectors, and his immense Yuz Museum in Shanghai helped establish the region’s bustling art scene.
lead_paragraph: Budi Tek, a Chinese-Indonesian billionaire who in the 2000s emerged almost overnight as one of the world’s leading art collectors, and who later founded one of China’s largest private museums, died on March 18 in Hong Kong. He was 65.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in April
abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles.

headline: Adams Seeks to Keep Mask Mandate for Preschoolers
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City said that his administration would seek to keep its school mask mandate in place for children under 5 as a judge moved to strike down the public health measure.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City said that his administration would seek to keep its school mask mandate in place for children under 5 as a judge moved to strike down the public health measure.

headline: Using Film to Tell a Personal History of America and Race
abstract: With “Who We Are,” the lecturer Jeffery Robinson and the directors Emily and Sarah Kunstler follow in the tradition of documentaries that excavate our past.
lead_paragraph: For over a decade, Jeffery Robinson has been telling an unvarnished history of the United States in an ever-evolving lecture presentation. His talks, now presented as part of his organization, the Who We Are Project, delve into how racism against Black people was bound up with the country’s legacy since its founding. The new documentary, “Who We Are: A Chronicle of Racism in America,” captures Robinson’s eye-opening account (filmed at Town Hall in New York City) and intersperses interviews with civil rights figures and others from his travels across the country.

headline: Hope Solo, Former U.S. Soccer Star, Charged With Impaired Driving
abstract: Ms. Solo had her two children in the vehicle when she was arrested in Winston-Salem, N.C., the police said. “The story is more sympathetic than the initial charges suggest,” her lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Hope Solo, a two-time Olympic gold medalist and former star goalkeeper for the United States soccer team, was arrested on Thursday in North Carolina and charged with impaired driving, resisting arrest and misdemeanor child abuse, the police said.

headline: With cases rising, Mayor Eric Adams is keeping New York City’s preschool mask mandate.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Friday that New York City will keep its school mask mandate in place for children under 5 in response to rising coronavirus cases in the city.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Friday that New York City will keep its school mask mandate in place for children under 5 in response to rising coronavirus cases in the city.

headline: Charles G. Boyd, Air Force General and Former P.O.W., Dies at 83
abstract: He began his 36-year career in the military as a fighter pilot and was the only prisoner of war in the Vietnam conflict to become a four-star general.
lead_paragraph: Charles G. Boyd, an Air Force fighter pilot who was held captive as a prisoner of war in Vietnam for nearly seven years, rose to the rank of four-star general and later forged a civilian career as an expert on homeland security and foreign policy, died on March 23 in Haymarket, Va. He was 83.

headline: Juror’s Error Did Not Affect Ghislaine Maxwell Verdict, Judge Rules
abstract: The juror’s statements to the media had clouded the sex-trafficking conviction of Ms. Maxwell, a longtime companion of Jeffrey Epstein.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge on Friday denied Ghislaine Maxwell’s request for a new trial, rejecting her claim that a juror’s failure to disclose his personal history of being sexually abused as a child had deprived her of a fair and impartial jury.

headline: Spike in Violence Poses Test for Israel’s Fragile Government
abstract: A rash of terrorist attacks has spawned criticism of the government from the left and right, and for opposite reasons. But the coalition’s diversity has constrained its options.
lead_paragraph: BNEI BRAK, Israel — A recent wave of terrorist attacks in Israel, the deadliest in seven years, has presented a stark challenge to Israel’s fragile coalition government, which has come under criticism from both ends of the political spectrum for policies that critics claim have compounded the risk of violence.

headline: Man Who Police Say Used Tinder to Hunt Women Is Charged With Murder

lead_paragraph: A man who prosecutors say killed a Queens woman shortly after a paperwork mix-up led to his release from custody four years ago was charged with her murder on Friday, the latest chapter in a cross-country crime story.

headline: In a Blow to Mets, Jacob deGrom Hits the Injured List
abstract: DeGrom, one of the team’s top starters, will miss his opening day start and will not throw for a month after shoulder tightness was diagnosed as a stress reaction.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Entering the 2022 season with a record payroll and several new talented players, the Mets had high hopes. Perhaps the biggest reason for that revolved around star pitchers Jacob deGrom and Max Scherzer, the leaders of what was supposed to be one of the best starting rotations in baseball.

headline: Democratic Hopes and Anxiety Rise Over the Jan. 6 Panel
abstract: As the congressional committee investigating the Capitol riot races to conclude its work, the political stakes are increasing along with the legal expectations.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the X factors that could, in theory, alter the contours of this year’s midterm elections: What does the Jan. 6 committee have in its pocket?

headline: Putin Knows What He’s Doing With Ukraine’s Refugees. This Is the World’s Big Test.
abstract: The response to Ukrainian refugees is a test of European solidarity.
lead_paragraph: The mass flight of refugees from Ukraine has created a humanitarian crisis that dwarfs anything Europe has seen since World War II. More than four million people have poured into neighboring countries, and as long as Russia’s savage war continues, millions more will flee. Already, the flow of refugees from Ukraine is far greater than the number from Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq who fled to Europe in 2015, upending European politics.

headline: The case of four men accused of plotting to kidnap Michigan’s governor over Covid rules goes to the jury.
abstract: The government’s accusations were jarring: Several men with militia ties had schemed to abduct Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan at her vacation home. The group, prosecutors and witnesses said, had held a series of “field training exercises” and discussed killing or stranding her in a boat in the middle of Lake Michigan.
lead_paragraph: The government’s accusations were jarring: Several men with militia ties had schemed to abduct Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan at her vacation home. lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sued New York’s ethics commission on Friday, contending that its efforts to force him to turn over the proceeds of a $5.1 million book deal were a violation of his constitutional rights.

headline: Refuse to cooperate with the Kremlin’s war, Zelensky tells Ukrainians and Russians.
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine threatened retribution for people who collaborate with occupying forces and accused retreating Russians of planting mines and even booby-trapping corpses.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called on ordinary people of his country and Russia alike to refuse to cooperate in Moscow’s invasion and occupation, and accused Russian forces in northern Ukraine of planting mines as they retreat, making it dangerous for people to return.

headline: The People, United, Must Fight Hard or Be Defeated
abstract: Amazon workers on Staten Island have created the company’s first union. The government needs to make it easier for others to follow.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Amazon fired Christian Smalls after he organized fellow workers at a warehouse on Staten Island to protest pandemic working conditions. On Friday, after a campaign the company bitterly opposed, the government announced that those workers had voted to unionize, and Mr. Smalls, their leader, popped open a bottle of champagne.

headline: Sarah Palin Announces She’s Running for Congress in Alaska
abstract: Ms. Palin released a statement on Friday that she was entering the race to replace Representative Don Young, who died last month.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin, a former Alaska governor and the Republican nominee for vice president in 2008, said Friday that she was entering the race for Alaska’s lone congressional seat, marking her return to national politics after she helped revive the anti-establishment rhetoric that has come to define the Republican Party.

headline: Life in an E.R. During Covid
abstract: Thomas Fisher talks about “The Emergency,” and Maud Newton discusses “Ancestor Trouble.”
lead_paragraph: Thomas Fisher’s new book, “The Emergency,” details his life as an emergency physician at the University of Chicago Medical Center, where he’s worked for 20 years. It provides an up-close look at a hospital during the pandemic, and also zooms out to address the systemic issues that afflict American health care.

headline: Two high schools in New Jersey reinstate mask mandates following outbreaks.
abstract: New coronavirus cases have led to the resumption, if temporarily, of some mitigation strategies.
lead_paragraph: South Brunswick High School, in Middlesex County, N.J., announced that beginning on Friday masks again became mandatory in classrooms and will be required through next week in order to curb the spread of coronavirus during a significant spike of cases. The move signals a potential resumption of mitigation strategies in schools as the highly contagious BA.2 subvariant of Omicron spreads across the country.

headline: U.S. Will Help Transfer Soviet-Made Tanks to Ukraine
abstract: The transfer, a response to a request from Ukraine’s president, will mark the first time the Biden administration has helped send tanks in the five-week-old war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration will work with allies to transfer Soviet-made tanks to bolster Ukrainian defenses in the country’s eastern Donbas region, a U.S. official said on Friday.

They had booked the open-top bus. They had arranged a whole day of festivities. They were well aware it was tempting fate, but they had no choice: These things, after all, take time and planning.

abstract: The Huskies withstood several late pushes by the Cardinal to set up a showdown against South Carolina on Sunday night.
