lead_paragraph: Can you find Bosnia and Herzegovina on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European nation with three million people?

headline: Wall Street’s Rigid Culture Bends to Demands for Flexibility at Work
abstract: Many big banks are offering flexible working arrangements — sometimes grudgingly — as they chase talent that would rather stay home.
lead_paragraph: When Tom Naratil arrived on Wall Street in the 1980s, work-life balance didn’t really exist. For most bankers of his generation, working long hours while missing out on family time wasn’t just necessary to get ahead, it was necessary to not be left behind.

headline: ‘The Illegality of the Plan Was Obvious’
abstract: A judge has ruled that Donald J. Trump most likely committed a crime in trying to stop the certification of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: After months of investigation by a congressional committee, a federal judge has found that President Donald J. Trump and his allies most likely engaged in illegal activity in the wake of the 2020 election.

headline: Best and Worst Moments From the 2022 Grammys
abstract: Young artists brought dramatic performances, Doja Cat had an emotional moment at the microphone and Volodymyr Zelensky recorded a serious plea from Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The 64th annual Grammy Awards promised a return to (relative) normalcy following a scaled-down 2021 ceremony that largely took place outdoors. In Las Vegas for the first time, and with the pop spectacle dialed back up, the show’s most impactful moments were often its least flashy: a sober plea for help from President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine; Doja Cat’s teary moment at the microphone; performances on rooftops that put a spotlight on a different crop of artists. (High-octane live moments from Billie Eilish and H.E.R. made a big impact, too.) Here are the show’s highlights and lowlights as we saw them.

headline: Putin’s European allies
abstract: The fight between democracy and autocracy is happening not only in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has described the world as being engaged in a “battle between democracy and autocracy,” and Ukraine has become the central front.

headline: Senate negotiators announce a deal on a smaller Covid spending proposal without global vaccine funding.
abstract: The $10 billion package does not include funds for the global vaccination effort, frustrating some Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Senators announced a deal on a $10 billion coronavirus aid package on Monday to provide additional aid for domestic testing, vaccination and treatment efforts, after dropping a push to include billions for the global vaccination effort.

headline: The Biennial World Cup May Be Dead, but FIFA’s Fight Isn’t Over
abstract: FIFA has quietly given up on a plan to hold the World Cup every two years. But surrender may not mean peace for its president, Gianni Infantino.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Gianni Infantino strode into the bright lights of a packed convention center alongside the emir of Qatar on Friday and declared that he expected this year’s World Cup to be the best ever. It was not an unusual boast; Infantino has made it before, in Russia in 2018, and he will surely make it again when the tournament heads to North America in 2026. But behind his beaming smile, and his bombastic words, the trip to the desert had been the setting for the FIFA president’s latest disappointment.

headline: Who Was Your Favorite Musical Artist This Year?
abstract: Were any of your top songs, albums or artists recognized at the Grammy Awards?
lead_paragraph: At the Grammy Awards on Sunday, Olivia Rodrigo, Silk Sonic and Jon Batiste took home some of the top prizes during what New York Times critic Jon Caramanica called “an utterly inconsistent night.”

headline: Grammys Red Carpet: Show Girls, Tiger Queens and Pearly Kings
abstract: The Vegas evening was an exuberant reminder of why red carpets can be fun for both stars and fans.
lead_paragraph: Ah, Las Vegas: It provides inspiration in so many ways. That’s how it seemed, anyway, judging from the Grammy red carpet, newly located to the MGM Grand Garden Arena in the city of … gosh, so many things! Sin and lights and camp and Elvis.

headline: Elon Musk becomes Twitter’s largest shareholder.
abstract: The Tesla chief executive, who has been critical of Twitter’s content moderation policies, has bought 9.2 percent of the social media company.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

headline: Zelensky blasts Merkel and Sarkozy for denying Ukraine NATO membership.
abstract: In a video address, he said that NATO’s decision in 2008 not to give Ukraine a path to membership helped lead to atrocities by Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine lambasted the former leaders of Germany and France, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy, in a video address released late on Sunday, seemingly blaming them for the deaths of Ukrainian civilians.

headline: Julian Gaines Has a Question: ‘How Do I Paint Oregon Black?’
abstract: A love for Nike led him away from his home in Chicagoland to a grand artist’s studio on a weed farm outside Portland.
lead_paragraph: In a cavernous studio on a weed farm in Forest Grove, Ore., about halfway between Portland and the Tillamook State Forest, Julian Gaines, an artist born and raised in Chicagoland, is creating a body of work devoted to Black American life.

headline: What to Know About the Sacramento Shooting
abstract: At least six people were killed and 12 wounded on Sunday in a killing that the police say involved multiple shooters.
lead_paragraph: Six people were killed and at least a dozen wounded in downtown Sacramento on Sunday in what the authorities say is the largest mass shooting in the city’s history.

headline: Carrie Lam, racked by Covid failures, won’t seek a new term to lead Hong Kong.
abstract: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, announced on Monday that she would not seek a second term, after a huge surge in coronavirus infections left the global financial hub with one of the highest virus death rates in the world.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, announced on Monday that she would not seek a second term, after a huge surge in coronavirus infections left the global financial hub with one of the highest virus death rates in the world.

headline: Elon Musk’s Latest Twitter Adventure
abstract: The Tesla chief bought a big stake in the social media company. What’s his plan?
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million in California
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.
lead_paragraph: This house is in a mostly residential section of Altadena, about a five-minute drive from the shopping along Lake Avenue. A number of trailheads are within a short drive or walk, including Henninger Trailhead, which has paths of varying difficulty for hikers and mountain bikers.

headline: At the Grammys, the Young Succeed Most When They Seem Old
abstract: Despite nods to Gen Z, this year’s show favored history-minded performers like Silk Sonic, Jon Batiste, H.E.R. and Lady Gaga.
lead_paragraph: There is no surer way for a young musician to acquire a quick coat of gravitas than an appearance on the Grammy Awards. And there is no surer way for a young musician to speed the way to the Grammys than by already appearing to be old.

headline: You Want Your Child Vaccinated, but Your Ex Says No
abstract: For some parents who share custody, the Covid vaccine has created a minefield of issues that initial divorce decrees could not have anticipated.
lead_paragraph: In late 2021, Adele Grote, a divorced mother of two in Minneapolis, took her children to a vaccination clinic at the Mall of America. But when her 13-year-old daughter called her father to let him know they were getting the shot, Ms. Grote knew they would have to leave without it.

headline: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on Ukraine
abstract: Uncritically sharing posts about Ukraine can make you an accidental conduit for war propaganda. Here's what to watch for.
lead_paragraph: Uncritically sharing posts about Ukraine can make you an accidental conduit for war propaganda. Here's what to watch for.

headline: She Moved From the Chem Lab to the Kitchen, but Not by Choice
abstract: In Bonnie Garmus’s debut novel, “Lessons in Chemistry,” a woman who has been banished to the home front turns it into a staging ground for a revolution.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

headline: ‘Downstate’ and ‘Catch as Catch Can’ in Playwrights Horizons New Season
abstract: The company has announced five works for its 2022-23 lineup, which will include Agnes Borinsky’s “The Trees,” directed by Tina Satter.
lead_paragraph: “Downstate,” a Bruce Norris play that The New York Times’s chief theater critic, Jesse Green, has called a “squirmy moral-thrill-ride,” will make its New York premiere in October as part of Playwrights Horizons’s new season, the company announced on Monday.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: On culinary wanderlust, with recipes for fried fish, savory bread pudding and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. “We domestic sensualists live in a state of longing, no matter how comfortable our own places are,” Laurie Colwin wrote in “The Lone Pilgrim,” and I often think about that when I’m cooking. I could be, for instance, halfway through the preparation of Heston Blumenthal’s magical recipe for fried fish with vodka and beer batter (above) and realize, deep in my bones, that what I really desire is kimchi grilled cheese, or chicken paprikash.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the U.N. Report on Limiting Global Warming
abstract: Current pledges to cut emissions, even if nations follow through on them, won’t stop temperatures from rising to risky new levels.
lead_paragraph: Nations are not doing nearly enough to prevent global warming from increasing to dangerous levels within the lifetimes of most people on Earth today, according to a new report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of researchers convened by the United Nations. Limiting the devastation won’t be easy, but it also isn’t impossible if countries act now, the report says.

headline: Stopping Climate Change Is Doable, but Time Is Short, U.N. Panel Warns
abstract: A major new scientific report offers a road map for how countries can limit global warming, but warns that the margin for error is vanishingly small.
lead_paragraph: Nations need to move away much faster from fossil fuels to retain any hope of preventing a perilous future on an overheated planet, according to a major new report on climate change released on Monday, although they have made some progress because of the falling costs of clean energy.

headline: Rwandan Court Declines to Extend Sentence for Paul Rusesabagina
abstract: Mr. Rusesabagina, who inspired the movie “Hotel Rwanda” and later lived in exile in the United States, had been given a 25-year term in a case condemned by human-rights groups.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A court in Rwanda on Monday turned away an attempt by prosecutors to extend the 25-year sentence for Paul Rusesabagina, the hotelier turned dissident whose story was portrayed in the Oscar-nominated movie “Hotel Rwanda,” to life in prison.

headline: Machine Gun Kelly Has a Second No. 1 Album, ‘Mainstream Sellout’
abstract: The pop-punk musician’s latest release had the equivalent of 93,000 sales in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Machine Gun Kelly, the onetime rapper who has remade himself into the jester prince of a new wave of pop-punk, opens at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with his latest album, “Mainstream Sellout.”

headline: Even a Broken Femur Can’t Stop Tony Hawk
abstract: A documentary chronicles the challenges of Hawk’s skating career. He sat down to discuss the devastating leg injury that made promoting it (and walking) a challenge.
lead_paragraph: While everyone’s attention was focused elsewhere, another thing happened at this year’s Oscars. Tony Hawk, the world’s most iconic skateboarder, unveiled his latest trick: Standing without a cane.

headline: New Mezcals With a ‘Mad’ Backstory
abstract: Fósforo, a new mezcal brand financed by Jim Cramer, is releasing two styles of the spirit made from tobalá.
lead_paragraph: A new mezcal, Fósforo, will add two spirits to the crowded mezcal market, with sales beginning online on Monday and on shelves April 18. Both are distilled from the tobalá varietal of the agave plant, a species little known to Americans until recently and which has become increasingly popular among mezcal fans. Behind the spirits is Aarón Alva Sánchez, a fourth-generation mezcalero (mezcal maker) in Huehuetlán el Grande, Puebla, who has spent 20 years taming tobalá, an agave plant with a reputation for being difficult to cultivate. In a twist, Fósforo is backed not by an actor or musician (as is common in the world of celebrity tequilas and mezcals), but by Jim Cramer of “Mad Money” fame and his wife, Lisa Detwiler. Fósforo’s two offerings are the fruity and grassy Tobalá, and the ashy and vegetal Tobalá Penca, which is aged for one to three months in glass carboys with a cooked agave leaf.

headline: Understand the Science of Sourdough
abstract: A detailed new book by the molecular biologist Karyn Lynn Newman offers lively insight.
lead_paragraph: Two years into the pandemic, and perhaps you still haven’t tackled sourdough? This highly detailed new book, “Sourdough by Science,” written with lively insight by Karyn Lynn Newman, a molecular biologist, might get you into fermentation after all. Dr. Newman clearly explains what goes on with sourdough starter. Though she gives instructions for developing your own, she recommends buying it for reliability. Different flours, salt, proportions and equipment, as well as the steps that ensure successful dough-making, are covered. And there are recipes, including options you might not associate with sourdough, like focaccia. What if your crust is not shiny? Is the flavor too sour? She troubleshoots as well.

headline: A New Option for Kosher Meat Delivered to Your Door
abstract: Prairie Street Prime offers glatt kosher meat for celebratory occasions like Passover.
lead_paragraph: Prairie Street Prime is a new delivery option for glatt kosher meat, like a hefty slab of brisket to braise for Passover (the first night is April 15), or for rib roast or tomahawk steak for a more spectacular presentation.  The company, based in Great Neck, N.Y, has been in development for several years. After some trial runs last year, it began shipping nationally this year. Some of the Star-K certified beef is U.S.D.A. Prime grade. The company’s founder, Elliot Moskowitz, a financier, saw that for kosher meat there was no equivalent to high-end companies like Snake River Farms or Pat LaFrieda selling directly to consumers. So he stepped in. The prime tomahawk steak ($130), once seared, then finished in a slow oven, was quite tender and had rich flavor. At around 40 ounces, it serves two to four. The choice grade tomahawk is $100. There are also short ribs, rib steaks and roasts, prime or choice, as well as lamb and veal. The meats are shipped frozen.

headline: Barachou Expands Its Offerings
abstract: The Upper West Side store has opened a second location in the West Village with more kitchen space and more to offer.
lead_paragraph: Barachou, Rebecca Tison’s Upper West Side pastry shop, opened in 2019 and specializes in a kaleidoscope of cream puffs and other French pastries. She found a steady clientele, which allowed her to open a second location. It’s in the West Village and seems to attract a stream of shoppers and snackers for coffee and pastries at cafe tables. She has more kitchen space downtown and has expanded her repertory to include individual pastries and tarts, with more savory options like croissants and olive and Cheddar bread. More complex pastries, like Paris-Brest, and a thick French custard flan are also new.

headline: A Tennessee Twist on Ham for Easter Brunch
abstract: The Nashville butcher shop Porter Road provides national shipping for its feast, which includes biscuits and pimento cheese.
lead_paragraph: Porter Road, a chef-owned butcher shop in Nashville that ships nationally, has assembled an Easter brunch package of ham and biscuits. (Just add eggs.) A half boneless ham — about 5.5 pounds of pasture-raised pork, cured, mildly smoked and ready for a slick of glaze for that Sunday centerpiece — will serve eight to 10. It comes with biscuits, both buttermilk and sharp Cheddar, and a tub of traditional Southern pimento cheese, all from Callie’s Hot Little Biscuit; $130, including shipping ($20 extra to some destinations). The company also sells half and whole hams without the accessories. Orders must be placed no later than April 11 for delivery by April 15.

headline: Mother of Slain 12-Year-Old Begs for Answers: ‘I’m Asking for Justice’
abstract: Kade Lewin was fatally shot on Thursday evening as he sat in a parked car with family members in Brooklyn. No arrests have been made.
lead_paragraph: The family of a 12-year-old boy who was fatally shot last week in Brooklyn pleaded for answers at a news conference with Mayor Eric Adams on Monday, describing deep pain and frustration that innocent victims continue to be caught up in gunfire.

headline: These Colorful Chocolate Easter Eggs Dazzle
abstract: A beautiful set of treats, with fillings like coffee cream, mango and more, from Norman Love Confections is sure to  delight.
lead_paragraph: Chocolate Easter eggs, half-eggs really, are having their Jackson Pollock moment this year at Norman Love Confections in Fort Myers, Fla. Mr. Love covers the dark, milk and white chocolate shells in ombré pastels with contrasting spatters. Inside are opulent fillings like caramel, coconut cream, coffee cream, peanut butter, raspberry and mango for a two-bite treat. There are 10 varieties, $26 for the box. An assortment of the  eggs and other chocolates, 25 pieces, is $55.

headline: Ford and Stellantis say car sales fell at the start of the year.
abstract: The automakers’ performance in the first three months was in line with that of other companies, like General Motors and Toyota.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Monday that its new-vehicle sales in the United States fell 17 percent in the first three months of the year, in line with other automakers that are struggling to keep their factories running amid a global shortage of computer chips.

headline: Four Days That Changed Golf
abstract: Tiger Woods was not supposed to win the 1997 Masters, but when he did, by 12 strokes — one of 20 Masters records he set in that tournament — he remade the game and catapulted himself to stardom.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the first round of the Masters

headline: Here’s how Russia has avoided defaulting on its debt.
abstract: But analysts question whether sanctions will eventually affect Russia’s ability to pay.
lead_paragraph: Despite strict economic sanctions, shrinking currency reserves and nervous banks, Russia has kept up with payments for government debt, confounding expectations from just a few weeks ago, when the ratings agencies believed a default was imminent and the government said it might repay its international loans in rubles.

headline: Perfecting Neapolitan Pizza in Los Angeles, With Help From Tokyo
abstract: At Pizzeria Sei, Sang Woo Joo uses global wisdom to nudge a rigid style into the future, one pie at a time.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Every day, the pizza at Pizzeria Sei is a tiny bit different from the day before. I know this because I can’t stop going to Pizzeria Sei.

headline: Horrified by the Killing of Civilians in Ukraine
abstract: Readers urge stronger intervention and steep penalties for any war crimes. Also: Politicians, act for us; balloons’ peril; tenant evictions; smashing rackets.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cole Sprouse on Finding a Healthy Balance in Hollywood
abstract: The former child actor wanted to leave showbiz. Now, the “Moonshot” and “Riverdale” star is finding he can act and tend his photography career as well.
lead_paragraph: “I hope you don’t mind, I’m going to be scarfing down this chicken wrap at the same time we talk,” Cole Sprouse politely informs me as he sits in the kitchen wearing a fuzzy, baby blue sweater. The wrap in question is already halfway to his mouth.

headline: ICE Lawyers Directed to Clear Low-Priority Immigration Cases
abstract: The effort could significantly reduce a backlog of asylum and deportation cases as the Biden administration anticipates a huge surge of migrants crossing the border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is seeking to clear potentially hundreds of thousands of deportation and asylum cases pending before immigration courts, an unprecedented move that could significantly reduce the current backlog of 1.7 million cases.

headline: What’s the Best Advice You’ve Received About Motherhood?
abstract: Your response may be used in an upcoming story.
lead_paragraph: Mothers can get lots of unsolicited advice, starting even before a child is born: “Don’t eat that, you might harm the baby!” “Sleep on your side, you don’t want to cramp the little one!” And once the kid arrives, all bets are off. From feeding an infant to disciplining an unruly teen, people seem to think it’s all up for discussion.

headline: A Landscaper, an Aspiring Social Worker: Lives Cut Short in Sacramento Shooting
abstract: It was still unclear on Monday who was behind the gunfire that left six dead and 12 wounded in California’s capital early Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The six people killed in an eruption of gunfire in downtown Sacramento over the weekend, one of the worst mass killings in the city’s history, ranged in age from 21 to 57, the county coroner’s office said Monday.

headline: Holy Cross is renaming its science complex for Fauci.
abstract: The move, announced Monday, will coincide with Dr. Anthony S. Fauci’s 60th reunion at the college’s campus in Worcester, Mass., in June.
lead_paragraph: The College of the Holy Cross is renaming the science buildings on its campus in Worcester, Mass., in honor of one of its most famous graduates, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.

headline: Biden Calls Putin a War Criminal After Images from Bucha Surface
abstract: President Biden said reports of indiscriminate killings of civilians in the town of Bucha, Ukraine, constituted a “war crime” and that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia should face charges.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said reports of indiscriminate killings of civilians in the town of Bucha, Ukraine, constituted a “war crime” and that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia should face charges.

headline: Jury Selection Begins in Sentencing Trial for Parkland Gunman
abstract: The process is expected to take weeks. Jurors will then sit through a lengthy trial to determine if the gunman should be sentenced to death or life in prison.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — In the four years since a former student killed 17 people and injured 17 others in Parkland, Fla., the classroom building where the shooting took place has remained standing, unused and fenced off, on the grounds of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

headline: A Century of the BBC, a ‘Quasi-Mystical’ Part of England’s Psyche
abstract: David Hendy’s “The BBC” looks back at 100 years of wartime reporting, dramas, satires and weather reports.
lead_paragraph: The British Broadcasting Corporation, the BBC — the Beeb — turns 100 this year. “Hullo, hullo, 2LO calling, 2LO calling,” a few thousand listeners heard through the hissing ether at 6 p.m. on Nov. 14, 1922. “This is the British Broadcasting Company. 2LO. Stand by for one minute please!” What followed were short news and weather bulletins, read twice, the second time slowly so that listeners could take notes.

headline: World War II, Ukraine and the Future of Conflict
abstract: Richard Overy’s prodigious “Blood and Ruins” is a sweeping history of World War II packed with lessons for the future.
lead_paragraph: “Books have their own fates,” the Romans taught. Running for just under a thousand small-print pages, “Blood and Ruins,” too, has had its own fate. After 40 years of painstaking scholarly effort, Richard Overy was overridden by Vladimir Putin. Russia’s murderous assault on Ukraine makes the subtitle, “The Last Imperial War, 1931-1945,” ring premature. After 77 years of relative peace in Europe, the longest ever, conquest and slaughter are back. So are sorrow and pity.

headline: Atrocities in Bucha could complicate Russia-Ukraine talks.
abstract: It was unclear what effect the killing of civilians outside Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, would have on negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Russian and Ukrainian negotiators have been holding intermittent peace talks since a few days after the war began, but it has not been clear that they would amount to anything — or that the Kremlin was serious about negotiating.

headline: Why the Grammys Couldn’t Resist Jon Batiste
abstract: The jazz pianist is an inheritor more than an innovator, but he puts the past to use in service of fun, blending genres and embodying the pleasures of his hometown, New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Accepting the Grammy for album of the year on Sunday night, Jon Batiste delivered a minute-and-a-half manifesto that hinted at his roots in the musical culture of New Orleans.

headline: Anne Parsons, Who Revived the Detroit Symphony, Dies at 64
abstract: She shepherded the orchestra through a bitter six-month strike and then worked to ensure that it flourished after what many considered a near-death moment.
lead_paragraph: Anne Parsons, who as president and chief executive revitalized the Detroit Symphony Orchestra in the aftermath of a bitter strike, using education and technology to attract new audiences, died on March 28 in Detroit. She was 64.

headline: Book Banning Efforts Surged in 2021. These Titles Were the Most Targeted.
abstract: Most of the targeted books are about Black and L.G.B.T.Q. people, according to the American Library Association. The country’s polarized politics has fueled the rise.
lead_paragraph: Attempts to ban books in the United States surged in 2021 to the highest level since the American Library Association began tracking book challenges 20 years ago, the organization said Monday.

headline: With a Neutral Stance on Ukraine, Viktor Orban Pulled in Voters
abstract: The Hungarian prime minister’s party also made a strong showing in Sunday’s election, though independent observers said the vote was tilted in the ruling party’s favor.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Savoring the election victory of a rare European leader who has not condemned him as a war criminal, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday congratulated Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary for winning a fourth term and said he looked forward to an expansion of “partnership ties.”

headline: The Ruble Has Bounced Back. What Does That Mean?
abstract: Russia’s financial position is stronger in the short term than many expected.
lead_paragraph: President Biden bragged on Twitter on March 26 that “as a result of our unprecedented sanctions, the ruble was almost immediately reduced to rubble.” It was an ill-timed tweet. The Russian currency did crash in February after sanctions were imposed, but by the time Biden exulted, it had already regained lost ground. It’s now worth about 1.2 cents, which is down from 1.3 cents before the war but well above its wartime low of less than 0.8 cents.

headline: ‘Your Wife Seems to Care About the Rose Bushes’
abstract: Readers weigh in.
lead_paragraph: In the seven months since I began this newsletter, I’ve received thousands of emails from readers. These have led to some in-depth correspondences with all sorts of people who have pushed my thinking in meaningful ways. Today I want to thank everyone who has written in and respond to some emails publicly, which I’ll try to do somewhat regularly. I have always envisioned this newsletter as a dialogue between you and me, so if you have any concerns or thoughts or even just endless praise, please write to me at kang-newsletter@nytimes.com.

headline: On the Scene: At a Far Right Rally in France
abstract: I went to a rally held by Marine Le Pen, the far-right French presidential candidate who is rising in the polls.
lead_paragraph: I went to a rally held by Marine Le Pen, the far-right French presidential candidate who is rising in the polls.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Police in Malicious Prosecution Case
abstract: Plaintiffs need show only that the charges against them were dropped, the majority said, to satisfy a requirement that they had obtained a “favorable termination” of the prosecution.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday in favor of a Brooklyn man who said he had been falsely accused by police officers of resisting arrest, saying he could sue for malicious prosecution under a federal civil rights law.

headline: Sri Lanka Protesters Defy President, Rejecting a Cabinet Shuffle
abstract: The country’s Rajapaksa dynasty is facing its toughest challenge yet as protesters demand that the president step down amid a devastating economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — After weeks of upheaval over Sri Lanka’s economic crisis and growing resentment to his rule, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa offered the public a sacrifice, urging almost his entire cabinet, including several family members, to resign en masse while promising reform.

headline: Satellite images show bodies lay in Bucha for weeks, despite Russian claims.
abstract: The images rebut Russia’s claim that the killing of civilians in Bucha, near Kyiv, took place after its soldiers had left town.
lead_paragraph: Update: New video shows Russian soldiers opening fire on a cyclist in Bucha.

headline: U.S. colleges that once championed surveillance virus testing are backing away.
abstract: Institutions that used to test everyone on campus regularly now say it’s enough just to test the unvaccinated and people with symptoms.
lead_paragraph: Colleges and universities across the United States have relaxed campus requirements for coronavirus testing of vaccinated people in recent weeks, chipping away at some of the last widespread surveillance testing programs and dismaying public health experts, who say that robust sources of transmission data will be lost.

headline: Two More Republicans Back Jackson as Senate Moves Toward Confirmation
abstract: The support of Senators Mitt Romney and Lisa Murkowski for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination was a counterpoint to the bitterly partisan confirmation process so far.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A nearly unified wall of G.O.P. opposition to Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson cracked slightly on Monday as two more Senate Republicans said they would side with Democrats in supporting her, paving the way for her confirmation as the first Black woman on the Supreme Court.

headline: Gene Shue, All-Star and Longtime N.B.A. Coach, Dies at 90
abstract: He had a seven-decade pro career, starting as a guard with the Pistons before coaching for 22 years, leading the Bullets and the 76ers to the finals.
lead_paragraph: Gene Shue, an All-Star N.B.A. guard of the late 1950s and early ’60s who went on to turn losers into winners in 22 seasons as a pro coach, died Sunday at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 90.

headline: The Cocktail Bar Dead Rabbit Will Expand to New Orleans and Beyond
abstract: New locations of the Lower Manhattan bar are in the works, and a sister bar, Hazel and Apple, will open in Charleston, S.C., this year.
lead_paragraph: The Dead Rabbit is multiplying. The cocktail bar and pub in Lower Manhattan has plans to open new branches in New Orleans and Austin, Texas, in 2023, with hopes to open other locations in the next five years. A sister bar, called Hazel and Apple, will open in Charleston, S.C., later this year.

headline: ‘Dating Coach’ Charged in Capitol Riot Gets Prison Term for Gun Crime
abstract: Samuel Fisher, who as Brad Holiday traded in conspiracy theories and misogyny online, still faces federal charges related to Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: A self styled dating coach who prosecutors say participated in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol was sentenced to three and a half years in prison after he pleaded guilty to a gun possession charge in Manhattan Supreme Court on Monday — a case that emerged through a search warrant related to his apparent involvement in the riot.

headline: The War Moves East, as Putin Looks for a Victory
abstract: Having failed to score a quick triumph, Russia is shifting its attention to the contested breakaway enclaves, in Ukraine’s East. It is also shelling large cities to keep enemy forces from the expected new areas of battle.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Soldiers waved off traffic, emerging from trenches dug into the side of a multistory apartment building, telling motorists to turn around. Firefighters arrived soon after, unfurling hoses to combat a growing blaze ignited by an artillery round that hit a nearby housing complex.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: The Fallout from Bucha
abstract: President Biden called the atrocity a “war crime.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden called the indiscriminate civilian deaths in Bucha a “war crime” and said the U.S. would impose additional sanctions on Russia. Some European leaders also demanded tougher sanctions, including a total ban on Russian fuel imports. Here are the latest updates.

headline: The Horror in Bucha
abstract: Mounting evidence of atrocities is spurring calls to hold Russia accountable.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: South Africa lifts its Covid ‘state of disaster’ after two years.
abstract: Public health measures imposed under the declaration have often been strict, including bans on alcohol sales and certain types of clothing.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa is ending its national “state of disaster” over the coronavirus pandemic, which has been in effect for 750 days and allowed the government to impose some of the broadest public health restrictions seen anywhere.

headline: Gov. Larry Hogan Approves New Maryland Congressional Map
abstract: Drawn by Democrats and approved by a Republican governor, the new map will most likely result in a similar delegation to the state’s current one.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland on Monday signed into law a new congressional map drawn by Democrats, a little more than a week after a judge called their previous effort an “extreme gerrymander” and threw it out.

headline: Judge Keeps New York’s New Electoral Map Intact for Now
abstract: The stay by an appellate judge puts on hold a lower-court ruling that New York’s newly drawn congressional and legislative districts were unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: A New York appellate judge on Monday hit the brakes on a sweeping lower-court decision that invalidated newly drawn legislative districts favorable to Democrats and threatened to throw the state’s election season into turmoil.

headline: Terry Francona Is Back and Feeling Feisty
abstract: Francona missed huge chunks of two seasons with health issues, and the Cleveland Guardians are thrilled to have their merry prankster of a manager back in the clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — Terry Francona is healthy again. You can see it in Mike Barnett’s hair.

headline: Images of Russian Atrocities Push West Toward Tougher Sanctions
abstract: President Biden called for Vladimir Putin to face trial for war crimes, and European officials will meet to consider possibly banning some Russian energy imports.
lead_paragraph: The images of dead Ukrainians, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders on Monday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy, as the Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault.

headline: Tommy Davis, Batting Star With the ’60s Dodgers, Dies at 83
abstract: A two-time batting champion, he helped power a dominant Los Angeles team, but a serious injury derailed his career, and he fell short of the Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Davis, a former Brooklyn-born baseball prodigy who became a two-time All-Star, won two consecutive National League batting titles and led the star-studded Los Angeles Dodgers to a World Series championship in 1963, died on Sunday in Phoenix. He was 83.

headline: Has the Pandemic Changed Your Mental Health?
abstract: Many of us are trying to adapt to the new normal with emotional and mental scars that didn’t exist before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years of illness, upheaval and loss, many of us are being asked to return to something resembling our prepandemic lives. Offices are filling up, masks are coming off and more governments and organizations are making plans to “live with” the virus.

headline: ‘Sitting at Home and Trembling’: A Town Emerges After a Russian Retreat
abstract: A local official said he was detained and interrogated by the Russians, and described what he called mock executions.
lead_paragraph: NOVA BASAN, Ukraine — Badly frightened and hungry, residents of Nova Basan, a town east of Kyiv, emerged from their cottages and farmhouses on Monday, and described living through the terrifying ordeal of the Russian occupation — detentions, threats and a strict curfew that confined them to their homes with no outside communication for more than a month.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Senate Committee Votes on Jackson Nomination
abstract: Senators on the Judiciary Committee deadlocked 11 to 11 along party lines in the evenly divided chamber, forcing Democrats to take extra steps in the full Senate to keep Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation to the Supreme Court on track.
lead_paragraph: Senators on the Judiciary Committee deadlocked 11 to 11 along party lines in the evenly divided chamber, forcing Democrats to take extra steps in the full Senate to keep Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation to the Supreme Court on track.

headline: Covid’s Toll on Diabetic Americans
abstract: After older people and nursing home residents, no other group seems to have been hit harder.
lead_paragraph: After older people and nursing home residents, no other group seems to have been hit harder by Covid than people with diabetes. They account for a staggering 30 to 40 percent of all U.S. Covid deaths, several studies suggest.

headline: U.S. government to jury in 1MDB trial: Convict even if you don’t believe our star witness.
abstract: The defense said the only evidence of involvement by Roger Ng, who is accused of receiving illegal kickbacks, was the testimony of Tim Leissner, a former Goldman partner who admitted on the stand to lying a lot.
lead_paragraph: A federal prosecutor told jurors on Monday that they had received enough evidence to convict a former Goldman Sachs banker for his role in one of the biggest international money laundering and bribery schemes even without the testimony of the government’s star witness.

headline: Lygia Fagundes Telles, Popular Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 98
abstract: One of her country’s first writers to address female sexuality from a woman’s perspective, she produced four novels and dozens of short stories that could be read as political allegories.
lead_paragraph: Lygia Fagundes Telles, one of Brazil’s most popular writers, whose stories of women trapped in unsatisfying relationships could also be read as allegories of her country’s political situation, died on Sunday at her home in São Paulo. She was 98.

headline: Western Officials Condemn Reports of ‘Massacre’ by Military in Central Mali
abstract: The State Department and the French foreign ministry said they were alarmed at reports of deaths caused by the Malian armed forces and their allies — Russian mercenaries with the Wagner Group.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — French, American and European officials have expressed serious concerns about allegations that hundreds of people were killed last week in a town in the West African nation of Mali by Malian soldiers accompanied by Russian mercenaries on a campaign to fight insurgents.

headline: TikTok to the Grammys: How a ‘Bridgerton’ Musical Beat Broadway
abstract: With their award for “The Unofficial Bridgerton Musical,” two musical theater newcomers won against veterans like Andrew Lloyd Webber and Stephen Schwartz.
lead_paragraph: When the lyricist-composer duo behind “The Unofficial Bridgerton Musical” stepped onstage Sunday to accept their Grammy for best musical theater album, the list of people they wanted to thank did not start with a record label or producer, but with their social media followers.

headline: Medicare enrollees can get free home coronavirus tests from pharmacies.
abstract: Roughly 60 million Americans who are enrolled in Medicare can now get up to eight free home coronavirus tests per month from pharmacies or health care providers in a move by the Biden administration to expand testing access.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 60 million Americans who are enrolled in Medicare can now get up to eight free home coronavirus tests per month from pharmacies or health care providers in a move by the Biden administration to expand testing access.

headline: Sarah Palin Knows How to Get Attention. Can She Actually Win?
abstract: Endorsed by Donald Trump for Alaska’s lone House seat, the former vice-presidential candidate hopes she can mount a political comeback. But she’s not the phenomenon she once was.
lead_paragraph: The last time Sarah Palin and Donald Trump shared a stage together, the former Alaska governor gave a meandering endorsement speech that displayed her inventiveness with the English language — and her instinctive connection to the Republican base.

headline: A Small Earthquake on Staten Island
abstract: Why a pro-union vote at Amazon may be a big deal.
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a relatively equal society, at least as far as incomes were concerned. Obviously there were class differences in 1974, the year I graduated from college; some jobs paid much better than others, some people were rich while others were desperately poor. But for most Americans these differences were much narrower than they are today.

headline: Bidens Will Host a White House Wedding Reception for Their Granddaughter
abstract: Naomi Biden, 28, the daughter of Hunter Biden and Kathleen Buhle, will marry Peter Neal, 24, this fall.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, plan to host a wedding reception this fall at the White House for their eldest granddaughter, Naomi Biden, who is set to marry her longtime boyfriend.

headline: Why Are Seemingly Functional Adults Falling for the ‘Furries’ Myth?
abstract: The culture war is also a generational war.
lead_paragraph: A Nebraska state senator, Bruce Bostelman, last month warned of an alarming new variety of deviance making its way into the state’s schools. “It’s something called furries,” he said. Schoolchildren, Bostelman claimed, were identifying as cats or dogs. “They meow and they bark.” And educators, indulging them, “are wanting to put litter boxes in the schools for the children to use,” said Bostelman.

headline: The matchup between the big men will be one to watch.
abstract: Armando Bacot of North Carolina and David McCormack of Kansas have been two critical players for their teams, and will almost certainly have key roles in the championship game.
lead_paragraph: In a basketball world where elite guard play and sharpshooting is both cherished and prioritized, the outcome of this national championship game could be decided by the towering, physical players who make the most impact around the rim.

headline: The C.D.C. will undergo a comprehensive re-evaluation, the agency’s director said.
abstract: Dr. Rochelle Walensky said that the appraisal would be the first step in modernizing the agency, which has received a barrage of criticism over its handling of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will undergo a monthlong comprehensive review and evaluation, a first step in modernizing its systems and processes and transforming it for the future, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the agency’s director, announced on Monday.

headline: Important Markings on Treasure Maps
abstract: Bruce Haight thinks he can do better than we can.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The American Crossword Puzzle Tournament ran April 1 to 3, and I hope that those who attended had a fabulous time. Congratulations to everyone who competed. You can read more about the tournament in Alexis Benveniste’s tour of the A.C.P.T.

headline: Review: In ‘Take Me Out,’ Whose Team Are You On?
abstract: Richard Greenberg’s 2002 play about baseball and homophobia gets a fine revival starring Jesse Williams and Jesse Tyler Ferguson.
lead_paragraph: Not for nothing is Darren Lemming, the fictional center fielder of a team called the Empires, also at the center of “Take Me Out,” Richard Greenberg’s gay fantasia on the national pastime.

headline: Kansas, With the Magic of a Record Comeback, Snatches Title Over North Carolina
abstract: The Jayhawks rallied from a 16-point deficit to down the Tar Heels in a thrilling — and intensely physical — N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament championship game.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — As Kansas players glumly trudged off the Superdome floor at halftime on Monday night, down by 15 points, mired in foul trouble and dazed by a powder blue North Carolina hurricane, David McCormack was all smiles.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Responses to evidence of Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Images of dead Ukrainians in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders yesterday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy. The Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault. Follow the latest updates.

headline: Corrections: April 5, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the Minverva Virgo, a tanker loaded with Russian oil that was forced to change course after its buyer fell through, misstated the tanker’s country of registry. The ship is Greek-flagged, not Croatian-flagged.

headline: In a Battle of Bigs, Kansas’ David McCormack Delivers
abstract: McCormack scored 9 points in the second half, including the Jayhawks’ last two field goals, to help Kansas win the national championship.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — David McCormack and his Kansas teammates were trailing by 15 points at halftime of the national championship game, but he was smiling just the same.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Mocks Trump’s Endorsement of Sarah Palin
abstract: “Trump endorsing Palin is like paste eating endorsing glue sniffing,” Kimmel joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Woman Is Fatally Shot in Bronx Crossfire
abstract: Two groups of men had been arguing nearby with guns drawn when the 61-year-old woman was shot in the back, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 61-year-old woman was fatally shot on Monday night in the Bronx, caught in the crossfire after two groups of men began arguing nearby with guns drawn, the police said.

headline: Remy Martin Gets Finish Kansas Wanted After Rocky Season
abstract: Martin, a transfer from Arizona State, spent a significant part of the season with a knee injury. But he excelled come tournament time.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — After the final buzzer, as he made his way across the court, the Kansas transfer guard Remy Martin stared triumphantly at the Jayhawks fans who were pressing against the Superdome’s railings to get as close as they could to him.

headline: Word of the Day: decrepit
abstract: This word has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word decrepit has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 10 in “A Street Basketball Mecca Gets a Face-Lift” by Jonathan Abrams:

headline: Forgiveness
abstract: What are your beliefs about forgiveness?
lead_paragraph: A recent Times Opinion piece reflects on the meaning of Lent, a season in preparation for Easter when Christians often focus on sin and repentance.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Do Home Covid Tests Expire?
abstract: A quirk in the regulatory process for home tests can mean the real expiration date doesn’t always match what’s on the box.
lead_paragraph: Q: Do home Covid tests really expire? I ordered what I was allowed. Now I see they have expiration dates. Some have already expired. What to do? Keep and use, or throw them out?

headline: Learning the Right Way to Struggle
abstract: Several common educational strategies lean into the idea that, in the classroom, challenge is something to embrace.
lead_paragraph: When Hunter, 6, started first grade last autumn, he struggled to match letter sounds with the shape of letters on paper. He found writing letters hard and writing words even harder. “It felt bad,” he said recently.

headline: Up-Close Ukraine Atrocity Photographs Touch a Global Nerve
abstract: The apparent execution of Ukrainian civilians by retreating Russian forces, their bodies strewn in streets and yards, has focused attention on what constitutes crimes in war.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was the way the lifeless bodies, bloodied by bullets, and some with hands bound, had been left strewn about or shoveled into makeshift mass graves. Or the reality of seeing them up close in widely circulated photographs and videos.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘We Know the Pledge. Its Author, Maybe Not.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about how a 13-year-old might have been the real author of the Pledge of Allegiance. Then they will decide: Should students regularly recite the pledge in school?
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “We Know the Pledge. Its Author, Maybe Not.”  by Sam Roberts

headline: 200,000 Dead, One Lone Defendant as Darfur Trial Begins
abstract: A brutal campaign in western Sudan left the world aghast. Two decades later, the first and only Darfur war crimes trial opened for a man accused of leading the terrifying janjaweed militia.
lead_paragraph: They were known as the janjaweed, the armed militia men who came racing on camels and horses at dawn, moving fast to kill and rape, burning huts and leaving another village destroyed in the Darfur region of Sudan’s impoverished far west.

headline: With ‘Bittersweet,’ Can Susan Cain Replicate the Success of ‘Quiet’?
abstract: In her new book, the former lawyer and best-selling author turns her sights on a different word, one that certainly suits our times.
lead_paragraph: BITTERSWEETHow Sorrow and Longing Make Us WholeBy Susan Cain

headline: Love and Scandal, Buried for Years at an Elite Boarding School
abstract: In Jonathan Galassi’s “School Days,” a sexual harassment investigation uncovers long-buried memories of desire and abuse.
lead_paragraph: SCHOOL DAYSBy Jonathan Galassi

headline: ‘Memphis’ Is a Rhapsodic Hymn to Black Women
abstract: Tara M. Stringfellow’s new novel follows three matrilineal generations of African American women as they navigate decades of life in Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHISBy Tara M. Stringfellow

headline: When an Advice Columnist Tries to Fix Her Daughters’ Issues
abstract: In her novel “The Wise Women,” Gina Sorell asks whether the fate of the shoemaker’s children also applies to the offspring of professional problem solvers.
lead_paragraph: THE WISE WOMENBy Gina Sorell

headline: Is It Possible to Body-Block Our Loved Ones From Pain? Alas, No.
abstract: In her essay collection, “Bomb Shelter,” Mary Laura Philpott explores the pleasures, pitfalls and challenges of loving people who will leave.
lead_paragraph: BOMB SHELTERLove, Time and Other ExplosivesBy Mary Laura Philpott

headline: How Far Will Parents Go to Protect Their Sons?
abstract: In “The Lifeguards,” Amanda Eyre Ward imagines what happens when a group of teenagers discovers a dead body.
lead_paragraph: THE LIFEGUARDSBy Amanda Eyre Ward

headline: In ‘Atomic Anna,’ the Nuclear Disaster in Chernobyl Launches a Time-Traveling Adventure
abstract: Rachel Barenbaum’s latest novel is about Chernobyl, yes, but also about comic books, the power of math, finding one’s truth, and love, both biological and found.
lead_paragraph: ATOMIC ANNABy Rachel Barenbaum

headline: Sex Goddess, Celebrity and the Best Hope for Her Country
abstract: Miguel Syjuco’s novel “I Was the President’s Mistress!!” is a political satire told through interviews with a kaleidoscopic cast of characters.
lead_paragraph: I WAS THE PRESIDENT’S MISTRESS!!By Miguel Syjuco

headline: A Son Looks Back on Life With an Irascible and Beloved Mother
abstract: “Tasha” is Brian Morton’s memoir of his complicated relationship with the woman who raised him.
lead_paragraph: TASHAA Son’s MemoirBy Brian Morton

headline: How to Record Thunderstorms
abstract: Find a quiet place and be patient. Prioritize your safety.
lead_paragraph: “You have to be patient because you can’t control thunderstorms,” says Frank Bry, 59, a sound effects recordist who creates libraries of sounds that he sells to video-game, television, movie and white-noise production companies. Bry has four collections of thunderstorm recordings collected over 30 years from his home in rural northern Idaho. Know that the landscape around you will shape how thunder sounds. Bry lives near a large lake surrounded by mountain ranges, resulting in a volume and resonance he calls “bodacious.” Still, he covets the way thunder peals over the deserts of New Mexico. “I’ve heard pretty phenomenal thunder recordings from there,” Bry says. “The sound is crisp and dry.”

headline: The Magic of Tiny-Home Videos
abstract: They’re an antidote to a widespread fantasy of living without constraints.
lead_paragraph: I wouldn’t mind living in a bathroom if it was the one at Jessica Alba’s family home, which has more windows (five) and shower heads (two) than my airless apartment in Queens. And Rainn Wilson’s pet pigs, who sleep in their own casita with a Dutch door — aptly called the Pig Palace — have already realized my pastoral fantasy and desire for more breathing space.

headline: ‘I Didn’t Feel Like Going, but I’m Glad I Did’: My Motto of the Moment
abstract: The pandemic turned many of us into hermits. It’s time to go out again.
lead_paragraph: One recent snowy Saturday morning, I coaxed myself out of bed, into semiformal attire and through the door to synagogue. It was the latest in a series of attempts to force myself to, well, do stuff, the kind of stuff that takes me out of my one-bedroom apartment and into human society.

headline: Can I Utter a Racial Slur in My Classroom?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether a word should ever be off-limits.
lead_paragraph: I teach business law at a private university. One undergraduate course I teach is employment law, which covers discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. I believe it is important to explain the groundbreaking significance of this legislation to my students, so I delve into the de facto apartheid in the South, with its Jim Crow laws, the widespread discrimination against all types of minority groups and the resistance by many legislators, especially in the South, to the passage of this law.

headline: Lessons Learned From Michele McNally
abstract: Two photographers share how Michele McNally, who shepherded a new age of photography at The New York Times, touched their lives and work.
lead_paragraph: Michele McNally, who served as The New York Times’s director of photography and then as a top newsroom manager, died on Feb. 18 at age 66. When she started at the newspaper in 2004, her mission was clear: to enhance The Times’s photojournalism and to show the newsroom just how powerful visual storytelling could be. She achieved both. Under her leadership, The Times won six Pulitzer Prizes for photography. But she also left a mark on the lives of those she worked with. Here, two Times photographers, Josh Haner and João Silva, share how Ms. McNally shaped The Times and their careers.

headline: Shanghai Avoided Covid Disaster for Two Years. Now We’re Locked Down.
abstract: What it’s like to lock down after two years free of Covid worries.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The volunteers in full protective gear — called big whites here in China — have packed up and moved on for the day; the apartment complex where I live is once again sequestered in silence. From my 18th-floor window, I can see the koi ponds and gardens below, empty; the hedge maze, empty; the fountain, somehow turned off, its waters unmoving as though in allegiance, in reprieve.

headline: Putin’s War Has Started a Global Food Crisis
abstract: These are the countries that will be most affected by rising food prices.
lead_paragraph: The humanitarian disaster produced by Russia’s needless invasion of Ukraine shocks the conscience: 10 million Ukrainians displaced and innumerable Ukrainians killed. But because Ukraine and Russia are both major food exporters, the human toll will grow much larger, far from Ukraine’s borders.

headline: The Psychic Contortions of the Black Mogul-Entertainer
abstract: Black billionaires are rare, and a disproportionate number of them are performers. What does that much wealth do to your art?
lead_paragraph: The story is so good it hurts to hear. In an era of stupefying inequality, one of the most famous members of the upper class is a former drug dealer from a notorious public-housing project. He switched the product and rode CD sales to a new ZIP code. He went from nobody to somebody to a fixture in public consciousness who hangs out with a former president. If you’ve been rapping along with Jay-Z since “Reasonable Doubt,” or maybe even his feature on the early Jaz-O single “Hawaiian Sophie,” you’d be forgiven for seeing that star scream across the sky and thinking his song was right: There’s nothing you can’t do.

headline: Joe Manchin’s Brand Is Not Helping Democrats. But There’s a Republican Who Might.
abstract: It’s time to stop slathering so much attention on Joe Manchin.
lead_paragraph: They say the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result. This aphorism now leaps to mind every time I hear that the White House and congressional Democrats are trying yet again to win Senator Joe Manchin’s backing for this or that proposal.

headline: He Quietly Turned Bank of America Around. Can He Do More?
abstract: Brian Moynihan’s cautious approach as C.E.O. fostered a turnaround after the 2008 financial crisis, but some question whether it’s holding the bank back now.
lead_paragraph: When Brian T. Moynihan arrived at Davos in the middle of a Swiss snowstorm in January 2010, just weeks after taking on the top job at Bank of America, he didn’t expect to be hit by a blizzard indoors.

headline: A Viral Case Against Crypto, Explored
abstract: The video essayist Dan Olson explains the dangers lurking in the culture and ideology that surround digital currency.
lead_paragraph: The hype around cryptocurrencies has reached a fever pitch. There are Super Bowl ads for crypto companies featuring celebrities like Matt Damon and Larry David. The Staples Center in Los Angeles is now the Crypto.com Arena. And behind that hype is a distinct vision: a more decentralized economy where individuals have more autonomy over their finances, a grass-roots internet free of the not-so-invisible hand of Big Tech, and a cultural ecosystem where artists and musicians can fairly monetize their work. Back in October, I had the crypto investor Katie Haun on the show to make that case.

headline: Here’s How Slowly New York City Is Moving on Electric Vehicles
abstract: New York has ambitious electrification goals, but it lags behind other major cities in the United States significantly.
lead_paragraph: There are just 15 electric public buses on the streets of New York, out of a fleet of more than 5,900 buses. There is just a single electric police patrol car, a Tesla, and only one electric garbage truck.

headline: America’s Vanishing Kingdom
abstract: My father fled Vietnam only to spend the rest of his life in American factories helping shore up the same military that had set our family adrift.
lead_paragraph: My dad’s American dream was made of aluminum. Not that he would have put it that way. He did not talk much, and never about his dreams, but most days for nearly 25 years he headed off to a factory and turned aluminum and other metals into parts and a paycheck. He started at the Torrington Company, once one of the largest producers of metal bearings in North America and the biggest employer in Torrington, Conn., where we somehow found ourselves in 1980. Half a decade had passed since the fall of Saigon. My dad had been in and out of a re-education camp; we had been in and out of refugee camps. After we did stints in Thailand and Hong Kong, someone, somewhere sent us to Torrington. My father died there three decades later, having spent the rest of his life making industrial and military supplies in America’s gun belt.

headline: Amazon Tried One of the Oldest Tricks in the Book, and It Backfired
abstract: The successful organization of a warehouse in Staten Island offers a real glimmer of hope for the American working class.
lead_paragraph: Faced with an unexpectedly strong organizing campaign by workers at one of its Staten Island warehouses, Amazon initially turned to one of the oldest tricks in the anti-union playbook: a little bit of racism.

headline: Rags-to-Riches Stories Are Actually Kind of Disturbing
abstract: From Horatio Alger and E.L. James to T. Boone Pickens and Charles Koch, books by and about the ultrawealthy reveal some of our darkest American fantasies.
lead_paragraph: Americans retain their faith in the American dream even as our prospects of upward mobility dim. The lives of the billionaires whose ranks continue to swell give us cause to hope, or envy. We avidly follow the doings of the ultrarich, both the real (Kim Kardashian, Elon Musk) and the unreal (Bobby Axelrod, Logan Roy). This isn’t new: Americans have always loved fiction that reaffirms our fantasies about wealth and social mobility. Perhaps no cultural figure helped to keep the American dream on life support longer than Horatio Alger, the 19th-century novelist who wrote adventure stories for boys.

headline: In Defense of Melancholy
abstract: Susan Cain’s new book examines how sadness makes us whole.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered why we love sad songs, or get choked up at a “Thank you, Mom” Olympics commercial? Questions like these were the impetus for Susan Cain’s new book, “Bittersweet: How Sorrow and Longing Make Us Whole.”

headline: The U.S. Economy Is Booming. So Why Are Economists Worrying About a Recession?
abstract: There is little sign that a recession is imminent. But sky-high demand and supply shortages are testing the economy’s limits.
lead_paragraph: Employers are adding hundreds of thousands of jobs a month, and would hire even more people if they could find them. Consumers are spending, businesses are investing, and wages are rising at their fastest pace in decades.

headline: In Europe, It’s Planes vs. Trains. For Many Travelers, Rail Is the Way to Go.
abstract: Amid concerns about climate change, Europe is investing heavily in trains. The idea is to make rail more appealing, especially as an alternative to short-haul flights.
lead_paragraph: Train travel in Europe is on the upswing, thanks to growing interest from travelers, a renaissance in sleeper trains, and new investments in high-speed rail lines across the continent. But to see major growth in passenger traffic — which is one of the goals of the European Green Deal — the continent’s railways will have to overcome a number of challenges, including booking difficulties and competition with short-haul flights, which remain the cheaper option on many multicountry routes.

headline: Should Libraries Get Rid of Late Fees?
abstract: Public libraries in New York recently decided not to fine overdue books. Should all libraries do the same?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever held onto a library book past its due date? If so, did you pay a fine? Have fines made you more hesitant to use the library?

headline: ‘Russia Is Half of Our Business.’ Or It Was.
abstract: European companies that relied on Russian customers are suffering collateral damage from the invasion of Ukraine and Western sanctions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The shoes, 600 pairs in all, lay untouched inside an Italian warehouse: magenta sandals, décolleté heels and gold ballerina flats, destined for Russian boutiques but stuck in a limbo of sanctions and economic upheaval from Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Forecasters Face Loss of Data as Weather Balloon Flights Are Cut
abstract: Disruptions to supplies of hydrogen and helium have led the National Weather Service to cancel routine launches at some sites.
lead_paragraph: The National Weather Service has cut back on weather balloon launches at some of its sites because of shortages of hydrogen and helium used to lift them, potentially affecting forecasts and weather and climate research.

headline: Can A.I.-Driven Voice Analysis Help Identify Mental Disorders?
abstract: Early tests have been promising, but issues involving bias, privacy and mistrust of “black box” algorithms are possible pitfalls.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a limited series on artificial intelligence’s potential to solve everyday problems.

headline: An E-Commerce Site for Ukrainian Fashion
abstract: Angel for Fashion hopes to bring Ukrainian designs to customers all over the world — except Russia.
lead_paragraph: Angel for Fashion is a new e-commerce platform that sells the wares of 30 Ukrainian designers. The styles it offers are eclectic: There are breezy dresses inspired by traditional Ukrainian designs from the Foberini label; cheekily glamorous looks from Frolov; and macabre leather offerings, like Kofta bags and Bob Basset masks and harnesses.

headline: Hotel Life Without the Hotel
abstract: The designer Olympia Le-Tan has created a home goods line with the kind of stuff you’d steal (or want to steal) from a hotel.
lead_paragraph: During the early days of the pandemic, the designer Olympia Le-Tan missed traveling. Or rather, she missed hotels.

headline: A Texas Home With a Brazilian Vibe
abstract: After living abroad for years, one Brazilian couple wanted a home that showed off their roots. So they built it themselves.
lead_paragraph: After living abroad for years, one Brazilian couple wanted a home that showed off their roots. So they built it themselves.

headline: In Houston, a Modernist Showplace With Some Brazilian Curves
abstract: After living abroad for years, one Brazilian couple wanted a home that showed off their roots. So they built it themselves.
lead_paragraph: Angelica and Gustavo Nechar moved many times in Brazil, where they were born and raised, and in France, where their careers flourished and they owned a Haussmann-style apartment in the 17th Arrondissement of Paris. But it wasn’t until Mr. Nechar’s work as a human-resources executive brought the couple to Houston in 2013 that they realized all of their previous homes had lacked one enticing thing: a design conceived just for them.

headline: A Battle Over Banning Gas and Oil Hookups in New Buildings
abstract: As the state struggles to enact a budget, the question of how to cut emissions from homes, offices, factories and shops rears its head.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll explore a brewing battle over Gov. Kathy Hochul’s proposal to ban gas and oil hookups in new buildings. And we’ll find out why New York City’s switch to electric vehicles from gas-burning ones is off to a sluggish start.

headline: Ohio Woman Convicted of Murder in 1993 Death of Newborn
abstract: Genealogical research helped lead police to the baby’s identity nearly three decades later.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio woman was convicted on Monday of murder in the 1993 death of her newborn baby, whom the authorities said she put in a garbage bag and dumped in the state’s northern woods.

headline: How the War in Ukraine is Creating a Global Food Crisis
abstract: Russia’s invasion has severely disrupted how the world feeds itself.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and Russia are enormous producers of wheat, corn, barley, sunflower oil and fertilizer. One study calculated that the two countries accounted for 12 percent of the world’s calories.

headline: Weapons and Sanctions
abstract: How can the world respond to Russian atrocities?
lead_paragraph: Civilians lay dead in the middle of the street. Others lay by the side of the road, next to or underneath their bicycles. Often, the victims had been shot in the head. Some of them had their hands tied.

headline: ‘Tony Hawk: Until the Wheels Fall Off’ Review: Shred Until Shredded
abstract: This new documentary about the pro skateboarder Tony Hawk explores his compulsion to continue skating at all costs.
lead_paragraph: The professional skateboarder Tony Hawk is revered for his indefatigability and inventiveness: He’s originated over 100 skateboard tricks, according to “Tony Hawk: Until the Wheels Fall Off,” a new documentary about his bumpy rise to fame. In interview footage in this movie, directed by Sam Jones, Hawk also seems an amiable enough fellow.

headline: How Do You Supplant a ‘Walking Statue’? Cockiness Helps.
abstract: With no shortage of confidence, Walker Buehler is taking the reins from Clayton Kershaw as the Dodgers’ ace and opening day starter. Kershaw couldn’t be happier.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The October air sizzled with excitement and suffocated with 103-degree game-time heat when Clayton Kershaw wound up and fired a heater of his own, a first-pitch fastball to Houston’s George Springer, to start Game 1 of the now intensely controversial 2017 World Series.

headline: Severe Weather in the South: Here’s What to Know
abstract: Five tornadoes touched down in Mississippi, a man was killed in his Texas home by a falling tree and more wild weather is in store for the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Five tornadoes touched down in Mississippi and at least one tornado struck in South Carolina on Tuesday as meteorologists and emergency officials braced for another round of unsettling storms in parts of the South on Wednesday, following a recent pattern of unpredictable weather in the region.

headline: What are war crimes, and how are they prosecuted?
abstract: World leaders have vowed to hold President Vladimir V. Putin responsible for any atrocities by Russian forces. Past experience shows such cases take years to build and prosecute.
lead_paragraph: World leaders have vowed to hold President Vladimir V. Putin responsible for war crimes as evidence mounts that Russian forces killed civilians in Ukraine.

headline: Breaking Up With Russia
abstract: Companies are feeling the effects of a sudden shift away from the country, as world leaders threaten tougher sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Calls for companies to cut ties with Russia have taken on a new urgency, as world leaders push for even tougher sanctions in response to the horror of images of scores of dead civilians in parts of Ukraine recently occupied by Russian forces. The next steps could include a ban on Russian coal exports and further restrictions on Russia’s ability to access foreign currency.

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Grammys, N.C.A.A. Champions, Russian Atrocities
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Why Germany Can’t Just Pull the Plug on Russian Energy
abstract: Under increasing pressure to sever the country’s reliance on Russian energy, German officials must contend with deeply rooted economic ties.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Russia supplied more than half of the natural gas and about a third of all the oil that Germany burned to heat homes, power factories and fuel cars, buses and trucks. Roughly half of Germany’s coal imports, which are essential to its steel manufacturing, came from Russia.

headline: Primate Societies Are Surprisingly Complex. So Are Their Gender Roles.
abstract: Frans de Waal’s “Different” is a fascinating study of gender among monkeys and apes, but its account of human behavior is less satisfying.
lead_paragraph: This year marks the 40th anniversary of “Chimpanzee Politics,” a book that forced us to look at our simian cousins in a new light. The author, a Dutch primatologist named Frans de Waal, offered an unprecedented look at the social world of chimpanzees. Their lives are crammed with alliances, betrayals, and Machiavellian maneuvers. “Chimpanzee Politics” was also the debut of a gifted writer. De Waal turned what might have been a dry monograph into something that read more like a character-packed novel.

headline: Can California Really Push Back Against Red States?
abstract: As conservative states move to enact far-right legislative agendas, California leaders say they’re spearheading the resistance.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing we know about California’s officials, it’s that they love to declare that California is a leader in everything — whether it’s tackling climate change or transforming the world through technology.

headline: Elon Musk Joins Twitter’s Board, Pitching Ideas Big and Small
abstract: Free speech, open-source algorithms — and an edit button: The world’s richest person will soon help steer the social media platform where he has a huge following.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

headline: A Lover’s Impact on David Wojnarowicz, for All to See
abstract: A show at PPOW gallery explores the artist and author’s first significant relationship, with Jean Pierre Delage, which liberated him emotionally and changed him artistically.
lead_paragraph: During an eight-month visit to Paris when he was 24, David Wojnarowicz embarked on his first serious love affair and began to take himself seriously as a visual artist. The full import of these changes became evident after his return to New York in June 1979, once he uncorked a stream of fervent letters to his lover, Jean Pierre Delage, and included drawings, photographs and other art work.

headline: Louis Head Has Options (Just Not as Many)
abstract: Head was optioned to the minors 12 times by Tampa Bay in 2021, setting a record and inspiring a new rule. Now in Miami, he just might stick around.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Baseball is a game of failure, they say, but it is all relative for Louis Head. A little more than a year ago, before he became The Man Of Many Options with a saga that inspired a rule change in Major League Baseball, Head was selling solar panels, door to door, in Arizona.

headline: Ke Huy Quan: From Short Round to Romantic Lead in Just Four Long Decades
abstract: A child star in the 1980s, he hit a dry patch and turned to stunt work in the 2000s. Now he has returned to acting in a part that blends his action and drama chops.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1980s, Ke Huy Quan was in two of the decade’s biggest movies, playing Harrison Ford’s orphaned sidekick, Short Round, in “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,” and Data, a tech-obsessed inventor of various bully-beating devices, in the comedy “The Goonies.”

headline: Roland White, a Shaper of Bluegrass and Country-Rock, Dies at 83
abstract: A mandolin player and singer, he made his mark with the Country Boys (later renamed the Kentucky Colonels), and his influence extended into the rock of the ’60s.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Roland White, a mandolin player and singer who helped shape major developments in bluegrass and country-rock over a seven-decade career, died here on Friday. He was 83.

headline: The 2022 Grammys: Let’s Discuss
abstract: What are the awards at this point, and who benefits from them?
lead_paragraph: What exactly are the Grammys, at this point? A ceremony that honors the best in popular music? Sometimes, but not often. A concert that explores the connections between generations of styles and songs? On a good day, maybe. A party thrown by the stars and behind-the-scenes movers of yesteryear that young stars aren’t quite sure if they want to be invited to, or embraced by? Yes, that’s it.

headline: The U.N. Security Council meets as Ukraine accuses Russia of atrocities.
abstract: Mr. Zelensky was expected to make the case that Russian forces have committed war crimes, as evidence emerges of civilian killings in the suburbs of Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is set to give one of his most high-profile speeches since the war began when he addresses the United Nations Security Council by video-link on Tuesday.

headline: He Worked for Warhol, but That’s Just Part of the Story
abstract: Vito Giallo, 91, looks back at a life full of treasures.
lead_paragraph: By the time the body of the stone dealer was discovered in his Upper West Side apartment, it had been decomposing for several weeks. The summer of 1969 was a scorcher, and the smell was so repellent that city officials ordered the building’s superintendent, Stanley, to dispose of everything in the unit. Stanley thought he might make some money off the man’s antique furniture, so he called Wally Gibbs, an antiques dealer, who called his friend and peer Vito Giallo for an appraisal.

headline: For Macron, France’s Troubled Industries Hit Home
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron vowed an economic revival, but as he seeks re-election, a Potemkin factory in the town where he was raised shows just how hard that can be.
