lead_paragraph: Two years after the coronavirus became the focus of all of my coverage as a science reporter for The Times (and all of my thoughts every waking hour), it happened: I tested positive for the virus.

headline: Facial Recognition Goes to War
abstract: Services that put a name to a face, including Clearview AI, are being used to identify Russian soldiers, living or dead, and to verify that travelers in Ukraine are who they claim.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after Russia invaded Ukraine and images of the devastation wrought there flooded the news, Hoan Ton-That, the chief executive of the facial recognition company Clearview AI, began thinking about how he could get involved.

headline: I’m a Conservative Professor Who Opposed Safe Spaces. I Was Wrong.
abstract: I often have to ask my students to keep quiet — all in the name of open and free expression.
lead_paragraph: Like other conservative professors who are advocates of free speech on campus, I once opposed efforts to create a classroom climate in which students are protected from speech they find emotionally upsetting, ranging from “microaggressions” to political perspectives that diverge from current liberal orthodoxy. Efforts to create these “safe spaces” seemed, to me, to infantilize students by insulating them from speech they found the least bit upsetting. After all, an unquestioned objective of a liberal education, I supposed, was to make students uncomfortable. Now I think that while we certainly shouldn’t be preoccupied with policing microaggressions or silencing contrarian viewpoints, we need to take the comfort of students far more seriously.

headline: Straight People Need Better Rules for Sex
abstract: What if consent isn’t enough?
lead_paragraph: If you talk to young people about sex, you may sense an unsettling malaise.

headline: Homeland Security Watchdog Omitted Damaging Findings From Reports
abstract: The findings were removed from inspector general investigations of domestic violence and sexual misconduct committed by officers in the department’s law enforcement agencies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general and his top aides directed staff members to remove damaging findings from investigative reports on domestic violence and sexual misconduct by officers in the department’s law enforcement agencies, according to documents obtained by The New York Times and two government officials familiar with the inquiries.

headline: How to Get a Free Covid Test in New York City
abstract: Officials have vowed to keep tests at city-run sites free, but delays in Congress are leading a number of other providers to begin charging.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials are working to bolster the city’s testing infrastructure as coronavirus cases rise — largely fueled by a highly contagious subvariant of the virus — but an election-year dispute in Washington, D.C., means some New Yorkers may have to pay to get tested.

headline: For the New Census Bureau Director, the Challenge of the Decade
abstract: Robert L. Santos, a career statistician, heads an agency in recovery from a tumultuous 2020 census. In an interview, he talks about making the 2030 count better.
lead_paragraph: The new director of the Census Bureau, Robert L. Santos, has his work cut out for him. He took office in January on the heels of a 2020 census hobbled by a pandemic, natural disasters and political interference by the Trump administration.

headline: How Elon Musk’s ‘Soft Power’ Might Shape Twitter’s Future
abstract: Casey Newton and Kara Swisher discuss Twitter’s recent shake-up.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk promoted himself from avid Twitter user to major stakeholder on Monday. Musk, the head of Tesla and SpaceX, who has over 80 million followers on the platform, now also owns a 9.2 percent stake in Twitter, making him the company’s largest shareholder. And by the time the company announced his appointment to the board on Tuesday, the internet was already speculating about the kinds of changes that Musk could influence. “He can make recommendations at the board meetings, but what he really has is soft power,” the tech reporter Casey Newton tells Kara Swisher.

headline: Ahead of His Masters Return, Tiger Woods Starts to Get Serious
abstract: Woods played nine holes with his favorite practice partners on Wednesday. But one noticed a change in the five-time champion’s demeanor.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Tiger Woods’s return to the Masters

headline: ‘Abbott Elementary’ Is Gifted and Talented
abstract: When it comes to the dynamics of public school in 2022, the season’s best new network comedy has done its homework.
lead_paragraph: If you follow local news or morning shows or social media, you’ve seen the inspirational videos. A dedicated teacher gets a surprise donation of back-to-school items, or P.P.E., or shoes. An educator asks for school supplies in lieu of flowers at her funeral. A school staffer pays out of pocket to make sure students have warm clothing or even food. It’s heartwarming, isn’t it?

headline: A Novelist Revisits Her ‘Haunted’ Childhood Home
abstract: In her fifth book, Samantha Hunt describes finding a manuscript left behind by her late father in the family’s 18th-century house.
lead_paragraph: A few months before her novel “Mr. Splitfoot” was published in 2016, Samantha Hunt had to solicit marketing blurbs from other authors.

headline: How Many Billionaires Are There, Anyway?
abstract: Forbes thinks there are 735 of them in America. Another count finds 927. Whatever the answer, the mystery is revealing — and the number is growing rapidly.
lead_paragraph: In 1981, Malcolm Forbes, the eccentric and fabulously wealthy magazine publisher, came to his editors with a request: Could they pull together a special issue about the 400 richest Americans? The idea was inspired by Caroline Schermerhorn Astor, the doyenne of Gilded Age New York, who regularly hosted the city’s high society in her Fifth Avenue ballroom, which was said to fit about 400 people. It’s quite possible Forbes saw something of himself in Astor. This was a different era of magazine publishing; Forbes — who wound up making the cut on his own list — lived like a sultan. He entertained celebrities and politicians on a 126-foot yacht called the Highlander. By the end of his run he owned a chateau in Normandy, 12 Fabergé eggs and a collection of hot-air balloons in fantastical designs — one shaped like the Sphinx, one like a bust of Beethoven, one like a Fabergé egg, one like the chateau in Normandy and, of course, one in the image of a sultan, about as tall as his yacht was long.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic gave the composer Andy Akiho some extra time to complete “Seven Pillars,” an evening-length work for the virtuosos in Sandbox Percussion. He collaborated with the quartet intimately over that extended period, before releasing a recording of the opus last year. The payoff for all that effort was a percussive essay rich in melody as well as drive. “Seven Pillars” finally gets its New York premiere at the Baryshnikov Arts Center at 8 p.m. on Thursday and Friday. Tickets are $25.

headline: U.T. Austin Acquires Archives That Give Insight Into the 1960s
abstract: The papers of Richard Goodwin, a speechwriter to John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, and his wife Doris Kearns Goodwin, a presidential historian, shed light on decision-making at crucial moments in American history.
lead_paragraph: Doris Kearns was an assistant professor of history at Harvard University in 1972, teaching a class on the American presidency and starting the book that would mark the start of her extraordinary career as a popular historian, “Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream,” when Richard N. Goodwin walked into her office.

headline: Shanghai Seethes in Covid Lockdown, Posing Test to China’s Leadership
abstract: Residents in Shanghai, China’s most populous and cosmopolitan city, have responded to the government’s pursuit of zero Covid with a rare outpouring of criticism.
lead_paragraph: Parents have organized petitions, imploring the government not to separate children infected with the coronavirus from their families. Patients have demanded to speak with higher-ups about shoddy conditions at isolation facilities. Residents have confronted officials over containment policies that they see as unfair or inhumane, then shared recordings of those arguments online.

headline: These Birds Aren’t Lost. They’re Adapting.
abstract: Bird-watchers love to see vagrants, or birds that have traveled far outside their range. But scientists say they have a lot to teach us in a world facing ecological change.
lead_paragraph: From what we can tell, the Steller’s sea eagle trekking across North America does not appear homesick.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: March 2022
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Here is the March edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.

headline: Hyundai’s Ioniq 5 Nods to Past While Pushing Toward E.V. Future
abstract: For now, supply may be constrained, but Hyundai is putting a big bet on building electrics for the American market.
lead_paragraph: One look at the charming Hyundai Ioniq 5 reliably spawns another. A weeklong drive suggests that Hyundai Motor may be a real dark horse in electric cars — if it can find enough batteries and factory capacity to put E.V.s in showrooms from coast to coast.

headline: Are 1,818 Airbnbs Too Many in Joshua Tree?
abstract: A short-term rental gold rush is fueling concern for the area’s signature trees and debates about whether the nature of life in the desert of southeastern California is changing forever.
lead_paragraph: For the last six years, the 10-acre Desert Yacht Club — a 1946 Chris Craft cruiser anchored on a rocky hilltop amid retro trailers near Joshua Tree, Calif. — has been Alessandro Giuliano’s primary source of inspiration, social interaction and income. The off-the-grid glamping site has appeared in the Italian version of Rolling Stone, on lists of epic luxury camping experiences and in films. Mr. Giuliano designed everything, including his walk-the-plank setup, which encourages his guests to wobble two feet above actual sharks’ teeth to facilitate their imaginations.

headline: ‘We Belong in These Spaces’: Jackson’s Successors Reflect on Her Nomination
abstract: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, who was confirmed to the Supreme Court on Thursday, will be the first Black woman to serve as a justice. Here’s what that means to Black women at her alma mater.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — To many of the women who belong to the Harvard Black Law Students Association, the nomination of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court has felt deeply personal.

headline: Covid Cases Are Rising Again. How Cautious Should We Be?
abstract: A new subvariant is driving an uptick, but New Yorkers differ over how to respond to the latest rise.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at two sets of statistics — on Covid-19 and crime — that are harder to parse than they may appear. The virus is surging again in parts of New York City, but so far is mainly hitting younger people. And new data shows that shootings have increased this year, yet homicides have dropped.

headline: Finland seizes artwork shipments suspected of violating E.U. sanctions on Russia.
abstract: The art was being transported back to Russia after being featured in exhibitions in Italy and Japan, the Finnish customs service said.
lead_paragraph: The Finnish customs authorities have seized three shipments containing works of art being transported back to Russia from exhibitions in Italy and Japan, because they were suspected of being subject to European Union sanctions imposed on Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, the Finnish customs service said on Wednesday.

headline: Film at 11: How a Minnesota Station Found Old Footage of a Very Young Prince
abstract: The 1970 clip is a “miraculous” find, a former editor at the local CBS station said. It shows an interview with Prince, 11, commenting on a teachers’ strike in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Liddy, a production manager at WCCO-TV, a CBS station in Minnesota, was watching footage of a 1970 teachers’ strike in Minneapolis in late February when he saw a familiar face.

headline: A Covid Mystery in Africa
abstract: Why coronavirus case and death rates have been so low in much of sub-Saharan Africa compared with the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: As countries have struggled with disease and death throughout the coronavirus pandemic, one part of the world seems to have been mostly spared: central and western Africa.

headline: Women Dominate Shortlist for International Booker Prize
abstract: Novels by Olga Tokarczuk, Mieko Kawakami and Claudia Piñeiro are in the running for the prestigious award for translated fiction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Olga Tokarczuk, the Nobel Prize-winning Polish novelist, is among five female writers shortlisted for this year’s International Booker Prize, arguably the world’s most important award for fiction translated into English.

headline: Yemeni Leader Hands Power to New Body as His Saudi Backers Seek to End War
abstract: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi abdicated days after a two-month cease-fire took effect, signs that his Saudi allies may be looking for a path out of the bloodshed.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Yemen’s exiled president stepped down on Thursday and passed power to a presidential council, a sweeping reshuffle supported by his backers in Saudi Arabia aimed at jump-starting efforts to end the seven-year war that has roiled the Arabian Peninsula.

headline: The G.O.P.’s ‘Putin Wing’
abstract: In Republicans’ own words.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump turned Vladimir Putin into a popular figure among a significant segment of Republican voters. As a candidate, president and ex-president, Trump has repeatedly praised Putin, calling him “strong,” “savvy” and “genius.” Trump has also echoed Putin’s ideology, by harshly criticizing NATO.

headline: What You Need to Know About France’s Presidential Election
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron will face Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader, in the runoff on Sunday. The outcome will be crucial for France and reverberate globally.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the French runoff election between Macron and Le Pen.

headline: Shanghai residents in lockdown criticize China’s ‘zero Covid’ strategy.
abstract: There has been an outpouring of public dissatisfaction rarely seen in China since the chaotic early days of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus races through Shanghai, in the city’s worst outbreak since the pandemic began, the authorities have deployed their usual hard-nosed playbook to try and stamp out transmission. What has been different is the response: an outpouring of public dissatisfaction rarely seen in China since the chaotic early days of the pandemic, in Wuhan.

headline: Vocabulary in Context: Women Off-Road
abstract: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article "Women Drive Off-Road in Saudi Desert for Fun and Bragging Rights."
lead_paragraph: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article "Women Drive Off-Road in Saudi Desert for Fun and Bragging Rights."

headline: ‘The Girl and the Spider’ Review: Where Did I Put That Thing?
abstract: The twin brothers Ramon and Silvan Zürcher have created a wonderfully discombobulating feature about an apartment move.
lead_paragraph: With “The Girl and the Spider,” the Swiss filmmakers Ramon and Silvan Zürcher, the identical twins behind the exceptional debut “The Strange Little Cat,” have made their second feature in a row that invites viewers to get lost in an apartment — or in this case, more than one.

headline: ‘La Mami’ Review: Tough Love
abstract: This documentary about the den mother of dancers at a Mexico City cabaret is vérité at its best.
lead_paragraph: At the Cabaret Barba Azul, women get paid to dance and drink with the male patrons, a custom that dates back to the 1930s. In the beautifully-rendered documentary “La Mami,” the director and cinematographer Laura Herrero Garvín (“The Swirl”) immerses us in the behind-the-scenes world of these dancers through the lens of their den mother: Doña Olga. Like them, Doña Olga also used to spend her nights dancing for pesos, but after 45 years working various jobs at the cabaret to support her five children, she has settled into her post in the club’s dressing room-bathroom combo. There she regulates the distribution of toilet paper with an iron fist, and doles out a charming mix of motherly nurturing and fierce rebukes. Like this bit of poetry: “Men are only good for two things: for nothing, and for money.”

headline: Review: The Director Lloyd Kaufman Returns With a Shakespeare Spoof
abstract: Kaufman, the king of lowbrow, is back with this lusty parody.
lead_paragraph: Should you be among those lamenting the lack of whale feces and exploding genitalia coming to a theater near you, not to worry: Troma Entertainment hears your pain. And with “#ShakespearesShitstorm” — billed, I kid you not, as a musical adaptation of “The Tempest” — the durable director Lloyd Kaufman lobs multiple notions at the screen to see what sticks. In a movie held together with this many slimy fluids, pretty much everything does.

headline: ‘Return to Space’ Review: Eyes on the Skies
abstract: Platitudes prevail in this overlong documentary about the partnership between NASA and SpaceX.
lead_paragraph: Glowing with grandiose pronouncements and uplifting sentiment, “Return to Space,” a draggy documentary about America’s first manned spaceflight since 2011, could be easily repurposed as promotional material for Elon Musk’s SpaceX.

headline: ‘As They Made Us’ Review: If the Apple Falls, Who Retrieves It?
abstract: A dutiful daughter navigates the consequences of her parents’ failings in Mayim Bialik’s engagingly compassionate directorial debut.
lead_paragraph: For her directorial debut, Mayim Bialik — the neuroscientist, sitcom star, and finalist for the “Jeopardy!” host gig — hewed to what she knew: reckoning with the legacy of volatile parents.

headline: ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 2’ Review: Keep Up! Bada-Brrring!
abstract: Jim Carrey’s reprised role as a villainous weirdo helps this fast-paced, family-friendly video-game-movie sequel maintain a refreshing silliness.
lead_paragraph: Introduced by Sega at the start of the 1990s, the zippy blue hairball Sonic the Hedgehog is now officially over the hill and picking up speed onscreen. “Sonic the Hedgehog 2” is a fast-paced romp that’s silly, filled with quips and unabashedly for children — which is refreshing, coming at a time when so many other children’s franchises have succumbed to Sturm und Drang.

headline: ‘Aline’ Review: Tale as Odd as Time
abstract: Celine Dion’s life story gets an unconventional telling from the French filmmaker Valérie Lemercier in this creative but flawed biopic.
lead_paragraph: The best compliment one can give the French serio-comic filmmaker Valérie Lemercier’s “Aline,” a biopic of Celine Dion in which Lemercier plays a fictionalized version of the pop star from infancy through widowhood, is that it evokes the disorientation of discovering the singer as she was on her first album: a 13-year-old with snaggleteeth. The movie’s passion is incredible — but, boy, is it embodied in something awkward.

headline: ‘Metal Lords’ Review: Shred of the Class
abstract: Teenage boys battling angst and bullies form a heavy metal band in this genuine Netflix movie.
lead_paragraph: In the charming coming-of-age movie “Metal Lords,” misfit teenage musicians form a band. Not just any band — a heavy metal band. These are kids who lag in gym class and get shoved into lockers, but in the privacy of their makeshift practice space, they sure know how to solo, riff and headbang.

headline: ‘All the Old Knives’ Review: Shooting Daggers Across the Table
abstract: In this thriller, Thandiwe Newton and Chris Pine work to out-smolder and outwit each other as old C.I.A. colleagues and former lovers catching up over dinner.
lead_paragraph: Espionage thrillers usually traffic in globe-trotting mayhem, so in “All the Old Knives,” it’s refreshing to find one whose main ingredients are two stars out-smoldering each other over dinner.

headline: ‘¡Viva Maestro!’ Review: A Documentary in Need of a Conductor
abstract: A wunderkind conductor attempts to keep young Venezuelan musicians working despite political strife at home in this film from Ted Braun.
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel earned his reputation as a wunderkind by leading prestigious symphonic groups like the Los Angeles Philharmonic. In front of the orchestras he leads, Dudamel is a live wire, his signature curls bouncing with each wave of the wand. And when the music stops, Dudamel turns his passion for his profession toward advocacy, supporting programs that help young Venezuelan musicians develop professionally.

headline: ‘a-ha: The Movie’ Review: The Creative Purgatory of the ‘Take on Me’ Trio
abstract: The documentary about the Norwegian synth-pop band plays like a slavish yet intermittently lucid Wikipedia entry.
lead_paragraph: A tragicomic air clings to bands who light up the sky like a firework and fade away. The Norwegian subjects of “a-ha: The Movie” are best known for their 1985 hit “Take on Me,” but, despite successful shows, seem mired in creative purgatory. Thomas Robsahm and Aslaug Holm’s documentary trawls the band’s career with musings from its three members — Paul Waaktaar-Savoy, Magne Furuholmen and the Ken Dollesque lead singer Morten Harket — and key associates.

headline: Is Julio Rodríguez the Future of Baseball? He Has No Doubt.
abstract: No goal is too ambitious for Rodríguez, a magnetic outfielder who plans to end the Seattle Mariners’ postseason drought.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — Challenge Julio Rodríguez at your own risk. During a spring training workout here over two weeks ago, Jerry Dipoto, the Seattle Mariners president of baseball operations, did just that with the team’s 21-year-old outfield prospect.

headline: ‘The Daily’ explores a Covid mystery in Africa.
abstract: As countries have struggled with disease and death throughout the coronavirus pandemic, one part of the world seems to have been mostly spared: central and western Africa. South Africa was deeply affected by waves of the coronavirus, as were countries in East Africa like Kenya and Uganda. But nations in the center and west of the continent appear to have been largely spared. Sierra Leone, for example, has reported a total of 7,700 cases and 125 deaths, according to the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University.
lead_paragraph: As countries have struggled with disease and death throughout the coronavirus pandemic, one part of the world seems to have been mostly spared: central and western Africa. South Africa was deeply affected by waves of the coronavirus, as were countries in East Africa like Kenya and Uganda. But nations in the center and west of the continent appear to have been largely spared. Sierra Leone, for example, has reported a total of 7,700 cases and 125 deaths, according to the Center for Systems Science and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University.

headline: Black women at Judge Jackson’s alma mater are celebrating this moment.
abstract: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, after hours of intense questioning during her confirmation hearing last month, delivered a message to young people who hoped to follow her path: “I want them to know that they can do and be anything.”
lead_paragraph: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, after hours of intense questioning during her confirmation hearing last month, delivered a message to young people who hoped to follow her path: “I want them to know that they can do and be anything.”

headline: Pro-Russian hackers have ramped up the use of Facebook in an information war, its parent company says.
abstract: Hackers in Russia and Belarus are using Meta’s platform for cyberespionage and disinformation campaigns, executives said.
lead_paragraph: Hackers affiliated with the governments of Russia and Belarus have turned their attention to Ukraine since the Russian invasion began in February, attempting to use Facebook for cyberespionage and disinformation campaigns, the social network’s parent company, Meta, said on Thursday.

headline: At a Contemporary Drama Festival, Staging the Frighteningly Real
abstract: At Berlin’s FIND festival of new international drama, several productions use transcripts to explore questions of state power and identity.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Outside a small stage at the Schaubühne theater here on Tuesday evening, a sign cautioned that the Chilean production “Oasis de la Impunidad” (“Oasis of Impunity”) featured strobe lights and onstage nudity.

headline: Shell says it expects to lose up to $5 billion for pulling out of Russia.
abstract: In an update to investors, the oil company projected a huge financial hit from its exposure to Russia.
lead_paragraph: The British oil giant Shell said on Thursday that its decision to pull out of its projects in Russia would slash its quarterly profit by $4 billion to $5 billion.

headline: A Surge in Ukrainian Refugees at California’s Southern Border
abstract: A growing number of Ukrainians are seeking entry into California from Tijuana.
lead_paragraph: A new chapter in the Ukrainian refugee crisis is playing out along California’s southern border.

headline: At Harvard, a Confederate flag spurred Jackson to act.
abstract: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When a Confederate flag was hung from the window of a dormitory at Harvard University more than 30 years ago, members of the Black Students Association saw it as an attempt to tell them they did not belong there.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When a Confederate flag was hung from the window of a dormitory at Harvard University more than 30 years ago, members of the Black Students Association saw it as an attempt to tell them they did not belong there.

headline: How Guns Are Sold
abstract: Gun control advocates are petitioning the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the firearms industry’s marketing practices.
lead_paragraph: Gun control advocates are petitioning the Federal Trade Commission today to investigate and regulate the firearms industry as it has with tobacco, alleging that gun manufacturers use deceptive advertising practices.

headline: ‘Cow’ Review: Dairy Cogs in the Machine
abstract: This documentary from Andrea Arnold takes an immersive approach to capturing the plight of industrial dairy cows.
lead_paragraph: “Cow,” the first documentary feature by the British filmmaker Andrea Arnold, captures the plight of industrial dairy cows by zeroing in on the life and times of one, Luma, up till her unceremonious demise.

headline: My Girlfriend and I Can’t Get Married. Should We Break Up?
abstract: A reader, citing “cultural differences,” seeks permission to leave one woman for another.
lead_paragraph: My girlfriend and I have been together for 13 years. We’re in our late 30s. But we’ve only lived in the same city for two of those years. (We live on opposite coasts of the United States now.) Because of cultural differences, we cannot get married or disclose our relationship to family or friends. The problem: I recently met another woman I like. She likes me too, and I know we could easily get married. But I feel ashamed of my feelings for her. I haven’t cheated on my girlfriend, but I haven’t told either woman about the other. I’m wondering if I should break up with my girlfriend to make it easier for her to find someone new. Or will that cause more problems?

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ Sets Summer Return Off Broadway
abstract: A revival of the Tony-winning Cyndi Lauper-Harvey Fierstein collaboration will begin performances at Stage 42 in July.
lead_paragraph: The sex is back in the heel.

headline: In Miami Beach, a Vibrant Pair of Boutique Hotels
abstract: Plus: beauty tips from Sharon Alexie, striking sneakers for spring and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: The Artist as Healer
abstract: Guadalupe Maravilla’s sculptures at the Brooklyn Museum and MoMA explore the trauma caused by war, migration and family separation.
lead_paragraph: In his Brooklyn studio, the El Salvador-born artist Guadalupe Maravilla got ready to activate “Disease Thrower #0,” the latest in his acclaimed series of sculptures that deploy the powers of vibrational sound as a form of healing.

abstract: This week’s properties are in Chelsea, Brooklyn Heights and on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are in Chelsea, Brooklyn Heights and on the Upper East Side.

headline: Collins was first among the Republicans to back Jackson.
abstract: The senator from Maine lent support to the nominee when it was uncertain whether she would get any G.O.P. backing at all.
lead_paragraph: Senator Susan Collins of Maine, always a closely watched Republican during Supreme Court confirmation debates, found herself in the spotlight again as the first member of her party to declare that she would vote to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson.

headline: 9 Ways to Imagine Jeff Bezos’ Wealth
abstract: A fortune of $172 billion is almost impossible to fathom. For the magazine’s Money Issue, the artist Mona Chalabi came up with some extremely original comparisons.
lead_paragraph: A fortune of $172 billion is almost impossible to fathom. For the magazine’s Money Issue, the artist Mona Chalabi came up with some extremely original comparisons.

headline: How Many Square Feet Does a $1,500 Monthly Rent Get You?
abstract: Remote workers may consider a move to another city if they want to save on rent.
lead_paragraph: The national median rent for a one-bedroom apartment has climbed 12 percent over the past year, to a record high of $1,400 a month, according to Zumper’s March rent report. This has left renters facing a financial squeeze, especially as the desire for more space has become a priority amid the pandemic and the rise of remote work.

headline: Killer of Woman in London Park Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
abstract: The murder of a schoolteacher, Sabina Nessa, 28, added to a sense of outrage amid fears the authorities were failing to address violence against women.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sabina Nessa, a popular and admired schoolteacher living in southeast London, was running late to meet a friend at a local pub when she left her home and cut through a park on an evening last September.

headline: With three crossing party lines, Jackson’s nomination vote parallels Gorsuch’s.
abstract: Only three Democrats voted for Justice Neil M. Gorsuch in 2017, after Republicans had blocked President Barack Obama from filling a vacancy.
lead_paragraph: With three Republicans supporting her, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation parallels that of Justice Neil M. Gorsuch in terms of bipartisan support.

headline: Can a Brazilian Pop Star Crack the U.S. Market? Anitta Says Yes.
abstract: In the past decade, the singer has earned fame and the respect of some of Brazil’s most lauded musical elders. Now she’s taking aim at new audiences but hoping to hold on to her roots.
lead_paragraph: “Meiga e Abusada,” the 2013 song that first catapulted the Brazilian singer Anitta to fame, begins with a Lady Gaga sample and a cool assertion. “I get everything I want,” she sings in Portuguese. “But it was so easy to control you.”

headline: A Graffiti Master’s Final Mural
abstract: An influential artist from the Bronx died last week, just days before he had planned to bring together two crews to paint one last mural.
lead_paragraph: An influential artist from the Bronx died last week, just days before he had planned to bring together two crews to paint one last mural.

headline: ‘Evil Came’: The Toll of Russia’s Occupation in Kyiv’s Suburbs
abstract: Land mines, bullet-riddled cars and corpses lying in the street. Residents of Bucha, Borodianka and Hostomel describe the horrors left behind by Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: Land mines, bullet-riddled cars and corpses lying in the street. Residents of Bucha, Borodianka and Hostomel describe the horrors left behind by Russian forces.

headline: A Reinvented Marine Le Pen Threatens to Upend French Elections
abstract: The far-right presidential candidate has opened up about her personal life and tweaked her policies to gain sympathy and credibility among more mainstream voters.
lead_paragraph: STIRING-WENDEL, France — Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader making her third attempt to become president of France, already had the backing of voters who came to listen to her recently in Stiring-Wendel, a former coal-mining town struggling to reinvent itself.

headline: A spate of coronavirus cases among top officials has Washington feeling uneasy.
abstract: The Gridiron Club dinner, an annual black-tie roast between journalists and presidential administrations held over the weekend in Washington, quickly devolved from a swampy cross-pollination party into an event where a lot of boldface names appear to have caught the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Gridiron Club dinner, an annual black-tie roast between journalists and presidential administrations held over the weekend in Washington, quickly devolved from a swampy cross-pollination party into an event where a lot of boldface names appear to have caught the coronavirus.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Pandemic Stimulus
abstract: Stimulus bills approved by Congress beginning in 2020 unleashed the largest flood of federal money into the U.S. economy in recorded history. Where did that $5 trillion go?
lead_paragraph: These treemap graphs show how roughly $5 trillion of pandemic stimulus funding was allocated from March 2020 through Feb. 2022. The data was collected by the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, a Washington think tank. The data includes the amounts dispersed or specifically committed after being authorized by Congress. It does not include money that was approved by administrative or Federal Reserve action.

headline: ‘Big John,’ a High-Profile Triceratops, Locked Horns With Its Own Kind, Study Suggests
abstract: A team of Italian scientists describe what they believe is a gaping scar from one of these ancient battles on the neck frill of the Triceratops.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to dramatic museum displays, many of us can imagine a Triceratops wielding its horns and sprawling neck frill to ward off a hungry Tyrannosaurus rex. But some scientists believe that Triceratopses used their deadly headgear against each other, too. Like dueling elk brandishing their antlers, Triceratopses may have interlocked their horns to woo mates or vanquish rivals.

headline: What Is Putin Really After in Ukraine?
abstract: Readers discuss a Bret Stephens column about whether or not Vladimir Putin miscalculated. Also: The Amazon union vote; treatment for sex offenders.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Trisha Brown Masterpiece, ‘Reset’ on an Inclusive Troupe
abstract: Candoco, a British dance company that has disabled and non-disabled dancers, makes its New York debut with Brown’s “Set and Reset/Reset” at BAM.
lead_paragraph: Trisha Brown’s “Set and Reset,” one of postmodern dance's most treasured and durable works, thrillingly excavates the tension between freedom and form, spontaneity and detail.

headline: Hideki Matsuyama will try to defend his 2021 victory.
abstract: He was the Masters Tournament’s first Asian-born champion and the first Japanese man to win a major golf championship.
lead_paragraph: Hideki Matsuyama is back in Augusta, Ga., taking a shot at winning a second consecutive ceremonial green jacket.

headline: J.M.W. Turner: The Romantic Turns Reformist
abstract: Britain’s commander of the churning waves was also a painter of technology and industry. The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston shows how he reshaped an art form.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Driving rain, salty air; the waves are so loud you can hardly hear the wailing. The weather is dreadful even by English standards, and the harbor-dwellers have rushed down to the beach, anxious to alert a ship in distress. Their clothes are soaked, their hair is bedraggled; they gaze out on the warning flares, bright flecks bursting in air against a small patch of blue.

headline: Nancy Pelosi and other lawmakers test positive for the coronavirus.
abstract: The House speaker, 82, was asymptomatic, and had previously been vaccinated and boosted, a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California tested positive for the coronavirus, her office said on Thursday, the latest high-profile official to do so as the virus spreads through Washington.

headline: Congress Sends Legislation Suspending Normal Trade With Russia to Biden
abstract: The measure, along with another that bans the import of Russian energy, are the first stand-alone bills to be sent to President Biden to punish Moscow since Russia invaded Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress voted on Thursday to strip Moscow of its preferential trade status and to ban the import of Russian energy into the United States, sending the legislation to penalize Russia’s economy over the invasion of Ukraine to President Biden’s desk.

headline: One-Third of Americans Faced Extreme Weather in Recent Years, Survey Finds
abstract: Hurricanes and winter weather, such as snow, ice storms and blizzards, were the most common events cited, according to a Gallup poll.
lead_paragraph: One in three Americans say they have personally been affected by an extreme weather event in the last two years, according to a Gallup poll released on Wednesday, reflecting a period that included a paralyzing ice storm in Texas, one of the largest wildfires in California’s history and a powerful storm that killed dozens of people in the New York region.

headline: Mira Calix, Iconoclastic Composer and Artist, Is Dead at 52
abstract: Her work spanned albums, public art installations, music for Shakespeare plays and touring with Radiohead.
lead_paragraph: Mira Calix, a composer, producer and visual artist whose work encompassed electronic music, orchestral commissions, public art installations, theater scores, music videos and D.J. sets, died on March 25 at her home and music and art studio in Bedford, England. She was 52.

headline: U.N. members vote to suspend Russia from the body’s Rights Council.
abstract: The resolution received 93 votes in favor and 24 against, and 58 countries abstained. China and other countries had said before the vote that they would not support the measure.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations General Assembly vote on Thursday approved an American-led effort to suspend Russia from the 47-member Human Rights Council over the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Two Black Coaches Join Brian Flores’s Lawsuit Against the N.F.L.
abstract: Steve Wilks and Ray Horton added claims that the Arizona Cardinals and Tennessee Titans discriminated in their hiring practices, echoing Flores’s allegations that the league showed bias against Black coaches.
lead_paragraph: Two Black coaches have joined a lawsuit filed in February by Brian Flores, the former head coach of the Miami Dolphins who accused the N.F.L. and its 32 teams of discriminating against African Americans in their hiring practices.

headline: Britain bets on nuclear power in its plan to boost energy independence.
abstract: The government said it aimed to fulfill a quarter of the estimated electricity demand in Britain with nuclear power by 2050.
lead_paragraph: The British government revealed on Thursday its plan to increase the country’s energy independence as European nations try to quickly reduce energy imports from Russia over the war in Ukraine.

headline: Pakistan’s Supreme Court Blocks Imran Khan’s Move to Stay in Power
abstract: The prime minister will now face a no-confidence vote, which he had tried to avoid by dissolving Parliament, a move his opponents called a coup.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Supreme Court on Thursday overturned Prime Minister Imran Khan’s move to dissolve Parliament, setting the stage for a no-confidence vote widely expected to remove him from office and offering a major victory to opposition leaders, who said that Mr. Khan had attempted an “open coup.”

headline: Discovery announces new leaders for soon-to-be Warner Bros. Discovery.
abstract: David Zaslav, the chief executive of Discovery who will lead the new company, appointed many of his longtime lieutenants to key positions.
lead_paragraph: Discovery announced a new leadership structure Thursday for the soon-to-be Warner Bros. Discovery media company, setting the stage for the closing of the combined company, which could happen as soon as Friday.

headline: Methane Emissions Soared to a Record in 2021, Scientists Say
abstract: For the second year in a row, concentrations of the potent planet-warming gas jumped by the largest amount since measurements began four decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Levels of methane in the atmosphere increased last year by the largest amount since measurements began four decades ago, government scientists said on Thursday, adding to concerns about the planet-warming gas, which spews from oil and natural gas operations.

headline: Winslow Homer: Radical Impressionist
abstract: A show of masterworks at the Met snaps into sharp focus the great American artist’s contemporary relevance.
lead_paragraph: The wondrous exhibition “Winslow Homer: Crosscurrents” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art begins with two picture-window-size holes in the wall: A visitor peers into one opening and then, through it, the other. Together they add a thrilling air of unpredictability. They also “frame” a painting hanging on a third wall deeper in the show: a fraught canvas titled “The Gulf Stream” that many consider Homer’s greatest work. It depicts a muscular, barechested Black man who lies, propped up on his elbows looking grimly into the distance, on the deck of a fishing boat with a broken mast. The hurricane has passed and his craft tilts toward capsizing, as sharks circle in the bloodied waters.

headline: ‘Donbass’ Review: War in Ukraine, the Prequel
abstract: Sergei Loznitsa’s film, completed in 2018, presents an absurd, horrific tableau of cruelty and corruption.
lead_paragraph: Sergei Loznitsa’s “Donbass,” which opens in American theaters today, is not exactly a new film. It was an Oscar entry in 2019 after making its debut at the Cannes Film Festival the year before, and the events depicted onscreen — fictionalized recreations of things rumored to have really happened — take place a few years before that, in the wake of Russia’s 2014 invasion of Eastern Ukraine.

headline: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Crimes and mysteries anchor a number of our recommended titles this week, from the murder case at the heart of Aamina Ahmad’s debut novel, “The Return of Faraz Ali,” to the search for a missing student in Sara Novic’s novel “True Biz,” set at a school for the deaf. Jane Pek offers an unconventional detective story in her debut novel, “The Verifiers.” And in “Scoundrel,” the Book Review’s crime columnist, Sarah Weinman, tells the true story of a convicted killer freed from prison in the 1960s after he became a cause célèbre on the right.

headline: How to Cook With Fava Beans
abstract: Answering a popular reader question, with a few tips and recipes.
lead_paragraph: Most mornings, a ruby-throated hummingbird hunts in the shade outside my office window, vibrating noisily as he zigzags for insects so tiny I can barely see them, zooming tirelessly around his garden (yes, I do believe it’s his garden now).

headline: The Bedbug Hunter
abstract: “I’m an exterminator and a bedbug eliminator. I’m a consultant. I’m a psychiatrist (I’m not a psychiatrist, I’m just being facetious).”

headline: Another Variable in the Winemaking Process: Climate Change
abstract: After two years of fires, the California winery Donkey & Goat has learned to pivot, combining appellations and even vintages to turn despair into deliciousness.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — If anyone doubts the jarring effect that climate change has already had on the California wine industry, ample evidence was on display in late March at Donkey & Goat’s outdoor tasting area in this neighborhood of motorcycle repair shops and urban wineries.

headline: Russians discussed killings of civilians in radio traffic intercepted by Germany, officials say.
abstract: The report adds to evidence of indiscriminate killings by Russian forces. It could not be confirmed whether the radio transmissions collected by German intelligence were from Bucha or another place near the capital, an official said.
lead_paragraph: German intelligence has intercepted radio transmissions in which Russian forces discussed carrying out indiscriminate killings north of Kyiv, the capital, according to two officials briefed on an intelligence report.

headline: We Can’t Predict the Grocery Future
abstract: Some of our pandemic-induced digital habits are here to stay. But what about buying bananas?
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom has been that the pandemic will spark a widespread and permanent shift in American habits from analog to digital. But what about that most basic habit — grocery shopping?

headline: Romney, a former opponent of Jackson, is one of her few Republican backers.
abstract: The Utah senator is the only one of the three G.O.P. supporters of Judge Jackson to have opposed her elevation to an influential appeals court.
lead_paragraph: With his vote to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court, Mitt Romney of Utah has proved to be that rarest of commodities in today’s Congress: a persuadable senator.

headline: Republicans’ Fresh Fixation on Vintage Homophobia
abstract: With words like “grooming” and “predations,” they’re trafficking in hateful slurs.
lead_paragraph: For much of my life, I was extra careful around young children, especially young boys.

headline: ‘The Wanderer’ Review: A Dion Musical Hits All the Familiar Notes
abstract: A new production about the 1960s doo-wop idol follows the usual rise-and-fall formula. Still, the songs are wonderful, as is the angel-voiced ensemble.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, all a show needs is a harmonizing ensemble perched out of windows and fire escapes in a well-appointed street scene to win you over. That’s mostly what gets “The Wanderer,” a new jukebox bio-musical about the rise of the singer-songwriter Dion DiMucci, across the finish line. Despite its falling into the genre’s tiresome tropes, this long-gestating production, which opened at Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey on Sunday night, succeeds on sheer sonic strength.

headline: ‘A face that looks like mine’: Black women in law welcome Jackson’s confirmation with pride.
abstract: Some said the questioning that Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson faced in her confirmation hearings was sobering.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Black women in law from around the country celebrated Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation to the Supreme Court on Thursday, with many saying they felt proud and inspired by her accomplishment.

headline: For Murkowski, the decision to support Jackson came amid a fraught political campaign.
abstract: Facing a primary challenge from the right in Alaska, the moderate Republican had to choose between placating restive conservatives or courting the center.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, one of three Republicans who voted to support Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation to the Supreme Court, found herself in a unique political position as she deliberated over the nomination.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Role of Religion in Their Lives, Similarities With Parents and Comeback Stories
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: This week on The Learning Network, we asked teenagers about the role that religion plays in their lives. We also wanted to hear about the traits or quirks they inherited from their parents, and, inspired by athletes like Tom Brady who have “un-retired,” we asked them their thoughts on comeback stories.

headline: European diplomats slowly close in on new sanctions, adding limitations.
abstract: As part of the European Union’s proposed measures to punish Moscow, a ban on Russian coal imports would be phased in over four months, instead of three.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union ambassadors meeting for a second day in Brussels on Thursday afternoon entered what officials said would be their last round of negotiations to approve a fifth package of sanctions against Russia, having dragged out the talks longer than expected, and inserting important limitations to the new measures.

headline: WordleBot: Your Daily Wordle Companion
abstract: First, play today’s Wordle. Then come here.
lead_paragraph: First, play today’s Wordle. Then come here.

headline: N.L.R.B. counsel calls for a ban on mandatory anti-union meetings.
abstract: The meetings are a common response by companies like Amazon and Starbucks to union drives among workers. The full labor board will make the decision.
lead_paragraph: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board issued a memo on Thursday arguing that the widespread employer practice of requiring workers to attend anti-union meetings is illegal under federal law, even though labor board precedent has allowed it.

headline: 2 Men Posing as Federal Agents Duped Secret Service, U.S. Says
abstract: Members of the Secret Service were placed on leave after receiving gifts, including rent-free apartments, from the men, an affidavit said. One claimed ties to Pakistani intelligence, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two men masquerading as Department of Homeland Security officers in Washington duped several members of the Secret Service, providing them with tens of thousands of dollars in gifts, including rent-free apartments, federal prosecutors said. One of the men told several people that he had connections to Pakistan’s main intelligence agency, prosecutors said in federal court on Thursday.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Raury and More
abstract: I'm The Times’s Arts & Leisure editor. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I'm The Times’s Arts & Leisure editor. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: Harris presided as Jackson was confirmed, but no Black women had a vote.
abstract: As President Biden’s nominee breaks a barrier on the Supreme Court, the Senate lacks a single Black woman to approve the confirmation.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, the first Black woman to hold the position and one of just 11 Black senators in American history, presided over the vote to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson as the first Black woman on the Supreme Court — one historic figure presiding over the elevation of another.

headline: Legal Effort Expands to Disqualify Republicans as ‘Insurrectionists’
abstract: New lawsuits target Representatives Paul Gosar and Andy Biggs, as well as Mark Finchem, a candidate for Arizona secretary of state, claiming they are barred from office under the 14th Amendment.
lead_paragraph: A legal effort to disqualify from re-election lawmakers who participated in events surrounding the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol expanded on Thursday, when a cluster of voters and a progressive group filed suit against three elected officials in Arizona to bar them under the 14th Amendment from running again.

headline: N.Y. Attorney General Seeks to Hold Trump in Contempt
abstract: The attorney general, Letitia James, has been conducting a civil investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s family business.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general, Letitia James, filed a motion on Thursday asking a judge to hold Donald J. Trump in contempt for failing to turn over documents in her civil investigation into his business activities.

headline: The Congressional Black Caucus rallies behind Judge Jackson.
abstract: The caucus, which began more than 50 years ago, posed for a photograph to celebrate the vote to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of members of the Congressional Black Caucus gathered in the Capitol’s Rayburn Room on Wednesday to pose for a photo, many of them holding T-shirts that read “Black Women Are Supreme.”

headline: Film Club: ‘The Great American Lawn: How the Dream Was Manufactured’
abstract: How did a perfectly manicured lawn become an iconic symbol of the American dream?
lead_paragraph: “The Great American Lawn: How the Dream Was Manufactured” is a seven-minute film that traces the history of how a perfectly manicured patch of grass came to represent the pride of homeownership and community. But where did that dream come from? And why do we still have it, given that lawns can hurt the environment and contribute to climate change?

headline: Review: Exploring Nature and Nightlife at Martha Graham
abstract: Martha Graham Dance Company brings two premieres and a classic to the City Center Dance Festival. The best new work? A soulful score by Jason Moran.
lead_paragraph: Isn’t it distressing when the oldest dance on a program has the most to say about the present? And more disconcerting when that dance feels it could have been the newest?

headline: How a Saudi-Led Alliance Battling an Iran-Backed Militia Devastated Yemen
abstract: Yemen was already the Arab world’s poorest country before its civil war began in 2014. Then a Saudi-led coalition joined the fight against the Iran-backed Houthi militia, spreading the ruin.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Months after a rebel movement aligned with Iran seized control of Yemen’s capital in 2014, Saudi Arabia pulled together a military coalition and unleashed a rain of bombs aimed at driving the rebels back to their homes in the mountains.

headline: Oh, Josh & Marsha & Ted & Lindsey … Sorry, Judge Jackson
abstract: At every stage, the nominee comported herself with professionalism, grace and dignity — the precise opposite of what we witnessed from some of the Republican lawmakers involved.
lead_paragraph: Although contentious — at times moronically so — the overall process to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court was relatively efficient, and the nomination was never in serious jeopardy. The final vote even wound up vaguely bipartisan, with three Republicans joining Democrats in supporting her.

headline: Nearly two-thirds of Africans may have contracted the coronavirus, the W.H.O. says.
abstract: The Africa director at the World Health Organization on Thursday urged African countries to ramp up coronavirus testing and contact tracing as she presented research suggesting that nearly two-thirds of people on the continent may have contracted the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Africa director at the World Health Organization on Thursday urged African countries to ramp up coronavirus testing and contact tracing as she presented research suggesting that nearly two-thirds of people on the continent may have contracted the coronavirus.

headline: The Pity of the Elites
abstract: How prestigious universities value student trauma.
lead_paragraph: When I was writing my book “The Loneliest Americans,” I spent a lot of time pondering a question: How does a person tell their own story in a fair way? The book has some elements from my own life, and I wanted to represent them well. My parents grew up in South Korea during the war. There were periods of my childhood in the United States when we were very poor. But I am now a comfortable man in his early 40s who has one of the most decadent luxuries a person can buy these days: a master’s degree in creative writing.

headline: We May Be Able to Prevent Some Mass Shootings
abstract: A new book explains the promise of “behavioral threat assessment.”
lead_paragraph: Sometime over the past decade, America seems to have resigned itself to thinking about mass shootings as if they were a kind of unavoidable natural disaster.

headline: Introducing WordleBot, the Upshot’s Daily Wordle Companion
abstract: It will tell you how skillful or lucky you were, and it could help improve your results.
lead_paragraph: WordleBot is a tool that will take your completed Wordle and analyze it for you. It will give you overall scores for luck and skill on a scale from 0 to 99 and tell you at each turn what, if anything, you could have done differently — if solving Wordles in as few steps as possible is your goal.

headline: ‘He Is a Child of War’: Giving Birth Amid Chaos in Ukraine
abstract: As artillery shells fall, pregnant women are delivering prematurely, being shuttled in and out of bomb shelters or having babies in basements without even a midwife to help. Tens of thousands more are displaced.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Before the war, Alina Shynkar’s gynecologist advised her to avoid stress during her pregnancy, suggesting she spend time “just watching cartoons and being silly.” It was simple enough advice, but not so easy to follow after air-raid sirens wailed, artillery booms rattled windows and vicious street fighting broke out a few miles away from her maternity hospital.

headline: Confirmed but on the sidelines: Judge Jackson is now a justice in waiting.
abstract: Her status is the consequence of Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s early and conditional announcement of his retirement.
lead_paragraph: The last three justices to join the Supreme Court did so while its term was already underway, causing them to have to scramble to get up to speed. Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will face the opposite problem: an extended stretch in which she will be in an unusual twilight space as a justice in waiting.

headline: A Transformative Justice Whose Impact May Be Limited
abstract: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will help make the Supreme Court look like the nation but will have little power to halt its rightward trajectory.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, the first Black woman confirmed to the Supreme Court, will in one sense transform it. Once she replaces Justice Stephen G. Breyer, one of the 108 white men who preceded her, the court will look a lot more like the nation it serves.

lead_paragraph: If you have some liquid dye and vinegar, you're good to go.

headline: Palestinian Who Killed 2 in Tel Aviv Is Shot Dead After Manhunt
abstract: The gunman initially escaped after his attack outside a busy bar at the heart of Israel’s most cosmopolitan city. After a nightlong search, police forces said they killed the gunman in a shootout near a mosque in Jaffa.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli security forces on Friday morning shot dead a Palestinian gunman who had fled the night before after killing two people and wounding 13 others outside a busy bar in central Tel Aviv. The gunman’s attack was the latest in the deadliest wave of terrorism in Israel since 2016.

headline: Hew Locke to Create Artworks for Met Museum Facade
abstract: The Guyanese-British artist will create four sculptures shaped into whole and fragmented trophies that reference historical works in the museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has selected the Guyanese-British artist Hew Locke to create new works for its Fifth Avenue facade niches, the third in a new series of site-specific commissions for the museum’s exterior.

headline: Joseph Kalichstein, Pianist of Subtlety and Refinement, Dies at 76
abstract: An acclaimed exponent of Schumann, Brahms and Mendelssohn, he was best known for his work as a member of the Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Kalichstein, an Israeli American pianist whose subtle, refined approach made him an exemplary chamber musician, especially as a member of the esteemed Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, died on March 31 in Manhattan. He was 76.

headline: A former Goldman Sachs executive tied to a scandal over leaked Fed documents is barred from banking.

headline: Capitol Fox’s Three Kits Euthanized After Rabies Exposure

lead_paragraph: GREENBELT, Md. — Pristine slivers of the impactor that killed the dinosaurs have been discovered, said scientists studying a North Dakota site that is a time capsule of that calamitous day 66 million years ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Chasing Andy Warhol,’ Street Theater Goes Pop
abstract: From Bated Breath Theater Company, the antics of this show, which winds through the East Village, offer little insight into Andy Warhol or his work.

Playing chess, striking a ballet pose, scooting through the drizzle. In “Chasing Andy Warhol,” a slapdash work of street performance by Bated Breath Theater Company, the pop artist, who died in 1987, has repopulated select blocks of Manhattan’s East Village.

lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s war of aggression runs on the money Russia gets by selling fossil fuels to Europe. And while Ukraine has, incredibly, repelled Russia’s attempt to seize Kyiv, Putin won’t be definitively stopped until Europe ends its energy dependence.

headline: New Season, New Mets: ‘We Just Want to Play Great Baseball’
abstract: The second year of the club’s reinvention got off to a terrific start thanks in large part to its unexpected opening day starter.

They have, to name a few important figures, a new manager, a new general manager and a new team owner — the last of that bunch making the biggest difference in the direction of any franchise.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon blow into town with a breezy acrostic.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This puzzle is a feat in themed cluing. I think you could make a case for every entry’s connection to the passage (although OBLIQUE could be a bit of a stretch). The passage is from a science book written for a mass audience called “Rain: A Natural and Cultural History,” by Cynthia Barnett. The book explains precipitation on a global and local scale (apparently there’s a village in India that gets 39 feet of rain per year), which explains the deluge of aquatic-themed clues and entries. The passage itself involves geography and the phenomenon of airflow over and away from the hot equatorial zone, which explains the smattering of ethereal references, like CHINOOK and AEOLIAN, as well as the cartographic trivia.

lead_paragraph: A recent Times article spotlighted “cult cruisers,” the term given to people (many of them retirees) who book back-to-back sailings, essentially living their lives on cruise ships and spending as little time as possible on land.

headline: They Were College Friends. Now They’re Art Thieves.
abstract: Grace D. Li’s debut, “Portrait of a Thief,” is both a heist novel and a reckoning.
lead_paragraph: The heist narrative, as depicted in films and TV shows, is often a romp. But the heist novels I adore (think Richard Stark’s canonical Parker novels) are pitiless, even merciless, about the costs incurred to those who steal as well as those who are stolen from.

headline: Immigrant Lives, Back to Back and Upside Down
abstract: Michelle de Kretser’s two-part novel, “Scary Monsters,” follows a young teacher in 1980s France and a bureaucrat in a dystopian future Australia.
lead_paragraph: SCARY MONSTERSBy Michelle de Kretser

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why Do We Yawn?’
abstract: In this lesson, you will learn about what happens in our bodies when we yawn and investigate the question of whether yawning is contagious.
lead_paragraph: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.

headline: Here’s What $220 Billion Brings: New Casinos, Bail Laws and a Stadium
abstract: New York’s agreement on a $220 billion state budget includes a raft of nonfiscal measures, including a three-year window to resume the legal sale of to-go drinks.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, N.Y. — With New York State lawmakers reaching agreement Thursday on a $220 billion state budget, you would expect most of the focus to be on how and where they intend to spend all that money.

headline: A Reporter Running at the Masters
abstract: Tiger Woods is the big story at Augusta this week, but there are unpredictable outcomes a sports journalist has to be prepared for.
lead_paragraph: Bill Pennington, a sports reporter, first covered the Masters golf tournament in 1991, as a columnist for The Record of North Jersey. In 1997, he reported on Tiger Woods’s first Masters win. A few months later, he joined the Sports desk at The Times. This week, Pennington is at Augusta National Golf Club working the course as a sportswriter for the 22nd time.

headline: How a ‘Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Tour Guide Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Stephanie Windland takes fans of the show around in a vintage car to visit the sites of 1950s New York.
lead_paragraph: “I love meeting people. I love costumes. And I love performing,” said Stephanie Windland, an actress who works as a guide for the Marvelous Mrs. Maisel Sites Tour. With her current gig, she gets to “talk about two things I adore: the show and this city.”

headline: As Gas Prices Went Up, So Did the Hunt for Electric Vehicles
abstract: Prices at the pump have apparently given some Americans second thoughts. But two practical problems remain: not enough cars and relatively few charging stations.
lead_paragraph: Thinking about buying an electric car? You’re not alone.

headline: The New York Dream of Cheap Rent and No Roommates? It’s Over.
abstract: The city is thriving, but many who scored a deal now face rent-renewal sticker shock. Rents rose 33 percent between January of 2021 and January this year, according to an online listing site.
lead_paragraph: The hallmarks of feeling like you’ve made it in New York City are often as follows: navigating the subway sans map, a maitre d’ who knows you by name and living alone, at last, in your own apartment. For a window of time during the pandemic, when many fled the city and landlords offered rock-bottom rents to tempt those who stayed, some could finally afford to reach that shining hill of solo living.

headline: Two Musicians of Color Are Creating Their Own Space
abstract: “Everything Rises,” by the violinist Jennifer Koh and the singer Davóne Tines, mines their experiences in the white-dominated classical music field.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, when the bass-baritone Davóne Tines was starring in Kaija Saariaho’s “Only the Sound Remains” at the Paris Opera, he stepped out of his dressing room and saw something surprising: another person of color.

headline: International Bonds Can Give Your Investments a Smoother Ride
abstract: The bond market is reeling, recording its worst performance in decades. International bonds might help your portfolio ride out the turbulence.
lead_paragraph: International bonds can baffle even experienced investors. Add to that the fraught state of the world, with warfare and a pandemic, and it’s little wonder many people shy away from them.

headline: You May Not Find Many Friends on This Power-Hungry Supreme Court
abstract: But large corporations and right-wing activists will have a majority of justices almost certainly on their side.
lead_paragraph: The confirmation of Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court on Thursday was as noteworthy for what it didn’t change as for what it did.

headline: Bidding War for Spirit Could Undercut Power of Four Big Airlines
abstract: The rival bids for Spirit from Frontier and JetBlue could create an airline that presents a more formidable challenge to American, Delta, Southwest and United.
lead_paragraph: When the dust settled on a big round of airline consolidation nearly a decade ago, four large companies came to dominate the industry. A new merger scramble could challenge that cozy arrangement.

headline: Fiona Hill on Whether Ukraine Can Win — and What Happens if Russia Loses
abstract: The foreign policy expert maps out the possible futures for the Russia-Ukraine war.
lead_paragraph: The Russia-Ukraine war has changed considerably in recent weeks. Vladimir Putin is no longer talking explicitly about regime change in Ukraine. The Russian military has shifted its focus away from taking Kyiv and toward making territorial gains in Ukraine’s east. The prospect of an outright Ukrainian victory is no longer out of the question. And negotiations between the parties over a possible settlement appear to be making some progress.

headline: Republicans and Democrats Agree Child Care Needs Help. Here’s How They Differ.
abstract: In a new bill, Republican senators adopted many of the Democrats’ goals, but they remain far apart on elements like how to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: The crisis in child care has become a rare issue of bipartisan agreement. Democrats are trying to revive their plan to subsidize child care for most families, and now Senate Republicans have introduced their own bill on the issue.

headline: Go Ahead, Count Naomi Osaka Out
abstract: Sometimes you deliver your best performance when your back is against the wall.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Osaka doesn’t usually follow pretournament chatter before she hits the court, but last month was an exception. One evening she heard a former rival of hers, Caroline Wozniacki, analyzing the lineup for the Miami Open on TV and predicting who would advance.

headline: Globalization Is Over. The Global Culture Wars Have Begun.
abstract: We’re entering the age of red world versus blue world.
lead_paragraph: I’m from a fortunate generation. I can remember a time — about a quarter-century ago — when the world seemed to be coming together. The great Cold War contest between communism and capitalism appeared to be over. Democracy was still spreading. Nations were becoming more economically interdependent. The internet seemed ready to foster worldwide communications. It seemed as if there would be a global convergence around a set of universal values — freedom, equality, personal dignity, pluralism, human rights.

headline: A Market Mystery: The ‘Wheat Whale’ That Came Out of Nowhere
abstract: Who was behind the surge of trading in wheat futures last month? Some point to a group of Reddit users who mobbed an E.T.F. offering exposure to the wheat market.
lead_paragraph: In early March, just days after Russia invaded Ukraine, a strange thing happened in the market for wheat futures: Trading came to an unexpected halt.

headline: For Ukrainian Writer, War Evokes Scars of Time in Captivity
abstract: Stanislav Aseyev, a 32-year-old journalist, had documented his abuse in a prison run by Russian-backed separatists. Now, the war reminds him of why Ukrainians are fighting for their lives.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Stanislav Aseyev spent two and a half years in a notorious prison run by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine, where he said he and other inmates were regularly tortured, beaten, demeaned and forced to wear bags on their heads. Yet, even he was unprepared for the grim scenes of abuse and executions that he witnessed in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha.

headline: The Biggest Promoter of Mexico’s Presidential Recall Election? The President.
abstract: The vote has the potential to upend the country’s political system. But many fear it will amount to nothing more than a tool for propaganda.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Strolling through Mexico’s capital these days, it would be easy to assume the country’s president is at imminent risk of losing his job.

headline: Lawsuit Charges For-Profit University Preyed on Black and Female Students
abstract: The suit claims Walden University not only misrepresented the costs and credits required for an advanced degree but also engaged in “reverse redlining” by targeting minority communities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aljanal Carroll never doubted her ability to beat the odds — not when a doctor told her she would never attend school after battling spinal meningitis as a child, or when she set her sights on a 4.0 G.P.A. in her master’s program, or when she heard it was rare for Black women to earn a doctorate in business administration.

headline: For This Opera Director, a Lot Is Riding on a ‘Handmaid’s Tale’
abstract: For her English National Opera debut, the company’s new artistic leader, Annilese Miskimmon, has chosen a work she hopes can bring in a new audience.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Annilese Miskimmon, the British opera director, looked tired and frazzled when she appeared on a recent video call. She was taking a short break from rehearsing “The Handmaid’s Tale” — the first production at English National Opera she is directing since taking over its artistic leadership in the middle of the pandemic. Those rehearsals had not been running smoothly, Miskimmon said, and had been hit by a recent surge in coronavirus cases in England. For a few weeks, the production had been rehearsing partly online.

headline: The Mysterious Man Who Built (and Then Lost) Little Tokyo
abstract: The remarkable hidden history of Tony Yoshida, who transformed a single block in New York City, helped start the cocktail revolution — and inspired John Belushi to become a samurai.
lead_paragraph: When word got out last month that Angel’s Share might close after nearly 30 years, the city — or at least a very vocal slice that was devoted to artisanal cocktails — spun into a paroxysm of despair.

headline: The Huge Endeavor to Produce a Tiny Microchip
abstract: As the global chip shortage continues, we take an inside look at how semiconductors are fabricated.
lead_paragraph: Some feature more than 50 billion tiny transistors that are 10,000 times smaller than the width of a human hair. They are made on gigantic, ultraclean factory room floors that can be seven stories tall and run the length of four football fields.

headline: A Super Building for Fragile Times
abstract: The Oregon State Treasury is moving into a newly constructed structure designed to withstand every disaster the designers could conjure.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — A giant earthquake. A huge flood. Wildfires followed by choking smoke. An ice storm that knocks out the power for days.

headline: ‘La French Tech’ Arrives Under Macron, but Proves No Panacea
abstract: The president has brought innovation, jobs and growth. Still, resentments fester on the eve of the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In full Steve Jobs mode, President Emmanuel Macron of France donned a black turtleneck in January and took to Twitter to celebrate the creation in France of 25 “unicorn” start-ups — companies with a market value of over 1 billion euros, or almost $1.1 billion.

headline: The L.G.B.T.Q. Romance Boom and the Next Big Addiction Treatment: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Energy Funds Lead Again, but Ukraine War Makes Future Uncertain
abstract: High oil prices have lifted the shares of energy companies, making that the best-performing sector among funds in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: The wild ride that energy markets have been on shows no signs of abating. After topping the charts in 2021, funds that invest in energy stocks once again turned in the strongest performance of any sector in the first quarter.

headline: ‘The City Lives’: With Russian Forces Gone, Kyiv Starts to Revive
abstract: The anxiety remains, but in Ukraine’s capital, large lines of cars are now forming on highways into the city and businesses are reopening.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — On Feb. 25, the day after Russia invaded Ukraine, Kolya Rybytva gathered his grandmother and younger sister and left Kyiv “quickly and without unnecessary sentiments,” he said, heading west. His parents and brother stayed behind to help in the war effort.

headline: Staying the Course May Be the Key to Wartime Investing
abstract: Experts say investors should resist the urge to make drastic changes to their portfolios because of global turmoil.
lead_paragraph: Entire sectors of the global economy are in turmoil after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, leaving investors worried about how they should react. Should they buy energy stocks? Shares of defense contractors? What about agriculture? Is it time to go to cash?

headline: How Germany’s Approach to Russia Backfired
abstract: German leaders believed that more trade would help ensure peace in the region. The war in Ukraine has revealed why that theory was flawed.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, Germany put forth a theory for how to work with Russia. Major energy deals, leaders argued, would keep Russia from going to war with its neighbors.

headline: The Electric Car Market Heats Up
abstract: Soaring fuel prices and climate change concerns are driving demand for the vehicles in Australia, as elsewhere. But they are particularly hard to find here.
lead_paragraph: Secondhand cars listed for tens of thousands more dollars than new cars. Batches of vehicles selling out in minutes. Monthslong wait times.

headline: Culture War, Redux
abstract: How did L.G.B.T. rights again become the subject of a culture war?
lead_paragraph: For a few years, the battles over L.G.B.T. rights seemed to be fading from the American political scene.

headline: Hollywood Gets a New Giant
abstract: The blockbuster merger of Discovery and WarnerMedia closed on Friday, putting many of the biggest names in movies, TV and news under one roof.
lead_paragraph: Discovery, the medium-size media company that began as a small cable network in 1985, has completed something once unthinkable: assuming ownership of a fabled Hollywood company that controls Batman, Harry Potter, “Sex and the City,” “Game of Thrones,”  CNN and March Madness.

headline: First Issue of Captain America Comic Book Fetches $3.1 Million at Auction
abstract: With the sale, Captain America joined Superman and Spider-Man in having debut issues that topped $3 million at auction.
lead_paragraph: A copy of the first Captain America comic book, featuring the memorable cover image of the superhero socking a stunned Hitler while fending off Nazi bullets, fetched more than $3.1 million at an auction Thursday, becoming one of the world’s priciest comic books.

headline: How to Stoop to New Heights With These Sidewalk Furniture Hunters
