abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Hello, readers.

headline: Latest E.U. Sanctions Get Personal With Putin’s Daughters and Confidants
abstract: The targets included one of the most trusted technocrats in Mr. Putin’s economic policy team and the head of a construction empire who used to practice judo with the Russian leader.
lead_paragraph: A number of high-profile names were added Friday to the European Union’s list of sanctioned individuals as part of the bloc’s fifth package of measures against Russia, none more personal for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia than his own daughters.

headline: ‘There Is No Reasonable Way for This to End’: Bill Browder on How to Stop the War
abstract: Mr. Browder, once a major investor in Russia, discusses what influences Vladimir Putin and whether punishing the oligarchs around him could help end his aggression in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: In Mariupol’s Drama Theater, a Cry for ‘Mama!’ That Offered Brief Relief
abstract: A family shares its story of surviving the Russian attack on a theater that officials in the besieged southern Ukrainian city believe killed about 300 people.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — The explosion — deafening, blinding — collapsed the walls around them, and “the moments afterwards felt like an eternity, waiting to hear my child’s scream so I would know she was alive,” Viktoria Dubovitskaya said. “Maybe she will be without legs or arms, but just let her be alive.”

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Classic Games, Lingering Scars and the Finish Line in Sight
abstract: Manchester City and Liverpool meet Sunday in the first of a series of collisions that could decide as many as three trophies. Neither team can be sure of what comes after that.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Pep Guardiola lay on his bed in a Madrid hotel room, staring at the ceiling, contemplating his next move. He had already endured two sapping games, half a dozen choleric news conferences, more than a week of highly charged, thinly veiled animosity. He was exhausted and exasperated, and he was still only halfway through.

headline: Putin’s War in Ukraine Shatters an Illusion in Russia
abstract: Russians long lived with an understanding: Stay away from politics, and live your life as you choose. The war in Ukraine wrecked that idea.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: I Got a Discount on My Rent-Stabilized Apartment. How Much Can the Rent Go Up Now?
abstract: As leases expire amid a hot rental market, tenants are reporting huge rent hikes. Here’s how to determine what you should be paying.
lead_paragraph: Q: A year ago, I moved into an apartment in a Brooklyn building for $3,800 a month. The lease I signed stated that base rent was $4,800, but I was being given a concession. Worried that rents might rise, I negotiated a rider limiting my rent increase to $200, and when my lease ended, my landlord offered me a new one for $4,000 a month. But after I did some research, I learned that the apartment is actually rent stabilized, so rent increases should be limited to the amount set by the city. But the landlord says that my base rent is $4,800, describing my lower payment as a concession. Is this correct or can I challenge it?

headline: At the Masters, Tiger Woods Will Take Some Ice With That
abstract: Woods’s improbable quest for a sixth green jacket rested largely on his recuperation regimen, but the weekend appeared to prove its limitations.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Tiger Woods stood in the glorious sunlight of a Georgia spring one afternoon this past week, a lingering dose of warmth before the frigid, hellish hours ahead.

headline: Kim and Pete, or Vladimir and Volodymyr?
abstract: Can America stay focused on Russia’s evil in Ukraine?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Please, Kim Kardashian, don’t elope with Pete Davidson.

headline: Football Asks Me to Make Moral Compromises. I Love It Anyway.
abstract: I’m not proud of myself, but nothing can keep me from this game.
lead_paragraph: American football is, to me, the most beautiful sport on earth. Every play is a high-level chess maneuver, performed by some of the most physically adept people alive. The intricacies of the game, the decision making, the coordinated dance of it all: It’s truly gorgeous. And at the professional level, football almost hums with the sound of its own excitement. There are moments in the midst of a great game when I think I’m lucky even to be able to watch it. It’s no wonder to me that football is the most popular spectator sport in America.

headline: In the Rush to Return to ‘Normal,’ What Happens to the Vulnerable?
abstract: We need a new normal.
lead_paragraph: “Covid-19 need no longer control our lives,” President Biden announced in the State of the Union address, speaking to a room of unmasked though back-room-tested members of Congress. He then offered, magnanimously: “If you’re immunocompromised or have some other vulnerability, we have treatments and free high-quality masks. We’re leaving no one behind or ignoring anyone’s needs as we move forward.”

headline: The Case for Paying Parents Who Care for Their Own Kids
abstract: Is being in the formal workplace necessarily a sign of progress?
lead_paragraph: In some European countries, parents can choose between sending their children to heavily subsidized day care or receiving a stipend from the government to take care of them at home.

headline: Russia Shuffles Command in Ukraine as Thousands Flee the East
abstract: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia reorganized the command of its flagging offensive in Ukraine on Saturday, selecting for the mission a general accused of ordering strikes on civilian neighborhoods in Syria, as Western nations poured more weapons into the country in anticipation of a renewed Russian assault in the east.

headline: I’m a Trans Woman. Bullies Don’t Surprise Me, but Allies Still Do.
abstract: Hating trans folks makes strange bedfellows.
lead_paragraph: In late March, President Vladimir Putin of Russia compared his country’s reputational plight to that of J.K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter series. In a speech railing against the West’s efforts to ostracize Russia, Mr. Putin groused about cancel culture run amok, pointing to what he called the cancellation of the author because she “did not please fans of so-called gender freedoms.”

headline: Wave of Terrorism in Israel Defies a Simple Narrative
abstract: Four recent deadly attacks have highlighted Palestinian anger over vanishing prospects of a Palestinian state, but the assailants’ diverse backgrounds have left many questions unanswered.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — The current surge in terrorist attacks in Israel has been framed by Palestinian parties and militant groups as a logical consequence of the entrenchment of Israel’s 55-year occupation of the West Bank, of Israel’s control over sensitive religious sites in Jerusalem, and of the dwindling commitment from some key Arab leaders to the creation of a Palestinian state.

headline: When a Supreme Court Justice Probably Endorsed Perjury
abstract: Taking a close look at John Marshall and the Marbury v. Madison case.
lead_paragraph: My Friday column was on the history and origins (mostly origins) of judicial review in the United States. For research, I read a brief but comprehensive book on Marbury v. Madison and the 18th-century context for the emergence of judicial review in the early American republic. I also read the relevant chapters of two recent biographies of Chief Justice John Marshall: “John Marshall: The Man Who Made the Supreme Court” by Richard Brookhiser and “Without Precedent: Chief Justice John Marshall and His Times” by Joel Richard Paul.

headline: Pandemic aid stalled in the Senate and Shanghai remained in lockdown: The week in Covid news.
abstract: The federal government has run out of money to cover coronavirus vaccines, testing and treatment for uninsured Americans, but Congress has yet to approve more pandemic response funding. A bill that would allocate $10 billion for those purposes stalled on Tuesday when Senate Republicans refused to advance it without a vote to keep in place pandemic-era border restrictions that President Biden has moved to lift.
lead_paragraph: The federal government has run out of money to cover coronavirus vaccines, testing and treatment for uninsured Americans, but Congress has yet to approve more pandemic response funding. A bill that would allocate $10 billion for those purposes stalled on Tuesday when Senate Republicans refused to advance it without a vote to keep in place pandemic-era border restrictions that President Biden has moved to lift.

headline: Eleanor Munro, Who Profiled Women Artists, Is Dead at 94
abstract: Her 1979 book featured interviews with dozens of artists, but she also wrote on other subjects — pilgrimages, for instance.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Munro, who in an illuminating 1979 book profiled and interviewed dozens of women artists, probing for common threads in their works and their experiences trying to pursue the creative life in a society and art world that limited opportunities for them, died on April 1 at an assisted living center in Rye, N.H. She was 94.

headline: N.F.L. Quarterback Dwayne Haskins, 24, Dies After Being Hit by Truck
abstract: A Heisman Trophy finalist at Ohio State and backup with the Pittsburgh Steelers, Haskins died on Saturday after being struck on a Florida highway.
lead_paragraph: Dwayne Haskins, 24, the backup Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback and a former standout at Ohio State, died Saturday, Steelers Coach Mike Tomlin confirmed in a statement.

headline: Disagreement and Delay: How Infighting Over the Border Divided the White House
abstract: The Biden administration has furiously debated how — and whether — to unravel Trump-era immigration policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden was livid.

headline: Boris Johnson visits Kyiv, as Britain promises Ukraine armored vehicles and anti-ship weapons.
abstract: Mr. Johnson, an enthusiastic supporter of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, walked with him and a group of soldiers through the streets of the capital, Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: Making a surprise visit to Ukraine’s capital, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Saturday promised more military equipment and missiles to Ukraine, underscoring his country’s role as Europe’s most enthusiastic supporter of the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky.

headline: Fire Chief Killed While Responding to Nebraska Wildfire
abstract: Chief Darren Krull of the Elwood Volunteer Fire Department died in a car crash during a fire that has scorched some 30,000 acres in two days.
lead_paragraph: A fire chief in Nebraska was killed while responding to a wildfire that has burned nearly 30,000 acres in the south-central part of the state, destroying farms and prompting evacuations, officials said.

headline: Arthur D. Riggs, 82, Dies; Led Team That Invented Artificial Insulin
abstract: His research into recombinant DNA provided a foundation for the biotech revolution, leading to a long list of lifesaving treatments.
lead_paragraph: Arthur D. Riggs, a biochemist whose pioneering research into the mechanisms of human DNA led him to a series of breakthrough advances, including the invention of artificial insulin and monoclonal antibodies, died on March 23 in Duarte, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Can Liberalism Thrive Without a Wolf at the Door?
abstract: The Ukraine War could inspire a reassessment of what liberalism should seek to be.
lead_paragraph: The idea that Vladimir Putin’s war against Ukraine would be a restorative tonic for Western liberalism, touted hopefully in the first few weeks of war, has taken sharp blows in recent days.

headline: Teenager Charged in Fatal Shooting of 16-Year-Old Girl in the Bronx
abstract: Jeremiah Ryan, 17, was charged with murder in the killing of Angellyh Yambo, who was shot as she walked home from school on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The police said that they had arrested a suspect in the fatal shooting of a teenager who was killed near her high school in the Bronx on Friday, the latest shooting in a monthslong string that has left New York City shaken.

headline: While life expectancy is rebounding in parts of the world, white deaths drive a further U.S. drop.
abstract: Life expectancy in the United States continued to drop in 2021, while rebounding from the pandemic in many other high-income countries, according to a new preliminary analysis that found the U.S. decline was driven largely by deaths among white Americans.
lead_paragraph: Life expectancy in the United States continued to drop in 2021, while rebounding from the pandemic in many other high-income countries, according to a new preliminary analysis that found the U.S. decline was driven largely by deaths among white Americans.

headline: Pakistan Parliament Ousts Imran Khan as Prime Minister
abstract: The country will now face early elections after days of brinkmanship in which Mr. Khan tried to dissolve Parliament to head off the no-confidence vote.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Imran Khan, the former international cricket star turned politician who oversaw a new era of Pakistan’s foreign policy that distanced the country from the United States, was removed as prime minister early on Sunday after losing a no-confidence vote in Parliament.

headline: The agriculture secretary is the latest addition to a coronavirus wave disrupting the Biden administration.
abstract: The U.S. secretary of agriculture, Tom Vilsack, has tested positive for the coronavirus, his department announced on Saturday, adding to a wave of cases disrupting the Biden administration days after he met with officials in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. secretary of agriculture, Tom Vilsack, has tested positive for the coronavirus, his department announced on Saturday, adding to a wave of cases disrupting the Biden administration days after he met with officials in Mexico.

abstract: A Sunday debut from David W. Tuffs puts a lot on our plate.

headline: Power Returning to Puerto Rico, but Frustrations Remain
abstract: Although much of the island saw electricity restored on Saturday, more than 200,000 residents were still waiting.
lead_paragraph: Power has been restored to 90 percent of Puerto Rico, according to the island’s power operator, though more than 200,000 residents remained without electricity on Saturday, three days after the outage began.

lead_paragraph: Outside the Alamo in San Antonio, a festive crowd took in the Battle of Flowers parade, part of Fiesta, an 11-day celebration that was downsized a year ago because of the pandemic.

lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Saturday is called moving day at the Masters Tournament because that is when top-performing golfers try to leapfrog up the leaderboard to position themselves for a championship charge in Sunday’s final round.

headline: Trump Endorses Dr. Oz in Pennsylvania Senate Race
abstract: The former president threw his weight behind the celebrity doctor, who is running for the Republican nomination for senator in a key state.
lead_paragraph: Wading into a tight Republican Senate primary in Pennsylvania, former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Mehmet Oz on Saturday, throwing his weight behind the former star of “The Dr. Oz Show,” who has been attacked by rivals as a closet liberal. Dr. Oz’s celebrity appears to have been a deciding factor for the former president, whose own political career was grounded in reality television.

headline: Woman in Texas Charged With Murder in Connection With ‘Self-Induced Abortion’
abstract: Whether the woman had the abortion or was aiding one was unclear.
lead_paragraph: A South Texas sheriff’s official said on Saturday that a 26-year-old woman had been indicted on a murder charge in connection with the “death of an individual through a self-induced abortion.”

abstract: It has been two years since the Masters Tournament welcomed a full house of spectators who live and die with every shot.

headline: Why This Coastal County Has the Highest Covid Death Rate in Its State
abstract: Ocean County, a predominantly white and middle-class community in central New Jersey, also has low vaccination rates.
lead_paragraph: Ocean County, a coastal region in central New Jersey, is home to some of the state’s most exclusive waterfront communities and its fastest-growing town, Lakewood.

headline: Why Calls for War Crimes Justice Over Ukraine Face Long Odds
abstract: If those in power act as if they are immune to the laws of war, it may be because they often are. But following through is not necessarily an empty exercise.
lead_paragraph: This past week, as Ukrainian forces retook the town of Bucha to find its streets littered with the bodies of bound and shot civilians, and as rockets rained on a train station packed with fleeing families, killing dozens, two words were on the lips of diplomats, world leaders and rights groups: war crimes.

headline: On the Border, Buying Clothes by the Pound at Ropa Usada Shops
abstract: Like thrift shops on steroids, giant used-clothing stores are part of the culture and economic life along the border with Mexico.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Texas — A mountain of clothes swallowed half of Juani Lira’s petite body, from the waist down. But the 67-year-old did not seem to mind. Ms. Lira closely inspected a pair of black shorts studded with rhinestones and tossed them behind her, unimpressed. Too flashy for her teenage granddaughter, she murmured.

headline: An Australia Homecoming, Mixed With Yearning and Trepidation

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The tangy smell of eucalyptus leaves lining the streets. A casual friendliness even from strangers. Ten types of Asian cuisine in a 100-yard radius of the city center.

headline: Molly Shannon’s Memoir Is Filled With Mischief and Pathos
abstract: “Hello, Molly!,” the former “Saturday Night Live” star’s new book, recounts early family tragedy and a career of transgressive humor.
lead_paragraph: Some people break into show business; others burst. Like her famous character on “Saturday Night Live,” the nervous Catholic schoolgirl Mary Katherine Gallagher, Molly Shannon was more of a battering ram, laying siege to the false-fronted structures of Hollywood with blunt, repetitive force. When you reach the part in her new memoir, “Hello, Molly!,” where the fortresses finally crumble for her, you want to get out the pom-poms and cheer.

headline: One Opera, Three Acts, Three Different Stagings
abstract: In Stuttgart, Wagner’s “Die Walküre” is being divided among a trio of creative teams with divergent visions.
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — In the late 1990s, the Stuttgart State Opera in Germany raised some eyebrows and hackles when it divided the four operas in Richard Wagner’s epic “Der Ring des Nibelungen” among four directors, one installment each.

headline: His Alter Ego: Comic Book Correspondent
abstract: George Gene Gustines, an operations manager at The Times, carved out a reporting beat for himself by owning up to his passion.
lead_paragraph: George Gene Gustines, whose alliterative byline evokes many a superhero alter ego, has, fittingly, been the unofficial New York Times comic book correspondent for nearly 20 years.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million

lead_paragraph: Corina Diehl is eager for more sedans and pickup trucks to sell her customers in and around the Pittsburgh area, but as the pandemic enters its third year, cars remain in short supply and the squeeze on inventory shows no sign of abating.

Trump, even though they have concluded that they have enough evidence to do so, people involved in the discussions said.

It can also be read as a summary of her philosophy.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Battle for the Mural — and the Future of Belarus’
abstract: How an act of graffiti at a playground in Minsk turned into a campaign of defiance against an increasingly totalitarian regime.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Belarus existed in an equilibrium of quiet authoritarianism. If the government’s repressions didn’t directly touch them, most Belarusians tolerated them. But over the course of 2020, the country’s history and identity, which never much interested a majority of people who lived there, became something they would sacrifice their lives for.

headline: We Are Wasting Time on These Climate Debates. The Next Steps Are Clear.

headline: How Do We Deal With a Superpower Led by a War Criminal?
abstract: There’s never been a pariah state as consequential as Russia.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to believe, but now impossible to deny, that the broad framework that kept much of the world stable and prospering since the end of the Cold War has been seriously fractured by Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. In ways we hadn’t fully appreciated, a lot of that framework rested on the West’s ability to coexist with Putin as he played “bad boy,” testing the limits of the world order but never breaching them at scale.

headline: My Advice for American Veterans Who Want to Get on a Plane to Ukraine
abstract: People there are suffering. Discouraging my fellow veterans from going there would be both hypocritical and disingenuous.
lead_paragraph: Like many people around the world, I viewed the images that have emerged in the last few days from Bucha, Ukraine, with horror and fury. I know that all wars cause ruin and destruction, that all wars destroy and shatter innocent lives. But, although I understand this intellectually and although I saw my fair share of human suffering as a soldier in Iraq, the seemingly endless mass graves and the bound and desecrated corpses left behind in Bucha by the fleeing Russian military felt to me some new circle of hell.

headline: The Week in Business: Elon Musk’s Newest Venture
abstract: Europe agreed to ban Russian coal. A former Goldman Sachs banker was convicted for his role in a $4 billion fraud. And the latest reading on inflation comes out this week.
lead_paragraph: Twitter announced on Tuesday that Elon Musk would join its board after he bought a 9.2 percent stake in the company, making him its largest shareholder — but the company then reversed itself late Sunday and said that Mr. Musk would not be joining the board. Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s chief executive, tweeted that Mr. Musk had told the company on Saturday morning that he would no longer become a board member. Mr. Musk, a heavy user of Twitter, had reached out to Mr. Agrawal before buying the shares to tell the chief executive that he wanted to discuss improvements to Twitter, people with knowledge of the discussions said. Mr. Musk, who has gotten into trouble for his own tweets, has publicly criticized Twitter for its content moderation policies and advocated open-source algorithms on the platform. He asked his more than 80 million followers last month if they wanted the capacity to edit tweets.

headline: Facing Disastrous Floods, They Turned to Mangrove Trees for Protection

It was, to me, a pinnacle of luxury on the cheap: a savory layer cake of turkey and white bread beneath a glossy fondant of gravy.

headline: S&P Global Places Russia in ‘Selective Default’

headline: How a Cancer Diagnosis Makes Jesus’ Death and Resurrection Mean More
abstract: “I look at Easter, and I say, ‘Because of this, I can face anything.’”
lead_paragraph: I’ve talked to Timothy Keller several times since he was diagnosed with Stage 4 pancreatic cancer almost two years ago. What strikes me each time is that it’s easy to forget he has a fatal disease. He is calm, sagelike, cheerful and still deeply curious about others and the world around him. He always asks me, genuinely, how I am doing and listens intently as I tell him. He offers advice, wisdom and even sympathy, though my complaints are all comparatively small compared to facing cancer. It’s hard to have a conversation with him without feeling more hopeful and buoyant.

But something was amiss at contact with the ball, and in the millisecond it took for Woods to transition from downswing to follow-through, he let go of the club. It flung to the ground over his left shoulder.

I still recall the quiet, steady force of his running in loops around the St. Mark’s Church sanctuary, alongside the pulse of Bob Marley’s “Exodus.”

headline: Elon Musk Will Not Join Twitter’s Board, Company Says
abstract: The announcement reverses a decision last week, when Twitter said Mr. Musk would become a board member after amassing a 9.2 percent stake in the company.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

headline: ‘Be Your Own Motivation’: Injured N.B.A. Stars Talk Recovery
abstract: Paul George is back for the Los Angeles Clippers; Victor Oladipo, for the Miami Heat. The road to return was long but has them back in time for the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: For about a month after he was sidelined with a torn ligament in his right elbow, Paul George could do nothing but wait.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: An exodus from eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces attacked civilian areas in eastern Ukraine yesterday as terrified residents fleeing westward joined an exodus of thousands, heeding warnings by the authorities that Russian troops were preparing a major assault. Follow the latest updates.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The First Lady’ and ‘Abbott Elementary’
abstract: Viola Davis, Michelle Pfeiffer and Gillian Anderson star in a new series about first ladies in the White House. And “Abbott Elementary” airs its season finale.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Exiled by Russian Bombs, a Ukrainian Soccer Team Embraces Its Journey
abstract: Shakhtar Donetsk was forced from its home city and then its country by Russian invasions. Its next stop? A series of exhibition games drawing attention to Ukraine’s plight.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t the sounds of the bombs, though he did hear those, that brought back the memories for Darijo Srna. It was the air raid sirens.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Administrative note: Thank you for your patience! Please refresh your web pages and reopen your applications. You should see a new Spelling Bee puzzle for today. Happy solving!

headline: New York’s Bail Laws Are Changing Again. Here’s How.
abstract: Governor Kathy Hochul pushed for a rewrite of the 2019 laws governing the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: One of the most contentious items in New York’s $220 billion budget deal had little to do with fiscal issues: For the second time, legislators revised laws governing bail for criminal defendants that they had passed just three years ago.

headline: ‘Cheap as Chips’ No Longer True in U.K. as Prices Soar for a Favorite Meal
abstract: The costs for fish and chips, a working-class staple in Britain for well over a century, have rocketed as the war in Ukraine has made the main ingredients scarcer. Of 10,000 shops, 3,000 may close.
lead_paragraph: HARTLEPOOL, England — When it opened in 2020, business was booming at Chunks, a store serving dozens of portions each day of Britain’s best known takeout meal: battered and deep-fried cod with fries, or chips as they are known here.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Fast, Frugal Track to a Cook’s Career? Community College.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn why some aspiring chefs are choosing community college-based culinary schools. Then, they will research a career that interests them.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “A Fast, Frugal Track to a Cook’s Career? Community College.” by Priya Krishna

headline: On Day 100, Mayor Adams Has Covid-19
abstract: Eric Adams tested positive after a series of public events promoting his first 100 days as mayor. He reminded eligible New Yorkers to take antivirals.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s case of Covid-19. He tested positive for the coronavirus just after meeting New Yorkers at several events marking 100 days in office, and is being treated with antiviral medications. And we’ll explain who’s eligible for the medicine and how to get it. It’s easier than you think — we tried it.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Cost of Fish and Chips Rises in War Economy, and U.K. Feels the Bite
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a bit of theater in a fish-and-chip shop, it’s a bit like being behind a bar. I’ve got customers that just come in for the banter and, for some of the older people, we might be the only people they speak to all day.”

headline: No Corrections: April 11, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Paul Krugman on Why the Economy Is Doing Better Than We Think
abstract: The economist and Times Opinion columnist discusses inflation, unemployment and the supply chain crisis.
lead_paragraph: From rising gas prices and inflation to the Russia-Ukraine war, the U.S. economy has experienced all sorts of turbulence recently. But it hasn’t all been a bad news story: The U.S. unemployment rate reached a low of 3.6 percent in March and wages are rising. In this conversation, Kara Swisher asks the economist and Nobel laureate Paul Krugman to put all these factors into perspective. “It’s not an A++ economy,” Krugman says, but it’s “immensely better” than where the economy was during the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: Liana Finck Imagines a Female God, in Her Own Image
abstract: The cartoonist’s new graphic novel, “Let There Be Light,” recasts the story of Genesis with God as a neurotic artist a lot like Liana Finck.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a short and sweet (and fallacious) argument for God’s existence. 1: Our idea of God is of a supremely perfect being — meaning a being that has all perfections, such as omniscience, omnipotence and beneficence. 2: Necessary existence is a perfection. Conclusion: God exists.

headline: What Does Judge Jackson’s Supreme Court Confirmation Mean to You?
abstract: Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson will be the first Black woman and the first public defender to serve as a justice. How do you think she will shape the court, now and in the future?
lead_paragraph: On April 7, Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson was confirmed to the Supreme Court in a 53-to-47 vote, with three Republicans joining all 50 members of the Democratic caucus in backing her.

headline: I Would Have Never Bought This Home if I Knew It Flooded
abstract: As the climate changes, flood rules need reform to protect communities on the front lines.
lead_paragraph: I have spent much of the past decade at the soggy edges of this country listening to the people whose homes and businesses flood worse and worse year after year as tides rise higher and storms become stronger. While I still haven’t gotten over the shock of hearing someone describe what it’s like to lose a home or a loved one, another story, submerged in this trauma, has started to surface.

headline: A Haitian Photojournalist Finds Safety in Manhattan
abstract: Dieu-Nalio Chéry, who covered the strife that has plagued his country, became a target of the violence himself, but  he and his family received help to settle in New York.
lead_paragraph: Dieu-Nalio Chéry never thought he would leave Haiti, much less that his journey would take him to a high-rise apartment building a block from the Hudson River.

headline: Truck Makers Face a Tech Dilemma: Batteries or Hydrogen?
abstract: Under pressure to cut emissions, truck manufacturers are choosing between batteries and hydrogen fuel cells. Wagering incorrectly could cost them billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Even before war in Ukraine sent fuel prices through the roof, the trucking industry was under intense pressure to kick its addiction to diesel, a major contributor to climate change and urban air pollution. But it still has to figure out which technology will best do the job.

headline: To Be Pro-Choice, You Must Have the Privilege of Having Choices
abstract: We must acknowledge the role that race plays in sexual and reproductive health outcomes in this country.
lead_paragraph: As a queer woman who grew up in North Carolina, I learned at an early age that my Blackness could be a source of great joy — but it could also pose a threat to my safety and autonomy.

headline: Biden Names Former Federal Prosecutor to Lead A.T.F.
abstract: The president nominated Steven M. Dettelbach to run the troubled agency, seven months after withdrawing his previous pick.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden nominated a former federal prosecutor, Steven M. Dettelbach, on Monday to run the embattled Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives — part of a renewed effort to combat gun violence and jump-start a stalled gun control agenda.

headline: Is Trump the Democrats’ Secret Weapon?
abstract: There are days when it certainly seems that way.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I was moved by Ketanji Brown Jackson’s remarks last week after her Senate confirmation: “In my family, it took just one generation to go from segregation to the Supreme Court.” What a ringing affirmation of what’s possible in the United States. And how depressing that only three Republican senators could bring themselves to vote for her, if only on the principle that every president deserves to get qualified nominees confirmed. Whatever happened to acknowledging the possibility that we can respect and admire people with whom we also disagree?

headline: ‘What If Africa Was the Birthplace of Fashion?’
abstract: As the first “amigo” designer for Alber Elbaz’s AZ Factory, Thebe Magugu poses the question — and offers a sneak peek into the collection.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, when the much-loved designer Alber Elbaz unexpectedly died from Covid just after introducing a label called AZ Factory, the fashion world first mourned, then wondered what would happen to his new company, backed by the luxury conglomerate Richemont. How could it go on without him?

headline: Putin’s War in Ukraine Is a Watershed. Time for America to Get Real.
abstract: How the United States should deal with Putin.
lead_paragraph: During his recent speech in Warsaw, President Biden said that Vladimir Putin “cannot remain in power,” only to clarify a few days later that he was merely expressing outrage, not announcing a new U.S. policy aimed at toppling Russia’s leader. The episode, interpreted by many as a dangerous gaffe, underscored the tension in U.S. foreign policy between idealism and realism.

headline: U.S. Weighs Shift to Support Hague Court as It Investigates Russian Atrocities
abstract: The government is hamstrung from helping the world’s war-crimes court by two laws and a policy aimed at barring it from charging Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is vigorously debating how much the United States can or should assist an investigation into Russian atrocities in Ukraine by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: A Full-Body Strength Training Workout at Home
abstract: If you’re willing to be creative, a set of elastic bands can be as effective as a gym full of weights.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I impulsively bought a set of mini exercise bands — thick rubber loops designed to engage your muscles as you stretch them. I was seduced by ads promising they could improve my posture, which is lousy after years of slumping over a computer. They claimed a handful of quick exercises would unhunch my shoulders while I “tone my muscles” and “sculpt my physique.”

headline: ‘This Was Trump Pulling a Putin’
abstract: Amid the current crisis, Fiona Hill and other former advisers are connecting President Trump’s pressure campaign on Ukraine to Jan. 6. And they’re ready to talk.
lead_paragraph: Fiona Hill vividly recalls the first time she stepped into the Oval Office to discuss the thorny subject of Ukraine with the president. It was February of 2008, the last year of George W. Bush’s administration. Hill, then the national intelligence officer for Russia and Eurasia for the National Intelligence Council, was summoned for a strategy session on the upcoming NATO summit in Bucharest, Romania. Among the matters up for discussion was the possibility of Ukraine and another former Soviet state, Georgia, beginning the process of obtaining NATO membership.

headline: China’s Echoes of Russia’s Alternate Reality Intensify Around the World
abstract: China’s officials and state media are increasingly parroting Russian propaganda organs on the war in Ukraine, undercutting U.S. and European diplomatic efforts, even after the killings in Bucha.
lead_paragraph: When Twitter put up a warning message atop a Russian government post denying civilian killings in Bucha, Ukraine, last week, China’s state media rushed to its defense. “On Twitter @mfa_russia’s statement on #Bucha got censored,” wrote Frontline, a Twitter account associated with China’s official English-language broadcaster, CGTN.

headline: The Shakespearean Tall Tale That Shaped How We See Starlings
abstract: Researchers debunked a long-repeated yarn that the common birds owe their North American beginnings to a 19th-century lover of the Bard. Maybe this ubiquitous bird’s story is ready for a reboot.
lead_paragraph: In 1890, a mustachioed eccentric named Eugene Schieffelin released a few dozen European starlings into New York City. His supposed goal? Introduce all the bird species mentioned in William Shakespeare’s plays to America.

headline: Descending Into Florida’s Underwater Caves
abstract: The world’s densest collection of freshwater springs is at the center of a slow-motion environmental tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Long before theme parks began sprouting from Orlando’s swamps, Florida’s freshwater springs were among the area’s main attractions.

headline: This Psychiatric Hospital Used to Chain Patients. Now It Treats Them.
abstract: Sierra Leone, one of the world’s poorest countries, is working to build a modern mental health system from scratch.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — For centuries, they called the foreboding building on a hill above this capital city the Kissy Lunatic Asylum. It was built in the early 1800s by the British colonial administration, and behind the high walls, patients were kept in chains. People here say the stench seeped from the brick walls, and the screams of patients, whose psychosis and trauma were untreated by medication or therapy, echoed out the narrow, barred windows.

headline: A Flock of Beautiful Birds in a City Is a Miracle, a Disaster and a Conundrum
abstract: A vast flock of purple martins has made Nashville’s symphony center its staging ground for the fall migration. It’s not just the city’s problem. It’s a human problem.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In the summer of 2020, a massive flock of purple martins set up camp in the trees surrounding the Schermerhorn Symphony Center, in the heart of downtown Nashville. The birds had left their nesting territories, both nearby and farther north, and were gathering in preparation for the fall migration. They stayed for two months.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Qatar?
abstract: Can you find Qatar on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with a population of almost 3 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Qatar on a map? What else do you know about this Middle Eastern nation with a population of almost 3 million people?

headline: Bucha’s Month of Terror
abstract: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: We documented dozens of killings of civilians and interviewed scores of witnesses to uncover Russian atrocities in Ukraine.

headline: How Two Friends Beat Amazon and Built a Union
abstract: A conversation with the warehouse workers who created the e-commerce giant’s first union against all odds.
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Russia’s Reset
abstract: A violent weekend in Ukraine shows how Russia’s goals are shifting.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s attacks on Ukrainian civilians and soldiers in recent days have made clear that its withdrawal from northern Ukraine is more an attempt to reset Vladimir Putin’s invasion than a full retreat. The focus now is on the battle for eastern Ukraine, where Russian forces have deployed brutal tactics.

headline: Why car prices are keeping pressure on high inflation.
abstract: Car prices have helped push inflation sharply higher over the past year, and economists have been counting on them to level off and even decline in 2022, allowing the rising Consumer Price Index to moderate markedly.
lead_paragraph: Car prices have helped push inflation sharply higher over the past year, and economists have been counting on them to level off and even decline in 2022, allowing the rising Consumer Price Index to moderate markedly.

headline: Elon Musk Backs Out
abstract: The world’s wealthiest man decided not to join Twitter’s board after all.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, we learned that Elon Musk had purchased a big stake in Twitter. Shortly after, the billionaire chief of Tesla — and Twitter power user — was invited to join the social media company’s board.

headline: 60 Seconds with Rachel Simon
abstract: A chat with one of the New York Times Crossword constructors.
lead_paragraph: I love how crossword puzzles continually teach me new things — whether it’s an uncommon word, a fun fact, or a little-known piece of history.

headline: These Photographers Chase New Zealand’s Glowing Waves
abstract: Capturing bioluminescence, a phenomenon in which glowing algae give crashing waves an electric blue glow, requires technical skill and a bit of luck.
lead_paragraph: On hot, moonless nights in New Zealand, they fan out across beaches in search of an elusive, shimmering quarry.

headline: A Conversation With Gov. Gavin Newsom of California
abstract: He talked with The Times about why he thinks the Golden State needs to push back against a national wave of conservative legislation.
lead_paragraph: When Rick Perry was governor of Texas in 2013, he made headlines for his repeated attempts to woo businesses away from California. Perry, a Republican, showed up in Sacramento and bought radio ads decrying California’s taxes and regulations.

headline: What You Get for $1.9 Million in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern home in Rancho Mirage, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1954 ranch house in St. Helena.
lead_paragraph: A midcentury-modern home in Rancho Mirage, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1954 ranch house in St. Helena.

headline: $1.9 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern home in Rancho Mirage, a two-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1954 ranch house in St. Helena.
lead_paragraph: This house was designed by Richard Leitch, a U.S.C.-trained architect who worked extensively in California’s desert resort cities during the mid-20th century. The home, which has been featured in a number of films and magazines, was renovated by the current owner, who updated it while maintaining its historic character, salvaging original details wherever possible.

headline: Shehbaz Sharif Becomes Pakistan’s New Prime Minister Amid Turmoil
abstract: Mr. Sharif, whose family has been dogged by accusations of graft for decades, was selected by Pakistan’s Parliament at a time of deep political divisions and economic tumult.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Parliament selected the opposition leader Shehbaz Sharif to become the country’s prime minister on Monday, ushering in a new government after the ouster of Imran Khan and capping a week of political turmoil that pushed the fragile democracy to the brink.

headline: With Threats All Around, Japan Moves to Shed Its Pacifist Constraints
abstract: Growing calls for more military spending after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine demonstrate Japan’s recognition that it must bolster its own deterrent power, not just rely on its U.S. alliance.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Late in February, just days after the Russian invasion, Ukraine asked Japan to ship an assortment of military equipment, from antitank weapons and ammunition to electronic radar and bulletproof vests.

headline: Japan’s Perfect Game Drought Ends With a 19-Strikeout Masterpiece
abstract: Roki Sasaki, 20, pitched the first perfect game in Nippon Professional Baseball in 28 years. But don’t expect to see him in M.L.B. anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: Roki Sasaki’s perfect game was a long time coming, the first in the Japanese majors since 1994. But the wait turned out to be worth it. Sasaki struck out 19 of the 27 men he faced, completing what would have to be described as one of the greatest games ever pitched.

headline: A One-Woman Rescue Squad for Homeless Students
abstract: The work of Norma Mercado, a Texas school system’s point person for dealing with homeless young people, is benefiting from a big but temporary surge in federal funding.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: What It’s Like to Compete at a Crossword Puzzle Tournament
abstract: A Wordplay columnist’s diary from one of the biggest solving events of the year.
lead_paragraph: Nothing could have prepared me for the 2022 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament — not the 2006 documentary “Wordplay”; not reading up on the history and lore of the event; certainly not my participation in the virtual A.C.P.T., which replaced the in-person event in 2021. From the surreal joy of meeting hundreds of other crossword lovers in real life to the sound of hundreds of solvers flipping their puzzles faceup at the same time, this year’s A.C.P.T. was an amazing experience.

headline: A Wooden Knife Sharper Than Steel? Scientists Say So.
abstract: Knives are humanity’s oldest tool, dating back millions of years. A group of scientists in Maryland have produced a version made of hardened wood, which they say is sharper than steel.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 years ago in “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” Julia Child, one of America’s most emulated chefs, described the necessity of decent, reliable kitchen equipment.

headline: Gosar, Far-Right Incumbent, Faces G.O.P. Challengers in Arizona
abstract: Casting themselves as alternatives to a polarizing lawmaker, these candidates could reveal a window into the Republican electorate.
lead_paragraph: KINGMAN, Ariz. — Inside a flag-covered roadside pizzeria, Robert Hall slings dough with a handgun on his hip and his politics on his sleeve. He says the southern border is overrun and the 2020 election was stolen — views that would normally make a voter like him a lock to re-elect his staunchly conservative congressman, Representative Paul Gosar.

headline: Here’s how much it is costing companies to leave Russia.
abstract: Companies are announcing the financial hits from pulling business out.
lead_paragraph: A slew of companies have announced plans to stop business in Russia over the last several weeks, and many of them are now sharing what those decisions may cost them.

headline: Introducing The New York Times Corps: A New Program
abstract: Seeking to cultivate journalism’s next generation, The New York Times Corps is a talent-pipeline program for U.S.-based college students from underrepresented groups.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to cultivate journalism’s next generation, The New York Times Corps is a talent-pipeline program for U.S.-based college students from underrepresented groups.

headline: Doctors, Attend to Your Mental Health
abstract: Removing the stigma from mental health care for doctors. Also: War crimes in Ukraine; the “Don’t Say Gay” law; baseball signs; Alcoholics Anonymous.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Janelle James Loves Being a Bad Boss in ‘Abbott Elementary’
abstract: The comedian talks about her breakout acting role as a hilariously terrible elementary school principal in the hit ABC sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Janelle James had no desire to be a TV actress. For years, she was content building a career in stand-up, landing the occasional writing gig or minor onscreen role.

headline: The London Deli Salad
abstract: A layer of crunchy dukkah over tender beans, peas and herbs makes for quite the mezze.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Yotam Ottolenghi joined The New York Times Magazine last week as an “Eat” columnist. For his first column, he wrote about the merits of hot and cold foods, and explored the concept of salad as practiced in his London delis. He gave us a recipe to go along with the prose, for a butter-bean salad with peas, herbs and pistachio dukkah (above).

headline: An Upper East Side Market Gets Serious About Gluten-Free Foods
abstract: A new location of Agata & Valentina takes inspiration from stores in Italy and has a gluten-free kitchen.
lead_paragraph: The Valentina half of the Upper East Side fancy food market Agata & Valentina is Agata Musco’s daughter, Valentina Puleo. She is gluten intolerant, with Celiac disease, hence the attention to gluten-free items in a new store opening Thursday across the street from the original. Ms Puleo and Ms. Musco did their homework in Italy, where gluten-free stores are prevalent. At their new store, prepared foods, pastries, breads and pastas are made on the premises in a kitchen totally free of gluten. There will be limited seating, a fresh pizza station, a coffee bar and a grab-and-go section with sandwiches, grain salads and bagels. Groceries, dried pasta, crackers, ice cream, some frozen foods and more will be available. The store will have some packaged kosher-for-Passover, gluten-free items and Easter pastries made in-house.

headline: Calabrian Chile Flakes to Use With Abandon
abstract: Boonville Barn Collective’s chile has a balanced heat that perks up pizza and pasta.
lead_paragraph: Freshness counts with dried crushed chile flakes: Look for bright red shards with an oily sheen, and more vibrancy on the palate. The new Boonville Barn Collective Calabrian Chile Flakes, from the 2021 fall harvest, deliver an almost floral aroma and balanced, lingering heat with a whisper of sweetness. Use with abandon on pizza, in linguine with clams, even over steamed lobster. The Northern California company was previously called Piment d’Ville, and is known for Espelette chile powder. Krissy Scommegna and Gideon Burdick took over ownership and gave it a new name in 2020, and expanded the inventory with assorted whole dried chiles and chile powders, all from chiles that they grow. I only wish the spices came in metal tins instead of transparent jars.

headline: Embrace the Bittersweet With Centerbe, From Faccia Brutto
abstract: The Brooklyn company released another spirit made with organic herbs, botanicals and spices.
lead_paragraph: Faccia Brutto, the line of organic aperitivos and digestivos inspired by Italy and made in Brooklyn by Patrick Miller, a former executive chef of Rucola, has just added Centerbe. It’s made with organic herbs, other botanicals and spices. The name is that of a spirit from Abruzzo, meaning “100 herbs.” Mr. Miller stopped at 20. The pale green color suggests a comparison with Chartreuse, but it’s more bittersweet and less syrupy. It’s a pleasing digestif on its own over ice; a splash of it tones down the sweetness in a Last Word cocktail and sneaks some herbal punch into a gimlet.

headline: Plant-Based Pastry Dough From Dufour Pastry Kitchens
abstract: The Bronx company has introduced a vegan option made with flour, water, sea salt and what the company calls “ethically-sourced palm fruit oil.”
lead_paragraph: Dufour Pastry Kitchens, the standard-bearer for frozen butter-based puff pastry dough, now offers a vegan option. The Bronx company, founded in 1985 by Judi Arnold, who died in January at 86, and Carla Krasner, has introduced a plant-based version made with flour, water, sea salt and what the company calls “ethically-sourced palm fruit oil.” It’s easy to handle and bakes up with nice flakiness for preparations like fruit tarts, hors d’oeuvres and mushroom Wellington (trading butter in the recipe for olive oil and omitting any egg wash).

headline: The Trick to Matzo Balls Is Bubbles
abstract: Seltzer keeps them light, but beer, cider or even Champagne can do the trick.
lead_paragraph: Some recipes for matzo balls call for seltzer instead of plain water. It’s an old grandma device to keep them light. So when my granddaughter Julia Fabricant craved matzo balls for the batch of chicken stock she made while quarantining at home from college last winter, she asked for a recipe; mine included seltzer. Though she had matzo meal in the pantry, there was no seltzer in the house. So she improvised and used beer with fine results, but kosher for Passover beer is hard to find. “How about cider?” she suggested. “Or Champagne,” I replied. It works. I’m swapping kosher for Passover sparkling wine for seltzer this year.

headline: A Spring Vegetable Matzo Brei From Breads Bakery
abstract: The store has introduced a new version with spring peas and other vegetables, made in eight-inch rounds like crustless quiches.
lead_paragraph: Matzo brei, a scramble of eggs and broken matzo that’s often a Passover breakfast staple, can be given a loftier assignment at the Seder table. If your observance is not strictly kosher for Passover, you might consider Breads Bakery’s matzo brei to serve alongside the chicken or brisket. They have been making it with mushrooms for several years and now has a version made with spring peas and other vegetables. In eight-inch rounds, like crustless quiches, they serve four to six but are not kosher. Warm them before serving. They are available for pickup at Breads Bakery near Union Square, Lincoln Center and the Upper East Side.

headline: After Upheaval, MOCA Bets on Johanna Burton to Bring Stability
abstract: She is the fifth person since 2008 to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, an important institution that has faced a great deal of turmoil.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Museum of Contemporary Art, with its enviable collection, has long been a symbol of California’s flourishing arts scene, and it helped spur the resurgence of a once barren patch of downtown Los Angeles. But waves of management upheaval have damaged its reputation and raised questions about its prospects at a time when arts groups all over the country are struggling to regain their footing after the disruptions of the pandemic.

headline: The Bust Economy Is Booming
abstract: Interest in busts has grown as the art form, once accessible to a wealthy few, has become more democratic than ever.
lead_paragraph: Meet Glenda. She has wisps of gold in her white hair, melatonin-drooped eyes and a tragic lack of torso.

headline: As Remote Work Becomes Permanent, Can Manhattan Adapt?
abstract: With more companies adopting hybrid work, New York City’s economy, which relies on commuters and full office buildings, faces an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: PwC, a global consulting firm with its American headquarters in New York City, has told 40,000 of its United States employees that they can work remotely forever. Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan, a white-shoe law firm with about 300 lawyers in New York, is allowing its staff to live anywhere in the country.

headline: Red Hot Chili Peppers Top Chart With ‘Unlimited Love’
abstract: The band reunites with its former guitarist, John Frusciante, and the producer Rick Rubin for its latest album.
lead_paragraph: Everything aligned for Red Hot Chili Peppers’ latest album, “Unlimited Love,” which has opened at No. 1 on the Billboard chart, the band’s second time at the top.

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Plain White Wedding Gown
abstract: As couples seek to plan nuptials that feel more personal, many are eschewing tradition. But this may be the most visible break yet.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Arasevi had no intention to follow custom when it came to choosing a wedding dress.

headline: Arbitrator Clears Buffalo Police Officers Who Shoved Protester
abstract: A video from June 2020 showed Martin Gugino, 75 at the time, motionless and bleeding after being pushed to the ground. The footage fueled outrage during a summer of unrest over police violence.
lead_paragraph: Two Buffalo police officers who shoved a 75-year-old man to the ground during a protest in 2020 have been cleared by an arbitrator, who said the use of force was “absolutely legitimate” because the man, who was hospitalized with a head injury, was “not an innocent bystander.”

headline: Tove Ditlevsen’s Fiction Is Bleak and Claustrophobic — Mostly in a Good Way
abstract: In “The Trouble With Happiness” and “The Faces,” the Danish writer who found posthumous English-language fame with “The Copenhagen Trilogy” writes about women who struggle and settle.
lead_paragraph: Tove Ditlevsen’s “The Copenhagen Trilogy” was one of last year’s major books. It’s a set of three slim memoirs — “Childhood,” “Youth” and “Dependency” — originally published in her native Denmark between 1967 and 1971. They’re told simply but are brutal and lonely, lonely, lonely. It’s as if Ditlevsen were probing a series of aching tooth cavities.

headline: Despite Low Turnout, Mexico Voters Back President to Stay in Office
abstract: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador drew overwhelming support among those who cast ballots, but the recall referendum failed to achieve the required 40 percent threshold to be binding.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Pitched by the president as a landmark exercise for Mexico’s democracy, Sunday’s recall referendum gave voters the chance to remove their head of state from office for the first time.

headline: With India on the fence over Ukraine, Biden meets with Modi.
abstract: India, heavily dependent on Russian weapons, has long tried not to take sides between Moscow and Washington. It has refrained from denouncing Russia’s invasion or imposing sanctions.
lead_paragraph: President Biden emphasized growing defense cooperation with India in a virtual meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Monday — a line U.S. officials have increasingly touted in the hopes of convincing New Delhi to come off the fence over Russia’s war on Ukraine.

headline: Psilocybin Spurs Brain Activity in Patients With Depression, Small Study Shows
abstract: The chemical derived from psychedelic mushrooms helped alleviate symptoms of depression and generated detectable neural responses that lasted weeks.
lead_paragraph: Psychedelic compounds like LSD, Ecstasy and psilocybin mushrooms have shown significant promise in treating a range of mental health disorders, with participants in clinical studies often describing tremendous progress taming the demons of post-traumatic stress disorder, or finding unexpected calm and clarity as they face a terminal illness.

headline: A New Writing Job Brings Change
abstract: I’ll continue to address how economics shapes the politics that frame our culture — and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: I was a little nervous when I started publishing this newsletter some six months ago. I knew how to write for the public. From essays to tweets to blogs, I have been writing for almost 20 years. I came to this venture with a pretty clear idea of what a newsletter is: a subgenre, somewhere between an essay and a blog. My version of the newsletter has been open-ended and process-oriented. It takes an audience of curious and brave readers to make this kind of newsletter work. I was nervous about finding that kind of audience at The Times, where so many readers come for the final version of things, as opposed to the drafts that help us make sense of things.

headline: Benedict Lombe Wins the Blackburn Prize for ‘Lava’
abstract: The British Congolese playwright earned the $25,000 prize for her memoir-monologue that deals with Black identity and displacement.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in the 44-year history of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, awarded annually to a female, transgender or nonbinary playwright who writes for the English-language theater, the honor has gone to the writer of a debut play.

headline: Email Is Slow and Creates Distance. That’s Why It’s Great.
abstract: In defense of a dinosaur.
lead_paragraph: Every morning around 9 o’clock, I walk down a narrow flight of stairs to my basement and fire up my work computer. It is a profoundly stupid machine — a PC with a glass outer case, flashing lights and a graphics card that was state-of-the-art back in 2018. The process of starting my day involves signing into three chat clients — Slack, Telegram and Discord — and clicking through any notification bubbles that might have popped up in the three minutes that have passed since I last checked those same apps on my phone.

headline: Globalization Isn’t Over. It’s Changing.
abstract: Cross-border trade and investment remain surprisingly strong.
lead_paragraph: “Deglobalization” is a word on many people’s lips these days — and understandably so. Russia has been largely cut off from the West for its appalling invasion of Ukraine. The economic marriage of convenience between China and the United States (“Chimerica”) is unraveling. And there’s more and more talk about reshoring — producing more stuff at home — either for national security reasons or to avoid future supply-chain disruptions such as those caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

headline: The city of Philadelphia will reinstate an indoor mask mandate, the first major U.S. city to do so this spring.
abstract: The move comes a little more than a month after the city lifted it.
lead_paragraph: With new coronavirus cases low but rising sharply in recent days, the city of Philadelphia announced on Monday that it will reinstate an indoor mask mandate a little more than a month after lifting it, becoming the first major U.S. city to do so.

headline: Legal Marijuana Sales Expected to Start Within Weeks in New Jersey
abstract: A state commission has granted seven medical-marijuana companies permission to start selling cannabis to all adults at 13 dispensaries.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half after New Jersey residents voted to legalize cannabis, the state on Monday gave seven medical-marijuana companies approval to start selling their products to all adults, opening the door to the first legal marijuana sales in the New York City region within a month.

headline: Virus outbreaks are pushing some U.S. universities to reinstate mask mandates.
abstract: A handful of U.S. colleges and universities are reverting to the past pandemic protocol because of rising cases on campuses.
lead_paragraph: A small number of U.S. colleges and universities are reinstating mask policies, citing coronavirus outbreaks on campus. The moves come at a time when the highly transmissible Omicron subvariant, known as BA.2, has become the dominant version among new U.S. cases, which are ticking up.

headline: New Drug Slashed Deaths Among Patients With Severe Covid, Maker Claims
abstract: A late-stage trial was halted after strong early results, according to the company, but the data have not yet been published or peer-reviewed.
lead_paragraph: An experimental drug halved the death rate among critically ill Covid patients who were receiving supplemental oxygen and were at high risk for serious lung disease and death, the drug’s developer announced on Monday.

headline: New York Lets ‘Fearless Girl’ Hold Her Ground, for Now
abstract: Officials voted to extend the sculpture’s permit but are requiring stakeholders to return in six months with plans for a permanent location.
lead_paragraph: The popular “Fearless Girl” sculpture will continue to stand outside the New York Stock Exchange after city officials voted on Monday to extend the sculpture’s temporary permit for 11 months. This decision comes with the stipulation that the city, the owner of the sculpture and the artist return in six months with a process for deciding the artwork’s ultimate fate.

headline: Macron Sets Out to Build a ‘Dam’ Against Le Pen. Can It Hold?
abstract: After Sunday’s vote, when nearly a third of ballots went to the extreme right, a united front of mainstream voters looked more precarious than ever.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A day after Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader, emerged as his challenger for the final round of France’s presidential election in less than two weeks, President Emmanuel Macron immediately set about on Monday to build the “dam.”

headline: Britney Spears, Out of Conservatorship, Says ‘I Am Having a Baby’
abstract: During her successful effort to end her conservatorship, the performer had complained that the team appointed to supervise her had blocked her from having additional children.
lead_paragraph: Months after Britney Spears was released from the conservatorship that she said was restricting her from having a third child, the pop star announced Monday in an Instagram post that she is pregnant.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Documenting Russia’s Terror Campaign
abstract: Plus, Japan takes a step away from its pacifist identity and South Korea eases restrictions.
lead_paragraph: A mother killed by a sniper while walking with her family to fetch a thermos of tea. A woman held as a sex slave, naked except for a fur coat and locked in a potato cellar before being executed. Two sisters dead in their home, their bodies left slumped on the floor for weeks.

headline: PG&E agrees to pay $55 million in penalties and costs over two wildfires.
abstract: The California utility settled civil charges and avoided criminal prosecution over the role of its equipment in igniting the blazes.
lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas & Electric agreed on Monday to pay $55 million in penalties and costs to settle civil cases brought by prosecutors over wildfires across six Northern California counties.

headline: Biden Announces Gun Control Measures and A.T.F. Nominee
abstract: President Biden unveiled new restrictions to curb the spread of “ghost guns” during an event to announce his nomination of Steven M. Dettelbach, a former federal prosecutor, to run the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.
lead_paragraph: President Biden unveiled new restrictions to curb the spread of “ghost guns” during an event to announce his nomination of Steven M. Dettelbach, a former federal prosecutor, to run the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

headline: Sikhs Sue Marine Corps Over Restrictions on Beards
abstract: The Marine Corps says it needs uniformity, especially during boot camp, and that beards pose risks. Sikhs say the rules are arbitrary and needlessly burden religious liberty.
lead_paragraph: A Marine artillery captain named Sukhbir Singh Toor has been on a mission over the past year to become the first Sikh in the United States Marine Corps allowed to openly practice his religion while in uniform.

headline: Twitter Grapples With an Elon Musk Problem
abstract: Mr. Musk, Twitter’s biggest shareholder, is free to buy more stock in the company and could use the platform against itself. Some employees are dismayed.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

headline: A Mentalist Sets a Central Park Running Record (Just as He Foresaw)
abstract: Oz Pearlman, better known as Oz the Mentalist, ran 19 loops of Central Park — 116 miles — in a single day.
lead_paragraph: Before sunrise last Friday, Oz Pearlman loosened up in front of Engineers’ Gate, one of the entrances to Central Park. He rubbed up his thighs and underarms with petroleum jelly, then peeled off his toe socks and coated his feet. This would not be a typical weekday morning jaunt through Manhattan’s preferred and most storied running terrain.

headline: Russia’s Buildup in the East
abstract: Satellite images show a column of Russian military vehicles moving toward the new front.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Tell Us Your Antiviral Story
abstract: We may feature your response in the Coronavirus Briefing newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Antiviral medications to treat Covid are becoming more common. Last month, the Biden administration announced its “test to treat” initiative, aimed at providing patients with the medications as soon as they learn they are infected.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Books That Make Us Think of Home: A Virtual Times Conversation
abstract: In a live audio conversation, the writer Saeed Jones joined Times editors and readers to discuss favorite books about home.
lead_paragraph: What are the books that bring to mind a place where you have lived? The books that give you a sense of community, create comfort or make you feel like you belong? The books that make you consider what home actually means?

headline: Ukraine Benefit Featuring Russian Ensemble Is Canceled in Vienna
abstract: Organizers said they canceled a performance by MusicAeterna after the Ukrainian ambassador in Austria expressed concern about featuring Russian artists.
lead_paragraph: A planned benefit concert in support of Ukraine was canceled in Vienna on Monday amid concerns about the Russian-based ensemble it was to feature, MusicAeterna, which is led by the conductor Teodor Currentzis and is supported by a state-owned bank in Russia.

headline: No More ‘Have a Nice Day’: Lviv Learns to Live With War
abstract: Ukraine’s cultural capital, the western city of Lviv, is trying to adjust to being on the fringes of war and at the center of massive displacement.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — When war came to Ukraine in February, Helen Polishchuk made some adjustments in the six-story bar she manages in central Lviv.

headline: Biden Urges Modi Not to Increase India’s Reliance on Russian Oil and Gas
abstract: The United States hopes to convince India to come off the fence over Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but New Delhi and Moscow have deep historic ties.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday urged Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India not to increase his country’s reliance on Russian oil and gas, officials said, part of a global effort by the United States to maintain economic pressure on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.

headline: A Spring Uptick, or Just Some Notable Positive Cases?
abstract: Cases are rising and a formal dinner seeded political infections, but public health officials urged calm.
lead_paragraph: Eric Adams, the mayor of New York City, is the latest major political figure to test positive for the coronavirus. Adams is fully vaccinated, has received one booster shot and says he is experiencing very mild symptoms.

headline: Patricia MacLachlan, ‘Sarah, Plain and Tall’ Author, Dies at 84
abstract: A best-selling children’s book writer, she focused on family life and its difficulties, earning acclaim for her gentle, spare prose.
lead_paragraph: Patricia MacLachlan, the celebrated author of children’s books, including the best-selling “Sarah, Plain and Tall,” about a young woman who moves to a pioneer homestead to join a widower and his children, died on March 31 at her home in Williamsburg, Mass. She was 84.

headline: Far From Defeated, Putin Intends to Escalate War in Ukraine
abstract: Austria’s chancellor said after meeting with Mr. Putin that the Russian president had “totally adopted the logic of war.”
lead_paragraph: Austria’s chancellor visited President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday — the first Western leader to see him in person since the Ukraine invasion — and said he came away feeling not only pessimistic about peace prospects but fearing that Mr. Putin intended to drastically intensify the brutality of the war.

headline: The Boston Symphony cancels its European tour over virus concerns.
abstract: The orchestra has also reported a surge in cases among its players.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Symphony Orchestra announced on Monday that it was canceling a four-city tour of Europe because of concerns about the spread of the coronavirus in Europe and the United States.

headline: How a Little-Known Democrat Tries to Hold On
abstract: Representative Tom O’Halleran of Arizona is seeking re-election as his district leans further toward Trump. His strategy? Don’t change. “I am,” he says, “who I am.”
lead_paragraph: Arizona has a history of producing lightning-rod members of Congress, like Representative Paul Gosar. But the Arizona politician you should be paying attention to — and who can potentially tell us a great deal about Democrats’ hopes of avoiding a 2022 wipeout in the House — probably isn’t on your radar.

headline: Trade and Peace: The Great Illusion
abstract: Sometimes globalization ends up empowering autocracy.
lead_paragraph: On April 12, 1861, rebel artillery opened fire on Fort Sumter, beginning the U.S. Civil War. The war eventually became a catastrophe for the South, which lost more than a fifth of its young men. But why did the secessionists believe they could pull it off?

headline: Zelensky says Ukraine takes ‘as seriously as possible’ an apparent threat of Russian chemical weapon use.
abstract: A Ukrainian unit in Mariupol claimed Russian forces had used chemical weapons there. Their report could not be independently confirmed.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in his latest address seized on an apparent Russian threat to use chemical weapons against the remaining defenders of Mariupol, as they prepare for what he called a “new stage of terror against Ukraine.”

headline: The Unbelievable Stupidity of Ending Global Covid Aid
abstract: Republican intransigence could help incubate a new variant.
lead_paragraph: America’s attempt to vaccinate the world against Covid is about to come to an end.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Star Colin Jost Takes a Spin on Ferryboat He Bought With Pete Davidson
abstract: After buying the retired Staten Island ferry at auction in January, the new owners rode it into New York Harbor en route to a temporary home.
lead_paragraph: Colin Jost, one of the stars of “Saturday Night Live,” has ridden the Staten Island Ferry across New York Harbor many times. But Monday he rode one for the first time as its owner.

headline: W.N.B.A. Draft: Kentucky’s Rhyne Howard Goes No. 1 to Dream
abstract: Howard, a senior guard, was the top pick after Atlanta made a deal with the Washington Mystics to move up in the draft.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta Dream, looking for a versatile player to help rebuild their roster, selected guard Rhyne Howard from the University of Kentucky as the No. 1 pick in the W.N.B.A. draft on Monday at Spring Studios in New York.

headline: Woman Pleads Guilty to Tackling Black Teen at SoHo Hotel
abstract: Miya Ponsetto admitted to committing a hate crime in the 2020 episode, parts of which were captured in a widely seen video.
lead_paragraph: A California woman who tackled a Black teenager at a SoHo hotel after falsely accusing him of stealing her cellphone pleaded guilty on Monday to a felony hate crime charge stemming from the altercation. Parts of it were captured in a widely seen video.

headline: Donors Pledge $41 Million to Monitor Thawing Arctic Permafrost
abstract: The six-year effort by climate scientists and policy experts aims to fill gaps in knowledge about planet-warming emissions and help affected communities in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Climate scientists, policy experts and environmental justice advocates on Monday announced a major project to better understand the contribution of thawing permafrost to global warming and to help Arctic communities cope with its effects.

headline: Corrections: April 12, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 12, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about efforts to save Florida’s starving manatees misstated where some of them went for the winter. It was northwest of the Indian River Lagoon, not northeast of it.

headline: Alaska Man Who Threatened to Kill U.S. Senators Gets Nearly 3 Years in Prison
abstract: Prosecutors said that Jay Allen Johnson left 17 threatening and expletive-laden voicemails over five months for Senators Lisa Murkowski and Dan Sullivan, both of Alaska.
lead_paragraph: An Alaska man who pleaded guilty to threatening to murder two U.S. senators has been sentenced to 32 months in prison and a $5,000 fine.

headline: Review: ‘The Little Prince,’ a Lumbering Circus
abstract: A stage version of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s classic of children’s literature lands on Broadway but remains stubbornly earthbound.
lead_paragraph: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s “The Little Prince,” a megaselling classic of children’s literature first published in 1943, begins with a crash landing. Now, an adaptation of the beloved tale has made a similarly unfortunate entrance on Broadway.

headline: As U.S. cases tick up, the new White House Covid czar says it’s not a moment to be ‘excessively concerned.’
abstract: The official, Dr. Ashish Jha, said hospitalizations remained very low and that officials were monitoring the trajectory of the virus closely.
lead_paragraph: The new White House Covid-19 response coordinator, Dr. Ashish K. Jha, said Monday that while there had been a recent uptick in new U.S. coronavirus cases, he was not overly concerned.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ballets, Bars and Bomb Scares: Lviv Learns to Live With War
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 12, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “If people day by day are faced with sad news about death, about blood, about bombs, they need to feel other emotions.”

headline: Driving Force
abstract: Dan Schoenholz’s puzzle is a job well done.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Some crossword constructors really excel at themeless puzzles, which typically run on Fridays and Saturdays. These puzzle makers focus on long entries that are fresh and exciting, and they emphasize cluing. For other constructors, the driving force behind their grids is an uncanny ability to generate clever wordplay-based themes and theme sets.

headline: Karl-Anthony Towns and the ‘Swaggy’ Timberwolves Are Ready
abstract: Towns, the Timberwolves center, said he’s never doubted himself and now he has the right team behind him. “Whatever it takes to win, we will do as a team,” he said.
