lead_paragraph: Karl-Anthony Towns has rarely experienced the kind of professional joy he has had this season.

headline: These 8 Conservative Men Are Making No Apologies
abstract: A group of conservative men spoke with Times Opinion about what it’s like to be a man in America today, touching on cancel culture, race and gender.
lead_paragraph: There was no talk of a stolen election, no conspiracy theories about voter fraud or rants about President Biden’s legitimacy. Yet listening to our 90-minute focus group with eight conservative men, you couldn’t help but worry for our democracy a bit.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Russian plans for a new assault on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: After meeting with Vladimir Putin yesterday, Karl Nehammer, the Austrian chancellor, said he feared that the Russian president intended to drastically intensify the brutality of the war. “The battle being threatened cannot be underestimated in its violence,” Nehammer said.

headline: Word of the Day: apprehensive
abstract: This word has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word apprehensive has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 17 in “Curling Drifts to the East, Where Rock Stars Are Being Born” by Sui-Lee Wee and Makiko Inoue:

headline: Where the Ice Is Still Abundant, These Penguins Are, Too
abstract: The western side of the Antarctic Peninsula has seen sharp declines in Adélie penguin populations in recent decades. Things look better on the eastern side. Take a tour.
lead_paragraph: Adélie penguins have had a rough time of it on the western side of the Antarctic Peninsula, where warming linked to climate change has occurred faster than almost anywhere else on the planet. That and other factors have led to sharp declines in Adélie populations in recent decades.

headline: Name, phone, address: The writing on a child’s back is now a symbol of Ukrainian parents’ terror.
abstract: A mother who wrote emergency contact information on her 2-year-old’s back has become a voice for countless Ukrainian parents forced to do the same.
lead_paragraph: The mother’s hands were shaking when she started writing on her 2-year-old’s body. They trembled so much that she couldn’t write correctly on her first try, even though the information was second nature: Her daughter’s name, Vira, along with her birth date and their family phone numbers.

headline: Rites of Spring
abstract: What do you enjoy about this season? What do you do to mark it?
lead_paragraph: Spring has sprung across the Northern Hemisphere. If, where you live, flowers are blooming, birds are making nests and the weather is getting warmer, what does that mean for you?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Why City Pigeons Are Worth Watching
abstract: The humble Columba livia is much more than a rat with wings.

headline: Stephen Colbert Laughs Off Trump’s Shilling for Dr. Oz
abstract: “Come on, he’s a con man. And so is Dr. Oz,” Colbert joked of the former president.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘In the Ocean, It’s Snowing Microplastics’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn how tiny bits of plastic have infiltrated the deep sea’s main food source and could alter the ocean’s role in an ancient cooling process.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “In the Ocean, It’s Snowing Microplastics” by Sabrina Imbler

headline: The Taliban Promised Them Amnesty. Then They Were Executed.
abstract: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been carrying out revenge killings of former U.S. allies.
lead_paragraph: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been carrying out revenge killings of former U.S. allies.

headline: Delia Ephron’s Memoir Could Be Called ‘Love, Loss and Love Again’
abstract: In “Left on Tenth,” the veteran author looks back on a series of life-altering events, including a whirlwind romance at the age of 72.
lead_paragraph: LEFT ON TENTHA Second Chance at LifeBy Delia Ephron

headline: The Taliban Promised Them Amnesty. Then They Executed Them.
abstract: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been on a crusade of revenge killings against former U.S. allies.
lead_paragraph: An Opinion Video investigation reveals the Taliban have been on a crusade of revenge killings against former U.S. allies.

headline: The Appalling Treatment of a Prisoner at Guantánamo
abstract: “The Forever Prisoner,” by Cathy Scott-Clark and Adrian Levy, tells the story of a man who has been held captive by the C.I.A. for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: THE FOREVER PRISONERThe Full and Searing Account of the C.I.A.’s Most Controversial Covert ProgramBy Cathy Scott-Clark and Adrian Levy

headline: Shocking the Bourgeoisie With Iran’s Misunderstood Modernist
abstract: “Blind Owl,” by Sadeq Hedayat, is a hallucinatory short novel that upends Persian artistic traditions.
lead_paragraph: In April 1951, the police in Paris called on my great-grandfather, Prince Mohamed-Hussein Firouz, to identify a dead body. It was that of Sadeq Hedayat, who is today eulogized as Iran’s great literary modernist. Days before, Hedayat had sealed up the apartment on Rue Championnet where he was staying and opened up the oven’s gas valve before lying down on the kitchen floor.

headline: Margo Jefferson’s New Memoir Experiments With the Form in Startling Ways
abstract: Jefferson’s “Constructing a Nervous System,” a companion to her earlier “Negroland,” explores the materials used to make identity and art.
lead_paragraph: If Margo Jefferson had gone into another profession — cabinetmaking, let’s say — she’d be the type to draw and redraw plans for a cabinet, build and tinker with the cabinet, stand back to look at the cabinet from every angle, probe the purpose of woodworking, take a break to go examine 2,000 other cabinets, then disassemble her own product and start from scratch with alternative tools, creating an object that no longer resembled a cabinet but performed all the functions of one in startling ways.

headline: Where Do You Go to Find Cool, Strange or Fascinating Information on the Internet?
abstract: An Instagram account is dedicated to highlighting strange, obscure and interesting facts found on Wikipedia. Where do you go to find hidden gems on the internet?
lead_paragraph: Do you regularly visit Wikipedia? What kinds of things do you look up? Do you ever search for intriguing, funny or strange facts or trivia? For example, are you interested in discovering a political party dedicated to opposing the use of PowerPoint? Or learning about the world’s most unwanted song? Or maybe finding photos of a chicken — yes, simply crossing the road?

headline: Everything We Wanted to Know About David Shields (and Already Asked)
abstract: His new book is composed entirely of questions posed in interviews over his long career.
lead_paragraph: THE VERY LAST INTERVIEWBy David Shields

headline: Two Strangers Meet in a Cafe in Cairo. What Happens Next Is Complicated.
abstract: In “If an Egyptian Cannot Speak English,” Noor Naga explores the forces of identity, belonging and globalism, as they bear down on two new lovers.
lead_paragraph: IF AN EGYPTIAN CANNOT SPEAK ENGLISHBy Noor Naga

headline: A Nurse Finds Herself on the Other Side of the Equation — as a Patient
abstract: In her memoir, “Healing,” Theresa Brown recalls what she learned from her own treatment for breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: HEALINGWhen a Nurse Becomes a PatientBy Theresa Brown

headline: She’s a 12-Year-Old Girl and Also a Spirit That Can See Into Her Family’s Past
abstract: In her debut novel, “Things They Lost,” Okwiri Oduor uses magical realism to explore toxic mother-daughter relationships.
lead_paragraph: THINGS THEY LOSTBy Okwiri Oduor

headline: How to Ask for an Extension
abstract: If possible, make your request in person. And if you think you need two more hours, say you need four.
lead_paragraph: “If you think you’re going to turn in higher quality work if you have an extra day or two, you should proactively ask for more time,” says Ashley Whillans, an assistant professor at Harvard Business School who studies time and time poverty, a phenomenon she defines as “the feeling of having too many things to do and not enough time in the day to do them.” Some 80 percent of working adults report experiencing this time crunch. Asking for an extension is one way to alleviate some of that pressure.

headline: Should I Have Lied to Help My Kid Brother Get Vaccinated?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what we gain from making hard choices.
lead_paragraph: My brother is 16 and lives with my parents. I am in my 30s and live several hours away. We have good relationships with one another, although my parents are extremely anti-Covid vaccine and anti-mask. They cannot be reasoned with over the issue.

headline: A Ukrainian Philosopher on What Putin Never Understood About Ukraine
abstract: Volodymyr Yermolenko discusses how Russia’s invasion has reshaped Ukrainian identity.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is only getting more brutal: We’ve seen the bodies of civilians strewn in the streets in Bucha, the city of Mariupol almost leveled and, just a few days ago, a Russian missile attack on a crowded train station in Kramatorsk killing at least 50 people. The United Nations has confirmed 1,793 civilian deaths in Ukraine, though the actual number is thought to be far higher.

headline: Unraveling a High-Rise Horror Story
abstract: A tip about elevator breakdowns at a high-rise residential building in Lower Manhattan proved to be more than just griping.
lead_paragraph: Last month, when Karen Zraick, a Times reporter on the Metro desk, got a tip from a tenant of a Lower Manhattan residential building, she wasn’t sure it would result in an article. The tipster wrote that elevator service in the building had been spotty, at best, since the fall. But elevator outages are unfortunately fairly common in New York City, particularly in the city’s public housing complexes, Ms. Zraick thought.

headline: Is Driving High as Dangerous as Driving Drunk?
abstract: There’s limited data on how marijuana impacts driving performance, but experts urge caution before getting behind the wheel.
lead_paragraph: Q: I know all about the dangers of driving while drunk. But is driving while high on marijuana as dangerous?

headline: What’s Shame Got to Do With It?
abstract: How and why we confuse shame and stigma.
lead_paragraph: In the old comic strip “The Family Circus,” four precocious children blamed invisible goblins — “Not me,” “Nobody” and “Ida Know” — for their messes. In the real world, adults who should be too old for invisible friends are doing the same deflection with a goblin named “Shame!”

headline: Rabbits Are Boring Pets. I Love Them Anyway.
abstract: My friends and family don’t get it. All I can do is try to describe what it’s like to be with them, the moments I’m not sure I can do without.
lead_paragraph: Everyone who knew anything about animals warned me against getting a rabbit in my early 20s, but I ignored them, and ended up with three. I inherited my first from a housemate, and then found the other two online after moving to the Czech Republic: one came from a teenage girl with too many extracurricular activities, the other from an elderly man who lived at the top of a tower block on the outskirts of town. He’d kept her for three years in a cage designed for pet rats, feeding her bird food and slices of brown bread. When I took her to the local vet, I was told that my rabbit had uterine cancer and a whole set of other health problems that needed treating at once. I duly shelled out the cash and spent the next couple of months nursing her back to health.

headline: To Help Children, Democrats Are Going to Have to Reach Across the Aisle
abstract: A bipartisan child tax credit expansion may actually be within reach.
lead_paragraph: The expiration of the child tax credit expansion late last year sent an estimated 3.7 million children back into poverty and undermined the financial security of millions more. With the rising cost of living squeezing family budgets, the expiration of the credit could not have been more poorly timed.

headline: Why Is This Night Different? (See QR Code.)
abstract: Some shun phones at the Seder table. But, these days, some also welcome them.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the Lawrenceville School, a boarding and day school in New Jersey, has a large Passover Seder for students, family members, alumni and faculty. After doing the Seder remotely in 2020 and in a tent in 2021, they will be back inside this year.

headline: A Rise in Murders Upends a Sense of Progress in Brooklyn’s East Flatbush
abstract: The killing of a 12-year-old boy in the neighborhood captured how a spike in shootings during the pandemic is complicating recovery in less affluent neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: On March’s final evening, a stolen car made its fourth pass down a quiet Brooklyn block and slowed to a stop before a row of neat brick homes. A gunman braced in the sunroof, then opened fire on three cousins having dinner in a parked car.

headline: What It Will Mean as Europe Frees Itself From Russian Energy
abstract: Soaring energy prices may speed the continent’s move to a green energy future.
lead_paragraph: Europe has benefited from relatively cheap natural gas from Russia for decades. But for all the talk now of diversifying away from this supply, the plain reality is that it will not be easy to find alternatives. It will be a yearslong undertaking.

headline: On TV, the Truth Hurts
abstract: Television is hooked on scripted dramas based on real life. But they rarely measure up either to actual life or to actual drama.
lead_paragraph: As seen on the news, real life right now is heartbreaking, terrifying, depressing and exhausting. But as entertainment? Real life is hot, hot, hot, baby!

headline: Viola Davis, Inside Out
abstract: How she drew on a life of private hardship to become one of the greatest actors of her generation.
lead_paragraph: For a month, Viola Davis had been stuck. In the spring of 2020, in the late nights of lockdown, she set out to write her memoir. She had her routine: Get out of bed in the middle of the night, make herself a cup of tea, start writing in her movie room, fall asleep in one of its leather recliners, wake up, write some more, nod off again. But for weeks, she couldn’t figure out exactly where to begin. Should she start with her life as a celebrity, or the beauty contest she lost when she was a child, or the fact that people always wanted to hug her when they ran into her in public? Nothing worked.

headline: Yelp Will Pay for Employees to Travel for Abortion Access
abstract: The company has relatively few workers in Texas, which has the most restrictive abortion law.
lead_paragraph: Yelp announced on Tuesday that it would cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, becoming the latest company to respond to a Texas law that bans the procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy.

headline: China Sets Aside Push to Spread Wealth in Pivotal Year for Xi
abstract: Xi Jinping’s rhetoric about redistributing wealth was aimed partly at drumming up public support. But it unnerved entrepreneurs and posed a drag on growth.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For much of last year, China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, waged a fierce campaign to rein in private capital and narrow social inequalities. Regulators cracked down on tech giants and wealthy celebrities. Beijing demanded that tycoons give back to society. And the Communist Party promised that a new era of “common prosperity” was on the horizon.

headline: In the Shadow of the Border Wall, a Catholic Kitchen Provides Hope and a Hot Meal
abstract: La Tilma, a restaurant run by Sacred Heart Catholic Church in El Paso, nourishes the lives of many Mexican immigrants in poverty.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Twenty years ago, Amelia Lopez Patrykus stood outside Sacred Heart Catholic Church, waiting for a free meal and groceries. The line was just blocks from the Rio Grande, separating Mexico from her new home in the United States.

headline: New DNA Analysis Supports an Unrecognized Tribe’s Ancient Roots in California
abstract: A collaboration between researchers and the Muwekma Ohlone Tribe offers new evidence that their ancestors have lived in the Bay Area for thousands of years.
lead_paragraph: In “The Handbook of the Indians of California,” published in 1925, the anthropologist Alfred Kroeber pronounced the Ohlone people “extinct so far as all practical purposes are concerned,” noting that only “a few scattered individuals survive.”

headline: From the U.S. to China: A 3-Month Quarantine Horror Story
abstract: A lawyer flew home to China hoping to see his family for the first time since the pandemic began. Instead, he was trapped in three months of quarantine.
lead_paragraph: Before boarding his flight from Los Angeles to the Chinese city of Guangzhou, Xue Liangquan, a California-based lawyer, knew he was in for a bit of a headache.

headline: Angry Drivers, Lots of Guns: An Explosion in Road Rage Shootings
abstract: Dozens have been reported in Texas alone amid a pandemic surge in gun purchases and a country increasingly on edge.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The trouble started with an argument between two drivers merging in slow traffic after an Astros baseball game last summer. It ended with two gunshots, fired from a moving Buick and exploding through the glass of a fleeing Ford pickup truck.

headline: Red States Push L.G.B.T.Q. Restrictions as Education Battles Intensify
abstract: With an eye toward parents’ anxiety, Republicans have put forward a wave of laws on classroom instruction, youth sports and health care. Some of the young people at the center feel isolated.
lead_paragraph: Last April, a high school senior in Utah named Gabriela Merida joined a student town hall hosted by her governor. She introduced herself, noted the pronouns she used and broached the subject of mental health challenges facing young L.G.B.T.Q. people. How, she asked, did the state plan to help constituencies like hers?

headline: At Home With Joel Grey, in the West Village
abstract: The prolific actor, writer and photographer just turned 90, in a 1970s-style loft that speaks to his many passions.
lead_paragraph: The prolific actor, writer and photographer just turned 90, in a 1970s-style loft that speaks to his many passions.

headline: Joel Grey, on Making a Space for Art and Dreams
abstract: The prolific actor, writer and photographer just turned 90, in a 1970s-style West Village loft that speaks to his many passions.
lead_paragraph: Rain threatened on a recent Tuesday morning, and there was a chill in the air. But inside Joel Grey’s loft in Manhattan’s West Village, it was spring.

headline: This Beach in Mexico Is an L.G.B.T.Q. Haven. But Can It Last?
abstract: The town of Zipolite has become an oasis for the queer community. But as its popularity has surged, some worry that the town’s spirit is beginning to vanish.
lead_paragraph: ZIPOLITE, Mexico — When the sun starts to slip toward the ocean in this idyllic beach town on Mexico’s Pacific Coast, a quiet migration begins. Groups of people, most of them gay men, many of them naked, amble down the beach toward a soaring rocky outcrop.

headline: An Angry Public Wants Sri Lanka’s President Gone
abstract: Gotabaya Rajapaksa is used to silencing and discrediting his political opponents. But that’s harder to do this time.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — As Sri Lankans waited hours in line for fuel, sweated through the springtime heat during daily power cuts, and watched the value of their incomes erode, the president, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, blamed forces beyond his control.

headline: Inflation Hits Fastest Pace Since 1981, at 8.5% Through March
abstract: Gasoline weighed heavily in the increases, while prices moderated in several categories. Some economists say the overall rate may have peaked.
lead_paragraph: Inflation hit 8.5 percent in the United States last month, the fastest 12-month pace since 1981, as a surge in gasoline prices tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine added to sharp increases coming from the collision of strong demand and stubborn pandemic-related supply shortages.

headline: The Ups and Downs of Remote Work in New York
abstract: People like working in their pajamas. But when employees don’t return to office, the city economy feels the pain.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at how the pandemic is rewriting the people-in-offices model that sustained Manhattan for generations. And, a playwright who decided not to change the name of her play.

headline: Globally, inflation is surging amid persistent pandemic disruptions and war in Ukraine.
abstract: This may be the beginning of “a new inflationary era,” according to the Bank for International Settlements.
lead_paragraph: Just as in the United States, policymakers in other countries have been caught off guard by persistently high inflation. Price increases were expected to ease as economies recovered from the pandemic, but surging energy and food prices have continued to lift inflation around the world.

headline: Biden’s Climate Shift
abstract: The war in Ukraine has led the president to retreat on his ambitious climate policies.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail and when he first came to office, President Biden had ambitious plans to deal with climate change, including promises to reduce fossil fuel production.

headline: Covid in the Northeast
abstract: Cases are rising there, but it’s uncertain if it’s the beginning of a larger surge.
lead_paragraph: Covid outbreaks in elite circles in Washington, D.C., and on Broadway have received a lot of media attention in recent days, but they appear to be only one part of a broader regional rise in infections: States in the Northeast are now reporting an uptick in cases.

headline: Nokia joins Ericsson as telecom giants leave Russia.
abstract: The decisions by the two Nordic firms signal difficulties ahead for Russia’s ability to expand and maintain its telecommunications networks.
lead_paragraph: Nokia, whose telecommunications equipment plays an important role providing internet and communications in Russia, said on Tuesday that it was exiting the country because of the invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Black Artists Lead Turner Prize Shortlist
abstract: This year’s nominees include a sculptor, a photographer and an artist who created a 31-foot statue of a dollop of whipped cream, with a fly on it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ingrid Pollard, a pioneering Black female photographer, and Veronica Ryan, a Black sculptor who found widespread recognition in her 60s, are among the nominees for this year’s Turner Prize, the prestigious British visual arts award.

headline: Sri Lanka stops debt payments as economic crisis deepens.
abstract: The government seeks to ease financial pressure as foreign reserves plummet and prices for essential goods soar.
lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka suspended payments on its international debt Tuesday, effectively putting the small island nation in default as it plunges deeper into an economic crisis.

headline: Weekly News Quiz for Students: Ukraine Food Crisis, Supreme Court Confirmation, Asteroid Shards
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Chick Corea, the Master Mixer of Jazz’s Past and Future
abstract: An eclectic array of musicians will gather in New York to celebrate the pianist’s legacy. Five collaborators and admirers discuss his experiments, artistry and generosity.
lead_paragraph: When the groundbreaking pianist Chick Corea died unexpectedly, at 79, in February 2021, he left a legacy of experimentation, preserving and expanding the jazz tradition. Over more than a half-century, he deftly navigated the music’s continually shifting boundaries. Corea started his career playing with the Afro-Cuban percussionist Willie Bobo and spent time with the bossa nova stalwart Stan Getz. His presence in Miles Davis’s “Bitches Brew” ensemble, and later, his leading role in Return to Forever, gave him a seminal role in the origins of 1970s jazz fusion.

headline: Is Another Covid Surge Coming to California?
abstract: Coronavirus cases in the Golden State have increased by 18 percent over the past two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Rising coronavirus cases in the Northeast and the proliferation of the highly transmissible BA.2 subvariant raise the inevitable question: Is another Covid surge coming to California?

headline: More Companies Take a Stand on Abortion
abstract: Yelp is the latest to pay for employees to travel out of state for treatment, responding to a recent Texas law that bans abortions after six weeks.
lead_paragraph: Yelp, the online search and review platform, is expected to announce today that, beginning next month, it will cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, The Times’s Alisha Haridasani Gupta and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch report. It is the latest company to respond to the Texas law that bans abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy.

headline: Amid Soaring Demand for Warehouses, an Effort to Make Them Greener
abstract: Some owners are taking steps to make their buildings more energy efficient, including upgrading building materials and turning the rooftops into solar farms.
lead_paragraph: Warehouses and distribution centers, decidedly unsexy buildings, became hot in the coronavirus pandemic as online shopping accelerated the rise in e-commerce and set off a frenzy of buying and building the boxy, low-rise structures, pushing up rents and increasing returns for investors.

headline: Boris Johnson Fined for Breaking U.K. Lockdown Rules
abstract: The British prime minister had seemed to turn the “partygate” tide with his handling of Ukraine. Then came the announcement that he broke the law.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In recent weeks Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has revived his fortunes at home by becoming Europe’s most aggressive supporter of Ukraine’s fierce fight against Russian invasion.

headline: Lt. Gov. Benjamin Resigns Following Campaign Finance Indictment
abstract: Brian A. Benjamin, New York’s second in command to Gov. Kathy Hochul, was charged with bribery, fraud and falsification of records while a state senator.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Brian A. Benjamin of New York resigned on Tuesday, hours after federal prosecutors unsealed an indictment implicating him in a brazen scheme to enrich his political campaigns with illegal donations.

headline: Police named a ‘person of interest’ connected to the shooting.
abstract: The man had rented a U-Haul that the police found near where the gunman boarded the subway, the police said as they continued their search for the suspect.
lead_paragraph: The police in New York on Tuesday evening identified a man they called a “person of interest” in the mass shooting on a crowded subway train in Brooklyn during the morning rush earlier that day that injured nearly two dozen people, five of them critically.

headline: Biden will allow summertime sales of higher-ethanol gas.
abstract: The White House estimated that the move would allow Americans to save 10 cents a gallon at the approximately 2,300 stations in the country that offer the blend known as E15.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced on Tuesday a plan to suspend a ban on summertime sales of higher-ethanol gasoline blends, a move that White House officials said was aimed at reducing gas prices but that energy experts predicted would have only a marginal impact at the pump.

headline: Western powers look into an unverified claim of possible use of a chemical agent in Mariupol.
abstract: Ukrainian commanders said “a poisonous substance” caused respiratory difficulties and neurological symptoms in a handful of soldiers and civilians.
lead_paragraph: The United States, Britain and other Western allies, along with Ukraine’s government, are examining claims that Russia deployed a chemical agent that sickened a handful of people in Moscow’s unrelenting bid to gain complete control over the ruined Ukrainian city of Mariupol.

headline: Laurence Fishburne Cools Down With Classic Jazz and Cashmere Blankets
abstract: The actor is back on Broadway for a revival of David Mamet’s “American Buffalo.” He discusses his other must-haves, like a chef’s knife, trampolines and crystals.
lead_paragraph: “I have a working knowledge of what my gifts are,” Laurence Fishburne said. “I’ve been blessed with a wonderful voice. And I have a real innate sense of the dramatic.”

headline: Passing the Last Puzzle Piece to the Next Generation
abstract: Amid great loss, a tradition is carried on.
lead_paragraph: I barely remember the hours between my father’s death and my departure. There was chaos. Frantic planning. Deep, unimaginable grief. I packed as quickly as I could and kissed my children goodbye. I left before sunrise to drive 900 miles, straight to my childhood home — where my parents lived together for more than 50 years — so I could hug my mother and cry in her arms. There were devastating phone calls to make and things to sort. She needed help packing her own bags.

headline: Ukraine War Pushes Germans to Change. They Are Wavering.
abstract: In just six weeks since Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced a strategic shift for his country, already doubts are emerging about how real and deep it is.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Olaf Scholz surprised the world, and his own country, when he responded to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with a 100-billion-euro plan to arm Germany, send weapons to Ukraine and end his nation’s deep dependence on Russian energy.

headline: Tuesday’s shooting is reminiscent of a string of other attacks in recent years.
abstract: Mass shootings in New York — attacks in which multiple people are shot — occur with some regularity. Just last week, three teenagers were shot in the crossfire outside a Bronx high school; one, a 16-year-old girl, died.
lead_paragraph: Mass shootings in New York — attacks in which multiple people are shot — occur with some regularity. Just last week, three teenagers were shot in the crossfire outside a Bronx high school; one, a 16-year-old girl, died.

headline: Boeing’s sales rebound continues, with the 737 Max leading the way.
abstract: The company had net sales of 145 aircraft in the first three months of the year as airlines got ready for a resurgence in travel.
lead_paragraph: Boeing sold 145 planes in the first three months of the year, after accounting for canceled orders, the company said on Tuesday, as airlines around the world start to lay the groundwork for a broader postpandemic rebound.

headline: Not Your Grandfather’s Skyscraper
abstract: Stefan Al’s “Supertall” is a thoughtful inquiry into the new generation of skyscrapers, which are taller and more ubiquitous than their predecessors.
lead_paragraph: The unrelenting construction of bigger and bigger skyscrapers in New York City is “shutting out the light of the heavens and circumscribing the air of the streets,” robbing citizens of their rights to light and air, “which, ‘in the pursuit of health, happiness and prosperity,’ they should demand,” wrote an architect named David Knickerbocker Boyd, who called the newest crop of tall towers “a menace to public health and safety and an offense which must be stopped.” Boyd’s view of the skyscraper as an urban plague makes him sound as if he were leading the charge against the forest of pencil-thin, ultra-tall towers that has sprung up lately on Billionaires’ Row in Midtown Manhattan. He might have done just that, had he not died in 1944. Boyd’s jeremiad was written 114 years ago, when anything with more than a dozen floors was considered a skyscraper, and the tallest building in the world was Ernest Flagg’s just-finished Singer Building at Broadway and Liberty Street, which rose to the then unheard-of height of 47 stories.

headline: Mayor Eric Adams says New York City will not surrender to the ‘violent few.’
abstract: Mr. Adams, a former police captain who ran on a public-safety message, recommitted to his anti-gun agenda in a speech on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Facing a growing public-safety crisis, Mayor Eric Adams said on Tuesday night that a mass shooting had turned a Brooklyn subway into a “war zone,” and that gun violence was a national problem New York City could not solve on its own.

headline: Most Active Hurricane Season Was Also Wetter Because of Climate Change
abstract: During the record-setting 2020 Atlantic storm season, the most extreme three-hour rainfall rates were 10 percent higher than they would have been without climate change, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Climate change contributed significantly to the severity of the ferocious 2020 Atlantic hurricane season, increasing both rainfall rates and rainfall totals, according to a study published on Tuesday.

headline: No reusable cup? In Australia, it’s at your own risk.
abstract: On a visit to Melbourne, a Times reporter got a lesson in cafe etiquette, and the challenges facing the sustainability movement.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The sour tone of voice from the barista could have curdled milk.

headline: Welcome Back to the Office. Isn’t This Fun?
abstract: Tech companies really want their employees to be happy — or at least less annoyed — about returning. So they’re providing concerts, food trucks and other perks.
lead_paragraph: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.

headline: PFAS: The ‘Forever Chemicals’ You Couldn’t Escape if You Tried
abstract: Virtually indestructible, these artificial compounds are used in fast-food packaging and countless household items, but they have been found as far away as virgin forests.
lead_paragraph: Based on nothing more than their name, per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances certainly don’t sound like something you’d want to find in your burger wrapper. But according to a recent investigation by Consumer Reports, they’re very much there — as well as in your salad bowl, fry bag and sandwich wrap.

headline: A Surprising Global Dance Showcase, Deep in the Heart of Texas
abstract: Dance Salad, an annual festival in Houston, is the brainchild of Nancy Henderek, whose hands-on involvement even extends to editing some of the works.
lead_paragraph: Harold George, a young dancer from Sierra Leone, was studying in Belgium in 1992 when a friendly Texas expat named Nancy Henderek invited him to perform in a showcase at the international school her children attended. She called the concert Dance Salad because of its bite-size sampling of styles and artists, including some of the city’s best professional companies.

headline: French Authorities Seize Oligarch’s Painting Before It Leaves for Russia
abstract: A work displayed in the blockbuster “Morozov Collection” exhibition will remain in France, and authorities have their eyes on another painting in the show.
lead_paragraph: A painting owned by a Russian oligarch that was seen by over 1.2 million people who visited a blockbuster art show in Paris will not be returning to Russia for the foreseeable future, a spokesman for France’s culture ministry said on Monday.

headline: France’s Voters Are Choosing Between Fear and Anger
abstract: Marine Le Pen and Emmanuel Macron are courting voters with emotion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The future of democracy in Europe is being decided simultaneously on the battlefields of Ukraine and in the ballot boxes of France.

headline: Photos From the Scene of the Brooklyn Subway Shooting
abstract: Times photographers are at the location where several people were shot during the morning rush at a train station in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A “person of interest” was identified by the New York police on Tuesday evening after a mass shooting at the 36th Street subway station in Brooklyn. At least 23 people were injured, officials said, in a violent episode that stoked fears about public safety as New York City struggles to recover from the pandemic.

headline: Subway service resumes with delays and trains are bypassing 36th Street.
abstract: The attack at a subway station in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn snarled subway lines all over the city, the authorities said, though many had picked up again by Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The attack at a subway station in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn snarled subway lines all over the city, the authorities said, though many had picked up again by Tuesday night.

headline: Gay Couple Was Denied I.V.F. Benefits. They Say That’s Discriminatory.
abstract: A former lawyer for New York City and his husband have filed a complaint against the city saying they were denied insurance coverage because of a definition of infertility that excludes gay men.
lead_paragraph: A same-sex married couple said in a complaint filed Tuesday that the City of New York discriminated against them in denying them in vitro fertilization coverage under the city’s insurance plan for employees.

headline: Video Shows Commuters on Train After Brooklyn Subway Attack
abstract: The video shows a smoke-filled subway car with passengers huddling on the floor. A wounded man can be heard yelling that he is in pain.
lead_paragraph: The video shows a smoke-filled subway car with passengers huddling on the floor. A wounded man can be heard yelling that he is in pain.

headline: Inflation Is About to Come Down — but Don’t Get Too Excited
abstract: The bullwhip is flicking back.
lead_paragraph: The inflation report for March came in hot, as expected: Consumer prices are up 8.5 percent over the past year. But more than two years into the pandemic, we’re still living on Covid time, where things can change very fast — so fast that official data, even about the recent past, can give a misleading picture of what’s happening now.

headline: A German State Is Last in Almost Everything. But It’s No. 1 in Vaccines.
abstract: Bremen — Germany’s smallest state — managed its vaccination campaign better than any other place in Germany. It succeeded by activating community networks.
lead_paragraph: BREMEN, Germany — This northern port city, combined with neighboring Bremerhaven, makes up the smallest and by many measures the poorest state in Germany’s federal system. In state comparisons of education or addressing child poverty, it consistently ranks dead last.

headline: Spain Reigns Again
abstract: One of New York’s oldest Spanish restaurants has been given a facelift and a completely new menu.
lead_paragraph: One of New York’s oldest Spanish restaurants has been given a facelift and a completely new menu.

headline: El Quijote Tilts Back Toward Its Earlier Glamour
abstract: It’s not as cheap as it used to be, but after years of faded glory at the Hotel Chelsea, the mainstay Spanish restaurant has been revived.
lead_paragraph: There used to be dozens of Spanish restaurants around Chelsea and the Village, and while it was possible to argue over which had the best paella there was no serious debate about which was the grandest. It was El Quijote, in the Hotel Chelsea.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Volodymyr Yermolenko
abstract: A conversation with the Ukrainian philosopher and editor.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Volodymyr Yermolenko. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Russian Runners, Banned in Boston
abstract: Readers discuss Bret Stephens’s objections to the ban and whether Russian citizens should suffer because of their leader’s actions. Also: Merrick Garland and Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Casa Carmen, Mexican That’s a Family Affair, Opens in TriBeCa
abstract: A Japanese restaurant to replace O Ya in the Park South Hotel, a Latin-inspired cafe in the Bronx, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Ramírez Degollado’s husband helped open El Bajío in Mexico City, in 1972, and, when he died a few years later, Ms. Ramírez Degollado, known as Titita, took over the restaurant. Since 2006, El Bajío has opened 18 more family-owned restaurants, known for the food of Veracruz, Oaxaca, Puebla and the Yucatán. Now she’s 83, and two of her grandsons, Santiago Ramírez Degollado and Sebastián Ramírez Degollado, who live in New York, are opening this homage to her. It’s the first restaurant outside Mexico for the family behind the El Bajío company, in a simple, subdued space, done with rustic elegance. Clay pots line one wall. The menu lists assorted tacos and will feature duck tostadas, plantain empanadas, enchiladas de mole Xico, fish Veracruz-style and shrimp in a charred chipotle sauce. Desserts include a warm corn cake with ice cream. The executive chef for the group, Josep Rivera, will spend a few weeks to help grease the wheels before returning to Mexico, and the wine list will feature several Mexican wines. (Opens Thursday)

headline: When the Yankees Play the Blue Jays, ‘Every Game Is Huge’
abstract: A tense series between division rivals showcases everything that is right about the ultracompetitive American League East.
lead_paragraph: When he stepped to the plate to lead off Monday’s game against the Yankees, Toronto Blue Jays center fielder George Springer was greeted with a shower of boos from the crowd at Yankee Stadium. He promptly singled.

headline: House G.O.P., Banding Together, Kills Bid to Honor Pioneering Black Judge
abstract: A right-wing congressman persuaded fellow Republicans to abruptly turn against a routine measure to name a federal courthouse in Florida for a Black State Supreme Court justice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a bitterly divided Congress, it was a rare measure that had been expected to sail through without a fight.

headline: Am I Done Suffering for Fashion?
abstract: Two years of a pandemic have lowered our patience for uncomfortable clothing.
lead_paragraph: As the world takes its hesitant steps toward normalcy, and more people return to the workplace, we need to accept the fact that the era of sweatpants may be drawing to a close. And yet, do we really want to abandon the freedom and comfort we have found during this otherwise grim time? I know I don’t. And apparently, I am not alone.

headline: Judge Bars 2 YouTubers From U.S.C. Campus
abstract: A lawsuit filed by the University of Southern California says the two men, who are not students, caused “terror and disruption” with what seemed like classroom takeovers.
lead_paragraph: A judge has barred two men from the campus of the University of Southern California in downtown Los Angeles after the university accused them of filming disruptive prank videos in classrooms for their YouTube channels.

headline: Nebula, a Big New Club, Wants Manhattan to Dance Again
abstract: Yang Gao, a newcomer to the nightlife business, took a gamble when he spent $12 million in the middle of a pandemic to carve out a 10,000-square-foot space in the heart of Midtown.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Yang Gao and Richie Romero were watching over a very noisy and very expensive construction project: Digging down, down, down, beneath the floor of an old building on West 41st Street, just off Times Square.

headline: The federal consumer bureau sued TransUnion and a former executive over deceptive sales tactics.
abstract: The company repeatedly flouted a ban on luring consumers seeking free credit reports into paid products, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau sued the credit-reporting firm TransUnion and a former senior executive — John Danaher, who led the company’s consumer sales unit — for violating a 2017 order to stop using deceptive tactics to lure customers into recurring subscription payments.

headline: On-Demand Webinar: Exploring Big Ideas Through Short Documentaries
abstract: In this webinar, a Learning Network editor and English teacher discuss how our weekly Film Club feature can be used across the curriculum.
lead_paragraph: In addition to the hundreds of articles published daily, The New York Times creates innovative visual storytelling through film and video. Times Video series — like Op-Docs, Modern Love, Diary of a Song and Conception — offer viewers an intriguing and unique perspective of the world.

headline: Heavy Floods and Mudslides Leave at Least 45 Dead in South Africa
abstract: Torrential rain left a trail of destruction in the coastal city of Durban — the latest disaster in a season of storms that some scientists say has been intensified by climate change.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Days of heavy rain on the eastern coast of South Africa left at least 45 people dead when rivers burst their banks and mudslides swept through the city of Durban and the surrounding area.

headline: Commuters are frightened by subway attack but say, ‘You can’t live in fear.’
abstract: Some passengers learned of the shooting through station announcements, messages from friends and family, and news alerts, while others did not know about it at all.
lead_paragraph: It was about 11:40 a.m. when a few cellphones on a Brooklyn-bound F train wailed with an emergency alert on Tuesday morning, warning New Yorkers to steer clear of the area where a man had shot 10 people in the subway in the Sunset Park neighborhood hours earlier. Two men passed the phone to each other, wondering how to get to their stop. Elsewhere on the sparsely filled car, people read books, listened to music, watched videos or texted on their phones.

headline: Actors in ‘Waitress’ Tour Seek to Join Labor Union
abstract: Employees of a nonunion production are seeking improved compensation and safety protocols, saying a union version of the same musical pays better.
lead_paragraph: A group of actors and stage managers employed by a nonunion touring production of the musical “Waitress” is seeking union representation, emboldened by a growing focus on working conditions in the theater business and by the labor movement’s recent successes in other industries.

headline: In a First, Google Goes After Puppy Fraud in Court
abstract: The company’s first consumer protection lawsuit, filed Monday,  claims a Cameroon man tricked would-be buyers using Gmail and other services.
lead_paragraph: In a first for the tech giant, Google filed a consumer protection lawsuit to shield the vulnerable and unsuspecting from what it called a “nefarious” scheme: the sale of adorable, but imaginary, puppies.

headline: Boris Johnson is fined for breaking British lockdown rules.
abstract: In recent weeks Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has revived his fortunes at home by becoming Europe’s most aggressive supporter of Ukraine’s fierce fight against Russian invasion.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has revived his fortunes at home by becoming Europe’s most aggressive supporter of Ukraine’s fierce fight against Russian invasion.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Never Asked; He Never Explained’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: My husband, Stanley, was sick for months before he died in April 2019. Taking care of him, I didn’t have time to prepare our 2018 tax returns. With an extension to October, I sorted through Stanley’s checkbooks and credit card statements. His charges and payments reflected the cruel arc of his illness: Stanley’s business-related expenses plummeted while his medical costs ballooned; his handwriting deteriorated. I relived his death through his taxes. Sometimes those two certainties — death and taxes — intersect in unexpected, heartbreaking ways. By working slowly, I was able to fulfill Stanley’s final obligations. On time. — Zelda R. Stern

headline: Mimi Reinhard, Who Typed Up Schindler’s List, Dies at 107
abstract: As a secretary in a forced-labor camp in World War II, she added her own name to the list of 1,100 Jews who would be spared from the gas chambers.
lead_paragraph: She wasn’t much of a typist, but she knew shorthand and spoke flawless German. And so Mimi Reinhard, an Austrian Jew who was being held in a Nazi labor camp near Krakow, Poland, during World War II, was given an office job. In that capacity, she would play a small but important role in one of the great heroic stories to emerge from the Holocaust, one in which the Nazis were outwitted and the lives of more than 1,100 Jews, including hers, were saved.

headline: This Cake Gives You a Moment of Warmth in the Middle of the Day
abstract: Chamomile cake is just right at teatime, an excuse to give yourself and friends an hour to sit down and linger.
lead_paragraph: When I was in graduate school, nearly a decade ago, I bought a cheap porcelain teapot that I still use today. It has faux-gold lining, with edges that gleam, and a pink-and-jade rosebud print across its surface. A halo of teal encircles the lid, which comes off with a clinking sound. If a cherub were a teapot, then this would be it. It’s priceless to me and dutifully sturdy, having stayed by my side across multiple New York City apartments and afternoon teatimes with friends.

headline: Trump Poses a Test Democracy Is Failing
abstract: Ordinary voters are supposed to punish authoritarians by removing them from office. Intensifying partisanship is threatening that mechanism.
lead_paragraph: Ordinary citizens play a critical role in maintaining democracy. They refuse to re-elect — at least in theory — politicians who abuse their power, break the rules and reject the outcome of elections they lose. How is it, then, that Donald Trump, who has defied these basic presumptions, stands a reasonable chance of winning a second term in 2024?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Photographing the Reality of War’

headline: ‘Seek and Hide’ Grapples With the Complexity of the Right to Privacy
abstract: The law professor Amy Gajda writes about the tug of war between the right to know and the right to be let alone.
lead_paragraph: In her wry and fascinating new book, “Seek and Hide,” Amy Gajda traces the history of the right to privacy and its (understandably fraught) relationship in the United States with the First Amendment. English common law includes the concept of “truthful libel” — the notion that anything harmful to a person’s reputation, even if factually accurate, could be treated as a punishable offense.

headline: The Dangerous Lesson Viktor Orban Taught Republicans

headline: The Great Chicago Gas Giveaway and the Return of Stunt Philanthropy

It was only minutes later, after I was able to switch lanes and pull ahead, that I saw the cars were waiting at a gas station. Had something in the news set off a flurry of panic buying? I turned on the radio and soon learned that the people I saw were not, in fact, buying fuel. They were hoping to get some free.

lead_paragraph: Last week the Supreme Court, by a 5-to-4 vote, put back into effect a Trump administration regulation that limited the ability of states to block projects that could pollute rivers and streams. The unsigned, unexplained order in Louisiana v. American Rivers came as part of a highly technical dispute over the scope of the Clean Water Act — and leaves for another day whether the regulation is a valid interpretation of that Nixon-era statute.

headline: 5 Ukrainian Art Accounts to Follow on Instagram Now
abstract: Artists continue to work, documenting the impact of events as they unfold to keep the world watching.
lead_paragraph: Social media give us responses to the Russian invasion of Ukraine almost instantly, but some of the most moving responses I’ve seen come from the young Ukrainian artists who’ve managed to make new work documenting events as they unfold.

headline: Why Experts Can’t Seem to Agree on Boosters
abstract: How can scientists look at the same evidence and come to such different conclusions?
lead_paragraph: Should you get another Covid booster shot?

headline: Living In ... Woodbridge, Conn.
abstract: This ‘suburban community in a country setting’ is just a 20-minute commute from Yale University, other educational institutions and biotech companies.
lead_paragraph: This ‘suburban community in a country setting’ is just a 20-minute commute from Yale University, other educational institutions and biotech companies.

headline: Russian Tech Industry Faces ‘Brain Drain’ as Workers Flee
abstract: Since their country invaded Ukraine, Russian tech workers have left by the thousands. They appear intent on rebuilding their lives and businesses in other countries.
lead_paragraph: In early March, days after Russia invaded Ukraine and began cracking down on dissent at home, Konstantin Siniushin, a venture capitalist in Riga, Latvia, helped charter two planes out of Russia to help people flee.

headline: Let Him Entertain You: Billy Crystal Returns to Broadway
abstract: The comedian is starring in “Mr. Saturday Night,” a musical version of his 1992 movie about an aging performer who won’t accept that his time in the spotlight is up.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Mess Proves Autocracy Hurts Everyone
abstract: The fear in China is that the strict coronavirus policy has become another Mao-style political campaign with devastating effects.
lead_paragraph: Long before the “zero Covid” policy, China had a “zero sparrow” policy.

headline: Why You Should Plant a Garden That’s Wasp Friendly
abstract: Those wasps you hate? They’re the best organic pest control around. Here’s how to keep them happy (and avoid getting stung).
lead_paragraph: Attention, spheksophobes: Wasps just want to help.

headline: Pencil Cases and Air-Raid Sirens: School at War for Ukraine’s Children
abstract: The country’s teachers are doing their best to provide lessons for the millions of school-age children whose education has been interrupted.
lead_paragraph: KRAKOW, Poland — Across Ukraine, kindergartens have been bombed, elementary schools have been converted into shelters and in some cities like Mariupol, their grounds have even become makeshift graveyards.

headline: Woodbridge, Conn.: A Rural Enclave Close to New Haven
abstract: This ‘suburban community in a country setting’ is just a 20-minute commute from Yale University, other educational institutions and a number of biotech companies.
lead_paragraph: Woodbridge, Conn., a quiet suburb on New Haven’s western edge, is a place where privacy comes easily. Most of the residential lots in town are at least an acre and a half, and multifamily housing is almost nonexistent. More than a quarter of the town’s land area is protected open space. And what little commercial activity is permitted is contained within the town’s southeastern corner, adjacent to the Merritt Parkway.

headline: Returning to Florence With ‘the World’s Most Opinionated Guide’
abstract: After two years, travel is at last opening up — the perfect time to look at this classic Tuscan destination with new, less jaded eyes. For a fresh perspective, let the critic and novelist Mary McCarthy be your guide.
lead_paragraph: “Almost nobody comes to see Donatello’s ‘David’ in the Bargello, the first nude statue of the Renaissance,” lamented Mary McCarthy in 1959 in “The Stones of Florence,” a masterpiece of American travel writing. A famously contrarian critic, she believed that Michelangelo’s David was overvalued, and, writing for a postwar generation of American travelers, wanted them to appreciate an earlier sculptural tradition.

headline: The Philippines Toppled One Marcos. Now His Son May Become President.
abstract: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has spent his political career trying to rehabilitate the family name. As the front-runner in the upcoming election, he may finally succeed.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — They bopped along to the beat of a martial law anthem updated into a pop tune. They cheered when an A-list celebrity proclaimed that the spirit of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former dictator, was alive. And when Mr. Marcos’s son and namesake held up the peace sign made popular by his father a generation ago, the shrieking crowds mirrored it in return.

headline: Cruxy O’Connor and the Central Park Ambush
abstract: One hundred years ago this week, the British spy was caught in what appears to be the Irish Republican Army’s only authorized attack on American soil.
lead_paragraph: It was a few minutes to 8 o’clock on the evening of April 13, 1922. When Patrick Joseph O’Connor came down the steps of his apartment building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, three of the Irish Republican Army’s top gunmen were lying in wait.

headline: A ‘Silent Victim’: How Nature Becomes a Casualty of War
abstract: Research on past conflicts suggests that the war in Ukraine could have a profound environmental impact.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A Quiet Spot in Grenada for $1.95 Million
abstract: This two-bedroom farm-style house on the coast of Carriacou, an island in the Caribbean nation of Grenada, is for sale for $1.95 million.
lead_paragraph: This two-bedroom farm-style house on the coast of Carriacou, an island in the Caribbean nation of Grenada, is for sale for $1.95 million.

headline: House Hunting in Grenada: A Better ‘Beach Shack’ on the Caribbean Coast
abstract: ‘There has been no tourism for almost two years’ in Grenada, agents say, leading to more opportunities for domestic buyers and savvy investors.
lead_paragraph: This two-bedroom farm-style house offers Atlantic Ocean and Caribbean Sea views from a bluff above a white sandy beach on the southeast coast of Carriacou, an island in Grenada.

headline: ‘We got him’: The police captured the gunman after a tip from the public.
abstract: New York City police officers on Wednesday apprehended the man who they believed opened fire on a Brooklyn subway train the previous day, officials said.
lead_paragraph: New York City police officers on Wednesday apprehended the man who they believed opened fire on a Brooklyn subway train the previous day, officials said.

headline: As pandemic-era remote work becomes permanent, Manhattan’s economy faces an uncertain future.
abstract: The list of companies permanently changing the way they work keeps growing longer and, for those in New York City, the five-day-a-week trek into Manhattan is becoming a fading corporate practice — with enormous consequences for the city, whose economy is especially dependent on filling its forests of office towers.
lead_paragraph: The list of companies permanently changing the way they work keeps growing longer and, for those in New York City, the five-day-a-week trek into Manhattan is becoming a fading corporate practice — with enormous consequences for the city, whose economy is especially dependent on filling its forests of office towers.

headline: A Subway Attack That Shook New York City
abstract: The gunman who injured 23 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, escaped, but the police identified a person of interest.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Two stories will dominate the conversation today: the attack in the subway that left at least 23 people injured, 10 from gunfire, and the resignation of Lt. Gov. Brian Benjamin, hours after he was arrested on corruption charges.

headline: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Yawning, Walking, Mowing the Lawn
abstract: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about yawning, share how they feel about walking, watch a film about the American lawn, make observations about a photograph and reflect on forgiveness.

headline: Yellen Calls on China to Push Russia to End Ukraine War.
abstract: The Treasury secretary told the Atlantic Council that the U.S. would press ahead with sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen urged China on Wednesday to persuade Russia to end its war in Ukraine and warned that staying on the sidelines could jeopardize China’s standing in the global economy.

headline: The Next Phase of the War in Ukraine
abstract: Moscow has narrowed its goals. What does that tell us about Russia’s military?
lead_paragraph: After a disastrous defeat in northern Ukraine, Russia has begun a high-stakes battle for the east, while Western allies arm Ukrainian fighters determined to stave off the attack.

headline: McKinsey Opened a Door in Its Firewall Between Pharma Clients and Regulators
abstract: The firm let consultants advise both drugmakers and their government overseers, internal records show. “Who we know and what we know” was part of their pitch.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Smith, a partner with the influential consulting firm McKinsey & Company, accepted a highly sensitive assignment in December 2017. The opioid manufacturer Purdue Pharma, beleaguered and in financial trouble, wanted to revamp its business, and an executive there sought out Dr. Smith.

headline: Inflation’s 40-Year High
abstract: We look at why prices might ease — and why they might not.
lead_paragraph: The overall cost of gas, food and other everyday items is increasing at its fastest rate in more than 40 years. And experts cannot say with confidence whether price increases will speed up or slow down in the coming months.

headline: U.S. tech companies are stepping up office perks, hoping to make employees feel happier about returning.
abstract: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.
lead_paragraph: When Google employees returned to their mostly empty offices this month, they were told to relax. Office time should be “not only productive but also fun.” Explore the place a little. Don’t book back-to-back meetings.

headline: ‘Father Stu’ Review: Screwball Salvation
abstract: Mark Wahlberg throws himself into the real-life story of an oddball priest in Rosalind Ross’s debut feature.
lead_paragraph: Mark Wahlberg dials himself up to 11 in “Father Stu,” a never-say-die story of religious redemption and all-American hustle. Wahlberg’s career is full of characters who totally believe in their own game, and here, he throws himself into the oddball role of Stuart Long — a Montana boxer turned beloved priest who developed a degenerative muscle disease and died at 50.

headline: What You Get for $2.2 Million
abstract: A Nashville Victorian owned by an HGTV host; a Key West, Fla., house where the writer John Dos Passos once lived; and a log cabin in East Durham, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A Nashville Victorian owned by an HGTV host; a Key West, Fla., house where the writer John Dos Passos once lived; and a log cabin in East Durham, N.Y.

headline: $2.2 Million Homes in Tennessee, Florida and New York
abstract: A Nashville Victorian owned by an HGTV host, a Key West house where the writer John Dos Passos once lived, and a rustic log cabin in East Durham.
lead_paragraph: The owner of this house, Kortney Wilson, is also the listing agent, as well as the host of “Masters of Flip” and “Music City Fix,” HGTV shows focused on restoring historic homes in Nashville. This house, in the Lockeland Springs neighborhood, is a mix of old and new, with an open kitchen, exposed-brick walls and several original fireplaces.

headline: Delta Air Lines sees a turn toward profit, and carriers’ shares soar.
abstract: Delta said its March operations were profitable, despite rising fuel costs. It reported a first-quarter loss, but revenue exceeded its forecast.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines reported a quarterly loss on Wednesday as thriving ticket sales were offset by high fuel prices. But it said that its March operations were profitable and that it had been able to pass some of the higher cost of fuel along to customers.

headline: Scrambling in Play-In, Nets Offer Glimpse of What They Can Be
abstract: For three quarters, the Nets again showed their best side. A matchup against the Celtics in the playoffs will require a more complete effort.
lead_paragraph: For much of their N.B.A. play-in game against the Cleveland Cavaliers on Tuesday night, the Nets looked like the fearsome team that many observers had long said lay hidden behind their mediocre record. Kevin Durant was magnificent. Kyrie Irving didn’t miss a shot until the fourth quarter. Multiple teammates made significant contributions well above what was usually expected of them.

headline: What We Know About the Brooklyn Subway Shooting
abstract: The police have arrested a suspect, a 62-year-old man who has posted vitriolic rants on YouTube and criticized New York’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: A man who the police had identified as a suspect in the Brooklyn subway shooting, Frank R. James, was taken into custody on Wednesday, according law enforcement officials.

headline: Britain’s inflation rate climbed to 7 percent, the highest in 30 years.
abstract: Household budgets are squeezed as wage increases are not keeping pace with rising prices.
lead_paragraph: In Britain, several pieces of dispiriting economic news arrived this week: Prices are rising at their fastest pace in 30 years, wages adjusted for inflation fell the most in nearly eight years and the economy hardly grew in February.

headline: Severe Storms Sweep the South, Killing at Least 1
abstract: A person in Arkansas was killed after a tree fell on a mobile home, the authorities said, after thunderstorms caused damage across several states.
lead_paragraph: Severe thunderstorms ripped through portions of the Midwest and the Mississippi Valley on Wednesday, killing at least one person in Arkansas and causing damage in several other states.

headline: Has U.S. Inflation Peaked?
abstract: Prices rose last month at the fastest pace in more than four decades. Some economists think inflation may be subsiding.
lead_paragraph: Inflation in the U.S. was running at 8.5 percent in the year to March, new data showed yesterday, the highest level in more than 40 years.

headline: Are You Reluctant to Get a Covid Booster?
abstract: Share your story with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Less than half of vaccinated Americans who are eligible for a Covid booster have gotten one, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: ‘Mississippi Masala’: A Love Story Among the Displaced
abstract: In Mira Nair’s sweet, sexy film from 1991, an Indian American woman falls for a Black cleaner played charmingly, as ever, by Denzel Washington.
lead_paragraph: Mira Nair’s “Mississippi Masala” begins with a bit of family history that is also a history lesson — the expulsion of Uganda’s sizable South Asian population, ordered from the country by the military strongman Idi Amin in 1972.

headline: More Than 120 Dead After Tropical Storm Hits the Philippines
abstract: The first such storm of the year caused widespread flooding and landslides in the central part of the country.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Rescue workers battled intermittent heavy rain to reach many people still missing Wednesday, three days after Tropical Storm Megi pummeled the country, causing widespread landslides and flooding in the central Philippines.

headline: Could California Switch to Permanent Daylight Saving Time?
abstract: Lawmakers in the Golden State and elsewhere are considering eliminating the biannual time switch.
lead_paragraph: In November 2018, Californians overwhelmingly approved a ballot measure that promised to do away with the twice-a-year changing of the clocks that many of us have come to revile. Daylight saving time, it seemed, would soon be a thing of the past.

headline: Michel Bouquet, Award-Winning French Actor, Dies at 96
abstract: One of his country’s great theater performers, he went on to appear in more than 100 films playing ordinary men whose surface blandness masked complex lives.
lead_paragraph: Michel Bouquet, a French actor whose talent for suggesting passion and turmoil beneath a bland, middle-class facade made him a favorite of New Wave directors, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 96.

headline: Mayor Eric Adams says the ‘person of interest’ in Brooklyn subway shooting is now a suspect.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday morning that the man who the police had identified as a “person of interest” in the mass shooting on the subway in Brooklyn the day before was now considered a suspect.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday morning that the man who the police had identified as a “person of interest” in the mass shooting on the subway in Brooklyn the day before was now considered a suspect.

headline: Weaker oil demand, especially in China, might ease supply crunch caused by sanctions.
abstract: The International Energy Agency foresees slower growth in demand for oil, caused by high prices and economic slowdowns.
lead_paragraph: The International Energy Agency said Wednesday that Covid lockdowns in China were likely to sharply cut the growth in demand for oil in that country, potentially easing a supply crunch caused by sanctions on Russia.

headline: New Zealand welcomes vaccinated tourists from Australia and relaxes more policies.
abstract: The latest steps toward reopening are being taken in a country that has maintained some of the strictest coronavirus precautions in the world.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of tourists and international students arrived in New Zealand from Australia on Wednesday, some to reunite with family and friends, in a further sign of reopening in countries that have maintained some of the world’s strictest coronavirus restrictions.

headline: In Elden Ring, the Struggle Feels Real
abstract: The video game evokes the hardship and disappointment of the pandemic, but also the hope of human communion.
lead_paragraph: In the last two years, the pandemic has brought us many works of art that have tried to definitively capture humanity’s struggle. There was that movie with Leonardo DiCaprio turning pink as he shouts at the top of his lungs for people to look up at the comet hurtling toward Earth. It was so on the nose that it provoked little thought: Yes, we are divided, likely doomed. What of it?

headline: ‘When you live in New York City, you’ve got to recover’: At the 36th Street station, more officers and plenty of commuters.
abstract: The platform was crowded and the mood was somber Wednesday morning as police officers patrolled the 36th Street station in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, about 24 hours after a gunman shot 10 people inside a train approaching the station.
lead_paragraph: The platform was crowded and the mood was somber Wednesday morning as police officers patrolled the 36th Street station in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, about 24 hours after a gunman shot 10 people inside a train approaching the station.

headline: British territory freezes $7 billion in assets believed to be tied to Roman Abramovich.
abstract: Jersey, an island in the English Channel, froze assets believed to be linked to the Russian oligarch, on whom Britain imposed sanctions after Russia invaded Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The economic vise is tightening around Roman Abramovich, whose assets were targeted by British authorities more than a month ago as part of the West’s sanctions on Russian oligarchs after the invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Israel’s Oldest Museum Takes a New Look at Israeli Art
abstract: For decades, museums presented Israeli art as a companion to the country’s history. The Tel Aviv Museum of Art breaks away from that approach — with surprising results.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — When the Tel Aviv Museum of Art’s permanent collection of Israeli art reopened in February, the first work visitors saw wasn’t even Israeli. It was a bust by a Scottish Jewish artist, Benno Schotz, who spent most of his life in Glasgow.

headline: Bringing Consent to Ballet, One Intimacy Workshop at a Time
abstract: Touch is a requirement of a dancer’s job. Now when choreography involves simulated sex or violence, some companies are bringing in intimacy directors.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — The intensity of the choreography left visible marks on Bethany Kingsley-Garner’s body. On a recent afternoon in the Glasgow studios of Scottish Ballet, she was running through an upsetting scene in Kenneth MacMillan’s 1978 ballet “Mayerling.” Her character, Stephanie, is violently assaulted on her wedding night by her husband, Crown Prince Rudolf. As she was grabbed, thrown and lifted, Kingsley-Garner’s back, visible through a cutout in her leotard, grew increasingly red from the rough — sometimes audibly so — skin-to-skin contact.

headline: Man Who Stole Dozens of Golf Carts Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
abstract: For four years, the man, Nathan Rodney Nelson, 46, acted at night, stealing carts from golf courses and driving them to a getaway vehicle, prosecutors said. Then his phone number gave him away.
lead_paragraph: A man who admitted to stealing or trying to steal 84 golf carts across several states in an effort to solve his financial troubles was sentenced on Tuesday to two years in prison, the authorities in North Dakota said.

headline: U.S. and Ukrainian Groups Pierce Putin’s Propaganda Bubble
abstract: U.S.-backed news outlets and Ukrainian activists use Cold War techniques and high-tech tactics to get news about the war to Russians.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Using a mix of high-tech and Cold War tactics, Ukrainian activists and Western institutions have begun to pierce the propaganda bubble in Russia, circulating information about the Ukraine war among Russian citizens to sow doubt about the Kremlin’s accounts.

headline: Alyssa Nakken Adds Yet Another First by Coaching First Base
abstract: The San Francisco Giants coach became the first woman to take an on-field role in a Major League Baseball game. “This is my job,” she said.
lead_paragraph: It was an unusual scene at Oracle Park in San Francisco on Tuesday. The Giants’ first-base coach was ejected in the third inning, and after his replacement took the field, Eric Hosmer, the first baseman for the San Diego Padres, came over to shake her hand.

headline: Death Toll in South Africa Floods Passes 306
abstract: The devastation fueled criticism that the government should have been better prepared for the weather after intense rain in 2017 and 2019.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The death toll from several days of punishing rain that drenched the city of Durban and the surrounding areas near South Africa’s east coast rose to more than 306 on Wednesday, prompting criticism from residents that the government had failed to prepare for what are now increasingly frequent storms.

headline: More Holiday Prep!
abstract: Readers are looking for recipes for Passover, Easter and Ramadan, and we have lots of options.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. We’re in another holiday chute this week, with Passover coming on Friday night, Easter on Sunday and Ramadan ongoing. My inbox is flooding with requests for recipes.

headline: Fighting the Latest Efforts to Outlaw Abortion
abstract: Readers discuss moves to ban abortion pills and lament passage of an Oklahoma anti-abortion bill. Also: Saving baseball; sex and manners; Covid vaccines.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Masks Stay On: C.D.C. Keeps the Mandate on Planes
abstract: Despite pressure from airlines and industry groups, the Biden administration extended the requirement to wear masks while traveling on public transportation through May 3.
lead_paragraph: Despite great pressure from airlines, the hospitality industry and Republican lawmakers to lift the rule requiring masks on planes and other public transportation, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention extended the federal transportation mask requirement for two weeks on Wednesday, five days before it was set to expire. The mask mandate now expires May 3, if it is not extended yet again.

headline: Chloë Sevigny and Cory Kennedy Honor the Downtown Poets
abstract: The Poetry Project held an eclectic gala in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Phantoms from a vanishing downtown were summoned to St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery last Friday for the Poetry Project’s 55th anniversary gala. The organization is an enduring harborage for New York City poets, and the event brought several generations of the creative community under one steeple to celebrate the spoken word.

headline: Sister of suspect in Brooklyn subway shooting says ‘he’s been on his own his whole life.’
abstract: Frank R. James, whom the police apprehended in connection with the attack on Tuesday, was born in the Bronx but spent his life moving from city to city, his sister said.
lead_paragraph: Even as Frank R. James, the 62-year-old man suspected by the police of opening fire in a crowded subway car, was taken into custody in the early afternoon on Wednesday, new details about his troubled life began to emerge, including a criminal history in at least two states.

headline: Major Matisse Exhibition Coming to Philadelphia
abstract: “Matisse in the 1930s,” a new show devoted to that innovative decade of the painter’s work, is slated to open this fall at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: In 1930, Albert Barnes, the art collector and founder of the Barnes Foundation, did something a bit audacious: He asked Henri Matisse, who was visiting the United States as a juror for the Carnegie International exhibition in Pittsburgh, to create an enormous painting. Matisse, then 60, had not completed any paintings during the previous year.

headline: Despite Russian Warnings, Finland and Sweden Draw Closer to NATO
abstract: The invasion of Ukraine has heightened security fears, pushing even formally nonaligned countries toward the Western alliance.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Even before his invasion of Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had warned Sweden and Finland of “retaliation” should they join NATO. It was, after all, Ukraine’s desire to join the alliance that he cited time and again as provocation for his war.

headline: ‘You would think it’s a safe place’: A nurse recounts an attack on a Mariupol hospital.
abstract: The attack last month was among the first signs that Ukraine was facing a merciless war.
