lead_paragraph: Wildfires, tornadoes and a rare spring blizzard brought destruction across the U.S.

headline: The Russian media dismisses photographic evidence of atrocities in Ukraine as ‘fake.’
abstract: Russians are being shown some of the same distressing imagery from the war as the rest of the world, but with a big twist.
lead_paragraph: State television programs in Russia have not shied away from showing images of death and destruction in Ukraine. Viewers have seen corpses in the streets of Bucha, blasted-out cars at a train station in Kramatorsk and the remains of a hospital complex attacked in Mariupol.

headline: British Militant Convicted for Role in Deaths of Americans
abstract: The verdict capped a two-week trial that featured the testimony of former captives who detailed relentless beatings, waterboarding and killings by an Islamic State cell known as the Beatles.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A federal jury on Thursday convicted a British militant accused of being a member of the brutal Islamic State cell known as the Beatles in the abduction, abuse and deaths of four Americans, a hard-won victory for the families of victims who pressured the government to bring him to justice.

headline: The Presidents of Columbia, Howard and N.Y.U. Announce Their Retirements
abstract: Lee Bollinger of Columbia, Wayne A.I. Frederick of Howard and Andrew Hamilton of N.Y.U. have had to guide their universities through Covid.
lead_paragraph: There is suddenly a long Help Wanted list for university presidents. In the past two days, the leaders of Columbia, Howard and New York Universities have announced that they are stepping down.

headline: Frank Langella Fired From Netflix Show After Misconduct Investigation
abstract: The actor was removed from his leading role in the mini-series “The Fall of the House of Usher.” The production plans to reshoot the scenes in which he had appeared.
lead_paragraph: The actor Frank Langella was fired from his leading role in “The Fall of the House of Usher,” a Netflix mini-series based on Edgar Allan Poe works, after a misconduct investigation.

headline: At the Aldrich Museum, the Coyote Takes the Lead
abstract: Duane Slick deploys his canine friend in a thrilling show. For the 60-year-old artist and professor, this first museum solo is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in the Midwest, the artist Duane Slick recalls, spending weekends with his parents and his six siblings at functions with their fellow Meskwaki and Ho-Chunk people was an important part of his life. But the visits also meant that show-and-tell became a fraught activity once he returned to school.

headline: Ukrainians Face New Hurdle at U.S. Border: No Dogs
abstract: Federal health guidelines limit the entry of pets from countries like Ukraine with a high incidence of rabies. For some refugees, the rule has been devastating.
lead_paragraph: Natasha Hrytsenko, a lifelong resident of Ukraine, had always dreamed of having a fluffy white dog. When she started working, Ms. Hrytsenko, now 30, used her first two paychecks to buy a purebred mini Maltese puppy. She brought Eddie home to the Kyiv apartment that she shared with her older sister.

headline: Loro Piana Gets a New Headquarters and Store
abstract: The former was designed by Vincent Van Duysen, and both are set, fittingly, in a storied Milan building that was once the bustling center of the local silk trade.
lead_paragraph: The imposing palazzo that sits at Via della Moscova 33 in Milan’s well-heeled Brera district was once a nexus of the local silk trade. Industrialists and artisans would travel from across Italy to the building, constructed in the late 19th century and known as the Cortile della Seta, to meet, trade and vote on industry matters. During World War II, the structure was destroyed by bombs; it was later rebuilt and used as a bank. As of this year, though, when it became the headquarters for Loro Piana, as well as the site of the 98-year-old brand’s second store devoted to interiors, the palazzo is once again home to high-end textiles.

headline: Mortgage rates climb to 5% for the first time since 2011.
abstract: The increase adds another burden for home buyers who were already struggling with rising prices.
lead_paragraph: U.S. mortgage rates rose to 5 percent for the first time in over a decade, raising the pressure on the housing market and adding another burden to home buyers who were already struggling with rising prices.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Their Favorite Musical Artists, Long Walks and Treating Themselves
abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
lead_paragraph: This week on The Learning Network, we asked teenagers to tell us about their favorite musical artists and to weigh in on this year’s Grammy Awards. We also asked them if they enjoy long walks around their communities and to share how often they treat themselves to something special.

headline: A Napa Favorite Goes Back to the Future
abstract: A new team at Stony Hill is making important changes while embracing its history and its singular style of wines.
lead_paragraph: ST. HELENA, Calif. — Through almost 70 tumultuous years of California wine history, one thing seemed never to change: Stony Hill Vineyard, a pioneer of California chardonnay since its first vintage in 1952 and perhaps Napa Valley’s first cult wine producer.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Mental Health Apps, S.T.I.s and Covid
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: ‘To Olivia’ Review: Roald Dahl and Patricia Neal Cope With Tragedy
abstract: This drama about the author and the actress is poignant, elegant and aggravating.
lead_paragraph: A child’s outstretched hand ignored as she stands at her sister’s grave makes an indelible image in “To Olivia.” This drama, often touching but also vexing, recounts the lives of the children’s book author Roald Dahl and the actress Patricia Neal when their 7-year-old daughter, Olivia, died of complications from measles in 1962.

headline: How Would a Twitter Takeover Work?
abstract: Here's what would happen next with Elon Musk's bid to buy Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Here's what would happen next with Elon Musk's bid to buy Twitter.

headline: Are China and the United States on a Collision Course to War?
abstract: Kevin Rudd’s “The Avoidable War” examines the possibilities of a disaster and the ways China and America can avert it.
lead_paragraph: THE AVOIDABLE WARThe Dangers of a Catastrophic Conflict Between the US and Xi Jinping’s ChinaBy Kevin Rudd

headline: Nursing Homes Are in Crisis. We Can’t Look Away Any Longer.
abstract: The for-profit industry is not providing adequate care for the vulnerable.

headline: ‘Snarge’ Happens, and Studying It Makes Your Flight Safer
abstract: When a bird collides with an airplane, determining its species can help prevent future collisions. To do that, scientists need snarge.
lead_paragraph: When I wrote about European starlings and their complex North American origin story, I didn’t expect readers to be so fascinated by one particular word in the article: snarge. But as the emails, tweets and other feedback poured in, it became clear that this gnarly-sounding six-letter word and the field of scientific inquiry that produced it were worth closer examination.

headline: Paola Pivi’s American Moment
abstract: Behind an artist’s recasting of the Statue of Liberty with an Asian boy’s face is a searing personal story of an orphan.
lead_paragraph: Folks out for a stroll on the High Line this week are pulling out their iPhones to photograph a quizzical new sculpture, “You know who I am,” at the end of a rail spur in a valley of buildings at West 16th Street. Measured to the torch, the 16-foot-tall bronze copy of the Statue of Liberty — her classical face and straight Greek nose fitted with an emoji-like mask of an Asian boy — stands like a question mark asking visitors to connect two incongruous dots: the draped, classical figure that everyone knows, and a cartoon face with a button nose and startled eyes.

headline: With Jackson Headed to Supreme Court, New Judicial Battles Loom
abstract: Democrats aim to fill as many court vacancies as possible by the end of 2022, when Senate Republicans are in reach of winning control and slamming the brakes on President Biden’s picks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The partisan clash that concluded with the confirmation of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court is hardly the end of judicial showdowns in the Senate.

headline: He Made an N.H.L. Career Out of Being a Pest. It Isn’t Working in Court.
abstract: Sean Avery, the former Rangers hockey player, chose to represent himself in court on Thursday on a misdemeanor charge. The judge advised him not to.
lead_paragraph: The former New York Rangers player Sean Avery was known during his 13 seasons in the National Hockey League for being a provocateur. In retirement, he appears to have had a difficult time letting go of the role.

headline: Legal Marijuana Sales Will Start Next Thursday in New Jersey
abstract: All adults will be able to purchase cannabis at certain medical-marijuana dispensaries starting April 21.
lead_paragraph: The first sales of recreational, adult-use cannabis in New Jersey will start next Thursday, marking the culmination of a yearslong effort to legalize marijuana and to curtail the racially unbalanced penalties for possessing the drug.

headline: ‘We’re Never Going to Get That Top 40 Out of Us’
abstract: Wesley Morris loves awards shows, countdowns and best-of lists of all kinds. Is there any way to make them more inclusive?
lead_paragraph: This episode contains strong language.

headline: Feeling Like a Passover Pariah? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: When even Elijah has a seat at the table … but you don’t.
lead_paragraph: “There should be a JSwipe for Passover Seders,” said Pamela Rae Schuller, referring to the popular Jewish dating app. “We will show you pictures of the food we cook, and you swipe if you are into it.”

headline: ‘This Is American History’: The Hall of Fame Reconsiders Race
abstract: Dave Winfield and Ken Griffey Jr. will be among the advisers for a permanent exhibit that re-examines the contributions of Jackie Robinson and others.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Robinson lived only a decade as a Hall of Famer. He suffered from diabetes and died of a heart attack at age 53, in 1972. Robinson had integrated the major leagues a quarter-century before, and he never stopped striving for social justice.

headline: Hubble Telescope Zooms In on the Biggest Comet Ever Spotted
abstract: The space observatory helped scientists make a more precise measurement of the comet, which has a mass of 500 trillion tons and an appearance like burned toast.
lead_paragraph: Last year, scientists announced that they had discovered a colossal comet lingering just inside Neptune’s orbit. They estimated its icy core to be between 62 and 125 miles long, based on its brightness. If the estimates were accurate, this would be the largest comet ever discovered.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: If you’re looking for something to watch, our TV critic has great recommendations this week from Japan, the Netherlands and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: ‘Old Enough’When to watch: Now, on Netflix.

headline: Moody’s warns that Russia’s bond payments in rubles could lead to default.
abstract: The failure to fulfill its foreign debt obligation would be the first in more than a century for Russia, dealing with sanctions after its invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s repayment of foreign currency bonds in rubles could be considered a default if it does not reverse course and pay in dollars, Moody’s, the ratings agency, said on Thursday.

headline: New York City to Expand Gifted and Talented Program but Scrap Test
abstract: The mayor unveiled a plan to add seats in the highly selective program for both kindergartners and third graders and to permanently replace an admissions test with universal screening.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams on Thursday unveiled a plan to expand the city’s gifted and talented classes for elementary students and to permanently eliminate the contentious admissions test given to 4-year-olds in an effort to address concerns that the program has shortchanged low-income and Black and Latino students.

headline: Can an Art History Frame Help Expand the NFT Market?
abstract: An upcoming auction by Sotheby’s is the latest attempt to recast crypto collectibles as an artistic evolution and perhaps draw interest from a wider circle of collectors.
lead_paragraph: When digital artworks started selling for millions of dollars last year, the shock of pixelated punks and computerized graphics turned some traditional collectors into crypto skeptics.

headline: Brunch Cocktails That Go Beyond the Bellini
abstract: An Italian classic and a spin on spiked coffee are both sure to be a hit at the table.
lead_paragraph: Brunch isn’t truly brunch without a bevy of beverages: coffee, water, juice and, if you’re drinking alcohol that day, a cocktail. Unlimited mimosas and heavily adorned Bloody Marys are longtime go-tos, but you certainly need not limit yourself to them.

headline: Musk’s Twitter bid appeared to include a recurring reference to marijuana.
abstract: The Tesla chief executive has a history of incorporating a cannabis term into business decisions.
lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk has been at the center of a media storm, there has been a common thread that has appeared several times.

headline: Film Club: ‘The Life of Jerry Givens, a State Executioner Turned Death-Row Abolitionist’
abstract: What can we learn from Mr. Givens’s personal journey? What does it say about the issue of capital punishment?
lead_paragraph: “The Life of Jerry Givens, a State Executioner Turned Death-Row Abolitionist” is a seven-minute film from the Times’s “Cause of Life” video series that celebrates the messy, tenacious and extraordinary lives of people we lost to Covid-19. It profiles the life of Jerry Givens, a devout Christian who was Virginia’s chief executioner before he became an advocate of abolishing the death penalty. After learning firsthand about how the system was unjust, he spent the rest of his life trying to make amends.

headline: Franz Mohr, Piano Tuner to the Stars, Is Dead at 94
abstract: “I play more in Carnegie Hall than anybody else,” he said of his career adjusting instruments for Horowitz, Gould and others, “but I have no audience.”
lead_paragraph: Franz Mohr, who in his 24 years as the chief concert technician for Steinway & Sons brought a musician’s mind-set to the mechanics of important pianos and the care of those who played them, died on March 28 at his home in Lynbrook, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 94.

headline: Elon Musk Knows Exactly What He’s Doing
abstract: The billionaire could be at the helm of the internet’s loudest megaphone.
lead_paragraph: You can say this about Elon Musk: He’s never boring.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Flagship Sinks
abstract: Plus Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter and Britain’s plan to resettle asylum seekers … in Rwanda.
lead_paragraph: The flagship of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet sunk on Thursday after it suffered catastrophic damage.

headline: Deadly Wildfire Spreads in New Mexico
abstract: The McBride fire began Tuesday afternoon in Ruidoso, N.M., a village in the Sierra Blanca mountains. Officials said at least two people had been killed and more than 5,000 acres had burned.
lead_paragraph: The McBride fire began Tuesday afternoon in Ruidoso, N.M., a village in the Sierra Blanca mountains. Officials said at least two people had been killed and more than 5,000 acres had burned.

headline: Russia Hits Setbacks, as Flagship Sinks and E.U. Mulls Oil Ban
abstract: Ukraine said it hit a Russian warship in the Black Sea with its own missiles, a damaging blow to Moscow, symbolically and militarily, if its claim is confirmed.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Russia’s faltering war against Ukraine suffered a pair of setbacks Thursday when the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet sank after a catastrophic explosion and fire, as the European Union moved closer to an embargo on Russian oil imports.

headline: The Sinking of the Moskva
abstract: The flagship of Russia’s Black Sea fleet was damaged by a fire or a Ukrainian missile.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Former Nassau County Executive Sentenced to 12 Years in Bribery Scheme
abstract: Edward P. Mangano and his wife, Linda, were both convicted for their parts in what prosecutors called “a culture of corruption.”
lead_paragraph: Edward P. Mangano, the former Nassau County executive who for years participated in a bribery and kickback scheme, was sentenced Thursday to 12 years in federal prison for his role in what prosecutors called “a culture of corruption” at the heart of Long Island’s Republican political machine.

headline: Ohio Man Who Blamed Trump for Storming the Capitol Is Found Guilty
abstract: Dustin Thompson was the first defendant tried for his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack to use a Trump-made-me-do-it defense in front of a jury. He was convicted on all six charges against him.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio man who claimed that Donald J. Trump was legally responsible for his decision to break into the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and make off with a bottle of bourbon and a coat rack was convicted on Thursday in the first trial connected to the riot to feature a defense that blamed the former president.

headline: Tensions Over the Ukraine War Deepen the Chill Near the North Pole
abstract: The war and the comments of a Russian diplomat have strained relations on an archipelago in Norway where Russians, Ukrainians and Norwegians have lived peacefully for decades.
lead_paragraph: BARENTSBURG, Norway — At first glance, Sergey Gushchin, 50, is perhaps not a man one would assume to be the Russian consul general at the world’s northernmost diplomatic mission: ponytail, bluejeans, bass player in a punk band.

headline: Musk Says He Has the Means to Buy Twitter, but Investors Aren’t So Sure
abstract: Elon Musk could pledge his Tesla shares, borrow from banks or team up with private equity to raise the funds. Each option comes with caveats.
lead_paragraph: People who try to take over companies typically go to great lengths to show they have put together the money they need to do it. Not Elon Musk.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ed Buck Is Sentenced to 30 Years for Fatally Drugging 2 Men
abstract: Mr. Buck, 67, was once a Democratic political donor and activist who led a double life in which he lured men to parties at his apartment and drugged them with methamphetamine. Two of those parties turned fatal.
lead_paragraph: Ed Buck, a onetime Democratic donor and activist, was sentenced by a federal judge in Los Angeles on Thursday to 30 years in prison for giving two men fatal doses of methamphetamine at his West Hollywood apartment, prosecutors said.

headline: Marvin Chomsky, Director of ‘Roots’ and ‘Holocaust,’ Dies at 92
abstract: A four-time Emmy Award winner, he directed landmark historical TV dramas and the movie “Inside the Third Reich.”
lead_paragraph: Marvin Chomsky, an Emmy Award-winning director renowned for his work on historical dramas, including the blockbuster mini-series “Roots” and “Holocaust,” died on March 28 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 92.

headline: The G.O.P. Is Still the Party of Plutocrats
abstract: Unlike Europe’s right, it won’t even gesture toward actual populism.
lead_paragraph: I recently wrote about how international trade has made some Western nations — Germany in particular — unwilling to confront autocracy. Germany hasn’t just been weak-kneed in its response to Vladimir Putin; it and other European nations have stood by and even continued to provide economic aid to Hungary while Viktor Orban dismantles democracy.

headline: Democrats Face Tough Questions as a Border Saga Enters a New Chapter
abstract: We spoke with two White House correspondents for The New York Times, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear, about a Trump-era immigration policy that the Biden administration is ending.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is grappling with the political fallout of the end of Title 42, a pandemic-era policy established during the Trump administration that turned away most migrants from the border. I spoke with Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear, who reported recently on the administration’s divisions over immigration policy.

headline: Gina McCarthy, Top Climate Adviser, Is Said to Be Planning Departure
abstract: Ms. McCarthy was tapped by President Biden to lead an ambitious domestic climate agenda. Associates say she is frustrated by the slow pace of progress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gina McCarthy, the White House climate adviser, has told confidants that she has been frustrated by the slow pace of climate progress and intends to step down in the coming months, according to several people to whom she has spoken.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: Of Monsters and Men
abstract: This week’s episode takes a deep detour inside the mind of our protagonist.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Luc Picard’s subconscious is a largely unexplored subject in “Trek” lore, despite Jean-Luc being such an oft-discussed character. “Monsters” shows us that our friendly neighborhood captain has demons in his head that he is literally running from.

headline: Elon Musk, After Toying With Twitter, Now Wants It All
abstract: The billionaire executive recently became one of the company’s largest shareholders. Now he says he wants to buy the whole thing and change how it handles speech.
lead_paragraph: Follow for the latest updates on Elon Musk and Twitter.

headline: Man Is Charged With Arson in Fire at an L.G.B.T.Q. Club in Brooklyn
abstract: Prosecutors said John Lhota can be seen on security camera footage setting the blaze, which destroyed the club, Rash, and injured two workers.
lead_paragraph: A man wearing jeans and a gray hooded sweatshirt leaves his Brooklyn apartment on a Sunday night. About 10 minutes later, he fills a gasoline canister at a service station. Ten minutes after that, he walks into a new L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in the Bushwick section.

headline: The F.D.A. authorizes the first coronavirus breath test.
abstract: The InspectIR Covid-19 Breathalyzer, which is about the size of a piece of carry-on luggage, can produce results in less than three minutes and can be used in doctor’s offices, hospitals and mobile testing sites by trained operators.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration granted emergency use authorization to the first coronavirus test that can detect the coronavirus in a breath sample, within a few minutes and with a high degree of accuracy, the agency said Thursday.

headline: C.I.A. Director Airs Concern That Putin Might Turn to Nuclear Weapons
abstract: William J. Burns, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, cautioned that he had seen no “practical evidence” that would suggest such a move was imminent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The director of the C.I.A. said on Thursday that “potential desperation” to extract the semblance of a victory in Ukraine could tempt President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to order the use of a tactical or low-yield nuclear weapon, publicly discussing for the first time a concern that has coursed through the White House during seven weeks of conflict.

headline: Nebraska State Senator Says Candidate for Governor Groped Her
abstract: The state senator, Julie Slama, confirmed a news report saying that Charles Herbster, a leading candidate for governor, had touched her inappropriately in 2019. He denied the allegations.
lead_paragraph: A Republican state senator in Nebraska said on Thursday that she had been groped three years ago by a fellow Republican who is now a leading candidate in the party’s primary election for governor next month.

headline: ‘She Was Not Trash’: Body Found in Indiana Is Identified After 30 Years
abstract: Advances in DNA technology helped the authorities to identify remains found near a highway in 1992 as those of Margaret Ann Sniegowski Jr., who had disappeared from her home in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: For three decades, she was known only as Jane Doe, ever since her body was found dumped on the embankment of an interstate highway in Indiana in May 1992.

headline: The Case for Criticism
abstract: Experts say fear keeps us from sharing constructive feedback, but here’s how — and why — you should speak up anyway.
lead_paragraph: One thing I want to improve about myself is my ability to tell other people how to improve themselves. I am terrible at giving constructive feedback. I recently hired an administrative assistant, and I find myself far more inclined to praise her for how well she’s doing than to provide suggestions that might help her do an even better job — even though doing so would not only benefit her but also directly benefit me.

headline: A Financial Services Company Illegally Leased Dogs, Massachusetts Says
abstract: Monterey Financial Services LLC has agreed to pay $930,000 in debt relief and restitution to settle allegations that it was conducting the practice, which is banned in the Bay State and others.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Catalina Ortiz-Sierra lost her job and failed to make payments on what she thought was a loan, a collections agent in 2019 threatened to take away her dog, Milo, a Shih Tzu-poodle mix.

headline: Review: ‘Cyrano de Bergerac,’ Now Noseless and Drunk on Words
abstract: James McAvoy gives a ravishing performance, without benefit of prosthetics or props, in a new adaptation alive with the love of language.
lead_paragraph: “Ah, good my lords, what a nose is his! When one sees it, one is fain to cry aloud, ‘Nay! ’tis too much!’”

headline: Honoring the Past by Focusing on the Future
abstract: Named after a team from the Negro leagues, the Nashville Stars give young players, Black and white, passion and purpose in the game.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — It’s fitting that the Nashville Stars, a team for players ages 10 and under, are named in honor of an old Negro leagues team that played in Music City in the 1930s, ’40s, and ’50s. From the aggressive base running to the all-Black coaching staff and the speaker blaring a mix of hip-hop and R&B from the bleachers, the Stars embody the energy and excitement that made pre-integration Black baseball a cultural phenomenon as much as a sporting attraction. The team also serves as a stark contradiction of the stereotypical image of American youth baseball.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Presses Stephen Miller on Whether Trump Sought to Incite Crowd
abstract: In about eight hours of questioning, investigators pressed the former White House aide on former President Donald J. Trump’s use of “we” in his speech to supporters before the riot.
lead_paragraph: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol spent roughly eight hours on Thursday questioning Stephen Miller, a top White House adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, in an at times contentious exchange that included queries about Mr. Trump’s speech before a crowd the morning of the riot, according to two people familiar with the session.

headline: Kisses and Hugs
abstract: Trenton Charlson outfoxes us by thinking outside the box, without pushing the envelope.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — A Trenton Charlson puzzle is a good companion for a gray day, a blah day — or a day when you find out that in spite of all those precautions your faraway friends teased you for taking, you have landed in the Covid zone.

headline: Review: In ‘American Buffalo,’ Grift Is the Coin of the Realm
abstract: Sam Rockwell, Laurence Fishburne and Darren Criss star in an electric revival of the David Mamet play about capitalism in a junk shop.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday’s edition of the Fox News show “Life, Liberty & Levin,” David Mamet, the playwright turned Trumpite culture warrior, made an incendiary comment.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Daniel Raymon rustles up a real challenge.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This puzzle, a tough example of the Puns and Anagrams genre, is by a multitalented Times constructor, Daniel Raymon, who makes cryptic crosswords and daily grids as well. If you’ve been wondering about trying cryptics, I think if you can get through this grid, you’ll be ready to try more. It’s not that “Panda” puzzles are easy, but they do follow regular crossword rules: Every square is crossed by two entries, so you have two chances to figure everything out. There are also far more anagrams, which usually help a solver out. On the other hand, the puns can be pretty wild.

headline: A California legislator ended his efforts to pass a vaccine mandate for students.
abstract: The bill would have eliminated a personal belief exemption that has been used to circumvent similar mandates.
lead_paragraph: A bill that would have required all California students to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, eliminating a personal belief exemption that has been used to circumvent similar mandates, was pulled by its legislative sponsor on Thursday.

headline: Slowing Down Sped Up Their Relationship
abstract: Kabir Melwani and Leah Madeline Freedland met in graduate school, but really bonded while living in his parents’ home for months during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Kabir Melwani and Leah Madeline Freedland are never at a loss for adjectives when each is asked to describe the other.

headline: Bonding Over Faith and Football
abstract: Janice Matamoros and Rayburn Ewers, both octogenarians, met after moving to a senior living community in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Janice Matamoros and Rayburn Ewers, who goes by Otto, each prayed a lot before moving to the Belmont Village Senior Living community in Lakeway, Texas, in 2019. Though both of their prayers were answered, hers came with a bit of a twist.

headline: The Loneliness of the Locked-Down Single Mother
abstract: Having a job, a child and no help during a pandemic can take a toll — but also forge a special bond.
lead_paragraph: It began with a missing package. One day I got a message from a stranger on LinkedIn: “You don’t know me, but I live across the street, and I think I have your package.”

headline: Two Epic Dates and an Incredible Arcade Game Feat
abstract: Jennifer Banegas proposed to Alyssa Bush with a video game scoreboard and the words: “Ken Wil You Mar Me?”
lead_paragraph: When Alyssa Bush traveled from Baltimore to Seattle in February 2019, it was mainly to visit a friend with a new baby. But she also wanted to explore the city. With her friend preoccupied by parenthood, Ms. Bush logged into Tinder and Bumble, hoping to connect with someone she could meet for a drink or a meal. On both dating apps, she matched with Jennifer Banegas.

headline: The Cat’s Approval Was a Good Start
abstract: After nearly two decades together, Stuart Rembaum and Jim Post finally agreed to marry — but not before Mr. Rembaum’s cat “sanctioned the relationship” by allowing Mr. Post to pet her.
lead_paragraph: Even after being together for nearly two decades, Stuart Rembaum still struggled to find the words when it came to discussing a possible wedding to Jim Post.

headline: In a Week, Moving a Wedding from Ukraine to New York
abstract: In their last phone call before they married, Meny Stambler, who is Ukrainian, and Rikel Deutch, who is Russian, expected to wed in Ukraine. Hours after they hung up, Russian troops had invaded.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday evening in late February, Meny Stambler and Rikel Deutch talked to each other on the phone for the last time before their wedding.

headline: Moving From Elegy to Ecstasy, a Poet Pushes Against the Canon
abstract: In “Best Barbarian,” Roger Reeves riffs on Western tradition to challenge its omissions and expand its political and artistic possibilities.
lead_paragraph: Proceeding in prayerlike incantation, “Best Barbarian,” Roger Reeves’s terrific second collection, eruditely sets out to unite the Western literary canon with its omissions and oppressions. These poems resurrect an eclectic cast of characters, from Sappho to James Baldwin, to reflect on the poet’s vital yet unanswerable question: “What disaster will I deliver to my daughter?” From playful abecedarians to a psychedelic “durational” poem (which, when read aloud, is roughly the length of the Alice Coltrane song that inspired it) the reader traverses a sonic landscape from elegy to ecstasy.

headline: He Never Existed. Here Are His Selected Poems.
abstract: In “Madness,” the poet Gabriel Ojeda-Sagué has assembled a career retrospective for a writer he invented from whole cloth.
lead_paragraph: In his innovative fourth poetry collection, “Madness,” Gabriel Ojeda-Sagué imagines the life and work of a fictional “minor” poet named Luis Montes-Torres, who is said to have been born in 1976 and to have died of complications from brain cancer at the age of 58, in 2035. “Madness” is presented as a retrospective volume of his selected poems, published with analysis and commentary 20 years after his death.

headline: A Poet Who Looks at the Stuff of Daily Life and Sees Looming Apocalypse
abstract: Again and again in Ange Mlinko’s collection “Venice,” quotidian events generate nightmarish overtones.
lead_paragraph: Ange Mlinko’s poems are animated by an unusual combination of impulses. They are formal, highly polished, with hard, smooth surfaces and dense interiors, the products of intense and serious craft. But whereas formal so often suggests staid or restrained, Mlinko’s poems are anything but. They are wild, energetic, alive, wantonly catholic in their allusiveness, often downright chatty. Some have the feel of postcards, especially in their opening lines. “The hotel showers were splendidly profligate,” begins one poem in “Venice,” Mlinko’s sixth collection. The next one starts: “After the olivine waves of Marina di Torre del Lago,/we drive between colonnades of umbrella pines.”

headline: Best Known as a Holocaust Poet, Nelly Sachs Deserves Another Look
abstract: The Nobel laureate’s postwar collection “Flight and Metamorphosis,” published in 1959 and newly translated into English, reveals a poet full of mystery and depth.
lead_paragraph: An inviting poem is usually easy to understand; a good poem — inviting or not — usually complicates into surprise and depth. The poems in Nelly Sachs’s “Flight and Metamorphosis,” first published in German in 1959 and newly translated by the poet-critic-scholar Joshua Weiner (with Linda B. Parshall), seem little interested in invitation. But they are full of shifting surprises, mysteries and depths.

headline: One Last Book From an Outback Poet Who Was Part Hero, Part Pariah
abstract: Les Murray’s posthumous collection “Continuous Creation” highlights both his crankiness and the rough magnificence of the landscape he loved.
lead_paragraph: Born and raised in New South Wales, Australia, Les Murray was gaptoothed, pigheaded, booming, burly. (He would have said fat.) His childhood in Bunyah was not a long way from nowhere — you’d have to pass Coolongolook, Cooranbong and a lot of other one-kangaroo towns to get to Sydney, three hours away. A lover of the outback, molded but not deformed by university, he was proud of not belonging, boasting his degree the “least distinguished” ever bestowed by the University of Sydney. The best poet Australia had seen for a generation or two, by his early 30s he lived in partial exile from the literary scene. His longing for the bush grew until in his 40s he moved back to part of the old family dairy farm.

headline: Facing ‘the Can’t-See of the Future,’ in Verse and at the Chiropractor’s
abstract: In “Now Do You Know Where You Are,” the poet Dana Levin learns to write again and comes to terms with personal and political trauma.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of poets in the world — poets who write poetry, and poets who don’t. I fall into the second company as of late. So do many of my literary acquaintances. Mostly we write plaintive emails to each other about not writing poetry. It’s almost a genre.

headline: A Poet Looks at the End of the World, and Reaches for Hope
abstract: In “Canopy,” her seventh collection, Linda Gregerson mourns for humanity and the earth even as she clings to signs of personal connection.
lead_paragraph: What should we do about the end of the world? What about the end of our own lives? What should we say if we can’t do anything? Such questions have a history in poems as old as the history of poems: They animate funeral elegies, prayers to forestall the apocalypse, deathbed repentance like John Donne’s. And they have new resonance now, when climate change and global plague and general public exhaustion have put so many of us into such a rough mood, “casting about for ways to summon normal,” as the careful, careworn, learned Michigan poet Linda Gregerson says. Gregerson’s seventh collection tries patiently and concisely to support our aging bodies, our battered ecosystems and our traditions of memorable speech, along with her own Midwestern immigrant heritage with its “Scandinavian Grim.”

headline: Ocean Vuong Brings Books to Lunch Dates, ‘Just in Case’
abstract: “I feel truer to myself while reading than I do experiencing the world through my body — so any chance to read is ideal for me.”
lead_paragraph: “A Lesson Before Dying,” by Ernest J. Gaines, “Walking in Wonder,” by John O’Donohue (in conversation with John Quinn), “A Death in the Family,” by James Agee, “Afropessimism,” by Frank B. Wilderson, “We Think the World of You,” by J.R. Ackerley, “Jane Eyre,” by Charlotte Brontë, “Hot Milk,” by Deborah Levy, “Poetics of Relation,” by Édouard Glissant, “The Sign of Jonas,” by Thomas Merton.

headline: The U.S.F.L. Isn’t Back. The U.S.F.L. Is Here.
abstract: Here’s what to know about the pro football league with the familiar name that begins its season on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The nicknames are familiar to those with long memories: the New Jersey Generals, the Philadelphia Stars, the Tampa Bay Bandits. So is the league name: the U.S.F.L.

headline: In Edna St. Vincent Millay’s Diaries, the Private Life of a Celebrity Poet
abstract: Seven decades after Millay’s death, “Rapture and Melancholy” paints a picture of artistic triumph, romantic tumult and a daily life that descended into addiction.
lead_paragraph: Edna St. Vincent Millay (1892-1950) was once the most famous poet in America. Her collections sold tens of thousands of copies, and her readings filled theaters from New York to Texas. She was the female voice of the Jazz Age, the New Woman incarnate whose passionate and iconoclastic verse earned her a devoted following. Her 1920 poem “First Fig” became an anthem for a generation tired of Victorian mores:

headline: The Shape of the Void: Toward a Definition of Poetry
abstract: “Poetry leaves something out,” our columnist Elisa Gabbert says. But that’s hardly the extent of it.
lead_paragraph: I once heard a student say poetry is language that’s “coherent enough.” I love a definition this ambiguous. It’s both helpful (there’s a limit to coherence, and the limit is aesthetic) and unhelpful (enough for what, or whom?). It reminds me of a dictionary entry for “detritus” that I copied down in a notebook: “the pieces that are left when something breaks, falls apart, is destroyed, etc.” That seemed so artfully vague to me, so uncharacteristically casual for a dictionary. It has a quality of distraction, of trailing off, of suggesting you already know what detritus means. Part of me resists the question of what poetry is, or resists the answer — you already know what it means.

headline: A Poet’s Poet: The Astonishing Career of John Keats
abstract: Robert Pinsky reviews Lucasta Miller’s “Keats: A Brief Life in Nine Poems and One Epitaph.”
lead_paragraph: Early in her book about John Keats, Lucasta Miller calls Lord Byron an “aristocratic megastar.” That funny epithet is accurate for Byron’s more-than-superstar celebrity in his day. It also suggests the many ways Byron was the opposite of Keats. Miller quotes Byron, in a letter, referring to the younger and much less well-known poet as “Jack Keats or Ketch or whatever his names are.”

headline: The First Fully Illustrated Selection of Pablo Neruda’s Question Poems
abstract: “Book of Questions,” the Nobel laureate’s last great work of poetry, is lyrical, meditative, philosophical. Is it also for children?
lead_paragraph: BOOK OF QUESTIONSBy Pablo NerudaIllustrated by Paloma ValdiviaTranslated by Sara Lissa Paulson

headline: Corrections: April 15, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about how the shift to remote work has affected New York City misstated the percentage of New York workers who went into the office before the pandemic. It is more than 90 percent, not 80 percent.

headline: What is Poetry?
abstract: To celebrate National Poetry Month, we’re devoting an entire issue to the form.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate National Poetry Month, we’re devoting an entire issue to the form.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Short Fuses and Plentiful Guns: Bullets Fly on U.S. Roads
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “This was not a road rage incident — this was a grown man who took the life of a child because his feelings got hurt.”

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Obstacles to Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s faltering war against Ukraine met further obstacles yesterday when the flagship of its Black Sea fleet sank after a catastrophic explosion and fire, and the E.U. moved closer to an embargo on Russian oil imports. Follow the latest updates from the war.

headline: War Brings New Iron Curtain Down on Russia’s Storied Ballet Stages
abstract: Ballet has long been a symbol of Russian culture. Now it is becoming a symbol of Russian isolation.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Just days after the invasion of Ukraine, Olga Smirnova, one of Russia’s most important ballerinas, posted an emotional statement on Telegram, the messaging app. “I am against war with all the fibers of my soul,” she wrote.

headline: Late Night Isn’t Thrilled About Elon Musk’s Attempted Twitter Takeover
abstract: “He is super smart, definitely, but he admits that he also loves dumb jokes, so we don’t know how this could turn out,” Trevor Noah said of the Tesla C.E.O.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
abstract: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.
lead_paragraph: LUBLIN, Poland — On a recent morning, I sat in the sun-filled dining room of a tidy house in eastern Poland, across from one of the most generous men I’ve ever met.

headline: Word of the Day: illustrious
abstract: This word has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word illustrious has appeared in 92 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 2 in “Broadway’s Cort Theater Will Have a New Name: James Earl Jones” by Michael Paulson:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Fuel Prices Send Airfares Higher, but Travelers Seem Ready to Pay
abstract: Supplies are not keeping up with demand, and costs may go higher, experts say.
lead_paragraph: A stunning rise in the cost of jet fuel has sent airfares soaring, and industry experts say they are likely to go higher. For now, though, travel-starved consumers seem more than willing to pay up.

headline: Cities Try to Turn the Tide on Police Traffic Stops
abstract: Chiefs, prosecutors and lawmakers are rethinking the value, and the harm, of minor traffic stops like the one that ended in a man’s death in Grand Rapids.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles is overhauling its traffic policing, aiming to stop pulling over cars — frequently with Black drivers — for trivial infractions like broken taillights or expired tags as a pretext to search for drugs or guns.

headline: ‘Choose or Die’ Review: Press Start. Or Not.
abstract: In this horror movie, a vintage computer game forces players to make gruesome decisions.
lead_paragraph: “Choose or Die” almost sounds like a marketing slogan for Netflix’s scroll of mediocrities — but no, it’s just another horror movie on the streaming service. As horror movies go, you could choose better.

headline: Kim Jong-un Gives North Korean TV Anchor a Luxury Home
abstract: Ri Chun-hee, who delivers the news with a soaring, bombastic tenor, received a two-story apartment in a riverside complex from the country’s leader, apparently for her loyalty.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — When a brand-new luxury residential district opened in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, this week, the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said it would be reserved for his most elite supporters, those he called “true patriots.”

headline: Mayor Adams Adds More Spots in Gifted Programs
abstract: A hundred places for kindergartners and 1,000 for third graders will be added in an attempt to make the program more equitable.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Mayor Eric Adams plans to reboot the gifted and talented program for the city’s public schools. We’ll also look at a former New York Rangers player whose scrappiness in the courtroom brought back memories of scrappiness on the ice. And the Mets will play their home opener today.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 15, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Journey to Transnistria: Inside Russia’s Disinformation Bubble
abstract: We traveled inside Transnistria, a Moscow-backed breakaway state in Moldova, to find out how Russia’s disinformation campaign stretches beyond its borders.
lead_paragraph: We traveled inside Transnistria, a Moscow-backed breakaway state in Moldova, to find out how Russia’s disinformation campaign stretches beyond its borders.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of “Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore.”
lead_paragraph: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a review of “Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore.”

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Second Place’ and ‘Lady Bird Johnson’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: SECOND PLACE, by Rachel Cusk. (Picador, 192 pp., $17.) Cusk’s first novel since her acclaimed Outline trilogy shares similarities to her previous work — a sharply observant narrator, meditations on themes of art, beauty and the “tyranny” of parenthood — but it is also a departure. Dwight Garner, the Times critic, commented that this book has “a swirling hothouse quality that’s new” and that it “pushes its needles into the red.”

headline: Newly Published Poetry, From Gaza to Zoom Rooms and More
abstract: A selection of new poetry collections, from Mosab Abu Toha, Marlanda Dekine, Basie Allen, Shane McCrae, Ama Asantewa Diaka, Mary Jo Salter, Eloisa Amezcua and D. Nurkse.
lead_paragraph: THINGS YOU MAY FIND HIDDEN IN MY EAR: Poems From Gaza, by Mosab Abu Toha. (City Lights, paper, $11.17.) Written from his native Gaza, Abu Toha’s accomplished debut contrasts scenes of political violence with natural beauty: In one poem, a “nightingale departs the wet earth” two stanzas before the “sound of a drone / intrudes.”

headline: Yellow Creatures
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: What Good Friday and Easter Mean for Black Americans Like Me
abstract: Jesus’ story does not end with his crucifixion. Similarly, racism will not have the final word.
lead_paragraph: I encountered my first corpse in middle school. My cousin Tammy, one of the most beautiful members of our family, died of complications from AIDS at the age of 28. The last time I saw her alive, lesions covered the portions of her frail frame not draped in hospital blankets and IVs.

headline: Poems of Exile, Introspection and Self-Discovery (Cicadas, Too)
abstract: New collections from Akwaeke Emezi, Solmaz Sharif, Colm Toibin and Phoebe Giannisi.
lead_paragraph: In 39 concise, impactful poems, Akwaeke Emezi’s debut collection, CONTENT WARNING: EVERYTHING (47 pp., Copper Canyon, paperback, $16), is a triumph of selfhood that painstakingly journeys between belief and becoming. Holding tenderness and rage in one breath, the Nigerian-born nonbinary author excavates trauma, divorce and loss without restraint: “what wars have been fought on me what hauntings I carry in the blaze of/unspeakable light.” Emezi has previously written a memoir and screenplays as well as fiction, but poetry feels like a natural fit for the presumably autobiographical material in this collection, which often soothes as much as it shocks.

headline: Reporting From Amazon’s Hometown, and Seeing the Company Everywhere
abstract: Karen Weise, a technology correspondent, shares how she covers Amazon and its far-reaching businesses.
lead_paragraph: Karen Weise is a technology correspondent based in Seattle who has covered Amazon, which is headquartered there, for The Times since 2018. With its e-commerce operation, line of web services and grocery businesses, Amazon maintains a vast reach across American society. The company has been on a hiring spree in recent years, including a large push during the pandemic, which has brought its role as a major U.S. employer into sharper focus.

headline: Repetition, Repetition, Repetition: Working With Alliteration, Anaphora and Epistrophe in Poetry
abstract: In three short lessons, students will explore three types of literary devices using The New York Times Magazine’s Poem column.
lead_paragraph: Poets love to use repetition in their poems.

headline: How Do You Come Together With Your Community?
abstract: Do you participate in community events like parades, dances or concerts?
lead_paragraph: As pandemic restrictions ease, have you been able to gather with your community for block parties, fairs or festivals? How has it felt to come together in those ways again?

headline: In This Time of War, I Propose We Give Up God
abstract: Why would we emulate such terrible behavior?
lead_paragraph: This weekend, Jews around the world will celebrate the holiday of Passover, the name of which comes from the story of God passing over the homes of our distant ancestors on his way to slaughter the firstborn sons of evil Egyptians. Our forefathers, the story goes, marked their doorposts with lamb’s blood in order to spare their sons the awful fate of their enemies’.

headline: The Cruel Lesson of a Single Medical Mistake
abstract: A Tennessee nurse is facing prison time for a medical error.
lead_paragraph: We all carry the memory of our mistakes. For health care workers like me, these memories surface in the early morning when we cannot sleep or at a bedside where, in some way, we are reminded of a patient who came before. Most were errors in judgment or near misses: a procedure we thought could wait, a subtle abnormality in vital signs that didn’t register as a harbinger of serious illness, an X-ray finding missed, a central line nearly placed in the wrong blood vessel. Even the best of us have stories of missteps, close calls that are caught before they ever cause patient harm.

headline: How Love Changes Your Brain
abstract: In her new book, Stephanie Cacioppo, a neuroscientist, delves into romance, loss and human connection as she writes of her love story with her husband.
lead_paragraph: Can we do without love? For many years, the neuroscientist Stephanie Ortigue believed that the answer was yes. Even though she researched the science of human connections, Dr. Ortigue — an only child and, in her 20s and 30s, contentedly single — couldn’t completely grasp its importance in her own life.

headline: Military Memo Deepens Possible Interstellar Meteor Mystery
abstract: The U.S. Space Command seemed to confirm a claim that a meteor from outside the solar system had entered Earth’s atmosphere, but other scientists and NASA are still not convinced.
lead_paragraph: In early 2014, a dishwasher-size meteor dashed over the shores of Papua New Guinea before sunrise as it burned up in the fiery friction of Earth’s atmosphere. But two Harvard researchers argued that this wasn’t just any space rock: It originated from another star system, they said, making it the first observed meteor of interstellar origin.

headline: Wait, What if People Did Just Stay Home in Their Pajamas?
abstract: New neighborhood businesses far from Midtown are thriving. Maybe it’s time to redefine what “comeback” means.
lead_paragraph: For several weeks now, Mayor Eric Adams has been obsessively pushing a recovery agenda hinged on the return of tens of thousands of workers to offices in Midtown and Lower Manhattan. In his plan, the pandemic would be left more or less to history when the starting bell signaling the return to normalcy rings. But the surreal counterprogramming of the past few days gave us, instead, a Covid-positive mayor addressing a rattled city from quarantine after a gunman opened fire on an N train in Brooklyn during rush hour on Tuesday morning.

headline: How Rocco DiSpirito, Chef, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Food is the focus, from afternoons at Balthazar to cooking for his family and friends at night.
lead_paragraph: Rocco DiSpirito has been a fixture on the American food scene since the 1990s. He has owned a three-star restaurant, been a reality television star and written over a dozen cookbooks, which range in theme from Italian American to “comfort keto.”

headline: How Barnes & Noble Went From Villain to Hero
abstract: To independent booksellers, the enormous chain was once a threat. Now it’s vital to their survival. And it’s doing well.
lead_paragraph: After years on the decline, Barnes & Noble’s sales are up, its costs are down — and the same people who for decades saw the superchain as a supervillain are celebrating its success.

headline: Biden to Nominate Michael Barr as Fed Vice Chair for Supervision
abstract: Mr. Barr faced pushback from progressives when his name was floated for a different position.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Friday that it intended to nominate Michael S. Barr, a law professor and a former Obama administration official, to be the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision.

headline: How to Negotiate for Better Pay and Perks When the Job Offer Lands
abstract: With workers in high demand, the most costly mistake they can make is leaving the bargaining table without asking for more.
lead_paragraph: Sabrina Hill knew this email was the final straw.

headline: Their Cheating Heart, Your Damaged Retirement Plan
abstract: Financial infidelity destroys trust. It can deliver a serious blow to your post-career planning, too.
lead_paragraph: As a certified divorce financial analyst, Jessica Matthews walks clients through money problems that may have contributed to the end of their marriages, some of them from financial infidelity.

headline: Some U.F.C. Fighters Have Ties to a Chechen Leader Loyal to Putin
abstract: Ramzan Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya, is facing U.S. sanctions and accused of brutal abuses. Yet some fighters and others who work with the U.F.C. have kept ties with him.
lead_paragraph: Khamzat Chimaev’s victory last weekend in a bruising fight served as a declaration in mixed martial arts: Chimaev, an undefeated welterweight, is quickly becoming the Ultimate Fighting Championship’s next superstar.

headline: The Wolf of Crypto
abstract: Jordan Belfort, the inspiration for “The Wolf of Wall Street,” is marketing himself as a cryptocurrency guru.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: $100 Billion. Russia’s Treasure in the U.S. Should Be Turned Against Putin.
abstract: It’s the only way to signal that the United States is committed to making even the world’s most powerful states pay for their war crimes.
lead_paragraph: As Vladimir Putin vows to continue his genocidal invasion of Ukraine, investigators at the Treasury Department and Justice Department are scrambling to seize Russian yachts, mansions and the other spoils of his despotic regime. Meanwhile, in Washington, Representatives Tom Malinowski of New Jersey and Joe Wilson of South Carolina have advanced a bipartisan measure to clarify exactly how much power the executive branch has to liquidate those assets.

headline: The Smallest New Yorkers Join the Pandemic Biking Surge
abstract: Electric cargo bikes have become a popular way for parents to ferry their children to school and play dates, even if it means navigating city traffic.
lead_paragraph: When Annie Weinstock began toting her two young children to day care and playgrounds on a cargo bike three years ago, she sometimes spotted one other family in her Brooklyn neighborhood riding a similar bike.

headline: They Expected Luxury. They Got Leaky Ceilings and Broken Elevators.
abstract: Complaints of poor construction are on the rise in new luxury rental and condo buildings, after two chaotic years of New York real estate amid the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Hero, a new 22-story condominium building in Long Island City, Queens, promised luxury: tall ceilings, high-end appliances and Spanish oak cabinetry in every apartment. Amenities would include a yoga studio, a gym, a pet spa, a roof deck “sky lounge” and a Zen garden.

headline: Sienna Miller Found Catharsis in ‘Anatomy of a Scandal’
abstract: In the new Netflix series, the actress plays a woman whose husband’s affair gets played out in the British press. She was drawn to the echoes of her own life.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when Sienna Miller received the scripts for “Anatomy of a Scandal,” a high-gloss limited series from David E. Kelley and Melissa James Gibson, she read them straight through. “I binged them in the way that you would want to binge a six-part drama,” she said.

headline: Thinking About Going to the 2022 World Cup in Qatar? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Tickets are on sale for the world’s most popular sporting event, but concerns over worker exploitation and laws against homosexuality have complicated the decision to attend for some fans.
lead_paragraph: The most avidly followed sports event on earth, the FIFA World Cup, returns this fall — another chance to find out if what’s often been said about soccer is true: That 22 men chase a ball for 90 minutes, and the Germans always win.

headline: ‘A Magician Up There’: How It Feels to Watch Ja Morant Fly
abstract: An aerial artist. A skateboarder. A BMX rider. A skydiving instructor. They all see parallels between what they do and what Morant does when he dunks in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Bolton maneuvers in the air for a living, using silks and hammocks to defy gravity at heights of up to 25 feet. The sensation of being in the air, she said, is often one of empowerment, an extension of childhood fantasies becoming adult realities.

headline: Faced With a Changed Europe, China Sticks to an Old Script
abstract: Europe was viewed as lacking the power and the will to contest China’s rise. But now, a harder line toward Russia has implications for Beijing.
lead_paragraph: When European leaders recently pressed China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, to distance himself from Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, he doggedly stuck to prepared remarks for the video summit, shutting down any opening for their demands.

headline: Struggling Louisiana Neighborhood Sees New Highway as a Perilous Exit
abstract: Residents of Lafayette are wary of a project that has dragged on for decades, but they believe that their community — where vehicles hit buildings and pedestrians — has few options.
lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, La. — These days, the McComb neighborhood of Lafayette is dotted with deserted homes, ravaged by neglect and the merciless weather of southern Louisiana. Many businesses, including the last supermarket, fled years ago, taking jobs with them. And cutting through the community is the Evangeline Thruway, a half-dozen lanes packed with cars and 18-wheelers rushing through on their way to somewhere else.

headline: 16 Easter Brunch Recipes That Are Easy Like Sunday Morning
abstract: Enjoy a fabulous holiday meal without spending hours in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Brunch and Easter go hand in hand, but it’s still a weekend, and no one wants to spend all of their free time in the kitchen. Keep it simple with a wonderful meal that won’t take up too much of the day. Here are 16 easy Easter brunch recipes our readers love.

headline: Growing Religious Fervor on the Right and the Illusions Shattered by Putin’s War: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Tanzania’s First Female President Wants to Bring Her Nation in From the Cold
abstract: Samia Suluhu Hassan became the only female head of government in Africa when her predecessor suddenly died. She is setting a new course.
lead_paragraph: DODOMA, Tanzania — Shortly before midnight on a spring night last year, Samia Suluhu Hassan, then Tanzania’s first female vice president, appeared on television to announce to a shocked nation that the president was dead.

headline: Here’s a Better Way to Care for Your Yard. Your Neighbors, and the Planet, Will Thank You.
abstract: Ditch the gas leaf blower and switch to an electric one. Or a rake.
lead_paragraph: The most recent United Nations climate report reminds us, once again, of what we already know: The steady rise in global temperature spells catastrophe. We must adapt to what cannot be undone and commit to reducing greenhouse gas emissions caused by the burning of fossil fuels.

headline: Russia’s loss of its Black Sea flagship would make capturing Odesa harder, analysts say.
abstract: The loss of the Russian Navy’s Black Sea Fleet flagship will make it more difficult to gain full control over Ukraine’s southern coast and ultimately move on the port city of Odesa, military analysts say, although it is unlikely to derail Moscow’s war campaign entirely.
lead_paragraph: The loss of the Russian Navy’s Black Sea Fleet flagship will make it more difficult to gain full control over Ukraine’s southern coast and ultimately move on the port city of Odesa, military analysts say, although it is unlikely to derail Moscow’s war campaign entirely.

headline: 27 Years in Solitary Confinement
abstract: The Supreme Court is to decide whether to hear the case of a Texas prisoner who says his decades in isolation amount to “cruel and unusual” punishment.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, Dennis Wayne Hope committed a series of armed robberies. After proving adept at escaping prison, he was put in isolation. He has been there for nearly three decades.

headline: Amazon vs. the Union
abstract: The company and its new union share the same problem.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, Derrick Palmer clocked in for his 7:15 a.m. shift at Amazon’s giant warehouse on Staten Island and spent the day packing boxes with board games, iPhones and mini vacuum cleaners. The following morning, he boarded a train to Washington, D.C., where more experienced labor leaders hailed him and his best friend, Christian Smalls, for doing what had once seemed impossible: unionizing an Amazon facility.

headline: She Wrote for the Piano’s Extremes: Bronfman on Ustvolskaya
abstract: Yefim Bronfman discusses Galina Ustvolskaya’s Fourth Sonata, which he will play at Carnegie Hall on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Galina Ustvolskaya, a reclusive composer who lived in St. Petersburg, Russia, from her birth in 1919 to her death in 2006, has acquired a reputation for works of unearthly spiritual strength and formidable technical demands. “Your fingers literally bleed,” the violinist Patricia Kopatchinskaja has said of playing them.

headline: Here’s what the takeover could mean.
abstract: Twitter’s board is considering Elon Musk’s offer. Here are the possible next steps.
lead_paragraph: Now that Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, has made public his bid to purchase Twitter, the next steps include board discussions on the proposal and the possibility of other people making offers. Here’s what else the takeover bid means.

headline: Quiz Time on the Campaign Trail
abstract: Several “gotcha” questions for candidates, including one that Anthony Albanese got wrong, raise deeper questions about the quality of the nation’s political discourse.
lead_paragraph: During the first week of the federal election campaign, politicians have been asked about: the price of bread, milk and petrol; the JobSeeker rate; the wage price index; the cash rate; the unemployment rate, and more.

headline: She Liked What She Saw (on His T-shirt)
abstract: Lindsey Ward introduced herself to Michael Richardson at a pool party in 2003, when both were about to start middle school, because she liked the band on his T-shirt.
lead_paragraph: One of the first things Dr. Lindsey Madison Ward noticed about Dr. Michael Taylor Richardson was his System of a Down band T-shirt.

headline: ‘Too smelly to sleep’: Thirteen days in a Shanghai isolation facility.
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Shanghai residents have been sent to quarantine and isolation facilities. One woman described her ordeal.
lead_paragraph: After Leona Cheng tested positive for the coronavirus late last month, she was told to pack her bags for a hospital stay. When the ambulance came to her apartment in central Shanghai to pick her up two days later, no one said otherwise.

headline: Where in California Do Women Under 30 Earn More Than Men?
abstract: Young women are outearning young men in San Diego, Sacramento and Santa Barbara.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, an American woman under 30 with a full-time job earned, on average, 88 percent of what a similar man made. By 2019, young women’s pay had grown to 93 percent of men’s pay, which, while not ideal, can certainly be considered progress.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How Barnes & Noble went from villain to hero. Also in this edition: New Zealand’s glowing waves and a mentalist sets a new Central Park record.
lead_paragraph: How Barnes & Noble went from villain to hero. Also in this edition: New Zealand’s glowing waves and a mentalist sets a new Central Park record.

headline: Super League Bitterness, Now Playing in a New York Court
abstract: A lawsuit filed by an American soccer entrepreneur says the head of European soccer declared “war” on him for working with three top soccer teams.
lead_paragraph: It has been a year since the European Super League was born and collapsed in a two-day soccer supernova of angry statements, legal threats and bad blood. But the project’s repercussions are far from over.

headline: When Classical Music Was an Alibi
abstract: The idea that musicians and their work are apolitical flourished after World War II, in part thanks to the process of denazification.
lead_paragraph: On April 16, 1955, the soprano Camilla Williams became the first Black singer to appear with the Vienna State Opera, bowing as Cio-Cio-san in Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly.” Critics hailed it as a landmark and said it illustrated how much Vienna had changed since the end of World War II, a decade earlier.

headline: That Letter Offering to Buy Your Stock? Think Twice.
abstract: Known as a “mini-tender,” the bid is usually for a price below market value. Such offers tend to fly under regulators’ radar.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, I opened my mail to find an intriguing offer: A company wanted to buy stock that I held.

headline: Imogen Poots Keeps Everyone Guessing in ‘Outer Range’
abstract: The British actor plays an enigmatic interloper in this new science fiction Western on Amazon. “The trickery of it is what made it so fun,” she said.
lead_paragraph: When Imogen Poots arrives in the premiere of “Outer Range,” a trippy new science fiction Western series, the first impression is of an ingénue.

headline: How Russian disinformation spreads beyond its borders.
abstract: A New York Times’ video team traveled to the breakaway region of Transnistria to find out what residents there believe about the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February, Moscow has ramped up its propaganda and disinformation efforts, crafting a through-the-looking-glass image of the war in which Ukraine and the West — not Russia — are to blame for Russia’s attack.

headline: As Virus Sidelines Another ‘Macbeth’ Actor, Its Director Steps Onstage
abstract: Daniel Craig was back in the title role after testing positive earlier. But when the virus kept another actor out, the play’s director, Sam Gold, went on.
lead_paragraph: A new Broadway production of “Macbeth,” determined to keep going even as cast members continue to test positive for the coronavirus, came up with an unusual solution Thursday night: The director went on to replace an absent performer.

headline: Nightclubs? They’d Rather Play Shuffleboard and Jenga.
abstract: As people ease back into the nightlife scene, board game cafes and niche clubs offer relaxed ways to socialize. Here’s where you can play shuffleboard and Guess Who.
lead_paragraph: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.

headline: Bill Gates: How to Develop Life-Saving Drugs Much Faster
abstract: We need to accelerate our work on safe medicines that help combat quick-spreading pathogens like the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic would look very different if scientists had been able to develop a treatment sooner. The death rates are likely to have been far lower, and it may have been harder for myths and misinformation to spread the way they did.

headline: Mike Bossy, Hall of Famer on Champion Islander Teams, Dies at 65
abstract: He led the N.H.L. in goals twice as his team won four consecutive Stanley Cups in the early ’80s, but he felt it never got the recognition it deserved.
lead_paragraph: Mike Bossy, the Hockey Hall of Fame wing who played a key role in propelling the New York Islanders to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships in the early 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Montreal. He was 65.

headline: U.S. Offers Protection to People Who Fled War in Cameroon
abstract: Temporary protected status will allow an estimated 40,000 Cameroonians to legally live and work in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced on Friday that it would offer temporary protected status to nationals of Cameroon, shielding them from deportation and enabling them to obtain work permits, amid escalating armed conflict that has spawned a humanitarian crisis in the African country.

headline: A Duchess Brought Low by ‘A Very British Scandal’
abstract: In a new show on Prime Video, Claire Foy plays a British aristocrat whose sex life became the subject of salacious tabloid stories in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Everybody loves a sex scandal, and a posh one is even better. The great and the good brought down in disgrace: That’s a story people want to hear.

headline: It’s Julie Doucet’s World
abstract: After a two-decade break, the comic artist returns with “Time Zone J,” a graphic autopsy of youthful passion from the vantage point of a middle-aged woman.
lead_paragraph: The Montreal-based comics artist Julie Doucet began self-publishing her zine, Dirty Plotte, in 1987. Three years later, it became the foundation stone of the influential Canadian comics publisher Drawn & Quarterly.

headline: What Britain’s Deal With Rwanda Means for the U.K. Asylum System
abstract: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to send some of those seeking refuge to the central African country. What effect would the change have?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government has announced a plan to send some asylum seekers to Rwanda, a move that prompted an immediate backlash from opposition politicians, international legal experts and human rights defenders.

headline: Twitter Counters a Musk Takeover With a Time-Tested Barrier
abstract: The company is intent on fending off the billionaire’s bid to buy it in a deal that could be worth more than $40 billion.
lead_paragraph: Twitter does not want to become a plaything of the world’s richest person.

headline: For U.K. Covid Victims’ Families, Fines for Johnson Prolong Heartbreak
abstract: Those unable to be with dying loved ones find no satisfaction or closure with the penalty Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces for breaking lockdown rules.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Safiah Ngah’s father began coughing up blood and was rushed to the hospital from his home in central London in January 2021, she was confident that she would see him again.

headline: You Decide Which Games Matter
abstract: The F.A. Cup and the Conference League have meaning not because of tradition or design, but when the players, and particularly the fans, decide they are important.
lead_paragraph: Only a little more than a year ago, the Europa Conference League was still just an idea. It did not, in truth, even seem like an especially good idea. Explaining where such a league would fit into the game’s pecking order, what its purpose would be, hardly had the making of a compelling elevator pitch.

headline: A.I. Is Mastering Language. Should We Trust What It Says?
abstract: OpenAI’s GPT-3 and other neural nets can now write original prose with mind-boggling fluency — a development that could have profound implications for the future.
lead_paragraph: You are sitting in a comfortable chair by the fire, on a cold winter’s night. Perhaps you have a mug of tea in hand, perhaps something stronger. You open a magazine to an article you’ve been meaning to read. The title suggested a story about a promising — but also potentially dangerous — new technology on the cusp of becoming mainstream, and after reading only a few sentences, you find yourself pulled into the story. A revolution is coming in machine intelligence, the author argues, and we need, as a society, to get better at anticipating its consequences. But then the strangest thing happens: You notice that the writer has, seemingly deliberately, omitted the very last word of the first                   .

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: The late-night hosts had their hands full this week with news about President Trump endorsing Dr. Mehmet Oz in his Senate race and Elon Musk’s push to buy Twitter.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts had their hands full this week with news about President Trump endorsing Dr. Mehmet Oz in his Senate race and Elon Musk’s push to buy Twitter.

headline: More Than 150 Injured in Violence at Jerusalem Holy Site
abstract: Dozens of people were injured in fighting between Israeli riot police and Palestinians at the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, on the first day of a rare convergence of Ramadan, Easter and Passover.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people were injured in fighting between Israeli riot police and Palestinians at the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, on the first day of a rare convergence of Ramadan, Easter and Passover.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Fried chicken and pancakes would make for a great Easter brunch changeup.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan miracle: My family scored the prime parking spot down the street from Bubby’s in TriBeCa, hit the spot five minutes after it opened, ordered eggs and bacon, sourdough bread and grits, and were eating not 20 minutes later — a Sunday breakfast in advance of sending one of the children back to college after spring break.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’: There Will Be (Way More) Blood
abstract: The “Breaking Bad” prequel is back for its final season. Here’s what to remember about where we left off, as Jimmy’s transformation into Saul nears completion.
lead_paragraph: It’s been two years since anyone watched a new episode of “Better Call Saul,” but the characters presumably haven’t aged a minute.

headline: Lizzo’s Disco Dance Party, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Phoebe Bridgers, KeiyaA, Wild Pink and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: How Panera Bread Navigated Covid, the Labor Market, Inflation and More
abstract: Niren Chaudhary took over as C.E.O. just before the pandemic. He now has the company focused on climate change.
lead_paragraph: While Panera Bread is often situated in strip malls alongside other fast casual restaurants, the company has long been a pioneer of using quality ingredients and promoting healthy choices. It was among the first companies to add calorie counts to its menus, and it maintains a “No No List” of more than 150 substances — such as high-fructose corn syrup and aspartame — that it will not use in its recipes.

headline: Brazil’s climate politics are shifting. That matters for the whole planet.
abstract: The Amazon is emerging as a central issue in this year’s presidential campaign. Leaders have taken note.
lead_paragraph: In Brazil, beef isn’t just food. It’s political. It’s a symbol of dignity and equality, and the price of beef is a kind of barometer of well-being in the country.

headline: How Did You Find Your Place in New York City?
abstract: Apartment hunting in the city has never been easy, but as the pandemic eases, the search has become seemingly impossible. If you landed a new home recently, tell us your story.
lead_paragraph: It’s not an easy time to find an apartment to rent in New York City.

headline: Christopher Coover, Auction Expert on the Printed Word, Dies at 72
abstract: At Christie’s, he managed sales of rare books, manuscripts and documents by the likes of da Vinci, Lincoln and Kerouac. On TV, he lent his eye to “Antiques Roadshow.”
