headline: No Corrections: April 18, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Review: ‘The Minutes,’ an Official History of American Horror
abstract: In Tracy Letts’s new play, a tedious City Council meeting cracks open to reveal the secret record of what happened in Big Cherry.
lead_paragraph: If you set out to imagine the dullest possible setting for a play, you might come up with something much like the one Tracy Letts puts before you in “The Minutes,” a Steppenwolf Theater production that opened on Sunday at Studio 54. What could be more tedious, onstage or in life, than a City Council meeting with little on the agenda besides approving the official record of the last one? Or arguing the merits of a “Lincoln Smackdown” cage match attraction at the next annual heritage festival?

headline: China’s Economic Trends Hint at Cost of Zero Covid Strategy
abstract: The country’s lockdowns have trapped truck drivers on highways, halted production lines and forced some importers to source goods from outside China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Faced with its worst Covid-19 outbreak yet, China has been enforcing an expanding number of mass quarantines, strict lockdowns and border controls. The measures may yet work, but official data released on Monday show they are exacting a grim toll on the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Word of the Day: venturesome
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word venturesome has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 28 in “A Spiritual Meeting in the Sand and a Wedding There, Too” by Lois Smith Brady:

headline: Golden State’s Playoff Reappearance Doesn’t Quite Feel Like Old Times
abstract: The heart of the roster — Stephen Curry, Klay Thompson and Draymond Green — is back in the N.B.A. playoffs, a world away from the team’s soul in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The scene felt both comfortingly familiar and oddly askew.

headline: The Female Soccer Players Challenging France’s Hijab Ban
abstract: France’s soccer federation forbids hijab-wearing women from competing in soccer games, even though FIFA allows them. A collective of Muslim players is fighting what it considers a discriminatory rule.
lead_paragraph: SARCELLES, France — Every time Mama Diakité heads to a soccer game, her stomach is in knots.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Fighting for the Right to Wear Their Identity
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “What we want is to be accepted as we are, to implement these grand slogans of diversity, inclusiveness. Our only desire is to play soccer.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A showdown in Mariupol.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of shelling and bombings, Russia gave Ukrainian fighters in Mariupol until yesterday morning to lay down their weapons or be “eliminated.” When Ukrainian officials vowed that they would not surrender, Russian forces intensified their attack on the southeastern city, including at the Azovstal steel plant, near Mariupol’s port. Follow the latest updates.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Better Call Saul’ and a Freddie Mercury Tribute
abstract: AMC’s “Breaking Bad” prequel begins its final season. And a documentary about a 1992 tribute concert for Freddie Mercury airs on the CW.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 18-24. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: How a Manhunt Unfolded: An Alert, a Tweet, a Call From the Suspect
abstract: Frank James was on the loose for 31 hours after the subway attack.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look back at 31 hours when New York City was on edge — from the attack on the subway in Brooklyn to the arrest of a suspect. We’ll also see a photograph that will soon be up at the National September 11 Museum, the one image of a victim that the museum lacked.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Jim Farley Tries to Reinvent Ford and Catch Up to Elon Musk and Tesla
abstract: Ford’s chief executive is about to introduce an electric F-150 pickup truck that could determine whether the automaker can survive and thrive in an industry dominated by Tesla.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Jim Farley, the chief executive of Ford Motor, took a spin in what could become one of the most important vehicles in the company’s 118-year history: an electric F-150 pickup truck.

headline: A Late Night Subway Session
abstract: A surprise performance underground, from this week's Metropolitan Diary
lead_paragraph: A surprise performance underground, from this week's Metropolitan Diary

headline: Julia Roberts Hasn’t Changed. But Hollywood Has.
abstract: “There were incremental shifts in opportunity and it made more sense. Now it’s made more of air.”
lead_paragraph: “There were incremental shifts in opportunity and it made more sense. Now it’s made more of air.”

headline: Tony Kushner on the Republican ‘Fantasy’ of a Nation Controlled by ‘Straight White Men’
abstract: The playwright discusses the recent wave of anti-L.G.B.T.Q. policies and how far the country has — or hasn’t — come since the AIDS epidemic.
lead_paragraph: From Gov. Ron DeSantis signing Florida’s so-called Don’t Say Gay bill to Gov. Greg Abbott issuing a Texas directive that would classify medical care for transgender adolescents as “child abuse,” Republicans across the country seem to be doubling down on anti-L.G.B.T.Q. policies. Their argument? It’s about “parental rights.” But the playwright Tony Kushner has seen this kind of battle play out before. His “Angels in America” hit two-part play examined the AIDS epidemic and L.G.B.T.Q. life in the United States. And Kushner says this new wave of legislation is just the latest incarnation of a clampdown on rights under the conservative “fantasy” of a nation under “exclusive control by white straight men.”

headline: I’m a High School Junior. Let’s Talk About ‘Huckleberry Finn’ and ‘Mockingbird.’
abstract: The problem isn’t that we disagree; it’s how we argue.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — In late 2020, when the Burbank Unified School District removed five classic novels from mandatory reading lists in my city’s classrooms, I started a petition to protest the decision. The petition, which is still open, has more than 5,000 signatures.

headline: If Two Songs Sound Alike, Is It Stealing?
abstract: A judge ruled that Ed Sheeran did not plagiarize “Shape of You.” In pop music, are coincidences bound to happen?
lead_paragraph: When songs have similar melodies, chords or lyrics, do you think it is more often a result of plagiarism or sheer coincidence?

headline: Down on the Black Bayou, a Family History Repeats Itself
abstract: In “The Crocodile Bride,” Ashleigh Bell Pedersen unravels four generations of abuse and survival.
lead_paragraph: THE CROCODILE BRIDE By Ashleigh Bell Pedersen

headline: Sadness and Loss Are Everywhere. Books Can Help.
abstract: The saddest stories can show us how full of grace the fallen world can be.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I was 10 when “Brian’s Song” aired in 1971 as an ABC Movie of the Week. It is the story of the abiding friendship that grew as Brian Piccolo, who was white, and Gale Sayers, who was Black, competed for playing time as N.F.L. rookies with the Chicago Bears. It’s also the story of Piccolo’s death of cancer at 26. I was a girl in Birmingham, Ala., then “the most segregated city in America,” when “Brian’s Song” reminded this country that race was not an insurmountable barrier to love.

headline: Don’t Call Her ‘Baby.’ At 62, Jennifer Grey Is Taking the Lead.
abstract: In her memoir, “Out of the Corner,” the “Dirty Dancing” star opens up about rhinoplasty gone wrong, the implosion of her career and why she’s telling her story now.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Grey arrived at a recent breakfast at the Peninsula Hotel in Beverly Hills in a flurry of regrets about the state of her shirt and her hair (both were impeccable). Before the waiter had a chance to pour coffee, the star of “Dirty Dancing” asked a question that would be an apt subtitle for her memoir, “Out of the Corner,” which Ballantine will publish on May 3.

headline: This Is Not the Year of the Optimist
abstract: But there’s got to be a silver lining here somewhere.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Happy Easter, Gail. The news has been so depressing lately. A crazy guy opens fire in a subway in Brooklyn. The Russians are committing atrocities in Ukraine and are about to start a major offensive in the east. And my tuna melt on rye costs $21 at a not-much-to-look-at New York City diner, not including the tip.

headline: Elizabeth Warren: Democrats Can Avoid Disaster in November
abstract: More must be done to enact President Biden’s agenda before the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Democrats are the party of working people. Ahead of the 2020 election, we advanced ideas and plans that we believed would, in ways big and small, make our democracy and our economy work better for all Americans. Across this country, voters agreed with us — and gave us a majority in Washington so that we could deliver on those promises.

headline: A Rising Tally of Lonely Deaths on the Streets
abstract: More than ever it has become deadly to be homeless in America, especially for men in their 50s and 60s.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Can the S.E.C. Require ‘Gag Orders’ When It Settles Cases?
abstract: The Supreme Court has been asked to review the practice, which a judge called “a stew of confusion and hypocrisy” and which challengers say violates the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the summer of 2020, as the pandemic raged and the presidential election neared, Michael D. Cohen, President Donald J. Trump’s onetime lawyer and fixer, was put to a choice. Mr. Cohen wanted to serve out the balance of his three-year sentence, for campaign finance violations and other crimes, at home.

headline: Why It’s Time to Start Caring Much More About Clean Hydrogen
abstract: Europe is giving investors the green light they need to take risks on climate technologies.
lead_paragraph: Today’s energy crisis has a familiar ring. In the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, energy supplies have faltered, and prices have skyrocketed. Americans are seeing costly gasoline, and in Europe, natural gas prices are around five times typical levels for this time of year, driving up the price of electricity and even threatening bankruptcies across industries that depend on gas.

headline: What if Public Funds Were Controlled by the Public?
abstract: Through the dry-sounding Participatory Budgeting Project, Shari Davis is pushing a quietly radical idea: Democracy shouldn’t be confined to voting.
lead_paragraph: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.

headline: The Next Hurdle in Europe’s Energy Transition: Being More Enticing Than NFTs
abstract: Financing the next generation of green energy technologies means larger investments and getting venture capitalists to turn their attention away from “fast money.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Jakob Bitner was 7, he left Russia for Germany with his parents and sister. Twenty-eight years later, he is set on solving a vexing green-energy problem that could help Germany end its dependence on imported energy from Russia, or anywhere.

headline: Shopping for Loft Beds
abstract: When your ceilings are high but your square footage is limited, a loft bed may be the solution you’re after.
lead_paragraph: If you have a tiny bedroom that doesn’t have enough room for all the furniture you need, a loft bed may be the answer.

headline: The Pandemic Has Been Hard on Our Feet
abstract: Here’s what’s plaguing them and how to avoid it.
lead_paragraph: In March of 2020, Krista Fahs began working from home. As she sidled up to her desk, the 53-year-old sales associate for a computer distributor put aside her usual sneakers. She found herself doing laundry, playing with her cat and even visiting neighbors without putting on shoes. “I was barefoot all the time,” she said.

headline: How a Dollar General Employee Went Viral on TikTok
abstract: Mary Gundel loved managing a store in Tampa, Fla. But when she detailed its challenges on social media, the company — and fellow employees — took notice.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: French Candidates’ Economic Programs Hold Key to the Election
abstract: Promising tax cuts, higher wages and changes in the retirement age, President Macron and Marine Le Pen vie for undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As President Emmanuel Macron wove through crowds during a campaign stop in northern France last week, an elderly voter got in his face to protest one of his most unpopular economic proposals: raising the retirement age to 65 from 62 to fund France’s national pension system.

headline: A ‘Wild West’ of Marijuana Shops Grows in Toronto
abstract: Permitted to operate during the pandemic, even during lockdowns, Toronto’s marijuana shops have flourished and changed the character of an iconic neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — If you are hankering for a government-sanctioned joint, then you have come to the right city.

headline: Abundance, Exploitation, Recovery: A Portrait of South Georgia
abstract: A series of ecological initiatives, including the eradication of several invasive species, has dramatically revived the life and landscape of this remote sub-Antarctic island.
lead_paragraph: Sally Poncet first came to South Georgia in 1977. Back then, she said, the sub-Antarctic island was as gorgeous as it is today: A spine of mountains, some 100 miles long, defines the terrain; glaciers drape down from the peaks, with verdant slopes running up to meet them; glistening beaches wrap around the shoreline. But in those days, Ms. Poncet recalled, the island had an empty feel to it. “You felt a lack,” she explained. “It wasn’t alive like you knew it could be.”

headline: They’re Some of Hollywood’s Top Publicists. Just Don’t Ask Them Why.
abstract: Meet the women of the Lede Company.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t decide what is OK and what’s not OK, you know what I mean?” Amanda Silverman said over the phone on March 1, six days into Russia’s war on Ukraine. Discussing geopolitics was not the intended purpose of the call; Ms. Silverman’s life as a celebrity publicist was. As Vladimir Putin shook the world order, she had clients to manage.

headline: Treasury makes a plea for more I.R.S. funding on Tax Day.
abstract: The Biden administration continued to push for $80 billion in new funding for the tax collection agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As millions of Americans raced to finish filing their tax returns on Monday, the Biden administration made another plea for Congress to give the Internal Revenue Service more money.

headline: Rushing Against War, and Time, Ukraine Makes It to the Biennale
abstract: Russia’s invasion complicated well-laid plans. But, despite the odds, Ukraine will present work at the international art showcase in Venice.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — The 78 bronze funnels were ready, the pump tested and the backdrop was almost done. So when it looked as if war was most likely coming to Ukraine, Maria Lanko, one of the curators of the Ukrainian pavilion at the Venice Biennale, was determined to get the artist Pavlo Makov’s fountain sculpture safely out of the country.

headline: Biden’s Student Loan Dilemma
abstract: America’s two-year experiment in debt deferral has had unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, 45 million borrowers now owe $1.6 trillion in debt for federal loans taken out for college — more than consumers owe on any other debt except mortgages.

headline: The ‘Messy Middle’
abstract: The West is arming Ukraine and punishing Russia. Today we look at the countries that aren’t.
lead_paragraph: If you live in most any Western country, your government’s support for Ukraine, including sending weapons and imposing sanctions on Russia, can give the impression of a united global response to Vladimir Putin’s invasion.

headline: ‘See You Then’ Review: The More Things Stay the Same
abstract: Former lovers reconnect, litigating the past and present, in this drama from Mari Walker.
lead_paragraph: The golden glow that halos around the two former lovers reconnecting in “See You Then” is tinged with melancholy. More than a decade has passed since the sudden breakup of Kris (Pooya Mohseni) and Naomi (Lynn Chen). Some things have changed, some things stayed the same. That such an aphorism is easily applied to any number of “Before Sunrise”-style movies of people reminiscing and litigating what once was sets Mari Walker’s film at a disadvantage. But the chemistry of its stars gives the movie a curious magnetism that is almost enough to forgive its flaws.

headline: Calls for Covid funding are renewed as doses near expiration.
abstract: A tense battle may soon resume over the stalled $10 billion pandemic aid package that senators failed to pass earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: Millions of coronavirus vaccine doses that the United States has already purchased and could send abroad could soon expire because of the impasse in Congress over additional pandemic aid, Senator Chris Coons has warned.

headline: Meet the First Class of Our Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship
abstract: These five constructors will work for three months with New York Times puzzle editors to create grids that reflect a range of cultural reference points.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Games team is pleased to announce the inaugural class for the Diverse Crossword Constructor fellowship. Selected from over 200 applicants, these five constructors will work under the guidance of the New York Times puzzle editing team for three months to create puzzles that reflect their lives and cultures. At the end of the fellowship, their puzzles will be submitted through our general process to be considered for publication.

headline: What is Patriots’ Day?
abstract: The third Monday in April commemorates the Revolutionary War battles of Lexington and Concord in 1775.
lead_paragraph: Just as the first Tuesday in November is for voting and the second Sunday in May is for mothers, the third Monday in April holds a special place in the hearts and calendars of Massachusetts residents.

headline: Russian attack on Lviv shakes sense of security in a relatively safe city.
abstract: Vlada Belau believed she had finally established a semblance of normalcy in the city of Lviv after fleeing from Kyiv, nearly 300 miles to the east, when it was bombarded in the early days of the war.
lead_paragraph: Vlada Belau believed she had finally established a semblance of normalcy in the city of Lviv after fleeing from Kyiv, nearly 300 miles to the east, when it was bombarded in the early days of the war.

headline: To Push Back Russians, Ukrainians Hit a Village With Cluster Munitions
abstract: The New York Times verified that Ukraine’s forces appeared to fire at least two of these internationally banned weapons in a neighborhood, putting Ukrainian civilians at extreme risk.
lead_paragraph: HUSARIVKA, Ukraine — It was in early March when the spent warhead of a cluster munition rocket landed next to Yurii Doroshenko’s home in eastern Ukraine, having dispensed its lethal bomblets over his village.

headline: Alex Jones’s Infowars Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The conspiracy theorist and his companies are facing lawsuits over his false claims about the Sandy Hook school shooting.
lead_paragraph: Three companies affiliated with the far-right broadcaster and conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, among them the media outlet Infowars, filed for Chapter 11 protection on Sunday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Texas, according to court documents.

headline: Five Big Questions for Elon Musk and Twitter
abstract: Will he go hostile, what is Twitter really worth and more.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision in an effort to block Elon Musk, who, you might have heard, wants to buy the social media platform. The maneuver will give Twitter’s management time to assess the offer and potentially invite other buyers via a sale process.

headline: California Delays K-12 Vaccine Mandate
abstract: State officials say schoolchildren won’t have to be vaccinated against the coronavirus until July 2023 at the earliest, a year later than planned.
lead_paragraph: In October, Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that California would become the first state to require all schoolchildren to receive the coronavirus vaccine.

headline: The big questions about what happens next in Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter.
abstract: After Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision, Elon Musk appears to be hinting at the possibility of a hostile bid.
lead_paragraph: Over the holiday weekend, Twitter’s board put in place a poison pill provision in an effort to block Elon Musk, who wants to buy the social media platform. The maneuver, which would make it more difficult and expensive for Mr. Musk to acquire shares without the approval of the board, will give Twitter’s management time to assess the offer and potentially invite other buyers via a sale process.

headline: What You Get for $3.3 Million in California
abstract: A 1926 Lloyd Wright showplace in Glendale, a midcentury ranch-style home in San Anselmo and a 1948 house in Orinda.
lead_paragraph: A 1926 Lloyd Wright showplace in Glendale, a midcentury ranch-style home in San Anselmo and a 1948 house in Orinda.

headline: $3.3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1926 Lloyd Wright showplace in Glendale, a midcentury ranch-style home in San Anselmo and a 1948 house in Orinda.
lead_paragraph: Lloyd Wright spent much of his early architecture career working under his father, Frank Lloyd Wright, in Southern California, where he managed the construction of the Hollyhock House (in collaboration with Rudolph Schindler) and the Ennis House, two of Los Angeles’s most architecturally significant homes.

headline: In 1972, only 8 women ran the race. Today, 12,100 are running.
abstract: Women had been banned from the Boston Marathon for 76 years before a change 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: For 76 years, men were the only athletes permitted to have their “vital statistics” — their race times — recorded in the running of the Boston Marathon. Women were prohibited from running the route because race organizers considered them “physiologically incapable.”

headline: A Russian strike hits Lviv, a city relatively untouched by violence.
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of displaced people from other parts of Ukraine have fled to, or through, Lviv to escape the fighting. Then it landed on their doorstep.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian missiles struck Lviv on Monday, killing at least seven people in the first reported deaths of the war in the western city, where hundreds of thousands of displaced people have fled to escape the fierce fighting in other parts of Ukraine.

headline: The men’s defending wheelchair champion withdraws less than an hour before the race.
abstract: Marcel Hug of Switzerland decided not to compete in the Boston Marathon for medical reasons.
lead_paragraph: Marcel Hug of Switzerland, the defending men’s wheelchair champion, withdrew less than an hour before the start of the race, citing medical reasons, the Boston Athletic Association said.

headline: The World Bank slashes its forecast for global economic growth.
abstract: The bank now expects the global economy to grow at a rate of 3.2 percent in 2022, down from its previous estimate of 4.1 percent.
lead_paragraph: The World Bank is slashing its forecast for global economic growth this year, citing the war in Ukraine, inflation and the lingering effects of the pandemic.

headline: Attention, High Schoolers: We Want to Hear From You
abstract: We’d like to know your opinion. Send us a letter about a recent article that caught your eye in The Times.
lead_paragraph: Once again we invite high school students to enter our letter-writing competition. Write a letter to the editor in response to a Times news or opinion article from the past week, and we will choose some of our favorites for publication.

headline: Before Brunch, a Stop at the Altar
abstract: Facing a shortage of prime times, more couples are marrying earlier in the day at weddings that some are finding easier to book and less expensive to host.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday March 12, Bria Pugh found herself wide-awake at 4 a.m. She isn’t an early-riser, nor did she have pre-wedding jitters. This was the call time for her hair and makeup before she walked down the aisle to marry Matthew Norman six hours later.

headline: Daniel Romanchuk of the U.S. Wins Boston Marathon Men’s Wheelchair Race
abstract: It was Romanchuk’s second victory in Boston. The defending champion, Marcel Hug of Switzerland, withdrew from the race on Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Romanchuk of the United States won the Boston Marathon’s men’s wheelchair race on Monday, securing his second victory there.

headline: Manuela Schär Wins Her 4th Boston Marathon in Women’s Wheelchair Race
abstract: She broke away from the pack early on and kept her lead for the entire race, finishing in 1 hour 41 minutes 8 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Manuela Schӓr of Switzerland won the Boston Marathon’s women’s wheelchair race on Monday, cruising to her fourth victory in the event.

headline: Bleak assessments of the Russian economy clash with Putin’s rosy claims.
abstract: While Vladimir Putin boasts that Russia is holding up under Western sanctions, his central bank chief and the mayor of Moscow warned that the worst was yet to come.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s central bank chief warned on Monday that the consequences of Western sanctions were only beginning to be felt, and Moscow’s mayor said that 200,000 jobs were at risk in the Russian capital alone, stark acknowledgments that undermined President Vladimir V. Putin’s contention that sanctions had failed to destabilize the Russian economy.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: It’s teatime: Make Eric Kim’s chamomile cake with strawberry icing for your next afternoon break.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Eric Kim’s latest “Eat” column in The New York Times Magazine takes on the pleasures of afternoon tea. He doesn’t approach the ritual in the British sense, nor in a ceremonial one. A friend bangs through the door and he brews a pot of chamomile or burdock, then serves it over conversation, ideally with a slice of cake: “a perfectly contained moment, a pause from the outside world.”

headline: As Philadelphia Puts On Masks Again, Other Cities Watch Closely
abstract: A sharp increase in new infections triggered the return of indoor mask rules a little more than a month after they were lifted.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Amid the jumble of warnings, rules and edicts on the counter of the H20 Laundromat — “No Cash,” “Watch Your Step,” “Not Responsible” — there was a new one on Monday morning, prominently displayed. “Masks required for everyone,” it said, “effective April 18.”

headline: Bank of America is confident in the economy even as its profits declined.
abstract: The bank reported lower quarterly profits, but it expects to earn significantly more money later this year from rising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America joined its peers in reporting lower profits for the first three months of the year but is keeping its optimistic economic outlook even as other lending giants have turned more cautious.

headline: Evans Chebet of Kenya Wins Boston Men’s Race, His First Major Marathon Victory
abstract: Chebet stamped himself as a major marathoning force with a decisive victory in 2 hours 6 minutes 51 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Evans Chebet of Kenya stamped himself as a major marathoning force with a decisive victory in 2 hours 6 minutes 51 seconds in the men’s race in Boston on Monday.

headline: Down the Rabbit Hole
abstract: Debut novels follow Asian American women researching the lives and work of elusive artists.
lead_paragraph: As every writer, teacher and tyrant knows, art is a powerful thing. These two debut novels explore the danger and wonder of art, its capacity to distort and illuminate the world.

headline: NASCAR, ‘Survivor,’ ‘Bachelor’: All have stars in the race.
abstract: A handful of celebrities and star athletes are running the Boston Marathon.
lead_paragraph: What do a NASCAR champion, a “Survivor” and a “Bachelor” have in common? By the end of the day — if all goes well — they will all have 26.2 miles under their feet.

headline: Peres Jepchirchir Wins the Boston Marathon in a Thrilling Finish
abstract: Jepchirchir, the Olympic and New York City champion, surged past Ababel Yeshaneh in the last few moments to win by four seconds.
lead_paragraph: It was a marathon, but it ended in a sprint.

headline: Elon Musk’s Bid to Take Over Twitter
abstract: Readers discuss the free speech and media ownership issues raised by the offer. Also: Strategy in Ukraine; Bernie Sanders; preying on people of color.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Washington Commanders Deny Financial Malfeasance in a Letter to F.T.C.
abstract: The N.F.L. franchise sent 102 pages of documents rebutting claims made by a former employee that the team failed to properly report ticket revenue and withheld refunds from fans.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Commanders on Monday offered a robust public rebuttal of congressional testimony made by a former team vice president who claimed that the team skimmed revenue from ticket sales meant to be shared with the rest of the N.F.L. and withheld security deposits from fans.

headline: A second global Covid-19 summit led by the White House is set for May.
abstract: Efforts to subsidize more global vaccinations have stalled in Congress, and new coronavirus cases are on the rise in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: The White House announced on Monday that it would co-host the second global Covid-19 summit next month, a gathering intended to build momentum for vaccine donations and for ending what the White House called the “acute phase” of the pandemic.

headline: Give the Gift of Herbaceous Dark Chocolate
abstract: Janet Mavec, a jewelry designer inspired by her farm and gardens, now sells dark chocolate bars infused with her lemon verbena.
lead_paragraph: Janet Mavec, a jewelry designer whose pieces are inspired by nature, works from her Bird Haven Farm and gardens in Pottersville, N.J., where the flowers, herbs and vegetables pose for her artistry, mostly in gold-plated brass. (The farm is open to visitors on select days.) But new to her line is chocolate: She uses lemon verbena that she cultivates to infuse bars of dark chocolate with delicate, aromatic floral notes. The chocolate is 72 percent cacao from the Dominican Republic and comes wrapped in pretty, leafy paper. It’s gift-worthy for Mother’s Day (don’t give just one).

headline: Attend a Talk With ‘the Challah Prince’
abstract: Idan Chabasov, known for his baroque creations on Instagram, will discuss and demonstrate challah-making at the Streicker Center.
lead_paragraph: By the time Idan Chabasov takes center stage at Temple Emanu-El’s Streicker Center, Passover will have ended and it will be time to talk of bread again. Mr. Chabasov, whose background is Sephardic, only came to appreciate the traditional braided loaf as an adult, in Berlin. He is now known as the “challah prince” thanks to his baroque creations posted on Instagram. On Monday at 6 p.m. he will discuss and demonstrate challah making with Shannon Sarna, a cookbook author. Coming up at the Streicker Center on the Upper East Side on May 12, the topic will be the Zabar family and stores.

headline: ‘Let’s Not Do That Again,’ a Crackling Satire Set Against a Senate Run
abstract: Grant Ginder’s fifth novel is about a woman whose adult children alternately help and threaten her political aspirations.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Grant Ginder is blessed with a byline so strong that it sounds like a nom de plume. For over a decade he’s also given great title: “This Is How It Starts” (2009). “The People We Hate at the Wedding” (2017). “Honestly, We Meant Well” (2019). This is the guy I want to sit next to at the wedding.

headline: For Those With Style and a Love of Foraging
abstract: The scarf company Echo has reissued several old designs, including one of mushrooms on a 35-inch silk square.
lead_paragraph: Echo, a New York company that has been producing scarves and similar accessories for nearly 100 years, has plumbed its archives and reissued several designs of yore. Mushrooms richly border one of them, on a 35-inch silk square that’s worth considering for Mother’s Day for a food-loving or foraging recipient. It comes in a purple-brown they call port, or in black.

headline: Just in Time for Grilling Season
abstract: Heritage Foods now offers spicy linguiça from the sausage maker the Mayor, in Richmond, Va.
lead_paragraph: Heritage Foods now offers linguiça from the sausage maker the Mayor, in Richmond, Va. The signature Portuguese sausage harbors the paprika spice of chorizo but with the fire dampened, and a finer texture, but it brings on the garlic like kielbasa. It’s perfect right off the grill, or sizzled and sliced into thick coins in a mess of Little Neck clams steamed in olive oil with sweet and hot peppers. Kyle Morse, a chef who owns the Mayor, uses heritage pork shoulder for his sausage. The name linguiça derives from the Portuguese word for tongue (língua), but is thought to be a reference to only the shape.

lead_paragraph: William Grant & Sons, the Scottish distilling company, has a portfolio of brands like Hendrick’s Gin, Reyka Vodka, Glenfiddich and Monkey Shoulder Scotch. Now the company has come up with Batch & Bottle: ready-made cocktails in bottles, not cans, using top-shelf spirits. They’re neither gimmicky nor sweet, but straightforward classics like a martini and a cosmopolitan with a whisper of rhubarb. headline: Rare Culinary Tomes at the International Antiquarian Book Fair
abstract: The dealer Ben Kinmont’s holdings will display a collection of 50 rare wine and food books and manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: Ben Kinmont, a rare book dealer from Sebastopol, Calif., will be at the New York International Antiquarian Book Fair this week. Among the books he will have on display are “Ein künstlichs und nutz lichs Kochbüch” by Balthasar Staindl (1544), the fourth cookbook ever published in Germany, and “The Sesmaisons Cookery Manuscript,” in French from 1767. He also has the “Thackrey Library: An Archaeology of Pleasures,” a collection of 740 rare wine and food books and manuscripts. (Forty-six will be on display in New York.) That includes a sixth century account of the purchase of grape vines written on papyrus and books on viticulture and oenology dating from the 14th through 19th centuries. The entire Thackrey Library can be yours for $2 million.

headline: How the Elites Monopolize Empathy

Penn seemed not to believe her claims of abuse despite the fact that she had been placed in foster care (the reason she considered herself first-generation). Like other elite institutions, Penn seemed to be using what I called a “trauma algorithm” to determine which hardships counted and which ones should be investigated. That newsletter, which was based on an article the journalist Rachel Aviv wrote in The New Yorker, generated a great deal of response from you, the readers, so I want to return to the subject.

headline: Searching for the Notorious Celebrity Book Stylist
abstract: In the name of personal branding, influencers might be paying someone to make them look like readers. But does a novel deserve more respect than a handbag?
lead_paragraph: YIGIT TURHAN, THE Milan-based director of branding and entertainment relations at Valentino, was in Los Angeles last year when he first heard about the infamous book stylist. Rumor had it that celebrities and fashion influencers were paying someone to select reading material for them to carry in public. (Whether they read it was another thing, and, to echo a sentiment shared by a pair of withering college-student characters on the HBO satire “The White Lotus” (2021), beside the point.) In paparazzi photos or on their own social media accounts, these props, because that’s essentially what they were, communicated something far more powerful than a press statement ever could. Today, when entertainers are required to have an immediate, uncontroversial and neatly packaged response to every newsworthy occurrence — when their personal brand is expected to, as Walt Whitman once wrote, contain multitudes — a picture of a book is worth a thousand words. But when Turhan, 34, asked for the name of this mysterious figure, his contacts got cagey. “They acted like they had never heard of such a thing, as if we hadn’t just discussed it,” he recalls.

headline: They Are the Heirs of Nazi Fortunes, and They Aren’t Apologizing
abstract: In a country that is celebrated for its culture of reckoning and remembrance, the richest families are often an exception.

It’s not just that it accounts for about 10 percent of G.D.P.; brands like Porsche, Mercedes, BMW and Volkswagen are recognized around the world as symbols of German industrial ingenuity and excellence. These companies spend millions on branding and advertising to ensure they are thought of this way. They spend less money and energy on discussing their roots. These corporations can trace their success directly back to Nazis: Ferdinand Porsche persuaded Hitler to put Volkswagen into production. His son, Ferry Porsche, who built up the company, was a voluntary SS officer. Herbert Quandt, who built BMW into what it is today, committed war crimes. So did Friedrich Flick, who came to control Daimler-Benz. Unlike Mr. Quandt, Mr. Flick was convicted at Nuremberg.

President Biden’s approval rating is at 42 percent, around where Donald Trump’s was at this point in his presidency. Recent polls asking whether Americans want Republicans or Democrats in Congress found that Republicans are leading by about 2 percentage points. And with inflation spiking to its highest point in decades, Covid cases rising and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine continuing to send economic and humanitarian shock waves across the globe, things don’t look as if they are going to get better anytime soon.

headline: How Much Should You Be Asked to Donate for a Colleague’s Gift?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when co-workers may feel pressured into making a donation at the office — and more.
lead_paragraph: I am a doctor. My colleague’s spouse was recently diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer. I privately communicated my support and offered to help, even though they’re very self-sufficient and have lots of resources, both financially and emotionally.

headline: Mike Lee and Ted Cruz Fought So That One Man Wouldn’t Have to Face the Pain of Defeat
abstract: They profess to be constitutional conservatives. But that isn’t quite the whole story.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz of Texas and Mike Lee of Utah are two of the most prominent “constitutional conservatives” in the Senate. They built their political careers on their supposed fidelity to the Constitution and the original intent of the founding fathers. Cruz made his constitutional conservatism the centerpiece of his 2016 campaign for president, while Lee has written three books on the founding era and presents himself, to the public, as a constitutional scholar rather than a mere politician.

headline: How Long Does Menopause Last?
abstract: And how will I know when it’s over?
lead_paragraph: Q: How long does menopause actually last? And how do you know when (or if) you are done?

abstract: Ashton Edwards, an apprentice at Pacific Northwest Ballet, is part of a rising generation of gender nonconforming dancers questioning ballet’s rigid gender roles.
lead_paragraph: Ashton Edwards’s ballet dreams were dashed at age 6. Raised as a boy in the Midwest, Edwards, who is nonbinary and now uses they/them pronouns, had hoped ballet would allow them to explore their truest self. “I wanted to be one of those beautiful, ethereal people on pointe,” they said, referring to the reinforced shoes that allow dancers to stand on the tips of their toes.

headline: In ‘Deaf Utopia,’ Nyle DiMarco Dreams of Integrating the Deaf and Hearing Worlds
abstract: “Being Deaf assigned me a battle,” said the model, producer and now writer. His memoir braids his life, his family’s legacy and the history of Deaf rights.
lead_paragraph: Nyle DiMarco’s new memoir, “Deaf Utopia,” begins in the womb. The year is 1989 and his mother, Donna, is hours into labor, straining to communicate with the doctor as he prepares to perform a C-section. Donna is Deaf, but there’s no sign language interpreter present; it would be another year before the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, which mandated that hospitals provide them. So it was by reading the doctor’s lips and the notes he wrote out by hand that she gleaned that her newborn twins, Nyle and Nico, were both Deaf too, the fourth such generation in the DiMarco family.

headline: Each White Flag: A Life Lost to Covid
abstract: Mourners from across the country gathered on the National Mall to honor loved ones.
lead_paragraph: In September 2021, more than 660,000 white flags were planted on the National Mall in Washington, D.C., as part of a participatory art project by Suzanne Brennan Firstenberg titled “In America: Remember.” It was not the first time the National Mall served as a memorial for those lost to a pandemic; in 1987 the Names Project AIDS Memorial Quilt had its first public display there.

headline: Your Office Is More Annoying Than You Remembered. Here’s How to Handle It.

abstract: Louisa Lim’s “Indelible City” charts the place’s reinventions and the author’s experience living there since she was a child.
lead_paragraph: For an authoritarian regime facing a restive population, it’s an ugly version of the Goldilocks conundrum: How to exert just the right amount of repression to quell demands for democracy, without going so far that you provoke disparate voices to unite in solidarity and opposition?

abstract: Well before self-driving cars become a reality, there are simpler approaches that can make roads much safer.

headline: To Tip, or Not to Tip?
abstract: Automated payment and the spread of tipping to every corner of the food-service business have helped workers weather the pandemic. But some consumers feel overwhelmed.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Anna Johnson found herself using an electronic screen to pay for a pickup order at a bakery in Phoenix, a normal enough experience at many food businesses she frequents. But this time, she was bewildered when the machine recommended that she tip as much as 35 percent — on cookies.

headline: When I Went Away From the World
abstract: The novelist Rachel Cusk’s pursuit of finality had taken her further and further away. She never considered how she was going to get back.
lead_paragraph: We stood by the ruffled water on the breezy Greek shore, in an uncertain light of evening. It was early spring, Sunday, a feast day, and we were told there were celebrations earlier, of which this was the aftermath — this silence in the village and beside the water, beside the shuttered houses and the empty little pier, where the sea grasses bent this way and that in the wind and the sky was as though absorbed in a private process of transformation, a movement out of winter that had not yet been accomplished. This was not our country: We had only just arrived, and the celebrations had not included us. We didn’t mind, having paid the price of inclusion earlier in our lives. In fact our feelings had become more or less irrelevant, without our entirely noticing. So that the old terror, of exclusion — or abandonment perhaps — didn’t trouble us, any more than the thistledown troubled us whirling softly off the vegetation by the water. We stood and waited for the boat.

headline: M.R.I.s Are Finding Connections Between Our Brain Activity and Psychology
abstract: How might we leverage knowing that a particular neurological feature makes someone more vulnerable to autism or Alzheimer’s or more likely to achieve academically?
lead_paragraph: In March, neuroscientists and psychiatrists from the School of Medicine at Washington University, St. Louis, along with colleagues elsewhere, published a study in the journal Nature that sparked widespread discussion in their fields. Researchers, the study noted, are increasingly using magnetic resonance imaging — which can reveal the brain’s structure and activity — to try to find links between what is seen on an M.R.I., like cortical thickness or patterns of connection, and complicated psychological traits, like cognitive ability or mental-health conditions. In theory, such so-called brain-wide association studies could yield incredibly valuable insights. Knowing that a particular neurological feature makes someone more vulnerable to autism, Alzheimer’s or another disorder, for example, could help predict, prevent or treat that condition. Likewise, if we can link certain features to desirable traits, like academic achievement, it might be possible to take advantage of that knowledge.

abstract: Her images of victims on the streets of Palermo were stamped on the nation’s consciousness as she challenged the grip mobsters had on her native Sicily.

lead_paragraph: For restaurant critics in New York City, the road forward is often hard to make out, but in the winter of 2020-21 the visibility was so low I sometimes felt I was driving in a blizzard. headline: Explosions at Schools in Kabul Kill at Least 6
abstract: Blasts outside an education center and a public high school in Afghanistan’s capital killed at least six people and wounded several students. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks.
lead_paragraph: Blasts outside an education center and a public high school in Afghanistan’s capital killed at least six people and wounded several students. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks.

headline: KYU, an Eclectic Miami Transplant, Opens in NoHo
abstract: Innovative mussels in the meatpacking district, an ode to Southern Italy in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Reversing a trend, a Miami restaurant is opening in New York. Since 2016, KYU (pronounced “cue”), in the Wynwood neighborhood of Miami, has been a destination, offering an eclectic, strongly Asian-leaning menu of often wood-fired specialties served in a high-decibel industrial setting. Appetites are vigorously satisfied; creature comforts less so. In New York, there are touches of luxury in the generous space that housed Bobby Flay’s Gato, with dramatic lighting and a glittering sweep of brass mesh to set off the lounge area. Alan Omsky and Jordan Sayfie, the founders, have joined with an English hospitality company, Reuben Brothers, for this expansion of the brand. (There’s already an offshoot in Mexico City, and other locations are in the pipeline.) Its signature is Japanese yakiniku grilling, which will be handled in an open kitchen with a chef’s table by Chris Arellanes, who worked at Per Se and Eleven Madison Park. Smoked Wagyu brisket, whole roasted cauliflower, six-hour smoked short ribs and a towering coconut cake are coming to New York, along with a newly conceived wood-fired bass with fermented brussels sprouts and dashi, and charred sunchokes with Parmesan cream and togarashi lime. The restaurant’s Miami cocktails, like the Wynwood Mule made with house-smoked pineapple, and the spicy shiso sour fueled with Thai chile tincture, are also traveling north. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: Jerrod Carmichael Knows How to Wear the Truth
abstract: The comedian’s latest HBO special, which explores family secrets and sexual orientation, is as much a therapy session as a stand-up show.
lead_paragraph: Of all that’s remarkable about Jerrod Carmichael’s latest comedy hour — the storied intimacy of the venue (the Blue Note Jazz Club), the spectral aptness of the lighting (kind of blue), the titanic silences, dental work that would thrill any neat freak — two aspects of this HBO special are especially exceptional. One is a matter of carriage. Carmichael is a stand-up comedian. But all he does in this new show is sit. The opening long shot follows him in the snow, headed toward the Blue Note, where he removes his coat and hat and promptly takes a seat upon the stage before a modest, expectant, engaged gathering of what Carmichael wants to feel is a family and what I can only call community support, because winter isn’t all he braves. For one thing, his long body is on a metal folding chair.

headline: Masks Are Still Required for N.Y.C. Public Transit, Taxis and Ride Shares

lead_paragraph: Riders are still required to wear masks while taking public transportation in New York City, despite a federal judge in Florida’s ruling on Monday to overturn the nationwide mask mandate on planes and public transit.

headline: Inflation, Interest and the Housing Paradox
abstract: Hike we must, but build we should.
lead_paragraph: One of the occupational hazards of my profession is having people ask me what’s going to happen to the market. I’m never sure whether to give the answer attributed to various famous financial titans — it will fluctuate — or to reply, more accurately, “God knows.” But some predictions seem safe. Clearly, the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates repeatedly over the months ahead, continuing that process until there are clear signs that inflation is coming down to tolerable levels.

headline: An Opera Rarity Reclaims Its Spot in the Repertory

headline: An Immersive Show Taps ‘an Oracle’ for a Spin on Greek Myth

lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Emma Cole, an expert in ancient Greek theater at the University of Bristol, wove through a maze of apartments, back streets and piazzas inside two huge warehouses in South London recently, she excitedly pointed out every nod to Greek mythology that she passed, including a shrine to the goddess Artemis and graffiti written in Linear B, an ancient form of Greek writing.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 2: Do the Hustle
abstract: Gus and the cartel chase Nacho, Kim and Jimmy pursue Howard — and everyone is conning someone.
lead_paragraph: This recap is for Episode 2 of the back-to-back season opener; click here for the recap of Episode 1.

headline: Ukrainian Children and Caregivers Are Being Separated at U.S. Border
abstract: Under a policy designed to protect young refugees from trafficking, Ukrainian children are being temporarily removed from caretakers who are not their parents.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After Iryna Merezhko persuaded her sister in Ukraine that her young nephew should join her in Los Angeles to wait out the war, she traveled halfway around the globe to pick him up. “I told him it would be a California vacation,” she recalled. “We would go to Disneyland, Universal Studios, the beach.”

headline: Several large U.S. transit systems have removed mask mandates.
abstract: Although New York and San Francisco continue to require masks, Atlanta, Philadelphia, Chicago and the nationwide Amtrak rail system have ended mandates.
lead_paragraph: As major U.S. airlines dropped their mask mandates in response to a federal judge’s ruling, public transit systems across the country scrambled to adapt on Tuesday. New York, San Francisco and Milwaukee kept requirements in place, while systems in Atlanta, Chicago, Washington and Philadelphia allowed riders to drop their masks, as did the nationwide Amtrak rail system.

headline: Nervous about flying? Here’s why a mask will still help protect you even if others aren’t wearing one.
abstract: There is plenty of evidence showing that masks protect the wearer, even when others around them are mask-free.
lead_paragraph: Masks work best when everyone around you is wearing one. That’s because when a person infected with the coronavirus wears a mask, a large percentage of the infectious particles they exhale are trapped, stopping viral spread at the source. And when fewer viral particles are floating around the room, the masks others are wearing are likely to block those particles that have escaped.

headline: Despair in Mariupol’s last stronghold: ‘They’re bombing us with everything’

lead_paragraph: DNIPRO, Ukraine — Under incessant fire from the air and with Russian troops closing in, a group of Ukrainian soldiers holed up in the besieged city of Mariupol issued a message of despair on Tuesday evening, expressing hope that their own forces would come to their rescue and demanding that the world do something to stop the Kremlin’s vicious war.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Sent Love Through Our Thumbs’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: In late 2020, I got very sick. After many months, specialists and dollars, there is still only a guess: long-haul Covid. I couldn’t breathe properly. An alien lived inside me. I was single, scared. What if something happened to me? My friend asked me daily for my “thumb status,” even though he hates texting because he says his thumbs are too big. On rare good days, I sent photos with a thumbs up. More were neutral thumbs. Most were thumbs down. Pain. Fatigue. Fear. Every day he asked. Every day I answered. Every day we sent love through our thumbs. — Emily O. Gravett

headline: Masks stay required for N.Y.C. public transit, taxis and ride-share vehicles.

headline: The Right Likes Book Bans. That Fuels the Left’s Cancel Culture.
abstract: Recreational puritanism begets itself.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the 1970s, one got a good snootful of what today might be wrongly described as critical race theory: The film “Sounder,” in the wake of a prominent novel, offered a searing depiction of sharecropping. The made-for-TV epic “The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman,” also based on a novel, took us through a sweep of history from slavery to segregation. The “Roots” mini-series, watched by millions (all at the same time, in a way that’s probably hard to imagine for those too young to remember life before D.V.R.s), portrayed the trans-Atlantic slave trade and plantation barbarity in a way American audiences hadn’t seen. As Charlayne Hunter-Gault reported for The Times in 1977, a Black economist in Philadelphia said, “It has made the brutality of slavery more vivid for me than anything I’ve seen or read.” To refresh a sense of what an event “Roots” was at the time, recall that the cast included some of the biggest names of the day, including John Amos, Lloyd Bridges and Sandy Duncan. Cicely Tyson, who passed away last year, starred in “Sounder,” “Miss Jane Pittman” and “Roots.”

headline: ‘The Runaways,’ ‘Brigsby Bear’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: This month’s outside-the-box streaming recommendations include quirky comedies, an uncommonly rich music biopic and genre movies that are a cut above.
lead_paragraph: Floria Sigismondi’s chronicle of this all-female 1970s rock band is not immune to the clichés of the period music biopic. But it amounts to far more — a celebration of the punk scene and D.I.Y. spirit, along with the expected (though generous) helpings of sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll. Dakota Fanning is terrific as the lead singer Cherie Currie, a role that proves an ideal vehicle for her hypnotic brittleness, while Kristen Stewart is in fierce form as Joan Jett, and Michael Shannon nearly steals the show as their sleazy manager and producer, Kim Fowley. Best of all, Sigismondi’s throwback aesthetic and Super-16 mm photography keenly evoke the look and feel of the era; it plays less like a period piece than a contemporaneous coming-of-age movie that was locked away for a few decades.

From his home studio in Madrid, with guitars on the floor and books and family photos on his shelves, Drexler dug into the cross-rhythms of a soleá por bulerías, the flamenco rhythm that underlies the title song of his new album, “Tinta y Tiempo” (“Ink and Time”).

abstract: This is fish rubbed with garlic and allspice, shallow-fried until the skin crisps, then doused with hot vinegar, carrots, onions and wicked Scotch bonnets.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Francine is coming,’’ they say. And then, leaning in, ‘‘She’s making escovitch.’’

headline: Why Those Moments of Care for Liza Minnelli and Joni Mitchell Felt Different
abstract: Awards shows are a natural setting for honoring aging legends. It’s reassuring when they don’t try to hide the frailty that aging can bring.
lead_paragraph: The first 53 minutes of music’s biggest night rolled along smoothly. This year’s Grammys had centerpiece performances from Olivia Rodrigo and BTS, plus a big reception for the newly minted Oscar winner Questlove; Trevor Noah, the host, told jokes that offended nobody’s spouse. It was only after Rodrigo accepted the award for Best New Artist that something unexpected happened.

headline: From Amazon to Starbucks, America Is Unionizing. Will Politics Catch Up?
abstract: A debate on how unions build power today and whether politicians — particularly Democrats — are still behind them.
lead_paragraph: From Amazon and Starbucks to large media companies, unionization has become a siren call for workers — white- and blue-collar — fighting for rights and fair wages. But in 2022, after two years of a pandemic, how have our ideas about unions changed? And are Democrats, the so-called party of the unions, still allies in the fight for workers’ rights?

headline: Solving a Garden-Party Murder in 1920s India
abstract: Harini Nagendra’s new novel, “The Bangalore Detectives Club,” stars a bookish, Sherlock-Holmes-loving young bride.
lead_paragraph: The first in an effervescent new mystery series by the ecology professor Harini Nagendra, THE BANGALORE DETECTIVES CLUB (Pegasus Crime, 304 pp., $26.95) turns the clock back a century. Kaveri has moved to Bangalore to become a proper wife to Ramu, the doctor to whom she was given in marriage as a 16-year-old. A solitary and bookish woman with a penchant for mathematics is not quite what her mother-in-law had in mind, and she makes that known. “Too much studying is bad for women,” she warns. “It makes their brains go soft.”

headline: Why Is Gut Health Taking Over TikTok?
abstract: Despite what social media might have you believe, there is no overnight shortcut to better digestive health.
lead_paragraph: Every few months, like clockwork, hundreds of videos promising tips and tricks to “hack” your gut flood TikTok. In March, influencers pushed shots of aloe vera juice: “My digestive system, like my gut health? Never been better,” one gushed in a video with one million likes while tapping on a purple bottle of the drink. Another, with the username “oliveoilqueen,” advocated drinking extra virgin olive oil every day in a video viewed more than 3.5 million times, claiming that doing so cleared her skin, made her periods less painful and fixed her frequent bloating. Videos tagged with #guttok have garnered nearly 400 million views. They’re crammed with suggestions for cucumber-ginger juices and boiled apples, bone broth in the morning and sludgy sweet potato soups at night.

headline: The Superpredator Myth Did a Lot of Damage. Courts Are Beginning to See the Light.
abstract: We don’t need to keep everyone in prison forever.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, many Americans have come to agree that we lock up too many people, for too long, in miserable conditions. But despite a growing political movement against prisons, imprisonment rates remain stubbornly high, and the United States is still the world leader in incarceration. To meaningfully shrink the prison system will require states to do something few have wanted to do: reduce some of the extremely long sentences imposed in the 1990s.

headline: I Lived the #VanLife. It Wasn’t Pretty.
abstract: The writer Caity Weaver’s pursuit of the manifest destiny of the millennial generation ended up looking better in the photos.
lead_paragraph: For the most part, I don’t remember things. My memory is not so much vague as it is glitchy; a generally blank screen that sometimes blinks to life and performs basic recall tasks. With scarce exceptions, my recollections are so inaccessible to me that they are more like the memories of a person I have never met or spoken to. Once, while rewatching one of my favorite films, I found myself wondering what its lead actor might be like in real life. Several scenes later, a revelation jolted me: I once flew cross-country to have lunch with that man, interviewed him about his life for two hours and had my 1,400-word summary of the experience published in a magazine. Geotagged iPhone photos are often some of my only clues that I have been somewhere or done something; I cherish them as proof that I, at one point, left my house.

headline: How The Times Has Mapped the War in Ukraine
abstract: Graphics journalists use annotated maps to show readers the current state of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Maps have played a critical role in The New York Times’s coverage of the war in Ukraine — and nearly every graphics journalist at the organization, from New York to Seoul to London, has helped with the mapping effort.

headline: Herschel Walker’s Senate Bid in Georgia Is Powered by Fandom
abstract: The football-star-turned-candidate has been converting Bulldogs fans into supporters. But some Republicans worry voters are blinded by his celebrity.
lead_paragraph: LaGRANGE, Ga. — Most came dressed in University of Georgia jerseys, hats and T-shirts. Some carried footballs and framed posters. It was a campaign stop for a Senate candidate, but for many Georgians who came to see Herschel Walker, politics was hardly the only draw.

headline: With or Without Trump, the MAGA Movement Is the Future of the Republican Party
abstract: The losing candidate in the 2020 election continues to exert tremendous power over his party. What does this portend for its future?
lead_paragraph: The fissures in the Democratic Party are on display for all to see, since it is the party in power, but the divisions in the Republican Party and the conservative movement are deeper, wider and far more threatening.

headline: Living In ... West Orange, N.J.
abstract: During the pandemic, the Essex County township has attracted city buyers with its open space and relatively affordable housing — all less than 20 miles from Midtown.
lead_paragraph: During the pandemic, the Essex County township has attracted city buyers with its open space and relatively affordable housing — all less than 20 miles from Midtown.

headline: Feeling the Squeeze? How to Be a Thrifty Traveler as Prices Soar
abstract: Inflation is here and it’s wreaking havoc on travel budgets. Our Frugal Traveler columnist on how to strategize in a world of rising prices.
lead_paragraph: Travelers are feeling the squeeze. Rising prices related to inflation, employment shortages and supply chain slowdowns are hitting the travel industry, just as summer travel planning — compounded by pent-up demand — peaks.

headline: West Orange, N.J.: Plentiful Green Space and an Easy Commute
abstract: During the pandemic, the Essex County township has attracted city buyers with its open space and relatively affordable housing — all less than 20 miles from Midtown.
lead_paragraph: Living in a Brooklyn apartment with two young children in the middle of the pandemic, Megan Melamed, 41, and Alex Abell, 39, started their search for a suburban home in Maplewood, N.J. But the couple, both social workers, soon realized it was out of their price range, so they turned to the nearby Essex County township of West Orange, where they eventually bought a 1915 house with four bedrooms in October 2020, for $457,500.

headline: Shanghai’s Low Covid Death Toll Revives Questions About China’s Numbers
abstract: The country’s largest city has recorded just 17 Covid deaths, despite surging cases. How China defines a Covid death may be part of the reason.
lead_paragraph: By the numbers, Shanghai has been an exemplar of how to save lives during a pandemic. Despite the city’s more than 400,000 Covid-19 infections, just 17 people have died, according to officials, statistics they have touted as proof that their strategy of strict lockdowns and mass quarantines works.

headline: Nicolas Cage Is in on the Nicolas Cage Jokes
abstract: In his new movie, “The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent,” the actor plays “himself” in all his meme-ified glory.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-two years ago, Nicolas Cage swaggered onto the set of a British talk show to promote his movie “Wild at Heart.” After performing a handspring and several kung fu-style moves, he whipped off his T-shirt, thrust it at the startled host, and put his leather jacket back on over his naked chest before proceeding with the interview.

headline: How Loneliness Is Damaging Our Health
abstract: Even before the pandemic, there was an “epidemic of loneliness,” and it was affecting physical health and life expectancy.
lead_paragraph: For two years you didn’t see friends like you used to. You missed your colleagues from work, even the barista on the way there.

headline: How a Lush Garden Grew Out of Soil Like ‘Wet Plastic’
abstract: James Golden’s New Jersey garden, Federal Twist, taught him that a gardener must match the plants to the place — however difficult that seems.
lead_paragraph: James Golden’s New Jersey garden, Federal Twist, taught him that a gardener must match the plants to the place — however difficult that seems.

headline: With Inflation, Workers Are Facing Return-to-Office Sticker Shock
abstract: The cost of a daily routine — travel, coffee, food — is far pricier than it was when offices shut down two years ago.
lead_paragraph: As the security software company KnowBe4 weighed whether to require a return to the office, executives knew to anticipate a certain set of concerns from employees. Less flexibility. More time in transit.

headline: How America’s Farmers Got Cut Out of the Supply Chain
abstract: As shipping companies concentrate on the most lucrative routes from China to California, almond growers are struggling to transport their wares.
lead_paragraph: During a normal spring, the sight of orchards bursting with clusters of almonds is a boon throughout California’s Central Valley. Here is money growing on trees.

headline: Only the Feds Could Disqualify Madison Cawthorn and Marjorie Taylor Greene
abstract: State courts or election boards lack jurisdiction in keeping alleged insurrectionists off a congressional ballot.
lead_paragraph: The events of Jan. 6, 2021, are casting a long shadow over the midterm elections. Voters in North Carolina are seeking to bar Representative Madison Cawthorn from running for re-election to his House seat, and those in Georgia are trying to do the same to Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene.

headline: How the Worst Site Can Become the Best Garden
abstract: James Golden’s New Jersey garden, Federal Twist, taught him that a gardener must match the plants to the place — however difficult that seems.
lead_paragraph: “A real wasteland.” “A derelict wood.” And: “Sort of frightening.”

headline: Deep in Colombia, Rebels and Soldiers Fight for the Same Prize: Drugs
abstract: The country signed a historic peace deal more than five years ago. But a power vacuum is fueling the rise of new armed groups competing to control the drug trade.
lead_paragraph: PUTUMAYO, Colombia — In a rebel-held town deep in the jungle, Joel ran drills beside his comrades, line after line of them in camouflage and boots, rifles at their sides.

headline: What You Get for $850,000
abstract: A 1938 cottage in Richmond, Va.; a 13-acre retreat in Abita Springs, La.; and a Craftsman bungalow in Denver.
lead_paragraph: A 1938 cottage in Richmond, Va.; a 13-acre retreat in Abita Springs, La.; and a Craftsman bungalow in Denver.

headline: $850,000 Homes in Virginia, Louisiana and Colorado
abstract: A 1938 cottage in Richmond, a 13-acre retreat in Abita Springs and a Craftsman bungalow in Denver.
lead_paragraph: About a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Washington, Richmond is filled with bustling, family-friendly neighborhoods like this one, just a few blocks from the University of Richmond, a private liberal arts college with about 3,900 students.

headline: Carved Into the Mountains of Lima
abstract: This modern seven-bedroom house carved into in the hills of Lima, Peru, is on the market for $2 million.
lead_paragraph: This modern seven-bedroom house carved into in the hills of Lima, Peru, is on the market for $2 million.

headline: House Hunting in Peru: A Modern Mountain Perch Above Lima
abstract: Political upheaval has stunted the high-end market in Peru’s capital, but domestic buyers are keeping demand high at the middle and lower end of the market.
lead_paragraph: A stone mountain rises behind this geometric 12,055-square-foot house in La Planicie, an affluent neighborhood in the eastern La Molina district of Lima, Peru. Designed by Peruvian firm Domenack Arquitectos and built in 2014, the seven-bedroom, eight-bath house incorporates natural elements like an indoor waterfall and volcanic stone around the pool deck.

headline: Why New York’s a Lonely Town, Especially Since Covid
abstract: We are still learning what the effects of prolonged isolation could be in a city where a million people live alone.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at something we all experienced in the pandemic when we lost friends or simply couldn’t get together — loneliness. We’ll also look at how the New York Public Library and the Brooklyn Public Library are countering book-banning efforts in other parts of the country.

headline: Building the First Long-Distance Hiking Trail in Kurdistan
abstract: Can it help knit together a nation?
lead_paragraph: Lawin Mohammad collects trails in the mountains of Kurdistan. He has met scores of shepherds on their daily wanderings. He confers with beekeepers on high passes. He follows aging pesh merga on their former patrols and waylays Christian and Yazidi pilgrims. When he is stopped on the highway at a military checkpoint, staring into the aviators of a heavily armed 20-year-old, he will ask the soldier whether he ever walks to the next village over. Or if his grandfather ever did. He makes inquiries among Syrians like himself who a decade ago took the dangerous crossing from Rojava into the foothills of the Zagros Mountains, in northern Iraq, at the start of the civil war. He parleys with children and imams. I have seen him work over at least one furtive treasure hunter. His informants are legion.

headline: 6 Rohingya Refugees Are Killed Fleeing Detention Center in Malaysia
abstract: In recent years, the Malaysian government has taken a more hard-line approach to the refugees in the country, which once offered a modicum of opportunity.
lead_paragraph: As hundreds of Rohingya refugees fled a detention center in Malaysia, six of them, including two children, were killed on Wednesday when they were struck by a car crossing a highway.

headline: In the fog of dementia, one grandmother learns again and again that her country is at war.
abstract: Millions of Ukrainians have been displaced since the war started. Many elderly or disabled people have been unable or unwilling to leave their homes.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Olga Boichak’s grandmother wakes up at her home in western Ukraine, turns on the television and discovers anew that her country is at war.

headline: When Texas Went After Transgender Care, Part 1
abstract: The story of one family seeking gender-affirming care in the midst of a political storm.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, there has been a sharp increase in the number of younger Americans who identify as transgender and are seeking medical intervention to support their transition.

headline: Why a Chinese Security Deal in the Pacific Could Ripple Through the World
abstract: In potentially opening the door to a Chinese military base, the Solomon Islands threatens the balance of power in a vital shipping region.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When the Solomon Islands’ prime minister stood before Parliament on Wednesday to announce that his government had signed a sweeping security agreement with China, he insisted that it would “not adversely impact or undermine the peace and harmony of our region.”

headline: Can Ukraine Keep Winning?
abstract: As a new phase of the war begins, we look at Russia’s advantages — and Ukraine’s.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has defeated Russia in the first phase of their war, and a second phase has begun.

headline: A Problem for Macron in France’s Election: ‘The Hatred He Arouses’
abstract: Given the choice between a president they suspect of despising ordinary people and a far-right candidate they detest, many French voters may stay home.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the French runoff election between Macron and Le Pen.

headline: ‘Cypress Hill: Insane in the Brain’ Review: Influential Rappers, Still Smokin’
abstract: This documentary by Estevan Oriol chronicles the rise of a group that he has been around since its inception.
lead_paragraph: In 1991, just a few years after Public Enemy released the single “Bring the Noise,” Cypress Hill, a hip-hop trio out of South Gate, near Los Angeles, released a debut that followed that exhortation to astonishing effect. The rapper B-Real delivered his anti-cop, pro-weed rhymes in a taunting, nasal tone, countered by the abrupt barks of Sen Dog. DJ Muggs created beats that were inventively off-kilter and put high-pitched whistles and sirens under and around hooks that were more than earworms — these tracks got under your whole skin.

headline: Myanmar faces a health emergency as its military regime targets doctors.
abstract: In recent weeks, Myanmar’s security forces have intensified their crackdown on doctors who oppose the military junta that seized power 14 months ago. Doctors have been at the forefront of a nationwide civil disobedience movement that has crippled the economy, and the regime has targeted health care workers from the start.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Myanmar’s security forces have intensified their crackdown on doctors who oppose the military junta that seized power 14 months ago. Doctors have been at the forefront of a nationwide civil disobedience movement that has crippled the economy, and the regime has targeted health care workers from the start.

headline: An Ace Took the Harder Option. Bad News for the Giants.
abstract: The Mets won both games of a doubleheader against San Francisco, and Max Scherzer’s decision to pitch the second game was all about teamwork.
lead_paragraph: The easy choice, for Max Scherzer, would have been to start the first game of Tuesday’s doubleheader at Citi Field. Pitchers thrive on routine, and only the opening game had a scheduled time for the first pitch. Scherzer has a Hall of Fame résumé, and if he had insisted on the opener for his first home start as a Met, he could have had his way.

headline: U.K. Court Brings Assange One Step Closer to Extradition
abstract: The court formally ordered the extradition of the WikiLeaks founder to the United States, but it still needs approval from a British cabinet minister and his defense can appeal to her directly.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A London court on Wednesday ordered the extradition of the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to the United States, the latest but not the last step in a long-running battle in British courtrooms.

headline: The End of Mask Mandates
abstract: As major airlines and some public transit operators drop requirements to wear face coverings, further conflicts may be on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: Major U.S. airlines have lifted mask mandates after a federal judge ruled that face coverings would no longer be required on airplanes, trains and other public transportation.

headline: Ukrainians Face Delays and Roadblocks as They Try to Enter California
abstract: A growing number of refugees are hoping to cross from Tijuana into San Diego.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Ukraine stretches on longer than many anticipated, California’s southern border has increasingly become a destination for refugees from the war-torn country.

headline: New York Times Names Marc Lacey and Carolyn Ryan as Managing Editors
abstract: A pair of veteran Times journalists will serve in the newsroom’s No. 2 position under the new executive editor, Joe Kahn.
lead_paragraph: Joseph F. Kahn, newly appointed as the next executive editor of The New York Times, announced his leadership team on Wednesday in a memo that urged his colleagues “to produce the most ambitious, consequential and creative work of our careers.”

headline: More Pandemic Fallout: The Chronically Absent Student
abstract: At one middle school, more than 40 percent of the students have been chronically absent this year. Districts are going to great lengths — offering gift cards, night classes — to reach them.
lead_paragraph: After the coronavirus pandemic pushed his classes online in the spring of 2020, Isaac Mosley, now 18, got used to spending his time outside of school.

headline: Mystery Persists After Initial Report Into China Eastern Jet Crash
abstract: A preliminary report by China’s air safety regulator summarized what worked during the flight, but did not speculate on what caused the plane to nose-dive.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The pilots had met China’s standards for flying a commercial jet. No problems were found with the aircraft before it took off. No dangerous cargo had been loaded aboard. Communications with the plane appeared normal until its deadly plunge.

headline: ‘Some Like It Hot’ Musical Plans Fall Opening on Broadway
abstract: Christian Borle, J. Harrison Ghee and Adrianna Hicks will star in a stage adaptation of the 1959 film comedy about two musicians on the run.
lead_paragraph: A new musical adaptation of “Some Like It Hot,” a classic cross-dressing comedy that is being recalibrated for contemporary audiences, will start performances in November and open in December on Broadway, the show’s producers said Wednesday.

headline: Biden Is Expected to Tap Arizona Prosecutor as Interim Director of A.T.F.
abstract: The selection of Gary M. Restaino is intended to inject a sense of urgency into the bureau until President Biden’s nominee to oversee the agency permanently is confirmed.
