headline: 6 Gun Shops, 11,000 ‘Crime Guns’: A Rare Peek at the Pipeline
abstract: In Philadelphia, the most comprehensive study in decades found a handful of dealers selling a huge number of guns used illegally. A House panel is uncovering similar patterns elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: 95 Wild Horses Died. A Virus Is the Likely Cause, Officials Say.
abstract: The outbreak at a Colorado facility has killed nearly 100 horses since Saturday. On Thursday, the Bureau of Land Management identified a “not uncommon” virus as the culprit.
lead_paragraph: An equine influenza virus likely caused the mysterious respiratory disease that has killed at least 95 wild horses and forced a federal holding facility in Colorado to go under quarantine, the Bureau of Land Management said Thursday.

headline: Pulitzer-Winning ‘Cost of Living’ Will Come to Broadway This Fall
abstract: Manhattan Theater Club will stage the Martyna Majok play, which explores disability and caregiving, at its Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
lead_paragraph: Martyna Majok’s “Cost of Living,” a play that explores disability and caregiving and which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2018, will be staged on Broadway this fall.

headline: In Films and on TV, a New Openness to Natural Black Hairstyles
abstract: The relationship between characters and their Afro-textured hair has become a focus of directors and stylists, who are mindful of Hollywood’s restrictive past.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: To Igor, With Love and Masterpieces, George
abstract: On the 50th anniversary of New York City Ballet’s Stravinsky Festival, remembering a collaboration for the ages: Balanchine and Stravinsky.
lead_paragraph: One week. Thirty ballets. Twenty of them new. Seven choreographers. Forty crates of vodka. Innumerable hours of work.

headline: Are Traditional Political Parties Dead in France?
abstract: Presidents, prime ministers, Parliament — France’s mainstream left and right-wing parties used to have it all. In the first round of April’s presidential elections, they got less than 7 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Since the 1950s, France’s traditional left- and right-wing parties have provided three-quarters of the country’s presidents and nearly all of its prime ministers.

headline: Turkey’s Leader Lands in Saudi Arabia, Seeking to Ease Tensions
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is visiting the kingdom for the first time in nearly five years, signaling a mending of relations over the killing of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey arrived in Saudi Arabia for his first visit in nearly five years on Thursday, capping his recent efforts to improve ties with the oil-rich kingdom at a time of deep economic distress at home and to ease years of tensions over the killing of the dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul.

headline: Placing a Bet on Italian Grapes in California
abstract: Kevin Harvey of Rhys Vineyards makes terrific pinot noirs. Now he sees nebbiolo and two Sicilian varieties as great options in a warming climate.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL MOUNTAIN, Calif. — The 10 acres of nebbiolo growing on this remote ridge about 25 miles west of Geyserville and 10 miles from the Pacific in northern Sonoma County, make the vineyard unusual enough in California. The other grapes make it positively singular.

headline: He Always Tweeted Like He Owned the Place
abstract: And in some ways he did.
lead_paragraph: Even before Elon Musk proposed a roughly $44 billion deal to take over Twitter, his tweeting habit had become an essential part of his public persona. He was the world’s richest person, the founder of Tesla, the SpaceX guy, and someone who would not, or could not, stop posting.

headline: White House plays down first-quarter growth decline.
abstract: The administration emphasized strength in consumer spending, even as Republicans blasted its management of the economy.
lead_paragraph: The White House dismissed a slump in first-quarter growth that was driven by a quirk in inventories and a jump in imports, emphasizing that Thursday’s report on gross domestic product also pointed to underlying strength in consumer spending.

headline: It Took Me 40 Years to Watch the Movie ‘Diva.’ It Was Worth the Wait.
abstract: At a friend’s urging, our critic saw the “mondo chic” 1981 film by the French director Jean-Jacques Beineix, ahead of a revival. He was thrilled.
lead_paragraph: For years, my friend Mark has been urging me to see “Diva.” Unless he was severely mistaken, he wrote in an email, “you will love” it. Well, 41 years after its debut in France, “Diva” is back on a big screen — Film Forum’s — for a week, restored and ready to prove Mark right. I did love it. My fate was sealed the minute some poor lady stumbles off a train and staggers through the station in a snazzy shirt dress. She’s not wearing any shoes, and Chantal Deruaz, the actor playing her, musters what distress she can for the chase that ensues. It ends with her collapsed on a Paris street, because a puckish, punky blond — he looks a lot like Flea — has flung an object in her back, as one might a card in a magic show. Seems like an ice pick. But it’s an awl. An awl.

headline: How DeSantis Transformed Florida’s Political Identity
abstract: The state has become an unlikely laboratory for right-wing policy, pushed by a governor with presidential ambitions.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida feels like a state running a fever, its very identity changing at a frenetic pace.

headline: What Makes Elon Musk Tick?
abstract: Walter Isaacson, a biographer who has written about Benjamin Franklin and Steve Jobs, is working on a book about the world’s richest man.
lead_paragraph: What drives Elon Musk?

headline: ‘Bad Roads’ Review: A Wartime Anthology
abstract: The movie, with its four vignettes about Ukraine, was the country’s submission for best international feature film for the Oscars.

headline: F.D.A. Moves to Ban Sales of Menthol Cigarettes
abstract: Public health experts say the proposal could save hundreds of thousands of lives, especially among Black smokers — 85 percent of whom use menthol products.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday announced a plan to ban sales of menthol-flavored cigarettes in the United States, a measure many public health experts hailed as the government’s most meaningful action in more than a decade of tobacco control efforts.

headline: Daniel Auster, Accused in Death of Infant Daughter, Dies After Overdose
abstract: The son of the famous novelist Paul Auster was found unconscious in a Brooklyn subway station and later taken off life support, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Auster, a Brooklyn man who had been charged in the death of his 10-month-old daughter from heroin and fentanyl exposure, died after being taken off life support on Tuesday following a drug overdose, two law enforcement officials said.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Hepatitis Symptoms, Migraine Triggers and Medicare
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Ramadan Nights Provide Cherished Pause in a Sudan on the Brink
abstract: “We come here to forget it all,” one young musician said during the daily end of the fast. “The heat, the electricity cuts, the protests. Here, at least, we can sing.”
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Friday night by the Nile, and a love song wafted on the warm breeze that blew across Tuti Island, a crescent of land at the confluence of the river’s two great branches.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | May 4, 2022
abstract: Are summer nights getting hotter? How have minimum daily temperatures from June through August changed over the past 60 years in nine cities?
lead_paragraph: These graphs of summer daily minimum temperatures were published in The New York Times. Examine the notes below the graph and the explanations on the Phoenix graph that apply to all of the graphs to best understand what the graph shows.

headline: At a Brooklyn Brownstone, an Easter Dinner That Bucked Tradition
abstract: The Argentine chef and artist Fernando Aciar and the French creative director Anna Polonsky treated friends to a meal that felt as personal as their newly renovated home.
lead_paragraph: It was not love at first sight when Fernando Aciar, a chef and artist, met Anna Polonsky, the founder and creative director of the design and branding studio Polonsky & Friends. “I did not have a good impression of her,” Aciar recalls of their chance encounter at a work event Polonsky had organized in 2012. “We certainly didn’t hit it off,” confirms Polonsky. About a year later, though, they bumped into one another again at a goodbye party for a mutual friend at a bar in Greenpoint. This time around, the two clicked. “It happened very fast,” says Aciar. “Anna was leaving the next day to go to Berlin for a wedding. When she got back, we went on a date to Estela. Four months later, we were engaged.”

headline: On the Scene: A Tense Ramadan in Sudan
abstract: During the holy month of Ramadan, Muslims break their daily fast with iftar, a meal that is shared with friends, families, and even strangers. In Sudan, people gathered for iftar in riverside villages, desert hurts and suburban streets.
lead_paragraph: During the holy month of Ramadan, Muslims break their daily fast with iftar, a meal that is shared with friends, families, and even strangers. In Sudan, people gathered for iftar in riverside villages, desert hurts and suburban streets.

headline: Key Justice Dept. Official Expected to Step Down
abstract: John Carlin, who occupies one of the most powerful and under-the-radar posts in the department, has dealt with major matters including the Jan. 6 investigation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top official under Deputy Attorney General Lisa O. Monaco is expected to step down this summer, as her office juggles numerous high-profile national security and criminal issues, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Jerrod Carmichael and More
abstract: I'm a Culture reporter. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I'm a Culture reporter. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: ‘Anaïs in Love’ Review: Portrait of a Woman on the Run
abstract: A restless woman discovers herself in a seductive French romance that throws out the usual dusty script about women, desire and pleasure.
lead_paragraph: What makes Anaïs run — and run? That’s the question slyly teased in “Anaïs in Love,” a French romance about a woman’s winding voyage toward self-discovery. Much like Anaïs herself, the contours of that journey at first seem transparently obvious: She’s young, self-absorbed, exceedingly restless, and she just needs to get her act together. Yet while all this frenetic motion can seem mildly charming (just like her), it can also be exasperating (also like her), which makes Anaïs and this movie more intriguing than they initially appear.

headline: Inside Twitter, Fears Musk Will Return Platform to Its Early Troubles
abstract: Content moderators warn that Elon Musk doesn’t appear to understand the issues that he and the company will face if he drops its guardrails around speech.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk had a plan to buy Twitter and undo its content moderation policies. On Tuesday, just a day after reaching his $44 billion deal to buy the company, Mr. Musk was already at work on his agenda. He tweeted that past moderation decisions by a top Twitter lawyer were “obviously incredibly inappropriate.” Later, he shared a meme mocking the lawyer, sparking a torrent of attacks from other Twitter users.

headline: John DiStaso, Star Reporter of New Hampshire Primaries, Dies at 68
abstract: The dean of the state’s political press corps, he was well positioned to grill, vet and analyze a new crop of presidential candidates every four years.
lead_paragraph: John DiStaso, a longtime New Hampshire political reporter who scrutinized a fresh crop of presidential candidates every four years, grilled them on the debate stage and analyzed their foibles and their prospects, died on April 21 in Manchester, N.H. He was 68.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: Mitsuko Uchida’s Beethoven, a soprano’s program of works by female composers and a lush repertory of sleep-related music are among recent highlights.
lead_paragraph: Slowly, slowly, Mitsuko Uchida adds to her Beethoven discography — these “Diabelli” Variations now joining her five sonatas and two surveys of the piano concertos, with Kurt Sanderling and Simon Rattle.

headline: Preparing for the N.F.L. Draft in Las Vegas
abstract: The glitz of this year’s draft is a preview of the Super Bowl party that Las Vegas will throw in 2024.
lead_paragraph: The glitz of this year’s draft is a preview of the Super Bowl party that Las Vegas will throw in 2024.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Subverted U. of North Carolina, Professors’ Group Says
abstract: In a new report, the group says that the Republicans created a hostile climate on campuses. The administration called the charges absurd.
lead_paragraph: A prestigious national academic group charged on Thursday that North Carolina’s legislature had politically interfered with the operations of the University of North Carolina for more than a decade, creating a hostile academic and racial climate at its campuses, including the flagship in Chapel Hill.

headline: Johnson & Johnson investors reject proposal to end global talc sales.
abstract: The shareholder resolution, which had urged the company to pull talc-based baby powder from shelves around the world, stemmed from concerns about asbestos contamination.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson’s shareholders voted against a proposal on Thursday to discontinue sales of its talc baby powder around the world as the consumer goods giant tries to shield itself from tens of thousands of lawsuits over the product.

headline: An Unsteady Moment for Tech
abstract: The past decade has been one long party for tech. Where we go from here isn’t so clear.
lead_paragraph: We are in an odd moment for technology. Can you feel it? The powerful forces of unstoppable change and tech wealth are rolling along, but mixed in there is a shred of something else: doubt.

headline: G.O.P. Concocts Fake Threat: Voter Fraud by Undocumented Immigrants
abstract: Far from the U.S.-Mexico border, Ohio’s Senate primary shows how the Republican obsession with the fiction of a stolen election has spawned a new cause for fear of illegal immigration.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Six years after former President Donald J. Trump paved his way to the White House on nativist and xenophobic appeals to white voters, the 2,000-mile dividing line between Mexico and the United States has once again become a fixation of the Republican Party.

headline: A Quick Guide to Grain Bowls
abstract: Alone with cheese and pepper, or in big grain bowls, farro can do it all.
lead_paragraph: Like many cooks I know, I don’t always follow recipes for grain bowls at home. Instead, I tend to use up what I have in the fridge and pantry, mixing and matching, figuring out how to make odds and ends delicious.

headline: ‘Crush’ Review: A Banksy Who Might Shred Homework
abstract: A mysterious artist and a love triangle are at the center of this high-school comedy, which can’t quite decide whether to be preposterous or sincere.
lead_paragraph: “Crush,” the debut feature of the director Sammi Cohen, is a cuddly, flimsy teenage comedy about a high-school love triangle. The plot hinges on two secrets: the identity of a mysterious campus artist known only as King Pun (whose oeuvre includes spray-painting the words “nice rack” by the gym’s basketball cart) and the furtive kisses enjoyed by Paige (Rowan Blanchard), a frustrated, love-struck young illustrator who is suspected of being King Pun. Paige’s flames, Gabriela (Isabella Ferreira), a popular flirt, and AJ (Auli’i Cravalho), a tongue-tied enigma, lead the track team. They also happen to be sisters. Paige’s romantic struggle is at once unusual and oddly undramatic — much like the dynamic between her flamboyantly straight best friends, Stacey (Teala Dunn) and Dillon (Tyler Alvarez), who constantly hook up with each other while competing in an election for student body president.

headline: Snap unveils a flying camera called Pixy.
abstract: The drone camera is the newest hardware product from the maker of Snapchat, which previously released smart glasses known as Spectacles.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the maker of the Snapchat messaging app, has long positioned itself as a camera company.

headline: Florida’s Punishment of Disney World
abstract: Readers criticize Florida for revoking Disney’s tax district over the “Don’t Say Gay” law. Also: Antidepressants work; Ukrainians’ dogs; North Korea’s nuclear arms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kehlani’s Journey of Healing
abstract: On “Blue Water Road,” the singer infuses confessional lyrics with newfound emotional clarity.
lead_paragraph: There’s a simple but powerful promise in “Little Story,” the orchestral epic that opens Kehlani’s new album, “Blue Water Road” — one that captures what it feels like to spend a lifetime chasing safe, tender intimacy in partnership: “Working on being softer/’Cause you are a dream, to me.”

headline: Supreme Court Bans Recovery for Emotional Harm in Discrimination Suits
abstract: Splitting 6 to 3, the court ruled that facilities receiving federal money cannot be sued under four federal laws for discrimination that causes emotional distress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dividing 6 to 3 along ideological lines, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that victims of discrimination that is forbidden by four federal statutes may not sue if the only harm was emotional distress.

headline: Live Webinar: Exploring How The Times Can Be Accessible for Every Learner
abstract: Join us on May 12 as we tour a broad range of accessible journalism formats, from photo essays to “bursts,” and discuss practical strategies for scaffolding more challenging text.
lead_paragraph: The variety of articles, essays, photojournalism, graphics, videos and podcasts we publish daily means that there is no simple answer to the question “What is the reading level of The New York Times?”

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: East meets West in our recommended titles this week, with books including Louisa Lim’s in-depth look at Hong Kong, Jenny Tinghui Zhang’s debut novel about Chinese manual labor in the American West, Harini Nagendra’s detective story set in 1920s Bangalore, India, and Caroline Elkins’s exploration of British imperialism across the Middle East and elsewhere.

headline: Measles cases are surging because the pandemic disrupted childhood vaccinations, global agencies say.
abstract: A rise of nearly 80 percent in reported measles cases in the first two months of 2022 is the result of millions of children missing out on routine shots, the U.N. and W.H.O. said.
lead_paragraph: Cases of measles have surged by nearly 80 percent worldwide so far this year, a dire consequence of pandemic-related disruptions to childhood vaccinations, the United Nations Children’s Fund and the World Health Organization said.

headline: ‘I Love That for You’ Review: The Art of the Sellout
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” alum Vanessa Bayer stars in a Showtime comedy about illness, lies and home shopping.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Gold, the supremely awkward protagonist of the new Showtime comedy “I Love That For You,” often lapses into a dialect you’ve never quite heard before, a straight-out-of-Cleveland, social-media-and-daytime-TV mishmash that embarrasses her even as she’s slinging it. Asked how she is feeling, she comes out with, “I’m hashtag-living, I’m hashtag-I’m-loving-it, boo-doom-poom-poom, yeah, let’s all go down to the Mickey D’s and get some cheesebuggaz.” It’s as if Annie Hall had been locked in a room for the last decade with just the E! channel.

headline: Review: Nico Muhly’s Moody Concerto for Two Pianos
abstract: In its American debut with the New York Philharmonic, “In Certain Circles,” featuring Katia and Marielle Labèque, had a freedom born from confidence.
lead_paragraph: Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s music director, designed an atmospheric program around the American premiere of Nico Muhly’s “In Certain Circles” at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

headline: They’re All Good Dogs, and It Has Nothing to Do With Their Breed
abstract: Retrievers that don’t retrieve and Papillons that point are all possible because the genes that shape dog behavior predate modern breeding that focuses on appearance, researchers find.
lead_paragraph: Don’t judge a book by its cover. Don’t judge a dog by its breed.

headline: Dropping Anna Netrebko, the Met Turns to a Ukrainian Diva
abstract: The Ukrainian soprano Liudmyla Monastyrska, replacing one of Russia’s biggest stars in “Turandot,” is using her platform to defend her country.
lead_paragraph: The call from the Metropolitan Opera came one afternoon in early March.

headline: After a Tempest, Philip Guston Shines in a Show True to His Spirit
abstract: The long-delayed survey, now wrapped in the equivalent of caution tape, opens at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. It’s been a learning-curve climb for four venues.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On Oct. 16, 1970, the American painter Philip Guston, who is the subject of a potent and controversial retrospective at the Museum of Fine Arts here, committed career suicide. Or so it seemed. In his late 50s, he was a star of the Abstract Expressionist movement, then still considered the mandarin market style. But that year, he filled a New York gallery not with his signature flickery, emberlike abstractions, but with paintings of goony, cartoonish figures wearing white Ku Klux Klan hoods. Instantly he plummeted from art world grace.

headline: ‘Small Kindnesses’: A Collaborative Poem by Teenagers From Around the World
abstract: After more than 1,300 teenagers told us about the small kindnesses they appreciate, the poet Danusha Laméris wove their answers into verse.

headline: Warning on Mass Extinction of Sea Life: ‘An Oh My God Moment’
abstract: A new study finds that if fossil fuel emissions continue apace, the oceans could experience a mass extinction by 2300. There is still time to avoid it.
lead_paragraph: At first, the scientists chose a straightforward title for their research: “Marine Extinction Risk From Climate Warming.”

headline: Revolt Brews in Michigan G.O.P. After Elevation of Trump Allies
abstract: The Republican old guard is protesting the direction of the party after it put forward two champions of Donald Trump’s election falsehoods for attorney general and secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: For Republican supporters of Donald J. Trump in Michigan, it seemed like a crowning moment: The state party chose two candidates endorsed by the former president, both outspoken preachers of 2020 election falsehoods, as its contenders for the state’s top law enforcement officer and its chief of election administration.

headline: Witness to a Fire
abstract: Why it’s so difficult to talk about self-immolation.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Wynn Bruce, a 50-year-old climate activist, set himself on fire in front of the Supreme Court building. After he died, a woman who identified herself as his friend tweeted that the act was planned to bring attention to the climate crisis. That it happened was reported by national news outlets, but it is difficult to figure out what more to say about self-immolation.

headline: With a Fleet of Bars on the Water, Two Brothers Drop Anchor Downtown
abstract: The latest venture for boat-bar owners Alex and Miles Pincus is their first permanent, landlocked watering hole in New York City. The bar evokes the feeling of drinking in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Alex and Miles Pincus refer to Holywater, their new bar below the sidewalks of TriBeCa, as their first “land bar” in New York City.

headline: Trae Young: Your Hair Is an Unsolved Mystery. But a Magnificent One.
abstract: The complex ’do of the Hawks player has been debated, dissed and memed. But our critic pays respect to its “confusion, awe and strength.”
lead_paragraph: What now? He’s gone. I mean, it’s gone. The single most fascinating thing about the N.B.A. playoffs hasn’t been, “Were the Nets ever really a team?” Or: “Whose death wish is better: Charles Bronson’s or Philly’s?” It’s not even: “Lord. What. Is. Ben Simmons. Wearing. To-night?” The single most fascinating thing about the last two postseasons has obviously been Trae Young’s hair.

headline: Radiation levels near the Chernobyl plant are within safe limits, the nuclear agency chief says.
abstract: The finding came after readings were taken this week at the site, which Russian forces had occupied but withdrew from in late March.
lead_paragraph: Radiation levels are elevated in some parts of the soil near the defunct Chernobyl nuclear plant in northern Ukraine, but do not pose a significant threat to workers or the environment, the head of the international nuclear watchdog agency said on Thursday.

headline: Holland Taylor Plays Ann Richards One Last Time
abstract: Taylor, 79, first performed her solo play “Ann,” about the former governor of Texas, in 2010. Now, she’s saying goodbye to the white suit.
lead_paragraph: The actress Holland Taylor had long been a fan of Ann Richards, the Democratic firebrand and former governor of Texas, and so she was “strangely overcome,” as she put it, when Richards died in 2006.

headline: What Were the L.A. Riots?
abstract: After the police officers who beat Rodney King were acquitted, Los Angeles went to war with itself. The violence lasted a week, but its causes stretched back years.
lead_paragraph: After the police officers who beat Rodney King were acquitted, Los Angeles went to war with itself. The violence lasted a week, but its causes stretched back years.

headline: Germany is preparing to forgo Russian gas. But a quick cutoff would hurt.
abstract: “We have to be ready for it,” the German chancellor said a day after Russia quit providing natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: A day after Russia cut off gas supplies to Poland and Bulgaria, the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, said on Thursday that his country must be prepared for the possibility that Germany could be next.

headline: Biden Says He Is Taking a ‘Hard Look’ at Student Loan Relief
abstract: President Biden said the amount would not be $50,000 per borrower, which some Democrats and advocates are pushing for as a way to address economic and racial disparities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Thursday that he is considering wiping out some student loan debt and will make a final decision “in the coming weeks.”

headline: The fight over voting continues. Here’s the latest.
abstract: Many politicians driving the clampdown on voting are on the ballot themselves this year.
lead_paragraph: The conflict over sweeping new restrictions on voting, largely confined to statehouses and governors’ desks since 2020, is spilling over into the midterm elections.

headline: States Sue Postal Service Over New Gas-Powered Mail Trucks
abstract: Sixteen states argue the Postal Service failed to properly vet clean alternatives to polluting trucks that could get as little as 8.6 miles to the gallon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorneys general from 16 states and the District of Columbia, along with five environmental groups and the United Auto Workers, launched a legal challenge against the United States Postal Service on Thursday, claiming that it violated the law when it ordered thousands of new mail trucks powered by gasoline instead of electricity.

headline: Where’d All the Method Acting Go?
abstract: The Method taught actors to channel the complexity and messiness of human emotion into a performance. Why is that so hard to find in the movies today?
lead_paragraph: In the 20th century, method acting was everywhere. Actors went to extreme lengths to inhabit the complicated psyche of a character, sometimes making audiences deeply uncomfortable. Think Robert De Niro in “Raging Bull” or Marlon Brando in “Apocalypse Now.” But in 2022, in our heyday of superhero blockbusters and bingeable story lines, the Method seems to be fading away.

headline: Shelter in Chinatown Is Canceled After Community Protests
abstract: The shelter in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge would have housed 49 men and is one of three that New York City planned for the area.
lead_paragraph: New York City has canceled one of three homeless shelters it planned to open in Chinatown, amid fierce resistance from Chinatown residents who fear that more homeless shelters will mean a further increase in anti-Asian hate crimes, many of which have been linked to homeless people.

headline: The L.A. Riots Were 30 Years Ago. I’m Still Trying to Understand Them.
abstract: In 1992, Héctor Tobar was a young reporter at The Los Angeles Times when the city erupted in violence. What really happened — and what didn’t?
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1991, I was in the Los Angeles Times newsroom when word came that a local Black motorist named Rodney King had been nearly beaten to death by the police. Despite the fact that our staff had been writing about sensational cases of police brutality for years, the crisis set off by the videotape of King’s being assaulted seemed to catch us by surprise.

headline: Film Club: ‘Solo, Piano — N.Y.C.’
abstract: What can the fate of a single discarded piano tell us about the world?
lead_paragraph: “Solo, Piano — N.Y.C.” is a five-minute film that touches on themes of music, community and the items we choose to discard. This simple, but moving, Op-Doc video is told through a series of still photographs taken outside of the filmmaker’s window of a lone piano standing curbside in New York City and the interactions of passers-by as the piano awaits its fate.

headline: Congress Clears Bill to Allow Lending Arms to Ukraine
abstract: House passage of the measure, which invoked the World War II-era Lend-Lease Act, sent it to President Biden for his signature.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Thursday overwhelmingly passed legislation that would allow President Biden to use a World War II-era law to quickly supply weapons to Ukraine on loan, sending the measure to Mr. Biden’s desk hours after he urged Congress to approve tens of billions of dollars’ worth of additional emergency aid for Kyiv.

headline: Flooding on the Red River (Then and Now)
abstract: Near-record water levels on the river between North Dakota and Minnesota came just days after the 25th anniversary of a devastating flood.
lead_paragraph: Near-record water levels on the river between North Dakota and Minnesota came just days after the 25th anniversary of a devastating flood.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Stanley Tucci heads back to Italy, and a gorgeous half-hour drama returns with even more time loops.
lead_paragraph: ‘Make or Break’When to watch: Arrives Friday, on Apple TV+.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: China’s Stimulus Plan
abstract: Plus a U.S. push for Ukraine funds and extreme heat in India and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: As China’s lockdowns continue and new infections continue to spread in Beijing, the central government has laid out a wide-ranging economic stimulus plan to staunch expected losses.

headline: Amazon reports slowing sales growth and indicates slowdown may continue.
abstract: Amazon benefited from the coronavirus pandemic as people flocked to online shopping. Now, shoppers’ behavior has shifted.
lead_paragraph: In the face of a pandemic that appears to be receding and the highest levels of inflation in four decades, Amazon on Thursday posted its slowest quarterly growth in years and its first quarterly loss since 2015.

headline: Here’s the 2022 N.F.L. draft order.
abstract: The Jacksonville Jaguars again pick first overall and eight teams have multiple first-round selections.
lead_paragraph: 1. Jacksonville Jaguars

headline: City in Washington Reaches $7.5 Million Settlement in Fatal Police Shooting
abstract: A police officer shot and killed Andrea Thomas Churna, 39, in her apartment building in Redmond, Wash., after she called 911 for help in September 2020, her lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: The city of Redmond, Wash., has reached a $7.5 million settlement with the family of a woman who was fatally shot in her apartment building in September 2020 by a police officer who responded to her 911 call for help.

headline: Apple’s growth slows, but still beats Wall Street’s expectations.
abstract: While the company did better in its first three months of the year than many of its tech peers, it warned that Covid problems in China will be an issue.
lead_paragraph: After a year of blistering sales growth, Apple showed that it has a more resilient business than many of its tech peers, even though it cooled off in the first three months of the year.

headline: The Red Sox will return to the U.S. from Toronto by bus, not by plane, to avoid stranding anyone who tests positive.
abstract: Win or lose, when the Boston Red Sox leave the Rogers Centre after their game against the Blue Jays Thursday evening, they won’t be flying out of Toronto. Instead, they will take a two-hour bus ride to Buffalo and fly from there to Baltimore for their game on Friday against the Orioles.
lead_paragraph: Win or lose, when the Boston Red Sox leave the Rogers Centre after their game against the Blue Jays Thursday evening, they won’t be flying out of Toronto. Instead, they will take a two-hour bus ride to Buffalo and fly from there to Baltimore for their game on Friday against the Orioles.

headline: Patients Taking Experimental Obesity Drug Lost More Than 50 Pounds, Maker Claims
abstract: The data have not yet been peer reviewed or published. But experts said the drug may give people with obesity an alternative to bariatric surgery.
lead_paragraph: An experimental drug has enabled people with obesity or who are overweight to lose about 22.5 percent of their body weight, about 52 pounds on average, in a large trial, the drug’s maker announced on Thursday.

headline: Biden Seeks Military Aid for Ukraine
abstract: The $33 billion request suggests the White House expects a sustained conflict.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Oklahoma Legislature Passes 6-Week Abortion Ban Modeled on Texas Law
abstract: The bill, which says civilians can sue doctors who perform the procedure, would close a door to women who had come to the state for abortions because of restrictive bans elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Legislature approved a bill on Thursday prohibiting abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, a ban that could sharply reduce abortion access not only for women in the state but for those who have been crossing its borders to work around increasingly strict anti-abortion laws across the South.

headline: James Corden Says He’ll Leave His CBS Show Next Year
abstract: The British-born host, who was a successful actor and comedian before joining the network’s late-night lineup, has been signaling for some time that he was considering leaving.
lead_paragraph: James Corden, the British theater actor and comedian turned late-night TV host in the United States, said on Thursday that he would leave his 12:30 a.m. nightly show on CBS next year. Mr. Corden made the announcement during a taping of his talk show in Los Angeles.

headline: Earl E. Devaney, Scourge of Waste and Corruption, Dies at 74
abstract: A former football lineman, he pushed back against abuse in federal agencies as one of the government’s most aggressive internal watchdogs.
lead_paragraph: Earl E. Devaney, who began his career as a Secret Service agent guarding President Richard M. Nixon and rose to become one of the American government’s most aggressive and feared internal watchdogs, died on April 15 in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 74.

headline: José Luis Cortés, Trailblazing Cuban Bandleader, Dies at 70
abstract: He was trained in the classics and jazz, but he helped popularize a new, danceable genre known as timba.
lead_paragraph: José Luis Cortés, a Cuban musician who with his popular band, NG La Banda, helped establish the lively genre of music known as timba and spread the sound with well-regarded albums and rollicking shows that had concertgoers dancing in the arenas and afterward in the streets, died on April 18 in Havana. He was 70.

headline: Newly Published, From Whitney Houston to Bioluminescent Fish
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: NONCONFORMERS: A New History of Self-Taught Artists, by Lisa Slominski. (Yale University, $45.) For centuries, the label “self-taught” has been used as a “blunt definition for not having formal academic training,” the London curator writes. Featuring William Edmondson, Bill Traylor, Aloïse Corbaz and more, this book highlights marginalized artists.

headline: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
abstract: This month’s nonfiction picks include one about uncovering a treasure trove of silent films and one that aims to uncover the methods of Kenny G.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Vote on N.Y.C. School Funding Will ‘Blow Up’ System, Chancellor Says
abstract: The Panel for Educational Policy blocked the Adams administration’s funding formula, a move that may delay school budgets for the coming year.
lead_paragraph: The Panel for Educational Policy, the governing body of New York City public schools, blocked the city’s proposed formula for determining how much money each school should receive — a move that will cause the “whole system to blow up,” said the schools chancellor, David C. Banks.

headline: Mel Kiper Jr. and Kirk Herbstreit won’t be in Las Vegas.
abstract: The longtime ESPN analysts will not cover this year’s draft in person.
lead_paragraph: Two faces very familiar to N.F.L. draft viewers will not attend this year’s event.

headline: How N.Y. Democrats Lost a Critical Redistricting Battle
abstract: When an independent redistricting commission failed to reach consensus, Democratic leaders decided to make their own maps and risk a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: It was 2020, more than a year before New York began its once-in-a-decade redistricting process, when Carl Heastie, the Assembly speaker, foresaw a problem.

headline: Republicans Blame Homeland Security Secretary for Spike in Migration
abstract: Congressional hearings this week offered a preview of Republican attacks on the Biden administration’s immigration policies as the midterm elections approach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans on Capitol Hill offered a preview this week of how they plan to attack the Biden administration’s immigration policies as the midterm elections approach, trying to make the homeland security secretary, Alejandro N. Mayorkas, accept blame for a historic spike in migration across the southwest border.

headline: Fertility Doctor Accused of Using His Own Sperm Is Ordered to Pay Millions
abstract: The doctor, Paul B. Jones, 83, was believed to have fathered at least 17 children with 12 women using artificial insemination from 1975 to 1997, one of the children said.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Colorado awarded $8.75 million on Wednesday to the plaintiffs in a civil lawsuit who accused a former fertility doctor of using his own sperm to impregnate at least a dozen women via artificial insemination over more than two decades.

headline: How do players get the correct draft hats?
abstract: Players who show up at the N.F.L. draft for Round 1 get measured in advance so that they can wear a properly fitting cap when their name is called.

headline: For Trump, May Could Be the Cruelest Month
abstract: The upcoming Republican primaries are a critical test of the former president’s grip on the G.O.P. Here are the key races to watch.
lead_paragraph: If you doubt the power of Donald Trump’s endorsement, look no further than the Ohio Senate race.

headline: America, Again the Arsenal of Democracy
abstract: President Biden follows in F.D.R.’s footsteps.
lead_paragraph: When Russia invaded Ukraine, the idea that it might lose seemed far-fetched. Vladimir Putin appeared to have a powerful, modernized army, supported by a defense budget a dozen times larger than Ukraine’s. You didn’t have to buy into Ted Cruz-style fantasies about the prowess of a military that wasn’t “woke” and “emasculated” to expect a quick Russian battlefield victory.

headline: Seven Lessons Democrats Need to Learn — Fast
abstract: Retooling the party for an age of disorder.
lead_paragraph: We all make mistakes; the question is, do we learn from them? Over the past couple of years people on the left side of the political and cultural spectrum have made their share. These have contributed to the Democrats’ extremely bleak political prospects going into the midterms. Far worse, it is now quite plausible that Donald Trump could win re-election in 2024.

headline: The Liberty Are Reinventing Themselves
abstract: The team enters the 2022 W.N.B.A. season with a new coach and center, returning players who were hampered by injuries last year, and the desire to become full-fledged title contenders.
lead_paragraph: The Liberty are not sure what the full identity of their revamped team should be. But they are certain about one aspect of it.

headline: Biden Digs In on Ukraine Strategy, Seeking $33 Billion More in Aid
abstract: “The cost of this fight is not cheap,” President Biden said. He also sent Congress a plan to increase the government’s power to seize luxury yachts, aircraft and other assets of Russian oligarchs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden signaled a vast increase in America’s commitment to defeating Russia in Ukraine on Thursday as he asked Congress to authorize $33 billion for more artillery, antitank weapons and other hardware as well as economic and humanitarian aid.

headline: The 2023 draft will be held in Kansas City, Mo.
abstract: The N.F.L. is continuing its practice of making the draft a traveling road show, drawing hundreds of thousands of fans in the process.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, New York was the semi-permanent home of the N.F.L. draft. But since the league decided to turn its marquee off-season event into a traveling roadshow in 2015, it has been staged in six different host cities, including this year in Las Vegas. Next up, in 2023: Kansas City, Mo.

headline: The largest transit system in the Bay Area reinstates a mask mandate for riders.
abstract: The decision will be effective until July 18, and could be extended.
lead_paragraph: Masks will again be required on Bay Area Rapid Transit, making the largest transit system in the San Francisco area the only one currently enforcing a masking requirement.

headline: Text Neck, Pinkie Pain and Other Ways Phones Can Wreck Our Bodies
abstract: Health providers say they are seeing more patients than ever with pain and joint ailments in their hands, necks, shoulders and upper backs — and that mobile phones are most likely playing a part.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, my best friend texted me to confess that she was worried about her texting. Her hands and fingers ached throughout the day, and the pain worsened when she used her smartphone. Could our incessant texting about parenting and politics be the culprit?

headline: Airbnb tells employees they can work remotely forever.
abstract: The company, a proponent of more flexible workplace models, previously set a September 2022 date for a return to its offices.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb told its 6,000 employees on Thursday that they would have the option to permanently work remotely, joining a growing number of companies that have ditched return-to-office plans, including Zillow and PwC. Airbnb also told its U.S. employees that they could move to anywhere in the country without a reduction to their compensation.

headline: N.F.L. Draft Order and Picks: First Round Results
abstract: The Jacksonville Jaguars took Travon Walker, a defensive end from Georgia, at No. 1 overall. Here’s a full list of the results from the first round.
lead_paragraph: 1. Jacksonville JaguarsTravon Walker, DE, Georgia

headline: Jaguars Take Travon Walker With the No. 1 Draft Pick
abstract: Jacksonville took the defensive lineman after selecting quarterback Trevor Lawrence first overall in 2021.
lead_paragraph: The Jacksonville Jaguars selected Georgia edge rusher Travon Walker with the No. 1 overall pick, hoping the defensive stalwart can pair with quarterback Trevor Lawrence to steer the franchise back to relevance.

headline: Russian intelligence was behind an attack on the editor of Novaya Gazeta, a U.S. official says.
abstract: Dmitri Muratov was on a train preparing to leave Moscow at the time of the attack, which caused chemical burns to his eyes.
lead_paragraph: Russian intelligence was behind an April attack in Moscow that inflicted chemical burns on a Nobel Prize-winning Russian newspaper editor, American officials said Thursday.

headline: Millions of Bees Bound for Alaska Are Rerouted and Die in Atlanta
abstract: A shipment of five million honeybees was diverted to Atlanta and left out on a hot tarmac. Local beekeepers tried to come to the rescue, but very few survived.
lead_paragraph: When Sarah McElrea arrived at the Anchorage airport last Friday to pick up the 800 pounds of honeybees she was having shipped from Sacramento, she got the first sense of a disaster in the making: The bees — some five million of them — were in Atlanta, not Anchorage.

headline: Is Australian Democracy in Decline?
abstract: With a federal election just a few weeks away, it’s time to put Australia’s system and political flaws into context.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been thinking a lot about that question lately, after reporting on what’s needed to strengthen the liberal world order after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and as Australia’s campaign season has intensified.

headline: Premier of British Virgin Islands Arrested on Drug Trafficking Charges in U.S.
abstract: Andrew Fahie, the elected head of government of the small Caribbean territory, has been charged with conspiracy to import at least five kilograms of a cocaine mixture and conspiracy to launder money.
lead_paragraph: The premier of the British Virgin Islands was arrested on Thursday in the Miami area on drug trafficking and money laundering charges, the authorities said.

headline: Just You and Me, Baby
abstract: Erica Hsiung Wojcik makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Some people like to solve crossword puzzles first thing in the morning, and some people like to solve them before they go to bed. I am a midday solver, and I’ll tell you why.

headline: Variety: Spiral
abstract: Will Shortz finally circles back with a new Spiral puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SPIRAL — We haven’t seen this elegant type of puzzle in the Times in over a year, and I know that everyone has been eagerly awaiting the return of the Spiral. It is definitely one of my favorites in the rotation of sporadic challenges. The puzzle is beguilingly simple to explain: A spiraling string of 100 boxes is filled in by two sets of clues, one winding from the outer edge of a circle (box No. 1) to its center (100), the other starting in the center and working its way out. Every letter in the string appears in each set of clues.

headline: Titans Trade A.J. Brown to Eagles and Draft Treylon Burks of Arkansas
abstract: The trade involving Brown, a star receiver for Tennessee, was the surprise move of the first round.
lead_paragraph: The Titans selected Treylon Burks, a wide receiver from Arkansas, with the No. 18 overall pick, a move enabled by a blockbuster trade of the Pro Bowl receiver A.J. Brown to the Philadelphia Eagles. The Titans also received a third-round pick.

headline: A Text a Day Kept Other Suitors Away
abstract: Shortly after Kavya Naini and Eric Elofson met, he left for a two-month work trip. With regular text messages, Mr. Elofson kept their early spark alive.
lead_paragraph: By the time he planned his fourth proposal to Kavya Lakshmi Reddy Naini, Eric Richard Elofson was well aware of the power of persistence. Soon after they started dating in 2017, he had to take a two-month trip to Asia for work and sent her text messages almost every day while he was away.

headline: Winning With Bingo, and Then Bringing Her the Stars
abstract: Alexandra Wagner and Stephen Sullivan, who met while working at a math-tutoring center in Chicago, had their first date at the city’s Adler Planetarium.
lead_paragraph: After what seemed like light years, Stephen Daniel Sullivan grabbed Alexandra Lauran Ullman Wagner’s hand in March 2018 under the stars projected onto the dome of the Grainger Sky Theater at Chicago’s Adler Planetarium.

headline: At an Extra-Credit Assignment, Romance Was an Added Bonus
abstract: Andrew Eversden and Rachel Wertz hit it off when they met as students in Rome, beginning a love story that would unfold over several years and in various countries.
lead_paragraph: While Andrew D’Alton Eversden was studying abroad at the American University of Rome in the fall of 2017, one of his professors offered students extra credit for volunteering. He chose to do so at a meet-and-greet event with a local refugee center, which was how he found himself waiting outside an Italian government building in the city on a September afternoon.

headline: He Stood by Her Side, and Never Left
abstract: As they dated over the years, Marissa Valdez found out just how much Brian Shirley cared for her and her family when two of her sisters, then her mother, were diagnosed with cancer.
lead_paragraph: Marissa Alexandera Valdez was a 16-year-old junior at the Bosque School in Albuquerque when she received the news that her 6-year-old sister, Mia, had been diagnosed with leukemia in February 2013.

headline: Coupled by Chance, Then by Choice
abstract: Alexandra Walsh and Dr. Ben Nguyen forged a connection after being paired as a team of volunteer E.M.T.s. Years later, they started to date.
lead_paragraph: Long before Alexandra Christine Walsh, a physician assistant, and Dr. Ben Anthony Nguyen were joining other health care professionals on the front lines in the fight against the coronavirus, the two were a dynamic duo helping to save lives for the Branchville volunteer fire company in College Park, Md.

headline: From Russia With Mixed Feelings
abstract: I begged my husband to leave Rostov-on-Don. Now I would give anything to be back there with him.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen years ago, my husband and I lived for a time in Rostov-on-Don, Russia, which was then only a short drive across the border from Mariupol, Ukraine, the city currently being decimated by Russian forces.

headline: With ‘Only One to Choose From,’ a Great Choice
abstract: Before meeting at a party in 2011, Michael Taylor and Tim Vincent both thought they would be single for life.
lead_paragraph: Michael Taylor is the rare person who can say that much of what he’s learned about long-term relationships was on the job.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In El Salvador, Relief Over Gang Crackdowns Even as Civil Liberties Suffer
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “People say, ‘Well, if I am going from being in the authoritarian and homicidal hands of the gang to being in the authoritarian hands of the state, I’ll take it.’”

headline: Corrections: April 29, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about fears in Washington and European capitals that the conflict in Ukraine may soon escalate into a wider war misidentified Seth G. Jones’s position at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. He is the director of the International Security Program, not the European Security Program.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: President Biden’s push for more aid to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Biden called on Congress to approve $33 billion in more aid to Ukraine, arguing that U.S. arms and humanitarian assistance are helping beat back Russian invaders in a conflict with global consequences. “The cost of this fight is not cheap,” he said. “But caving to aggression is going to be more costly.” Follow the latest updates from the war.

lead_paragraph: The Jacksonville Jaguars kicked off the 2022 N.F.L. draft with a risky, counterintuitive selection that could mire the franchise at the bottom of the standings for years if it backfires.

headline: 8,000 British troops will join allied exercises in Europe, officials say.
abstract: The troops will serve in the British-led Joint Expeditionary Force, created in 2014 in response to Russia’s seizure of Crimea from Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The British military will send some 8,000 troops to Europe as part of a larger allied deployment to deter further Russian aggression, British officials said.

headline: Weighing Risk When the Reporting Is Dangerous
abstract: A security team watches out for Times journalists abroad. There are strategies in place, but sometimes there’s no other choice but to leave a country.
lead_paragraph: In early March, Anton Troianovski, The Times’s Moscow bureau chief, working closely with newsroom leadership, decided he should leave Russia.

headline: They Survived the Holocaust. Now, They Are Fleeing to Germany.
abstract: A complex operation is underway to evacuate Holocaust survivors from Ukraine. For rescuers and evacuees alike, it means confronting the past.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, Germany — Their earliest memories are of fleeing bombs or hearing whispers about massacres of other Jews, including their relatives. Sheltered by the Soviet Union, they survived.

headline: On Ireland’s Census, a Blank Box Gives Residents a Chance to Tell Their Stories
abstract: The makers of the survey included a space for people to write or draw a message. The contents of these so-called time capsules will be revealed in 100 years.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Can the dead talk to the living? In Ireland, the answer now is officially yes — at least through their census forms.

headline: Ukraine singles out Russian soldiers for atrocities in Bucha.
abstract: In the first detailed set of allegations since the invasion, Ukrainian officials published the names and photos of Russian soldiers they say tortured civilians in a suburb of Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: KYIV — The Ukrainian authorities have published the names and photos of 10 Russian soldiers whom they accuse of kidnapping and torturing unarmed civilians in the town of Bucha, the most detailed accusation yet against Russian forces in Ukraine.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Halfway Home’ and ‘The Code Breaker’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: HALFWAY HOME: Race, Punishment, and the Afterlife of Mass Incarceration, by Reuben Jonathan Miller. (Back Bay, 352 pp., $18.99.) To learn how former inmates navigate life after prison, Miller, an associate professor at the University of Chicago, interviewed nearly 250 people and combines case studies with memoir to offer a wide view on incarceration in America. “A combination of scholarly insight and firsthand pain lends force to this book,” our reviewer, Michael O’Donnell, commented.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 29, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this GIF.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: We’ve Opened the Door Too Wide for Oil and Gas Companies
abstract: Government support could be the deciding factor in whether a new generation of climate-damaging infrastructure gets built.
lead_paragraph: Policymakers in the United States seem stuck in a bind. To alleviate a potentially catastrophic energy crisis in Europe, more U.S. oil and gas will need to flow there to replace Russian fuel. To make that happen, companies and politicians on both sides of the aisle are clamoring to boost drilling and fast-track new infrastructure. Americans, meanwhile, want cheaper gas.

headline: Fighting for Her Dignity, and Her Children, at the Cost of Her Reputation
abstract: Antonia Fraser’s “The Case of the Married Woman” tells the story of Caroline Norton, who scandalized 19th-century London society — and upended its laws.
lead_paragraph: Many modern women may well remember a time when they could not open a bank account, or sign for a mortgage, without a countersignature from their husband or father. Antonia Fraser, in her 90th year, certainly will. What none of us, happily, can remember is the time when married women had no legal status at all. Once a woman married, her legal identity was subsumed into that of her husband. A married woman could not sign a contract, nor draw up a will. She had no debts — which sounds great, until you realize that she could not owe money, because all her money, even that she earned herself, belonged to her husband, as did all her possessions. As did her children.

headline: Olive Gray, an Actor Since the Age of 10, Stars in ‘Halo’
abstract: The nonbinary actor grew up around a lot of famous people, including the Spice Girls, who would hang out in the living room.
lead_paragraph: Name: Olive Gray

headline: What Do You Think Are the Secrets to a Long Life?
abstract: What, if anything, is the secret to extending life? Does our society do enough for its oldest citizens?
lead_paragraph: Do you believe there is a “secret” to extending life? Or is life expectancy more random, determined largely by luck, fate or a “plan” ordained by a higher power?

headline: Lesson of the Day: ‘Inside a Home for L.G.B.T.Q. Seniors: “I Made Friends Here.”’
