headline: Hidden in a Fire Island House, the Soundtrack of Love and Loss
abstract: In tragedy, music provided solace during the AIDS epidemic, and newly discovered cassette tapes captured two decades of parties and pain.
lead_paragraph: In tragedy, music provided solace during the AIDS epidemic, and newly discovered cassette tapes captured two decades of parties and pain.

headline: Twitter, Your Bae Is Not OK
abstract: Perhaps — much as we might not want to admit it — it’s a good match.
lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk married his first wife in 2000, he reportedly decided that the dance floor was the opportune place to inform her, “I am the alpha in this relationship.”

headline: Likelihood of Trump Indictment in Manhattan Fades as Grand Jury Wraps Up
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney is continuing to investigate Donald J. Trump, but knowledgeable people say charges are unlikely to occur in the foreseeable future, if ever.
lead_paragraph: When some two dozen New Yorkers filed into a Manhattan courthouse this week to finish out their grand jury service, the case against a man who would have been the world’s most prominent criminal defendant was no longer before them.

headline: Elon Musk Might Break Twitter. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
abstract: The Twitter bid is a power play in the attention economy.
lead_paragraph: If Elon Musk’s bid to purchase Twitter comes to fruition, the world’s richest person will own one of its most important communications platforms. Twitter might have a smaller user base than Facebook, Instagram and even Snapchat, but it shapes the dominant narratives in key industries like politics, media, finance and technology more than any other platform. Attention — particularly that of elite leaders in these industries — is a valuable resource, one that Twitter manages and trades in.

headline: Millions of South Koreans Could Soon Get Younger (on Paper)
abstract: South Korea has three ways of calculating age, often adding a year or two to the international standard. The incoming president wants to change that.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — When Lee Jae-hye goes to the United States, she’s 30. When she’s back in South Korea, she’s 32.

headline: Jamie Hector Wants That Black Belt
abstract: The actor stars in “We Own This City,” a crime drama from the creators of “The Wire.”
lead_paragraph: The actor Jamie Hector grew up in South Brooklyn, watching karate movies on Saturday mornings. He began studying martial arts as a teenager. “I wanted to throw a ninja star,” he said. “I wanted to fight like Bruce Lee.”

headline: Antisemitism Increased Under Trump. Then It Got Even Worse.
abstract: The worldwide growth of a social crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Anti-Defamation League this week released a report showing that in 2021, there were more antisemitic incidents in America than in any other year since the group started keeping track over 40 years ago. “We’ve never seen data like this before, ever,” Jonathan Greenblatt, national director of the A.D.L., told me.

headline: 10 Years After Sandy, Fire Island’s Fragile Beaches Are Holding Up
abstract: A $170 million effort by the federal government helped the island recover in the aftermath of the 2012 hurricane, but residents recognize that another storm could wash all the progress away.
lead_paragraph: After Hurricane Sandy ravaged the Eastern Seaboard in 2012, Jared Della Valle took action. The storm had destroyed one of his homes on Fire Island, a narrow strip of land off Long Island, and damaged another. So he decided it was time to move.

headline: A New York Bagel From an Unexpected Borough: Connecticut
abstract: Popupbagels drives its suburban versions into a city with very fixed ideas of what makes a bagel. It’s a daring move, but it’s paying off.
lead_paragraph: A long line for bagels in New York City isn’t a remarkable sight. It is, though, when the bagels come from Connecticut.

headline: Models Have Been Exploited Forever. Can a Law Change Anything?
abstract: The Fashion Workers Act, a bill working its way through the New York Legislature, takes on a largely unregulated industry.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, the fashion world will gather for the Met Gala, the annual ritual of celebrity opulence that our current social revolution has not yet harpooned. The theme this year is the evolution of American style, an exploration not only of the work of historically significant designers like Charles James and Halston but also of the dressmakers and tailors who toiled in obscurity on their behalf. The egalitarian dabbling would seem to begin and end there, however, given that the party’s dress code this year is “gilded glamour.” Guests, according to Vogue, whose editor Anna Wintour famously presides over the event, have been asked to “embody the grandeur — and perhaps the dichotomy — of Gilded Age New York.”

headline: Solar Industry ‘Frozen’ as Biden Administration Investigates China
abstract: More than 300 solar projects in the United States have been canceled or delayed in recent weeks because of an investigation by the Commerce Department.
lead_paragraph: Plans to install 60 square kilometers of solar panels in Vermont are suddenly on hold.

headline: What Did the 2020 Census Teach Us? We Might Not Know Until 2023.
abstract: The most contentious census in memory will also be the slowest to release detailed statistics for businesses and governments to use. Blame it (partly) on the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two and a half years after the 2020 census stopped counting heads, the Census Bureau has yet to say how many children under age 5 live in Albuquerque, or how many women are in Sioux City. And it will remain that way for another year.

headline: A Monkish Conductor Who Expressed His Faith Through Music
abstract: A new 69-disc box of Dimitri Mitropoulos’s recordings are an opportunity to reassess a conductor who remains out of reach.
lead_paragraph: When Dimitri Mitropoulos was putting together the programs that he would conduct in 1947 as a guest of the New York Philharmonic — the ensemble he later led in a fraught tenure from 1949 to 1958 — he likely could not have predicted which item on his typically eclectic lists would be the most controversial.

headline: Working 9 to 2, and Again After Dinner
abstract: The pandemic upended the rigid 9-to-5 workday. Enter the age of the “triple peak” day.
lead_paragraph: How would Dolly Parton capture the daily grind in 2022?

headline: Family Court Lawyers Flee Low-Paying Jobs. Parents and Children Suffer.
abstract: New York hasn’t raised the attorneys’ fees since 2004, creating a shortage that has denied the most vulnerable their constitutional right to a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: For the past two years, Amanda Sanchez’s right to see her young son has depended on the crowded calendar of Helen Bua, the lawyer appointed to represent her in New York’s family court.

headline: A Black Man Ran to Gay Enclaves to Feel Safe. But Was He Welcome?
abstract: Zach Stafford, the former editor in chief of The Advocate, traveled to gay safe havens as he has for so many summers, but the summer of 2020 was different.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the pandemic made landfall in New York City in the spring of 2020 — and right as the city streets became ghostly reminders of what was — I began to run every morning.

headline: Musk’s Ties to China Could Create Headaches for Twitter
abstract: Elon Musk has invested heavily in China, where officials are willing to influence or punish companies that cross political red lines.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Elon Musk opened a Tesla factory in Shanghai in 2019, the Chinese government welcomed him with billions of dollars’ worth of cheap land, loans, tax breaks and subsidies. “I really think China is the future,” Mr. Musk cheered.

headline: On the Trail of Russian War Crimes
abstract: Lyudmyla Denisova, Ukraine’s top human rights official, is determined to right historical wrongs and make sure Russians are held to account.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — When Lyudmyla Denisova became Ukraine’s human rights commissioner four years ago, a job that she thought would round out a career in public service, it rekindled a youthful ambition. “I really wanted to become a prosecutor,” she said.

headline: When the Textile Industry Was Forced Out of the Textile Building
abstract: Companies may have lost their showroom hub, but low rents in Midtown, caused by the pandemic, allowed many of them to relocate.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, Arthur Tauber hauled 26 buckets of sand into his showroom at the Textile Building to promote a new collection of beach towels. Another time, his company set up a big, clattering factory-style sewing machine in the lobby, so visitors could watch it embroider multiple towels simultaneously.

headline: The Office Beckons. Time for Your Sharpest ‘Power Casual.’
abstract: Work wear reflects how people feel about their jobs and the economy as a whole. So it makes sense that dressing for the office is all over the place.
lead_paragraph: Instagram ads for one brand are touting a style known as “power casual.” Other retailers are calling it “business comfort” or “workleisure.” Heels are dropping lower or disappearing altogether, pants are getting “elasticized,” and Silicon Valley executives are throwing graphic T-shirts under blazers to smuggle a version of self-expression into a board meeting.

headline: A Georgia City Reckons With a New District, Led by Marjorie Taylor Greene
abstract: Powder Springs is one of two predominantly Black suburbs drawn into the far-right Republican’s district. If Ms. Greene is their voice in Congress, will she speak for them?
lead_paragraph: POWDER SPRINGS, Ga. — Less than a 30-minute drive from Atlanta, Powder Springs embodies the changes reshaping Georgia politics. Shops and restaurants owned almost entirely by Black proprietors line its downtown center and are frequented by a growing population of young and racially diverse residents. The suburban city elected its first Black mayor in 2015, and the county where it sits, the former Republican stronghold of Cobb, voted for President Biden by 14 percentage points in 2020.

headline: Saving the History of the Pines on Fire Island
abstract: Bobby Bonanno created the Fire Island Pines Historical Preservation Society, collecting photographs and documents and conducting interviews.
lead_paragraph: Erosion is a theme of the Pines, with its wind-tortured dunes and combustible wood buildings. But Bobby Bonanno, 65, who works as a hairdresser in Bellport, N.Y., and has visited the Pines for more than four decades, was concerned about the erosion of memory. To protect the heritage of the Pines, the affluent, largely L.G.B.T.Q. hamlet near the center of Fire Island, he decided to create the Fire Island Pines Historical Preservation Society.

headline: Help! I Spent a Fortune for a Credit-Card Companion Pass But the Virus Wouldn’t Quit
abstract: Are travelers missing out by not playing the credit-card game in search of first-class tickets? Our new Tripped Up columnist considers the fees and the benefits of two cards.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, my wife and I received a “Travel Together Ticket” from British Airways through a credit card offer and used it — along with 255,000 miles and $2,378 in taxes and fees — to book a flight from Washington to Hong Kong via London. The real value was in two first-class seats on the leg from London to Hong Kong. But the pandemic refused to quit and we exchanged our tickets for travel vouchers good through September 2023.

headline: An Education Panel Gets Feisty With the Mayor
abstract: The Panel for Education Policy balked at passing the Department of Education’s school funding formula for next year.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at an education panel that blocked New York City’s plan for allocating $10.5 billion in school funding. We’ll also look at the prospects for a raise for a small but important group of lawyers who haven’t had one since 2004.

headline: Growth Slows to a Crawl as War and Covid Grip the Biggest Economies
abstract: Europe’s growth in the first three months of the year was languid as the United States and China struggled to maintain momentum.
lead_paragraph: Rising prices, fallout from the war in Ukraine and continuing supply chain chokeholds slowed growth around the world in the first months of the year and hobbled efforts by major economies to recover from the pandemic.

headline: The Risks of a New U.S. Approach in Ukraine
abstract: Washington had taken pains to avoid the appearance that it was entering a direct confrontation with Moscow. That may be changing.
lead_paragraph: As the horrors of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine have became clearer, the Biden administration has pivoted to a more aggressive stance, with officials talking about constraining Moscow as a global power.

headline: Vaccines for Young Children
abstract: The federal government is telling us two different stories.
lead_paragraph: Why hasn’t the F.D.A. approved a Covid-19 vaccine for children under 5? Government officials have given two conflicting answers in recent days — one that places responsibility on vaccine manufacturers, another that casts the lack of approval as a deliberate federal policy.

headline: An ‘Angel’ for Homeless Students and the Revolt of the College-Educated Working Class: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: ‘The Northman’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Robert Eggers narrates a sequence from “The Northman,” starring Alexander Skarsgard.
lead_paragraph: The director Robert Eggers narrates a sequence from “The Northman,” starring Alexander Skarsgard.

headline: Watch Alexander Skarsgard Battle the Undead in ‘The Northman’
abstract: The director Robert Eggers narrates a scene that pits the star against a most unfriendly zombie.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Anglo-Saxon Kings Made Sure to Eat Their Vegetables, Study Shows
abstract: Contrary to popular belief, the ruling classes gorged on meat only on rare occasions, according to an analysis of more than 2,000 skeletons buried during medieval times.
lead_paragraph: Anglo-Saxon kings have long reigned in the popular imagination as rapacious meat lovers, eagerly feasting on thick slabs of mutton and beef, washed down with copious amounts of mead and ale.

headline: Under Lockdown in China
60 Seconds with Erica Hsiung Wojcik
abstract: A chat with one of the New York Times Crossword constructors.
lead_paragraph: For me, a working mother with two young children, crossword puzzles are my way to relax and unwind after a long day.

headline: Is the U.S. Economy Headed for a Slowdown?
abstract: A shrinking G.D.P., Amazon’s slowing revenue and supply chain woes all point to the economic engine shifting down a gear.
lead_paragraph: Those looking for signs that the U.S. economy is slowing had plenty to gawk at yesterday. G.D.P. shrank in the first quarter, for the first time since the early days of the coronavirus pandemic. Amazon said its revenue rose at the slowest pace since the dot-com bust. Apple said its supply chain woes were only getting worse. The S&P 500 index is on track to post its third monthly decline in four months.

headline: In Echo of Soviet Era, Russia’s Movie Theaters Turn to Pirate Screenings
abstract: In a Cold War throwback, some venues are showing bootleg versions after Hollywood studios pulled films from the country. Still, viewer numbers have tanked.
lead_paragraph: Since the invasion of Ukraine, Hollywood’s biggest studios have stopped releasing movies in Russia, and Netflix has ceased service there. But recently, some of the companies’ films have started appearing in Russian movie theaters — illegally.

headline: The N.F.L. Draft Fashion Scorecard
abstract: It may be the last bastion of raw red carpet self-expression.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible the last red carpet that is genuinely a place of self-expression rather than big brand fashion marketing belongs to the N.F.L. draft?

headline: A Different Kind of California Playlist
abstract: We’re debuting a new soundtrack dedicated to ambivalence, if not outright disdain, for the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: We Californians tend to get a little starry-eyed when talking about our home state, hung up on the rewards of living in a coastal paradise instead of the rougher reality.

headline: Fast Price and Wage Growth Keeps Fed on Track for Big Interest Rate Increase
abstract: The Personal Consumption Expenditures price index climbed 6.6 percent from a year earlier, the quickest pace of increase since 1982.
lead_paragraph: The price index that the Federal Reserve watches most closely climbed 6.6 percent in the year through March, the fastest pace of inflation since 1982 and the latest reminder of the painfully rapid price increases plaguing consumers and challenging policymakers.

headline: Elon Musk sells billions in Tesla stock as he prepares to buy Twitter.
abstract: He raised $8.5 billion in a series of sales this week and said he didn’t have plans to sell any more.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is amassing the funds he needs to buy Twitter, selling $8.5 billion in Tesla stock this week, according to filings released on Thursday and Friday.

headline: In ‘I Love That for You,’ Vanessa Bayer Sells Out
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” veteran’s new sitcom draws on her experience of childhood cancer and her obsession with home shopping TV.
lead_paragraph: According to Vanessa Bayer, being diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia as a 15-year-old wasn’t all bad.

headline: In Ukraine War, a Long Journey Begins in Prosecuting Rape
abstract: U.N. officials and human rights investigators are rushing more resources to authorities in Ukraine to help prosecute sex crimes.
lead_paragraph: The rape happened in the hours after midnight on March 14, in a classroom of a school outside Kharkiv, in eastern Ukraine. Two days later, Yulia Gorbunova interviewed the victim and helped persuade her to report the attack, which could ultimately be prosecuted as a war crime committed by invading Russian forces.

headline: Exxon Mobil and Chevron report big jump in profits because of higher oil and gas prices.
abstract: Despite pleas from the Biden administration for more supply, both companies said their global production fell in the first three months of the year.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the largest U.S. oil companies, on Friday reported a second consecutive quarter of robust earnings as oil and natural gas prices continued to rise after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Ziwe and Her Comedy Pals Party in Pink
abstract: The comedian celebrated Season 2 of Showtime’s “Ziwe.”
lead_paragraph: Subtlety is not Ziwe’s strong suit. The comedian, talk show host and writer, whose full name is Ziwerekoru Fumudoh, is known for asking very unsubtle, squirm-inducing questions of her guests, first on “Baited with Ziwe,” her YouTube talk series, and now on Showtime’s “Ziwe,” a variety and talk show that celebrated its second season with a party on Monday.

headline: Billionaire’s Late Bid Upends Sale of Chelsea F.C.
abstract: The offer by Jim Ratcliffe, worth $5.3 billion, would be the highest price ever paid for a sports team. But his chances of success are unclear.
lead_paragraph: The sale of the Premier League soccer team Chelsea, triggered when the British government sanctioned its Russian owner for his ties to the Kremlin, had already been the most peculiar team sale in recent sports history. On Friday, it suddenly became the most confusing, after one of Britain’s richest men entered the fray with a bold bid that upended a process that had appeared to be nearing its end.

headline: The ‘Ultimate Bird’ Once Prowled the Seas of a Young Japan
abstract: Researchers described Annakacygna, a family of flightless ancient swans that were filter-feeders.
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual today to find swans on rivers and lakes, splitting their time between pulling up water plants and punishing the unwise with powerful blows of their bony-elbowed wings.

headline: Why Ramadan Generates Millions in Charitable Giving Every Year
abstract: During the Muslim holy month, there is a strong focus on helping others.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Harby fasts from sunrise to sunset during the holy month of Ramadan. Then, after he breaks his fast, he heads from Brooklyn to Midtown Manhattan every day for a late night appointment with hundreds of homeless New Yorkers who rely on him and other Muslim volunteers for a hot meal.

headline: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Recap: A Chateau of Convenience
abstract: In the penultimate episode of this season, anything the crew needs from the plot to move forward, it gets.
lead_paragraph: The most interesting revelation in this week’s “Picard” comes in a throwaway line from Seven, in which she tells Raffi that she tried to join Starfleet after Voyager returned from the Delta Quadrant. That Captain Janeway — or possibly Admiral, depending on the timing of her promotion that we saw in “Star Trek: Nemesis” — went to bat for her. Starfleet said no, because of her Borg background.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How scientists are redefining the second. Also in this edition: a writer hikes to a Canadian wilderness resort and Sheryl Crow tells her life story.
lead_paragraph: How scientists are redefining the second. Also in this edition: a writer hikes to a Canadian wilderness resort and Sheryl Crow tells her life story.

headline: Prayer on a School Football Field: Awaiting a Supreme Court Ruling
abstract: Readers discuss whether a high school coach had the right to kneel and pray after games. Also: Genocide in Ukraine; Amazon’s response; Republican lies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Beijing closes its schools as it tries to contain a coronavirus outbreak.
abstract: The city is heading into a long holiday weekend, and officials are discouraging travel and unnecessary gatherings.
lead_paragraph: Schools in Beijing, where a coronavirus outbreak has alarmed Chinese leaders, were closed on Friday and dozens of buildings remained under lockdown, as a five-day holiday weekend approached.

headline: Boris Becker Sentenced to Two and a Half Years for Hiding Assets in Bankruptcy
abstract: The former tennis champion was found guilty by a London court on charges related to his 2017 insolvency.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Becker, the six-time Grand Slam tennis champion, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday in his bankruptcy case, after he was found guilty by a London court of hiding millions of dollars’ worth of assets and loans to avoid paying his debts.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Tuck into comforting cheese enchiladas or keep things light with a crunchy spring iceberg salad.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Bryan Washington is in The New York Times Magazine this weekend with what I think should be the recipe of the week, the dish everyone who reads his words will want to cook just as soon as they’re through his powerful essay: cheese enchiladas (above).

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include demented cultists, zombies with pause buttons, hellish stays at a hotel, an unsettling home share and a killer named Oopsie.
lead_paragraph: I’m not a huge zombie fan, but this taut Spanish-language film from the Uruguayan director Gustavo Hernández is an assured and surprisingly artful take on undead mayhem.

headline: Will We Give the Subway a Second Chance?
abstract: What we lose when public spaces no longer feel safe.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday and Saturday morning.

headline: The Decline of Ohio and the Rise of J.D. Vance
abstract: Once a severe Trump critic, he has aligned himself with the views of many conservative Ohio voters.
lead_paragraph: “We are going to break up the big tech companies, ladies and gentlemen. We have to do it,” J.D. Vance hollered at a rally for Donald Trump in Ohio last weekend. “You cannot have a real country if a bunch of corrupt scumbags who take their marching orders from the Communist Chinese tell us what we’re allowed to say and how we’re allowed to say it.”

headline: Jacques Perrin, Soft-Spoken Film Star and Producer, Is Dead at 80
abstract: A French actor, he was a heartthrob in the musical “The Young Girls of Rochefort,” a photojournalist in the thriller “Z” and a jaded director in the hit “Cinema Paradiso.”
lead_paragraph: Jacques Perrin, a comely and soft-spoken veteran French actor — he didn’t smolder so much as twinkle — who went from starring in musical and dramatic films to directing and producing them, most notably the political thrillers of Costa-Gavras and his own poetic documentaries about the natural world, died on April 21 in Paris. He was 80.

headline: Sam Smith’s Ode to Self-Acceptance, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Regina Spektor, Tokischa, Wilco and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Johnny Depp Case Brings Stan Culture Into the Courtroom
abstract: The defamation trial between Mr. Depp and Amber Heard is a case study in what happens when complex claims are filtered through the lenses of extreme fandom and social media.
lead_paragraph: A frenzied scene materializes four days a week at the Fairfax County Courthouse in Virginia as fans seek seats at the defamation trial between Johnny Depp and his ex-wife Amber Heard.

headline: A Body Bag and a Sister in Denial
abstract: The war in Ukraine is so big that it has shaken the world. But for a sister looking for her missing older brother, it was reduced to a visit to a morgue.
lead_paragraph: ZMIIV, Ukraine — The wind carried the smell of death across the street. The body of the dead man, burned, mutilated and barely recognizable, was taken from the refrigerator and laid on a metal gurney. The coroner smoked a cigarette and unzipped the black bag.

headline: Why Republican Insurgents Are Struggling to Topple G.O.P. Governors
abstract: Republicans in several states are trying to oust conservative governors by harnessing anti-establishment energy. But in battles for a state’s top job, it’s hard to beat the establishment.
lead_paragraph: Jim Renacci, an acolyte of Donald J. Trump who is trying to capitalize on outsider energy to oust the Republican governor of Ohio, has found himself outspent, way down in the polls and lamenting his lack of an endorsement from the former president.

headline: During Ramadan, Palestinians Barred From Aqsa Turn to Smugglers
abstract: For Palestinian Muslims, praying at the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem is an important part of Ramadan. Those barred by Israel are finding ways to get there anyway.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Only moonlight cut through the darkness early one recent morning by the time a smuggler led Husam Misk to a ladder propped against Israel’s concrete separation barrier.

headline: Wall Street Is Battered by Rising Fear About the Economy
abstract: The S&P 500 plunged nearly 9 percent in April, its worst monthly decline since March 2020, as rising interest rates and high inflation raised concerns about consumer sentiment.
lead_paragraph: April wound up being the worst month for Wall Street since the March 2020 panic over the coronavirus, capped by a plunge in stocks on Friday.

headline: Mayor Eric Adams Is Stuck on Ideas From 1994 for Crime in 2022
abstract: Tired “tough on crime” rhetoric is not the solution to crime in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City understands the assignment: to keep the nation’s largest city safe amid an alarming rise in violent crime. At least 40 of the people shot so far this year in New York were children and teenagers, or one in every 10 shooting victims. One of those children, Kade Lewin, 12, was shot and killed while sitting with relatives in a parked car in Brooklyn.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: The late-night hosts spent much of the week talking about Elon Musk, and James Corden announced he would depart his show next year.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts spent much of the week talking about Elon Musk, and James Corden announced he would depart his show next year.

headline: City Living, With Less Water
abstract: Los Angeles and Santiago are two of the latest cities to impose strict water restrictions in an effort to avoid disastrous shortages in the future.
lead_paragraph: São Paulo. Cape Town. Now Santiago and Los Angeles.

headline: ‘The Red Studio,’ Matisse’s Masterpiece, Gets a Life All Its Own
abstract: The objects in the painting are brought together in a spectacular show at the Museum of Modern Art. It’s a marvel of detective work by the curators.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s latest excursion into modernist art history by way of its astounding collection is “Matisse: The Red Studio,” a small but spectacular exhibition that dissects one of the artist’s greatest early paintings.

headline: Amid Hardening Western Resolve, Signs of Russia’s Stalling in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Pentagon officials say the Russian drive in Donbas is being hampered by poor logistics and stiff Ukrainian resistance.
lead_paragraph: Western support of Ukraine hardened Friday as the European Union was poised to approve an embargo on Russian oil, amid fresh assessments that the Russian military’s eastern offensive was faltering, hampered by logistical issues and stiff Ukrainian resistance.

headline: Superclubs and Spring Nights
abstract: The Champions League’s late-stage drama is a feature, not a bug. Let’s hope no one messes that up.
lead_paragraph: The nights happen so often now that the possibility they are a coincidence can be safely discounted. They occur with such startling regularity that they do not really count as rare, not anymore. They still possess the texture and the echo of an exception, but by this stage they are better thought of as part of the rule. They are a feature, not a quirk in the code.

headline: Finding the Sweet Spot at Yankee Stadium
abstract: Anthony Rizzo has the early home run lead in the majors. Here’s how he’s benefiting from Yankee Stadium’s design.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Rizzo has the early home run lead in the majors. Here’s how he’s benefiting from Yankee Stadium’s design.

headline: Wonking Out: Education Has Less to Do With Inequality Than You Think
abstract: College debtors aren’t a privileged class.
lead_paragraph: President Biden says that he is taking a “hard look” at student debt relief, which probably means that some significant relief is coming. For one thing, Biden promised relief during the 2020 campaign. For another, it’s one progressive priority he can address by executive action, which is important given the extreme difficulty of getting anything through an evenly divided Senate.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Felix Salmon
abstract: A conversation with the journalist.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Felix Salmon. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Leader of E.U. Border Agency Departs After Accusations of Abuses During His Tenure
abstract: The head of the agency, which became emblematic of the bloc’s hardening migration policy, has faced mounting allegations of mismanagement, harassment and human rights abuses at Europe’s borders.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When Fabrice Leggeri, a French civil servant, took over the European border agency known as Frontex in 2015, its operations were based out of a small office in Warsaw that mostly did administrative work.

headline: This Crispy Fish Is Irresistible
abstract: Kay Chun’s fish Milanese is topped with a lemony caper sauce, and makes for excellent sandwiches the next day.
lead_paragraph: There are some types of dishes you find the world over. They have different names on their passports and come in diverging styles, but they share delicious fundamentals. The breaded cutlet — known aliases include katsu, schnitzel and Milanesa — is one of them, and a favorite of mine. So I was in heaven when I had chicken Milanese last week at a restaurant, the first one I’ve had in a while, the cutlet golden and crisp, a wild heap of arugula salad on top and a jaunty lemon wedge on the side. It’s a full meal, and a perfect one at that.

headline: The Giants’ and Jets’ Early Draft Gets an Unusual Reception: Praise
abstract: The Jets scooped Ahmad Gardner, Garrett Wilson and Jermaine Johnson II, three of their eight top targets in the N.F.L. draft, while the Giants bolstered both lines with Kayvon Thibodeaux and Evan Neal.
lead_paragraph: There’s a classic YouTube video titled “NY Jets Draft Blunders” that has amassed nearly two million views. It shows an ESPN-produced montage of Jets fans reacting in despair to the team’s draft selections in the ’80s and ’90s, like when the team famously chose quarterback Ken O’Brien over the future Hall of Famer Dan Marino in 1983. In some cases the cascade of jeers begins at the mere mention of the position being drafted — a first-round fullback? — even before the player’s name is revealed.

headline: Started Out as a Fish. How Did It End Up Like This?
abstract: A meme about the transitional fossil Tiktaalik argues that although we did come out of the sea, we aren’t doing just fine.
lead_paragraph: It may not be the worst of times, but it is certainly not the best of times. The pandemic has no end in sight. The world is warming, the seas are rising and polar bears are barreling toward extinction. Also: taxes, the 9-to-5 workweek, the renewed threat of nuclear war.

headline: Christie’s to Sell a Dinosaur That Inspired the ‘Jurassic Park’ Raptor
abstract: The auction house says this is the first-ever sale of a Deinonychus, the species on which the ‘velociraptor’ in the 1993 movie was based.
lead_paragraph: Many people know them as agile bipedal dinosaurs with menacing claws and scrunched-up arms, hunting children through a kitchen in “Jurassic Park.”

headline: The Prosecutor Who Put John Gotti Away Explains How He Did It
abstract: John Gleeson’s “The Gotti Wars” is a memoir about what it took to jail America’s star gangster.
lead_paragraph: Overshadowed by Will Smith’s infamous slap at this year’s Oscars ceremony was a tribute to “The Godfather” on its 50th anniversary. The Corleone saga is embedded in the American psyche as a long slog for respect by immigrants and their offspring who regard themselves as uomini d’onore — men of honor. That self-image is, of course, nonsense in real life. John Gleeson, a federal prosecutor later turned federal judge, makes that amply clear in this dissection of how he took on the country’s star gangster of the not-distant past, John Gotti, and packed him off to prison for good.

headline: Why Netflix Is the Worst Performing Stock in the S&P 500
abstract: Shares in Apple, Amazon, Google, Facebook and Microsoft have all fallen this year, but Netflix has come in for the harshest punishment.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has been an amazing innovator and an extravagant spender. And if you forget that it borrowed billions to finance two decades of exponential growth, the company would be a resounding success.

headline: National Security Surveillance on U.S. Soil Dropped Again in 2021, Report Says
abstract: The F.B.I. also tried to estimate the number of its searches for U.S. data in messages gathered without a warrant. But the estimate — fewer than 3.4 million — was murky.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Court-approved national security surveillance on domestic soil fell for the third straight year in 2021, extending a trend that has coincided with the decline of the Islamic State, the rise of the coronavirus pandemic and the tightening of procedures after the F.B.I.’s botching of wiretap applications in the Trump-Russia investigation.

headline: Ukrainian Journalist Is Killed in Russian Missile Strike
abstract: The body of Vira Hyrych, a prominent Ukrainian radio journalist, was recovered after a Russian missile strike on her apartment building in Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: The body of Vira Hyrych, a prominent Ukrainian radio journalist, was recovered after a Russian missile strike on her apartment building in Kyiv.

headline: When a Restaurant Is a Work of Art
abstract: Carsten Höller’s latest work is a dining establishment, a social experiment — and a celebrity magnet.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — “Can somebody dim the Dan Flavin?” It’s not a request one generally hears at a restaurant, but on the inaugural preview night at Brutalisten, the artist Carsten Höller was pulling cords from their sockets at random, still working out a few kinks at his restaurant, including toning down the glaring fluorescent tubes of the Minimalist masterpiece on the dining room’s wall.

headline: ‘Ridley Road’ Review: Undercover With the Neo-Nazis
abstract: An intrepid young Jewish woman gets cozy with the enemy in a PBS drama that explores a little-known corner of British history.
lead_paragraph: It might seem as if there couldn’t be any nook or cranny of British history that hasn’t received its own television costume drama by now. But “Ridley Road,” premiering Sunday on PBS’s “Masterpiece,” finds some new and interesting territory.

headline: Review: Thomas Adès Charts a Journey Through Hell and Heaven
abstract: At the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the composer’s “Dante” is an extreme rarity in orchestral music: a new evening-length work.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Step into Walt Disney Concert Hall here this weekend, and you’ll find one of the rarest creatures in classical music: a new evening-length work.

headline: Review: Sasha Waltz’s Action Painting Swirls to ‘In C’
abstract: Waltz’s dance to Terry Riley’s seminal score, at the Brooklyn Academy, is loose and cheerful, giving a spatial sense of the suspension of time.
lead_paragraph: The directions for Terry Riley’s seminal 1964 composition “In C” are fairly simple. The single-page score consists of 53 short musical motifs, which the musicians play in order. But since each musician chooses how many times to repeat each figure before progressing to the next, there’s a continual shifting of alignment and displacement. That, combined with the unceasing, metronomic ticking of a C note, creates a tension between staying in place and moving on. It’s the sound of collective decision-making, the harmonious kind, more buzzing beehive than rowdy town-hall meeting.

headline: Drug Sentencing Bill Is in Limbo as Midterm Politics Paralyze Congress
abstract: A broadly supported bipartisan measure to eliminate a racial disparity in drug sentencing faces a difficult road as Republicans seek to weaponize the issue of crime against Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Equal Act would appear to be a slam dunk even in a badly divided Congress.

headline: Instacart Searches for a Direction as Its Pandemic Boom Fades
abstract: The grocery delivery start-up changed its leadership, slashed its valuation and shifted its strategy after sales slowed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last summer, Instacart had a rough reality check. After a year of explosive, pandemic-driven growth for its grocery delivery business, people were returning to grocery stores. Sales slowed. New customers were harder to find. It could have been the kiss of death for a start-up that expected to grow very fast.

headline: ‘Extremely Critical Fire Weather’ Threatens the Southwest
abstract: Parts of the region — including large swaths of New Mexico — have been seared by drought and raked by high winds, fueling existing wildfires and creating ideal conditions for new ones.
lead_paragraph: A large swath of the United States faced twin weather threats on Friday as a severe drought turned parts of the Southwest into a tinderbox, ripe for more wildfires, and powerful storms threatened to produce tornadoes and hail across the Central Plains.

headline: How to Clean Wood Cutting Boards
abstract: Wood cutting boards require more babying than plastic ones.
lead_paragraph: Wood cutting boards require more babying than plastic ones.

headline: Love Letter: Smiling, Remembering the Bad Times
abstract: Why would a sour time in marriage become sweet?
lead_paragraph: Melani Robinson, an American, never imagined that she would begin her marriage to her American husband, Neal, in Russia.

headline: May Vocabulary Challenge: Write a Story Using Our Words of the Day
abstract: How many recent Words of the Day can you use correctly in a 50-word story? Send us yours by May 31.
lead_paragraph: Note: The winners of the March Vocabulary Challenge are announced at the bottom of this post.

headline: A ‘Hard Hat Mass’ for Fallen Workers
abstract: Construction workers gathered at St. Patrick's Cathedral to honor their colleagues who died on the job.
lead_paragraph: Construction workers gathered at St. Patrick's Cathedral to honor their colleagues who died on the job.

headline: To Tackle Student Debt, Fix Ineffective Colleges
abstract: Graduates can’t repay their loans if they don’t learn anything useful in school.
lead_paragraph: Before the federal government forgives student loan debt, it would be good to understand what makes the debt so onerous. The problem isn’t overwhelming debt — it’s underpowered education.

headline: An Artist Shines Light on the Black Aristocracy
abstract: Glory Samjolly turned to social media to document the real life Black gentry gaining attention through pop culture sensations such as “Bridgerton.”
lead_paragraph: During a visit to a villa in Naples, Italy, Glory Samjolly cajoled her sister and a friend to engage in a witty form of cosplay. Posed regally in a period pastiche of men’s brocade vests, neck ruffs, knee breeches and lavishly embroidered frock coats, they were captured by Ms. Samjolly in a group portrait, its playfully subversive title, “The Honorable Women of Slayage in their study.”

headline: Klaus Schulze, Pioneering Electronic Composer, Is Dead at 74
abstract: In a prolific career spanning five decades, he helped pave the way for ambient, techno and trance music.
lead_paragraph: Klaus Schulze, a German electronic musician whose hypnotic, pulsating, swirling compositions filled five decades of solo albums, collaborations and film scores, died on Tuesday. He was 74.

headline: How Older Britons Are Cutting Costs
abstract: I went to the town of Clacton-on-Sea and talked to people struggling to get by.
lead_paragraph: I went to the town of Clacton-on-Sea and talked to people struggling to get by.

headline: British Terrorist Receives Life Sentence for Role in Americans’ Deaths
abstract: Alexanda Kotey, 38, was part of a brutal Islamic State cell known as the Beatles that kidnapped and tortured Western hostages in Syria.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A federal judge on Friday sentenced a British terrorist to life in prison for his central role in the kidnap, torture and killing of Western hostages who were held by the Islamic State in Syria.

headline: Why Americans Became More Vulnerable to Oil Price Spikes
abstract: When prices soared years ago, Americans launched broad efforts to wean the nation off oil and gas to protect households from price swings. But then supply rose and plans fizzled.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, when Americans faced surging prices at the pump, policymakers developed a vision to wean people off gas and oil: more efficient cars, more compact and walkable communities, more renewable energy.

headline: Trevor Bauer Suspended for Two Seasons Amid Abuse Claim
abstract: Bauer, a pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, had been on leave from the club as he faced allegations of sexual assault. Prosecutors in Los Angeles had declined to charge him criminally.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Bauer of the Los Angeles Dodgers has been suspended by Major League Baseball for two seasons, effective immediately, for violating the league’s domestic violence and sexual assault policy.

headline: These Strawberry Scones Don’t Need Jam to Shine, but It Doesn’t Hurt
abstract: Dotted with dried berries and baked into a round, these crisp-outside, tender-inside treats emerge from the oven full of jammy bites.
lead_paragraph: Scones and strawberry jam is such a classic pairing that, naturally, it’s rife with debate.

headline: The Courage Required to Confront Inflation
abstract: Inflation is the nation’s primary economic problem. The Federal Reserve still needs to move cautiously as it begins to raise interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, has often expressed admiration for the resolve exhibited by one of his predecessors, Paul Volcker, who was willing to crash the economy in the early 1980s to drive down inflation.

headline: F.D.A. sets aside June for potential decisions on vaccines for the youngest Americans.
abstract: Both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech have asked the agency to approve their vaccines for the youngest children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration laid out a tentative timetable on Friday for deciding whether to authorize a coronavirus vaccine for America’s youngest children, announcing that June 8 is the earliest date that it will present data to its outside advisers for a recommendation.

headline: From Battered Mariupol Steel Plant, Fighters Share Desperate Videos to Push Out Story
abstract: With independent media unable to access this last military holdout, videos from inside function as pleas for help and publicity on social media.
lead_paragraph: The footage shows a child wearing a makeshift diaper crafted out of tape and plastic bags, asleep in a dank and moldy room. An elderly woman with a bandaged head is seen dressed in a uniform jacket, once worn by steel plant workers, as she shakes uncontrollably. And small children make plaintive requests. “We want to go home,” a girl says. “We want to see the sunshine.”

headline: Review: In a New ‘Macbeth,’ Something Wonky This Way Comes
abstract: Daniel Craig and Ruth Negga star in Sam Gold’s oddly uneasy take on the Scottish play.
lead_paragraph: Macbeth, the character, is full of compunction, as well he should be, having murdered a king to get to his throne.

headline: 2 on Subway Tracks Killed by Train at a Manhattan Station
abstract: The deaths came a week after the bodies of two French graffiti artists who had been fatally struck by a train were found in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed Friday morning when a subway train hit them at a Manhattan station, the police said, the latest in a spate of such deaths and a sign of what transit officials describe as a worrying rise in unauthorized people venturing onto the tracks.

headline: A Minnesota candidate was in labor during her convention speech. The proceedings went on.
abstract: Videos of Erin Maye Quade’s speech ricocheted across the internet, with critics saying the process should have been suspended.
lead_paragraph: The pause, three minutes into a candidate’s speech about the toll of climate change, the pandemic and the murder of George Floyd, was not just for rhetorical effect.

headline: Should I Dress for Vacation Like a Travel Influencer?
abstract: A reader wonders whether comfort or fashion should come first.
lead_paragraph: There is so much to unpack in this question: the way social media has skewed our perceptions of self, the effect of influencer marketing and what to wear when you are seeing the world. Where to start?

headline: Jennifer Egan Talks About ‘The Candy House’
abstract: Egan’s new novel is a follow-up to her Pulitzer Prize-winning “A Visit From the Goon Squad.”
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Egan’s new novel, “The Candy House,” is a follow-up to her Pulitzer Prize-winning “A Visit From the Goon Squad.” A few characters appear in both books, but the novels are also united by Egan’s structural approach — an inventive one that, in “Goon Squad,” included a  chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and in “The Candy House,” a chapter written as a long series of terse directives to a spy.

headline: Catherine Spaak, Darling of Italian Cinema in the ’60s, Dies at 77
abstract: Born in France, she moved to Italy as a teenager and began a long acting career, which extended to Hollywood in the movie “Hotel.”
lead_paragraph: Catherine Spaak, a French-born actress who made her name crossing genres in Italian, French and occasionally American films, acting alongside stars like Jane Fonda and Rod Taylor, died on April 17 in Rome. She was 77.

headline: Watch These 12 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in May
abstract: A ton of movies and TV shows are disappearing for U.S. Netflix subscribers next month. These are the ones worth catching before they’re gone.
lead_paragraph: The erotic thriller, that bygone artifact of ’80s and ’90s sexual expression (and repression) is all the rage again — well, at least nostalgia for it is — and two prime examples of the form are leaving Netflix in the United States at the end of the month, so get them while you can. Also departing the service in May: two family favorites, a musical extravaganza, two beloved series and much, much more. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)

headline: Michael R. Jackson’s Big Broadway Thriller
abstract: With his bravura meta-musical, “A Strange Loop,” the playwright is showing Broadway audiences something they have never seen before.
lead_paragraph: During a walk along the Great White Way this winter, I saw something peculiar: two marquees advertising two Michael Jacksons. On 52nd Street, at the Neil Simon Theater, where “MJ: The Musical” has been running since December, there’s a graphic of the King of Pop in his iconic early ’90s pose: fedora perched low, obscuring his face; shirttails flying in the artificial wind; white glove; high-water pants; sparkling socks; feet en pointe. Seven blocks away, at the Lyceum Theater on 45th Street, another sign bore the name “Michael Jackson” and an illustration of a 20-something Black man’s head in semi-profile, with six tiny bodies floating around his face and hair. This image advertised “A Strange Loop,” the playwright Michael R. Jackson’s Pulitzer Prize-winning metafictional musical, which premiered on Broadway in April.

headline: Amanda Serrano and Katie Taylor Are Ready to Box Their Way Into History
abstract: They’re hoping for bigger paydays as a result of their groundbreaking headline bout at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Joe Frazier vs. Muhammad Ali. Evander Holyfield vs. Mike Tyson. Deontay Wilder vs. Tyson Fury. Katie Taylor vs. Amanda Serrano.

headline: Cases are rising in nearly every corner of the United States.
abstract: Hospitalizations remain low, partly a reflection of greater immunity in the population.
lead_paragraph: Coronavirus cases and hospitalizations are rising in a majority of American states, in what appears to be the first widespread increase since the peak of the Omicron surge in January.

abstract: Can computers help?
lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 pandemic is not over yet, but some researchers are already worrying about mousepox.

abstract: Geoff Morrell’s brief tenure was defined by the company’s being drawn into the partisan political fray, most notably in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Disney parted ways with its most senior communications and government relations executive on Friday after a tumultuous two-month period in which Disney became a political punching bag, particularly for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: Pressure Mounts on Cawthorn as Scandals Pile Up

headline: Philip J. Hilts, 74, Dies; Reporter Exposed a Big-Tobacco Cover-up
abstract: In one of many scoops for The Times, he revealed how the tobacco industry had kept secret its own research showing that nicotine was harmful and addictive.
lead_paragraph: Philip J. Hilts, who as a science reporter for The New York Times in 1994 exposed a tobacco company’s decades-long cover-up of its own research showing that tobacco was harmful and nicotine was addictive, died on April 23  in Lebanon, N.H. He was 74.

headline: Is American Democracy Built to Last?

lead_paragraph: When Yascha Mounk went on a German television program to talk about the rise of authoritarianism in Western democracies, he never expected a seemingly innocuous remark to cause such a stir.

headline: Review: In ‘Jerusalem,’ a Once-in-a-Lifetime Performance, Again
abstract: Mark Rylance is back in a role that won him a Tony more than a decade ago. But this London production isn’t just coasting on past kudos.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There’s mighty, and then there’s Mark Rylance in “Jerusalem,” a performance so powerfully connected to its part that it feels almost superhuman. That’s as it should be for a play about a larger-than-life character named Johnny Byron, who demands an entirely fearless actor, and has one in Rylance.

headline: Consumed by Ambition, Trevor Bauer Must Answer for His Behavior
abstract: Bauer had said his unhappiness came from always striving for new goals. With a two-year suspension over sexual assault allegations, M.L.B. is moving on without him.
lead_paragraph: This was before his biggest dreams began to blossom, and before his career fell apart. This was Trevor Bauer from three years ago, over lunch in suburban Cleveland, describing the forces that drove him.

headline: Former Idaho State Lawmaker Is Convicted of Raping an Intern
abstract: A jury unanimously found Aaron von Ehlinger, a Republican state representative from Lewiston, guilty of raping the 19-year-old in March 2021.
lead_paragraph: A former Idaho state representative was convicted Friday of raping a 19-year-old legislative intern after a dinner in March 2021, a case that spurred the Republican lawmaker’s resignation last year and the censure of another lawmaker who had doxxed the victim.

headline: Biden seeks to lure Russia’s top scientists to the U.S.
abstract: Legislation proposed by the president would suspend the requirement that Russian scientists have a sponsoring employer to gain a visa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden wants Congress to expedite visas for Russian scientists eager to leave their country in the midst of Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, an effort to accelerate a brain drain already underway and further deprive President Vladimir V. Putin of some of Russia’s top talent.

lead_paragraph: For many years, shortly after the flowers began to sprout, André Leon Talley would ascend the steps of a church on 84th Street and Fifth Avenue to pay homage to the gods of fashion.

lead_paragraph: A former Marine infantryman who left Kentucky to defend Ukraine in March was killed this week while fighting alongside the Ukrainian military, according to his uncle. He is believed to be the first American killed in the fighting.

headline: Civilians continue to seek refuge at a besieged steel complex in Mariupol.
abstract: That citizens are still seeking to shelter at the plant, where there is no prospect of escape or rescue, offers a testament to what they must be facing elsewhere in the devastated city.
lead_paragraph: Despite dire conditions at the Azovstal steel plant, the Ukrainian military’s last foothold in the key port city of Mariupol, civilians continue to arrive seeking shelter from Russia’s offensive, according to fighters there.

headline: Leap With a Twist

His debut was in 1995, also with a Saturday grid.

headline: The Mets Have an Imperfect Night to Remember
abstract: Tylor Megill and four relievers shut down Philadelphia, securing M.L.B.’s first no-hitter of 2022 and the second in Mets history.
lead_paragraph: The Mets and the Phillies had done this before in Flushing. On Father’s Day in 1964, Philadelphia’s Jim Bunning twirled a perfect game against the Mets at Shea Stadium. Bunning needed only 90 pitches in an effort now memorialized in Cooperstown, N.Y., on his Hall of Fame plaque.

headline: Governments Tighten Grip on Global Food Stocks, Sending Prices Higher

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ukraine has limited exports of sunflower oil, wheat, oats and cattle in an attempt to protect its war-torn economy. Russia has banned sales of fertilizer, sugar and grains to other nations.

abstract: Fear among older and other vulnerable people is building as war in Ukraine aggravates energy costs that inflation had already pushed higher.
lead_paragraph: CLACTON-ON-SEA, England — The bills are mounting for Maureen Hart, a former librarian living on a fixed income after hip and back pain from a fall forced her into an early retirement.

headline: Abbott Threatens to Declare an ‘Invasion’ as Migrant Numbers Climb
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has pursued an expensive and unusual effort to harden the border. But after a year, there is little to show for it.
lead_paragraph: EAGLE PASS, Texas — From a camouflage Humvee at the edge of the Rio Grande, a Texas National Guard soldier on the front lines of Gov. Greg Abbott’s campaign to secure America’s southern border was watching a man with a crutch crossing the river from Mexico.

headline: Once Soft-Spoken, Ohio Conservatives Embrace the Bombast
abstract: The slugfest for the Republican nomination for Ohio’s open Senate seat has buried the brand of good-natured, country-club conservatism that was once a hallmark of the state.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Republicans running for the seat of Ohio’s retiring senator, Rob Portman, appear determined to bury the soft-spoken country-club bonhomie that was once a hallmark of the party in this state, and replace it with the pugilistic brand of conservatism owned by Donald J. Trump and now amplified by the new band of Buckeye bomb throwers.

headline: How to Stay Calm Like a Monk
abstract: Shunmyo Masuno offers his advice.
lead_paragraph: Shunmyo Masuno offers his advice.

headline: My Neighbor Is Exploiting Our Shared Property Line. What Can I Do?
abstract: When miscommunications arise between neighbors, it’s often best to start with the benefit of the doubt, then escalate if necessary.
lead_paragraph: Q: A shared alley separates my Staten Island house from my neighbor’s. The property line runs down the middle of the alley, so we each own half of it. A gate attaches the two properties. My neighbor put a padlock on the gate, and has not given me a key. So I have no access to my property from that side — I can’t access the air-conditioning condenser and equipment. I have written to my neighbor asking for a key, but she has not responded. What can I do? If I need to make repairs on that side of my house can I cut the lock with a bolt cutter?

headline: The Double Bind of the Feminine Ideal
abstract: In Mieko Kawakami’s latest, a woman tries to shed her loneliness by drinking a lot.
lead_paragraph: Twice in Mieko Kawakami’s “All the Lovers in the Night,” a 34-year-old proofreader, Fuyuko Irie, receives a pale yellow bottle of perfume by the luxury brand Chloé. Both bottles are gifts from work friends: first the glamorous Hijiri, an outspoken neoliberal feminist who shows her affection by regularly commissioning Fuyuko for freelance jobs; and then Kyoko, an editor at the Tokyo publishing house that Fuyuko quits at the start of the novel, to work alone.

headline: Slice-of-Life Stories Shot Through With Dark Humor
abstract: Set mostly in western Ireland, Colin Barrett’s second collection is a painterly portrait of characters on the edge.

headline: Twitter Isn’t for Quitters
abstract: One thing that unites conservatives and liberals? No matter how loudly they denounce the social media platform, they don’t actually leave.
lead_paragraph: It was the moment conservative Twitter tried to cancel itself.

headline: The Golden Age of Air Travel Gets a Reality Check
abstract: Two new books trace the evolution of the industry from the perspective of women who worked in it.
lead_paragraph: As the so-called Golden Age of Travel boomed in the 1960s and ’70s, the airline industry left no doubt about what it was selling. The ability to get from one place to another was assumed; the real lure was the pretty young stewardesses, whose desirability and explicit availability were used as sexual bait to entice the nation’s burgeoning corps of male business travelers.

headline: Storms, Bombs, Contagions, Pandemics and Pandemonium
abstract: In her new novel, “Vigil Harbor,” Julia Glass imagines a not-so-distant future when a New England town is wracked by crises.
lead_paragraph: A recent headline in this newspaper captured in nine words a general mood that was once confined to the most anxious among us: “There Are Almost Too Many Things to Worry About.”

headline: Family Saga. Capitalist Satire. Climate Thriller. Debut Novel.
abstract: Vauhini Vara’s “The Immortal King Rao” is about a lot of things, from a father-daughter bond to the end of human civilization.
lead_paragraph: The premise of Vauhini Vara’s debut novel, “The Immortal King Rao,” is as simple as could be: A young woman named Athena, raised in secret on an island in the Puget Sound by an aging father who has injected her with genetic code that allows her to access the entire internet and also all his memories, finds herself in a prison named after her mother, awaiting judgment by algorithm for a crime she insists she did not commit. While she waits, she writes a lengthy self-defense addressed to the Shareholders of the mega-corporation that has replaced the U.S. government, indeed all governments, just as “Shareholder” with a capital “s” has replaced the word “citizen.”

headline: How the Executive Director of the Queens Botanical Garden Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Evie Hantzopoulos has lived in Astoria since 1999. She is committed to the neighborhood, shopping, socializing and volunteering locally.
lead_paragraph: As the first new executive director of the Queens Botanical Garden in nearly three decades, Evie Hantzopoulos is leading the Flushing-based nonprofit through a period of expansion that includes the building of a $32 million education center.

headline: These Bloodworms Grow Copper Fangs and Have Bad Attitudes
abstract: Scientists figured out the biochemical process that lets the turf-conscious worms grow sharp teeth using very simple materials.
lead_paragraph: Glycera dibranchiata is exactly the kind of creature you don’t want to find at the bottom of your beach bucket. They are called bloodworms for their translucent skin. Long and venomous, the worms are native to both coasts of North America and have four sharp fangs and a somewhat grumpy temperament: As they burrow through the sand, they will attack whatever they sense nearby.

headline: Inside the Flawed Vetting Process That Led Gov. Hochul to Brian Benjamin
abstract: An initial 63-page background check revealed two red flags in Mr. Benjamin’s past, but it failed to turn up a subpoena issued to his political campaign.
lead_paragraph: The first warnings about Brian A. Benjamin came early, just three days after Kathy Hochul learned she would become governor of New York and began a hurried search for her second-in-command.

headline: When the Best Part of Going Out Is the Late-Night Snack
abstract: Some of New York’s nightlife scenes are less about dancing and more about eating.
lead_paragraph: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.

headline: Mother’s Day Gifts, Reframed
abstract: After two years that did not go as most people desired, why not give Mom something you know she will want: a framed photo.
lead_paragraph: For every Mother’s Day that I can remember, my mom has always asked for the same thing: a poem. The tradition started at a time when my two siblings and I were too young to earn money of our own. It stuck because my mom, like others I have met, has always preferred sentimental to splurge-y gifts, even if my stanzas could never compare to Keats or Ginsberg.

headline: Christian Village in Israel Digs Into Its Crusader Past
abstract: The residents of Mi’ilya long wondered what archaeological treasures lay beneath a crumbling castle. Now, some are excavating their homes to find out.
lead_paragraph: MI’ILYA, Israel — In the middle of Eilia Arraf’s home — between two living rooms, a cactus garden and a makeshift gym — there are two large pits, each containing the ruins of a church that archaeologists believe was built about 1,600 years ago.

headline: A Winnipeg Landmark Rich in Symbolism Comes Under Indigenous Control
abstract: The Hudson’s Bay Company has turned over its former flagship store to an Indigenous group with big ambitions for the space.

headline: Sunflower Oil ‘Vanishes’ as Ukraine War Grinds On
abstract: Several British supermarkets have joined other chains around the world in asking shoppers to limit their cooking oil purchases, as supplies dwindle and prices rise.
lead_paragraph: First the coronavirus, then the war. Just as the pandemic caused shortages of essential items, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has disrupted important food supplies, driving up prices of staples like cooking oil in supermarkets around the world.

headline: What to Stream in May
abstract: Next month’s streaming options include new Sally Rooney fare, “Masterpiece” and a new season of “Hacks.”
lead_paragraph: It’s been two years since “Normal People,” the series adapted from Sally Rooney’s novel of the same name, debuted on Hulu. Depending on how warped your perception of time is lately, that may feel like it was just last week. Or perhaps the experience of watching the show glimmers in your memory like a relic from another lifetime. I’m of the persuasion that it’s been just long enough that I’m ready for another Rooney adaptation, so I’ve been eagerly anticipating “Conversations With Friends,” which arrives on May 15.

headline: ‘I Lost Everything’: Pakistani Airstrikes Escalate Conflict on Afghan Border
abstract: The airstrikes killed at least 45 people, stoking fears of a violent resurgence of the conflict in eastern Afghanistan, which has become a base for Pakistani militants.
lead_paragraph: MANDATAH VILLAGE, Afghanistan — It was nearly 3 a.m. in the mountainous borderlands of eastern Afghanistan when a deafening thud jolted Qudratullah awake. Confused, he staggered to the doorway of his mud brick home, looked outside and froze.

headline: Musk Joins Moguls to Kill S.E.C. ‘Gag Orders’ at the Supreme Court

headline: Looking Inward, and Back, at a Biennale for the History Books
abstract: Eyes are the key metaphor in the Venice Biennale’s central show of 213 artists, an unprecedented percentage of whom are women.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — It starts in the eyes: shy or seductive, gaping or sealed shut, aqueous frontiers between the mind and the world. There are the pupils of the German surrealist Unica Zürn, cohering out of dense, automatic black squiggles. The giant irises of Ulla Wiggen, each unique as a fingerprint and capable of unlocking a credit card or blocking passage across a border, painted in close-up on circular canvases. All over town, on palazzo-side posters and the hulls of the vaporetti, there are eyes announcing the 59th Venice Biennale: ghostly, milky corneas, drawn by the young Mexican artist Felipe Baeza, disembodied, floating in deep space.

headline: Connecticut Moves to Blunt Impact of Other States’ Anti-Abortion Laws
abstract: The state is among several acting to strengthen abortion rights protections as a Supreme Court ruling that could overturn Roe v. Wade looms.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut lawmakers approved a bill late Friday night that takes direct aim at states that have passed aggressive anti-abortion laws as the country prepares for a Supreme Court ruling this summer that could weaken or overturn the constitutional right to abortion enshrined in Roe v. Wade.

abstract: Feeding my desperate need to make words, one point at a time.

headline: ‘Nonbinary Runners Have Been Here the Whole Time’
abstract: In the past year, road races have debuted a nonbinary category, typically with around two dozen or fewer such competitors at each event.
lead_paragraph: As a middle-distance runner for Columbia University, Jacob Caswell did not feel like they had space to be themself.

headline: Engineers Discover 19 Revolutionary War Cannons in Georgia’s Savannah River
abstract: The Army Corps of Engineers found one after another while dredging. The cannons are believed to be from a British ship that was deliberately sunk before a battle.
lead_paragraph: The first cannon pulled up from Georgia’s Savannah River surprised the workers for the Army Corps of Engineers who dredged them out of the riverbed’s clay.

headline: In Northern Ireland, Divided Unionists Leave an Opening for Nationalists
abstract: But Sinn Fein, which is leading in polls ahead of next week’s elections, hasn’t focused its campaign on unification with Ireland.
lead_paragraph: CARRICKFERGUS, Northern Ireland — The sun was setting over the tidy, red brick homes in a Protestant neighborhood outside Belfast when two candidates for Northern Ireland’s legislature came to knock on doors on a recent evening. It might as well have been setting on the pro-unionist dreams of the residents.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Reports Drop in Earnings, Driven by Investment Losses

headline: How to Separate Parents From Their Money
abstract: It takes just a kid and an app.
lead_paragraph: As soon as my older daughter started playing the online world-building game Roblox, she began to beg for Robux, the game’s currency, which cost real-world dollars. Having read multiple stories about how kids accidentally-on-purpose spent lots of money on add-ons like “ultra rare” or “legendary” status virtual pets, I refused to buy into this scheme. No, honey, I will not spend my hard-earned American dollars on a Queen Bee that will probably end up working at a fast-food restaurant in your adopt-me universe.

headline: Tornado Tears Through City in Kansas, Causing Extensive Damage
abstract: No fatalities were reported in the city of Andover, near Wichita, but up to 1,000 structures may have been affected, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A tornado tore through a city outside Wichita, Kan., on Friday night, ripping through houses and power lines, uprooting trees and heaving cars onto buildings. No fatalities were reported.

headline: They Grew Up Legally in the U.S., but Can’t Stay After They Turn 21
abstract: Children of temporary visa holders who can’t gain permanent residency are one of several groups urging the Biden administration to act on an immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2011, after five years of working and living with his family in the United States on a temporary visa, Barathimohan Ganesan submitted green card applications for his wife, his 5-year-old daughter and his 11-year-old son.

headline: Can Elon Musk Make Twitter’s Numbers Work?
abstract: Financially speaking, the billionaire’s buyout of the social media network breaks all the usual rules.
lead_paragraph: At the peak of the buyout boom in 2007, private equity firms including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts bought the Texas energy giant TXU for $45 billion. It was — and remains — the largest deal of its kind in American history.

headline: Inside the Apocalyptic Worldview of ‘Tucker Carlson Tonight’
abstract: A New York Times analysis of 1,150 episodes reveals how Tucker Carlson pushes extremist ideas and conspiracy theories into millions of households, five nights a week.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times analysis of 1,150 episodes reveals how Tucker Carlson pushes extremist ideas and conspiracy theories into millions of households, five nights a week.

headline: How Tucker Carlson Stoked White Fear to Conquer Cable
abstract: A string of setbacks made the pundit flee television, the Republican establishment and even his home. He re-emerged with what may be the most racist, and successful, show in the history of cable news.
lead_paragraph: Tucker Carlson burst through the doors of Charlie Palmer Steak, enfolded in an entourage of producers and assistants, cellphone pressed to his ear. On the other end was Lachlan Murdoch, chairman of the Fox empire and his de facto boss.

headline: How Tucker Carlson Reshaped Fox News — and Became Trump’s Heir
abstract: As the host turned a civil war at Fox to his advantage, he found himself at the forefront of the nativist forces transforming conservative politics.
lead_paragraph: Tucker Carlson had a problem.

headline: Ukrainian Official Outlines Intentional Ambiguity on Strikes Inside Russia
abstract: The strikes have been one of the most intriguing, and opaque, new elements of the recent fighting. But when it comes to confirming their origins, “we don’t say yes and we don’t say no,’’ said the official.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A fuel depot in Russia burst into flames, moments after surveillance video captured the bright streaks of rockets fired from low-flying helicopters. A fire broke out at a military research institute near Moscow. Additional fuel tanks have exploded.

headline: What to Know About Tucker Carlson’s Rise
abstract: A Times examination of the host’s career and singular influence at Fox News shows how his trajectory traces the transformation of American conservatism itself.
lead_paragraph: Night after night on Fox, Tucker Carlson weaponizes his viewers’ fears and grievances to create what may be the most racist show in the history of cable news. It is also, by some measures, the most successful.

headline: Can We Please Get Over Our Twitter Obsession Already?
abstract: The platform just doesn’t matter as much as we seem to think it does.
lead_paragraph: I started my Twitter account in June 2008. And after 14 years on the platform, I have a lot of feelings about it. Twitter is meaningful to me, while constantly leaving me wondering why, exactly, that is the case.

headline: Why Forced Addiction Treatment Fails
abstract: The United States needs more programs that are compassionate and inviting.
lead_paragraph: Jason Norelli, a San Francisco native, spent several years homeless in and around the city’s Tenderloin district, addicted to methamphetamine. In 2001, he was legally mandated to attend rehab and has been in recovery ever since. Today he helps others like him get care.

headline: Climate Change Threatens Another California Forest, This One Underwater
abstract: These kelp forests sequester more carbon dioxide than the state’s redwood groves.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Calif. — The bull kelp forests off Northern California are sometimes spoken of as the redwoods of the sea. And like the redwoods, these forests are in danger. In less than a decade, these otherworldly undersea landscapes, lush with life, have all but disappeared along 200 miles of coast north of San Francisco’s Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: Nebraska Candidate for Governor Accused of Second Groping Incident at 2019 Dinner
abstract: Charles W. Herbster, who has been endorsed by Donald Trump for Nebraska governor, was accused of groping a second woman at a 2019 Republican fund-raising event. He denies both allegations.
lead_paragraph: A second woman has publicly accused Charles W. Herbster, the Republican candidate for governor in Nebraska endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, of groping her at a 2019 Republican fund-raising dinner.

headline: How Twitter’s Board Went From Fighting Elon Musk to Accepting Him
abstract: It’s highly unusual to move from a “poison pill” to a $44 billion deal in under two weeks. But Twitter’s board ran out of options.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s board had reached the end of the road.

headline: The Ohio Primary and the Return of the Republican Civil War
abstract: How the divides of the party’s 2016 primary campaign have risen fully to the surface again.
lead_paragraph: Why has the Ohio Republican Senate primary, which reaches its conclusion Tuesday, been so interesting (if not always edifying) to watch? In part, because it’s the first time the divides of the party’s 2016 primary campaign have risen fully to the surface again.

headline: An Oil Tanker Is Sabotaged. The Investigator Dies. Now What?
abstract: In Matthew Campbell and Kit Chellel’s real-life whodunit “Dead in the Water,” Big Oil, Big Insurance and global corruption clash on a giant scale.
lead_paragraph: Surely the first clue that something shifty was afoot was when the crew of the oil tanker Brillante Virtuoso helped the hijackers to board.

headline: Tornado Strikes Kansas Town Near Wichita
abstract: A tornado on Friday night ripped through Andover, Kan., damaging homes and heaving cars. No fatalities were reported.
lead_paragraph: A tornado on Friday night ripped through Andover, Kan., damaging homes and heaving cars. No fatalities were reported.

headline: Jail Officer and Murder Suspect Missing After Heading to Fictitious Appointment
abstract: The authorities in Alabama said it was unclear whether the officer had helped the inmate escape or whether she had been kidnapped.
lead_paragraph: Alabama authorities are searching for a corrections officer and a murder suspect who were last seen on Friday leaving the jail for what should have been a three-minute drive to the county courthouse for an appointment that turned out not to exist, officials said.

headline: C. Vivian Stringer, Celebrated College Basketball Coach, Says She Will Retire
abstract: Stringer, who reached four Final Fours, won more than 1,000 games over a half-century at Cheyney State, Iowa and, finally, Rutgers.
lead_paragraph: C. Vivian Stringer, the Hall of Fame women’s basketball coach at Rutgers University who first commanded a college sideline in 1971 and became one of her sport’s premier defensive minds, said Saturday that she would retire in September.

headline: Some Muslims Are Using Digital Rings to Track Their Praises to God
abstract: Much like the fitness tools that count steps, these electronic devices help keep a record of the day’s religious recitations.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Walking through the courtyard of Al Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem on a recent afternoon, Nisreen Biqwaidar wore a pink Apple Watch on her wrist to count her steps and a green ring on her finger to count her religious recitations.
